1594.summary: William Shakespeare's play Titus Andronicus is given its first performance at The Rose in London.

1594.title: Siege of Enniskillen Castle
1594.summary: The siege of Enniskillen Castle is started by an English commander but is abandoned after one month.

1594.title: Coronation of Sigismund III Vasa
1594.summary: The coronation of Sigismund III Vasa as King of Sweden takes place at Uppsala.

1594.title: Coronation of Henry IV of France
1594.summary: The coronation of Henry IV as King of France takes place at Chartres Cathedral.

1594.title: Raids on Puerto de Caballos
1594.summary: Two warships of the English Navy complete a raid on the Spanish city of Puerto de Caballos that results in pillaging.

1594.title: Siege of Coevorden Ends
1594.summary: The siege of the Spanish-held city of Coevorden ends after six months as the city surrenders to the Dutch Republic.

1594.title: Siege of Groningen Begins
1594.summary: The Siege of Groningen by the Dutch Republic begins with an attack against the Spanish-held city.

1594.title: Siege of Morlaix
1594.summary: The walled city of Morlaix controlled by the Spanish Army is besieged by the French Royal Army.

1595.title: Mehmed III ascends to the Ottoman throne
1595.summary: Mehmed III succeeds Murad III as Sultan of the Ottoman Empire and immediately orders the execution of his brothers.

1595.title: Henry IV declares war on Spain
1595.summary: During the French Wars of Religion, Henry IV declares war on Spain and orders military actions in the Spanish Netherlands.

1595.title: Matthias of Habsburg becomes Archduke
1595.summary: Matthias is appointed as the Archduke of the possessions in Southern Germany by Rudolf II following the death of Ferdinand II.

1595.title: Transylvania joins the Holy League
1595.summary: The Principality of Transylvania becomes part of the Holy League alliance against the Ottoman Empire.

1595.title: Establishment of Goa state archives
1595.summary: The state archives are established at the city of Panaji by historian Diogo do Couto in Portuguese India.

1595.title: Battle of Fontaine-Française
1595.summary: Henry IV of France defeats the Spanish at the Battle of Fontaine-Française, showcasing military prowess.

1595.title: Spanish expedition lands in Polynesia
1595.summary: Álvaro de Mendaña de Neira leads a Spanish expedition and makes the first European landing in Polynesia.

1595.title: Battle of Calugareni
1595.summary: The Wallachian leader Michael the Brave achieves a tactical victory against Turkish forces.

1595.title: Battle of Giurgiu
1595.summary: Michael the Brave defeats the Turkish army again, pushing them away from the Danube River.

1595.title: First performance of Richard II
1595.summary: What is believed to be the first performance of Shakespeare's play Richard II takes place in London.

1596.title: Drake's Assault on Panama
1596.summary: Sir Francis Drake, General Thomas Baskerville and an English force of 15 ships land at the Atlantic Ocean port of Nombre de Dios in an attempt to capture the Isthmus of Panama.

1596.title: Burning of Nombre de Dios
1596.summary: Francis Drake, unable to receive a ransom for the town of Nombre de Dios, orders the town and all Spanish ships in harbor to be burned.

1596.title: Death of Sir Francis Drake
1596.summary: With an epidemic of dysentery spreading through the English forces, Drake orders survivors to retreat to the English ships, where he dies of dysentery two days later on his flagship, Defiance.

1596.title: Battle of Pinos
1596.summary: The Battle of Pinos is fought between the English Navy and the Spanish Navy off the coast of Cuba, with heavy casualties on both sides.

1596.title: Siege of Calais
1596.summary: Spanish troops capture Calais during the ongoing conflict between England and Spain.

1596.title: Capture of Cádiz
1596.summary: An English fleet commanded by Robert Devereux and Lord Howard of Effingham sacks Cádiz.

1596.title: Beheading of King Dominicus Corea
1596.summary: King Dominicus Corea is beheaded by the Portuguese in Colombo, Ceylon.

1596.title: Coronation of Christian IV
1596.summary: The coronation of Christian IV as King of Denmark and King of Norway takes place at the Vor Frue Kirke cathedral in Copenhagen.

1596.title: The Second Armada wrecked
1596.summary: The Second Armada, a Spanish fleet sent to attack England, is wrecked in storms off Cape Finisterre, resulting in significant losses.

1596.title: The Cudgel War
1596.summary: The Cudgel War begins in Finland as poor peasants rise up against the authorities due to heavy taxation.

1597.title: Alchemia Published
1597.summary: Andreas Libavius's Alchemia, an early chemistry text, is published.

1597.title: Forced March of European Christians
1597.summary: Japan's Chancellor Toyotomi Hideyoshi sends 26 European Christians on a forced march from Kyoto to Nagasaki.

1597.title: Battle of Turnhout
1597.summary: Maurice of Nassau defeats a Spanish force under Jean de Rie of Varas, in the Netherlands.

1597.title: Execution of European Catholics
1597.summary: In Japan, 26 European Catholic Christians are executed in Nagasaki by crucifixion.

1597.title: Siege of Amiens
1597.summary: King Henry IV of France and General Thomas Baskerville begin the siege of the city of Amiens, which had been captured by the Spanish Army.

1597.title: Dutch Expedition to Indonesia
1597.summary: A Dutch expedition commanded by Cornelis de Houtman returns to Amsterdam after successfully reaching Java, opening the Spice trade to the Dutch.

1597.title: Battle of Myeongnyang
1597.summary: The Koreans, commanded by Yi Sunsin, are victorious over a Japanese invasion fleet in the Battle of Myeongnyang.

1597.title: Third Spanish Armada's Departure
1597.summary: The 3rd Spanish Armada departs with plans to invade the British Isles with a landing at Falmouth.

1597.title: Lazzaro Grimaldi Cebà Elected
1597.summary: Lazzaro Grimaldi Cebà is elected as the new Doge of the Republic of Genoa.

1597.title: Papal Approval of Christian Doctrine Fathers
1597.summary: The Roman Catholic order of the Congregatio Patrum Doctrinae Christianae is approved by Pope Clement VIII.

1598.title: Election of Boris Godunov
1598.summary: Boris Godunov is elected as the Tsar of Russia by unanimous vote of the parliament of nobles, the Zemsky Sobor.

1598.title: Death of Tsar Feodor I
1598.summary: The Tsar of the Russian Empire, Feodor I, dies of a sudden illness at the age of 40, leaving no children and bringing an end to the Rurik dynasty.

1598.title: Siege of Suncheon
1598.summary: The Siege of Suncheon, an attempt by Korean and Chinese troops to capture the Japanese-occupied Suncheon Castle.

1598.title: Battle of Noryang
1598.summary: An allied Korean and Chinese fleet under Korean Admiral Yi Sun-sin and Chinese Admiral Chen Lin defeats the Japanese navy, ending the Japanese invasions of Korea.

1598.title: Battle of Curalaba
1598.summary: The revolting Mapuche, led by cacique Pelantaro, inflict a major defeat on Spanish troops in southern Chile.

1598.title: Foundation of Santa Fe de Nuevo México
1598.summary: Juan de Oñate proclaims the founding of the colony of Santa Fe de Nuevo México, establishing the first capital near the Pueblo Indian city.

1598.title: Abdication of Irina Godunova
1598.summary: The Tsaritsa Irina Godunova abandons her brief rule as autocrat of Russia and abdicates in favor of her older brother, Boris Godunov.

1598.title: Conquest of Brittany
1598.summary: The Duchy of Brittany in France is conquered by King Henry IV, who forces the surrender of Philippe Louis de Lorraine-Mercœur.

1598.title: Capture of Győr
1598.summary: Count Adolf von Schwarzenberg of Austria captures the Turkish fortress at Győr, four years after Turkish forces had taken it over.

1598.title: Edict of Nantes
1598.summary: Henry IV of France grants French Huguenots equal rights with Catholics; this is considered the end of the French Wars of Religion.

1599.title: The Jesuit educational plan, Ratio Studiorum
1599.summary: Issued to standardize Jesuit education and improve academic rigor and administration in Jesuit schools.

1599.title: Acoma Massacre
1599.summary: Spanish soldiers, led by Juan de Oñate, attack the indigenous Keres people, resulting in the death of 500 men and 300 women and children.

1599.title: First performance of As You Like It
1599.summary: The earliest known performance of Shakespeare's play is presented at Richmond Park for Queen Elizabeth.

1599.title: Lease of land for Globe Theatre
1599.summary: The land for the Globe Theatre is leased by Shakespeare and his associates, laying the groundwork for a key venue in English theatre.

1599.title: Earl of Essex appointed Lord Lieutenant of Ireland
1599.summary: Robert Devereux is appointed by Queen Elizabeth I, marking a significant military and political appointment in Ireland.

1599.title: Siege of Zaltbommel
1599.summary: The siege begins as part of the Anglo-Spanish War, with significant military implications for the Dutch Republic.

1599.title: Swedish King dethroned
1599.summary: Sigismund III Vasa loses his throne to Duke Charles, marking a significant change in Swedish leadership.

1599.title: First Battle of Curlew Pass
1599.summary: Irish forces claim a notable victory against the English in a battle that reflects the tensions in Ireland.

1599.title: First performance at the Globe Theatre
1599.summary: The first recorded performance is of Shakespeare's Julius Caesar, marking a significant cultural event in London.

1599.title: Battle of Sellenberk
1599.summary: Michael the Brave defeats Andrew Báthory's army, representing a key moment in Romanian unification efforts.

1600.title: Scotland adopts January 1 as New Year's Day
1600.summary: Scotland adopts January 1 as New Year's Day instead of March 25.

1600.title: Renewal of the Nine Years' War
1600.summary: Hugh O'Neill, Earl of Tyrone, renews the Nine Years' War against England with an invasion of Munster.

1600.title: First recorded sighting of the Falkland Islands
1600.summary: Sebald de Weert makes the first recorded sighting of the Falkland Islands.

1600.title: Giordano Bruno's execution
1600.summary: On his way to be burned at the stake for heresy in Rome, Giordano Bruno has his tongue imprisoned after he refuses to stop talking.

1600.title: Huaynaputina volcano eruption
1600.summary: The Huaynaputina volcano in Peru erupts, in what is still the worst recorded volcanic eruption.

1600.title: Linköping Bloodbath
1600.summary: Five Swedish nobles are publicly executed by decapitation and Polish–Swedish King Sigismund III Vasa is de facto deposed as ruler of Sweden.

1600.title: First Dutch ship arrives in Japan
1600.summary: The first Dutch ship ever to arrive in Japan, the Liefde, anchors in Sashifu, in the Bungo Province.

1600.title: Unification of the Danubian Principalities
1600.summary: Michael the Brave becomes ruler of Wallachia, Transylvania and Moldavia, formally uniting the three Danubian Principalities.

1600.title: Première of Euridice
1600.summary: The première of Jacopo Peri's Euridice, the earliest known fully surviving work of modern opera, takes place in Florence.

1600.title: Battle of Sekigahara
1600.summary: The Battle of Sekigahara occurs where the Eastern Army led by Tokugawa Ieyasu emerges victorious against the Western Army led by Ishida Mitsunari, ending the Sengoku period.

1601.title: Treaty of Lyon
1601.summary: France gains Bresse, Bugey and Gex from Savoy, ceding Saluzzo in exchange.

1601.title: Essex's Rebellion
1601.summary: Robert Devereux, 2nd Earl of Essex, begins a rebellion against Queen Elizabeth I but is crushed.

1601.title: Execution of the Earl of Essex
1601.summary: The Earl of Essex becomes the first of the Essex's Rebellion participants to be executed.

1601.title: Establishment of Khandesh
1601.summary: Prince Daniyal Mirza is named the ruler of Khandesh by the Mughal Empire after his conquest of Ahmednagar.

1601.title: Sigismund Báthory Returns as Prince of Transylvania
1601.summary: Sigismund Báthory, who had abdicated, is proclaimed Prince of Transylvania.

1601.title: First Expedition of East India Company
1601.summary: The first expedition of the East India Company sets sail from England for the Spice Islands.

1601.title: Siege of Ostend Begins
1601.summary: The Siege of Ostend, which lasts more than three years, begins with a significant loss of life.

1601.title: The Spanish Navy Fleet Departs for Ireland
1601.summary: A Spanish Navy fleet departs Portugal to support an Irish rebellion against the British.

1601.title: Parliament of Elizabeth I
1601.summary: Queen Elizabeth I summons her 10th, and last, meeting of the English Parliament.

1601.title: Battle of Kinsale Ends
1601.summary: The Battle of Kinsale ends the siege of Kinsale, Ireland, which began in autumn 1601.

1602.title: Battle of Kinsale
1602.summary: The English defeat Irish rebels and their Spanish allies.

1602.title: First Production of Twelfth Night
1602.summary: In London, the first known production of William Shakespeare's comedy Twelfth Night takes place.

1602.title: Establishment of the United East India Company
1602.summary: The United East India Company is established by the United Provinces States-General in Amsterdam, with the stated intention of capturing the spice trade from the Portuguese.

1602.title: Danish–Icelandic Trade Monopoly
1602.summary: The Danish–Icelandic Trade Monopoly is established.

1602.title: Gosnold at Cape Cod
1602.summary: English explorer Bartholomew Gosnold, sailing in the Concord, becomes the first European at Cape Cod.

1602.title: Battle of Sesimbra Bay
1602.summary: Battle of Sesimbra Bay off of the coast of Portugal: Five galleons of the English Royal Navy defeat a larger force of Spanish Navy ships.

1602.title: Assassination of Abu'l-Fazl ibn Mubarak
1602.summary: Abu'l-Fazl ibn Mubarak, the prime minister for India's Mughal Emperor Akbar, is assassinated at Narwar.

1602.title: Mutiny of Hoogstraten
1602.summary: The Mutiny of Hoogstraten, a rebellion by soldiers of the Army of Flanders, begins with the seizure by 3,000 disgruntled mercenaries of the town of Hoogstraten.

1602.title: Battle of the Narrow Seas
1602.summary: An English fleet, joined by the Dutch, begins a pursuit of six Spanish galleys through the Strait of Dover, and defeats them the next day.

1602.title: Opening of the Bodleian Library
1602.summary: The Bodleian Library at the University of Oxford in England is opened.

1603.title: Death of Queen Elizabeth I
1603.summary: Queen Elizabeth I of England dies at Richmond Palace, having ruled since 1558. She is succeeded by King James VI of Scotland, uniting the crowns of Scotland and England.

1603.title: Establishment of the Tokugawa Shogunate
1603.summary: Tokugawa Ieyasu is granted the title of shōgun from Emperor Go-Yozei, establishing the Tokugawa shogunate in Edo, Japan, commencing the Edo period.

1603.title: Formation of the King's Men
1603.summary: The King's Men, a group of English professional actors, is granted its royal patent by King James. The group includes William Shakespeare among its principal actors.

1603.title: Founding of the Accademia dei Lincei
1603.summary: The Accademia dei Lincei, the oldest scientific academy in the world, is founded in Rome by Federico Cesi.

1603.title: Capture of Tabriz
1603.summary: The Safavid Army of Iran recaptures Tabriz from the Ottoman Empire after 15 years of occupation led by Iranian Emperor Abbas the Great.

1603.title: Sangley Rebellion
1603.summary: On the Philippine island of Luzon, the Sangley Rebellion against Spanish rule ends with the massacre of 20,000 Sangley Chinese residents in Manila.

1603.title: Trial of Sir Walter Raleigh
1603.summary: Sir Walter Raleigh goes on trial for treason in the Great Hall of Winchester Castle. He is found guilty but his life is spared by King James I at this time.

1603.title: Death of Sultan Mehmed III
1603.summary: Sultan Mehmed III of the Ottoman Empire dies, and is succeeded by his son Ahmed I.

1603.title: Execution of Yemişçi Hasan Pasha
1603.summary: Yemişçi Hasan Pasha, the Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire, is executed on orders of Sultan Mehmed III after failing to respond effectively to the Safavid Empire's actions.

1603.title: Completion of the first Star Atlas
1603.summary: Johann Bayer publishes the star atlas Uranometria, the first to cover the entire celestial sphere.

1604.title: Hampton Court Conference
1604.summary: The Hampton Court Conference is held between James I of England, the Anglican bishops and representatives of the Puritans. Work begins on the Authorized King James Version of the Bible and revision of the Book of Common Prayer.

1604.title: King James denounces Roman Catholic Church
1604.summary: King James of England denounces the Roman Catholic Church after learning that Queen Anne has been sent a rosary from the Pope.

1604.title: Order for Jesuits and Roman Catholic priests to leave
1604.summary: King James issues an order for all Jesuits and all Roman Catholic priests to leave his kingdom by March 19.

1604.title: Abdication of Sigismund
1604.summary: The Riksdag declares that Sigismund, Grand Duke of Lithuania and King of Poland, has effectively abdicated as King of Sweden, and recognizes Karl, Duke of Södermanland, as the new monarch.

1604.title: King James I's Royal Entry
1604.summary: King James I and Anne, Queen consort make the traditional Royal Entry to London after delays due to the ongoing plague.

1604.title: Opening of Parliamentary Session
1604.summary: King James opens his first parliamentary session as King of England, expressing his desire for a legal union between England and Scotland.

1604.title: Siege of Sluis
1604.summary: Maurice of Nassau begins the Siege of Sluis with Dutch and English troops, the city surrenders after three months, resulting in heavy casualties.

1604.title: Treaty of London
1604.summary: England concludes the Treaty of London with Spain, officially ending the Anglo-Spanish War after years of conflict.

1604.title: Kepler's Supernova observation
1604.summary: Kepler's Supernova is first observed, marking a significant event in astronomical history.

1604.title: Performance of Othello
1604.summary: The first recorded performance of William Shakespeare's tragedy, Othello, takes place at the Palace of Whitehall in London.

1605.title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
1605.summary: William Shakespeare's play is given its earliest recorded performance and witnessed by the Viscount Dorchester.

1605.title: Henry V
1605.summary: Shakespeare's play is presented for King James I of England, marking its earliest recorded performance.

1605.title: Don Quixote
1605.summary: Miguel de Cervantes' satire on chivalry is published in Madrid and becomes a global bestseller.

1605.title: Love's Labour's Lost
1605.summary: Shakespeare's play is presented for Queen Anne at the home of the Earl of Southampton, marking its earliest performance.

1605.title: Earthquake in Japan
1605.summary: A 7.9 magnitude earthquake strikes south of Honshu, triggering a tsunami that causes widespread damage and loss of life.

1605.title: The Merchant of Venice
1605.summary: Shakespeare's play is performed for King James I of England, marking its earliest recorded performance.

1605.title: Election of Stephen Bocskai
1605.summary: Stephen Bocskai is elected Prince of Transylvania at the capital, Belugrad.

1605.title: Capture in Dutch East Indies
1605.summary: Admiral Steven van der Hagen leads a fleet to capture land for the Netherlands, making it the capital of Dutch possessions in Asia.

1605.title: Proclamation in Ireland
1605.summary: A declaration states all people of Ireland are direct subjects of the British Crown, not of local lords.

1605.title: Papal conclave for Pope Clement VIII
1605.summary: A conclave to elect a successor to Pope Clement VIII opens in the Vatican after his death.

1606.title: Discovery of the Pitcairn Islands
1606.summary: Explorer Pedro Fernandes de Queirós of Portugal leads the first Europeans to discover the Pitcairn Islands.

1606.title: First confirmed sighting of Australia
1606.summary: Dutch navigator Willem Janszoon makes the first confirmed sighting of Australia by a European.

1606.title: Elevation of Livorno to city status
1606.summary: Ferdinando I de' Medici elevates Livorno to the rank of city.

1606.title: Charter of Virginia adopted
1606.summary: The First Charter of Virginia is adopted, granting rights to the Virginia Company to settle in North America.

1606.title: Creation of the Union Flag
1606.summary: The first version of the Union Flag is created to be worn by English and Scottish ships.

1606.title: Assassination of Tsar Dmitry I
1606.summary: Russia's Tsar Dmitry I is assassinated in the Kremlin.

1606.title: Discovery of Vanuatu
1606.summary: Pedro Fernandes de Queirós discovers the islands of Vanuatu, believing them to be part of Australia.

1606.title: Battle of Cape Rachado
1606.summary: A Dutch fleet is defeated by the Portuguese.

1606.title: First performance of King Lear
1606.summary: William Shakespeare's play King Lear is given its first recorded performance at the Palace of Whitehall.

1606.title: Signing of the Peace of Zsitvatorok
1606.summary: The Peace of Zsitvatorok is signed, recognizing the independence of Transylvania.

1607.title: Bank of Genoa Failure
1607.summary: The Bank of Genoa fails after the announcement of national bankruptcy in Spain.

1607.title: Completion of San Agustin Church
1607.summary: San Agustin Church in Manila is officially completed and will become the oldest church in the Philippines by the 21st century.

1607.title: Bristol Channel Tsunami
1607.summary: A massive wave sweeps along the Bristol Channel, possibly a tsunami, causing the deaths of 2000 people.

1607.title: Premiere of L'Orfeo
1607.summary: Claudio Monteverdi's L'Orfeo, the earliest fully developed opera in the modern repertoire, premieres at the Ducal Palace of Mantua.

1607.title: Battle of Gol
1607.summary: In the Battle of Gol, Susenyos defeats the combined armies of Yaqob and Abuna Petros II, making him Emperor of Ethiopia.

1607.title: Battle of Gibraltar
1607.summary: A Dutch fleet stages a surprise attack on a Spanish fleet at Gibraltar, leading to substantial Spanish losses and eventual bankruptcy.

1607.title: Establishment of Jamestown
1607.summary: Jamestown, Virginia, is established as the first permanent English settlement in North America, marking the beginning of the American frontier.

1607.title: Newton Rebellion
1607.summary: The Tresham landowners family kills more than 40 peasants during protests against enclosure of common land in Newton, England.

1607.title: Flight of the Earls
1607.summary: Hugh O'Neill and Rory O'Donnell flee Ireland for Spain with 90 followers to avoid capture by the English crown.

1607.title: Halley's Comet Observed
1607.summary: Halley's Comet is seen by Johannes Kepler, contributing to astronomical studies of the era.

1608.title: Jamestown Supply Mission
1608.summary: The first of the Jamestown supply missions returns to the Colony of Virginia with about 100 new settlers.

1608.title: Fire at Jamestown
1608.summary: At Jamestown, Virginia, fire destroys all the houses in the fort; the fort is repaired in March.

1608.title: Treaty of The Hague
1608.summary: Treaty of The Hague, a defensive alliance between France and the United Provinces of the Netherlands, is signed.

1608.title: Abdication of Sigismund Rákóczi
1608.summary: Sigismund Rákóczi, Prince of Transylvania, abdicates in favor of Gabriel Báthory to avoid a civil war.

1608.title: Coronation of Emperor Susenyos
1608.summary: Susenyos is formally crowned Emperor of Ethiopia, at the ancient city of Axum.

1608.title: Foundation of University of Oviedo
1608.summary: The University of Oviedo in Spain is founded.

1608.title: Telescope Demonstration
1608.summary: Dutch lens maker Hans Lippershey demonstrates the first telescope in the Dutch Parliament.

1608.title: Coronation of Matthias II
1608.summary: In Budapest, the coronation ceremonies take place for Matthias to be crowned as King Mátyás II of Hungary.

1608.title: Jamestown Supply Mission Returns
1608.summary: The second of the Jamestown supply missions arrives at Jamestown, Virginia, with 70 settlers.

1608.title: Founding of Liechtenstein
1608.summary: Karl of the House of Liechtenstein founds the Principality of Liechtenstein within the Holy Roman Empire.

1609.title: Avisa newspaper begins publication
1609.summary: Avisa newspaper begins publication, marking a significant advancement in media and journalism.

1609.title: The Basque witch trials
1609.summary: The Inquisition court at Logroño orders the arrest of four women, marking the start of the infamous Basque witch trials.

1609.title: The Bank of Amsterdam is established
1609.summary: The establishment of the Bank of Amsterdam represents a significant advancement in banking practices in Europe.

1609.title: Swedish Army marches east
1609.summary: The Swedish Army begins marching east to defend the Russian Empire during the Polish–Muscovite War.

1609.title: Treaty of Antwerp
1609.summary: The Twelve Years' Truce is agreed upon, allowing the Dutch East India Company to trade within the Spanish Empire.

1609.title: Shake-speares Sonnets published
1609.summary: Thomas Thorpe issues Shake-speares Sonnets, a significant moment in literary history.

1609.title: War of the Jülich Succession begins
1609.summary: The War of the Jülich Succession begins as Protestant and Catholic forces battle for control, affecting the political landscape of Europe.

1609.title: First detailed drawing of the Moon
1609.summary: Thomas Harriot becomes the first to make a detailed drawing of the Moon, marking a significant achievement in astronomy.

1609.title: Galileo demonstrates his first telescope
1609.summary: Galileo Galilei demonstrates his first telescope to officials, a pivotal moment in scientific history.

1609.title: Henry Hudson enters New York Bay
1609.summary: Henry Hudson sails into Upper New York Bay, marking a significant exploration of the Americas.

1610.title: Henry Hudson sails into Hudson Bay
1610.summary: Henry Hudson sails into what is now known as Hudson Bay, thinking he has made it through the Northwest Passage and reached the Pacific Ocean.

1610.title: Galileo Galilei observes Galilean moons
1610.summary: Galileo Galilei first observes the four Galilean moons of Jupiter: Ganymede, Callisto, Europa and Io.

1610.title: Publication of Sidereus Nuncius
1610.summary: Galileo Galilei's treatise on astronomy, Sidereus Nuncius, the first printed scientific record of observations through a telescope, is first published.

1610.title: Assassination of King Henry IV of France
1610.summary: King Henry IV of France is assassinated in Paris by François Ravaillac, a French Catholic activist who resents the Protestant monarch's decision to launch a war against the Catholic Spanish Netherlands.

1610.title: First performance of Macbeth
1610.summary: William Shakespeare's play, The Tragedie of Macbeth, is given its first performance, staged at the Globe Theatre in London.

1610.title: Establishment of Jamestown laws
1610.summary: The temporary Governor, Thomas Gates, issues The Divine, Moral, and Martial Laws in Jamestown.

1610.title: Siege of Jülich
1610.summary: The Siege of Jülich ends as the Holy Roman Imperial city surrenders to Maurice of Nassau, commander of the Dutch Republic troops.

1610.title: Publication of Vespro della Beata Vergine
1610.summary: Claudio Monteverdi's musical work Vespro della Beata Vergine (Vespers for the Blessed Virgin) is first published, printed in Venice.

1610.title: Coronation of Louis XIII
1610.summary: The coronation of Louis XIII of France takes place, marking a significant event in French history.

1610.title: End of the Basque witch trials
1610.summary: The Basque witch trials come to an end after almost two years, with six condemned to execution.

1611.title: Resignation of Maximilien de Béthune
1611.summary: Maximilien de Béthune is forced to resign as chief minister of France by Queen regent Marie's Regency Council, replaced by Nicolas de Neufville.

1611.title: Observation of Sunspots
1611.summary: Frisian astronomers Johannes Fabricius and David Fabricius observe sunspots by telescope, but these early discoveries are overlooked.

1611.title: Enthronement of George Abbot
1611.summary: George Abbot is enthroned as Archbishop of Canterbury in England, marking a notable religious event.

1611.title: Battle of Segaba
1611.summary: The Battle of Segaba ends the rebellion of Melka Sedeq in Ethiopia, led by Yemana Kristos, brother of Emperor Susenyos I.

1611.title: Moscow Uprising
1611.summary: The Moscow Uprising against Polish-Lithuanian occupation of Moscow results in major fires and significant civilian casualties.

1611.title: Denmark-Norway Declares War
1611.summary: Denmark-Norway declares war on Sweden and captures Kalmar, escalating regional tensions.

1611.title: Publication of King James Bible
1611.summary: The Authorized King James Version of the Bible is published for the first time, marking a major cultural and religious milestone.

1611.title: Performance of The Winter's Tale
1611.summary: William Shakespeare's The Winter's Tale is performed for the first time at the Globe Theatre, contributing to the cultural landscape.

1611.title: Siege of Smolensk
1611.summary: The Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth succeeds in the Siege of Smolensk after nearly two years, leading to the city’s conquest.

1611.title: Sanriku Earthquake
1611.summary: The 1611 Sanriku earthquake strikes off the coast of Japan, causing a devastating tsunami and loss of life.

1612.title: Axel Oxenstierna becomes Lord High Chancellor
1612.summary: Axel Oxenstierna becomes Lord High Chancellor of Sweden, persuading the Riksdag of the Estates to grant the Swedish nobility rights to hold higher offices of government.

1612.title: Gustavus Adolphus assumes responsibility for Russia
1612.summary: Gustavus Adolphus replies to Metropolitan Isidor and the estates of Novgorod, expressing his desire to assume responsibility for the government of Novgorod and claiming the title of Tsar.

1612.title: Death of Rudolf II
1612.summary: Rudolf II, Holy Roman Emperor, dies. Archduke Matthias is elected as his successor after several candidates vie for the position.

1612.title: Uprising in Moscow
1612.summary: An uprising led by Dmitry Pozharsky begins in Moscow against occupying Polish troops, marking a significant event in the struggle for Russian independence.

1612.title: Battle of Vittsjö
1612.summary: King Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden is forced to retreat from Denmark during the Battle of Vittsjö, nearly drowning in the process.

1612.title: False Dmitry III recognized as Tsar
1612.summary: The False Dmitry III, one of the pretenders to the Russian throne, is recognized as Tsar of Russia by the Cossacks, intensifying the political turmoil in Russia.

1612.title: Marriage of Prince Khurram and Mumtaz Mahal
1612.summary: Prince Khurram marries Mumtaz Mahal in Delhi, who later becomes known for the Taj Mahal built in her memory.

1612.title: Last witch burning in England
1612.summary: Edward Wightman, a radical Anabaptist, becomes the last person to be executed by burning at the stake in England for heresy.

1612.title: Battle of Swally
1612.summary: The forces of the English East India Company engage the Portuguese off the coast of India, resulting in an English victory.

1612.title: Galileo observes Neptune
1612.summary: Galileo Galilei becomes the first astronomer to observe Neptune, mistakenly cataloguing it as a fixed star due to its slow motion.

1613.title: Discovery of Giant Skeleton
1613.summary: Workers in a sandpit in the Dauphiné region of France discover the skeleton of what is alleged to be a 30-foot tall man, supposedly the remains of the giant Teutobochus.

1613.title: Treaty of Knäred
1613.summary: King James I of England successfully mediates the Treaty of Knäred between Denmark and Sweden.

1613.title: Marriage of Elizabeth and Frederick V
1613.summary: Elizabeth, daughter of King James I of England, marries Frederick V, Elector Palatine.

1613.title: Blockade of Syriam
1613.summary: King Anaukpetlun of Burma blockades the Portuguese port at Syriam with 80 warships and 3,000 men.

1613.title: Election of Mikhail Romanov
1613.summary: An assembly of the Russian Empire elects Mikhail Romanov Tsar of Russia, ending the Time of Troubles.

1613.title: First English Child Born in Canada
1613.summary: The first English child is born in Canada at Cuper's Cove, Newfoundland to Nicholas Guy.

1613.title: Samuel de Champlain Becomes Governor
1613.summary: Explorer Samuel de Champlain becomes the first unofficial Governor of New France in Canada.

1613.title: Capture of Pocahontas
1613.summary: Samuel Argall captures Algonquian princess Pocahontas in Passapatanzy, Virginia, to ransom her for English prisoners.

1613.title: Arrival of Tobacco in England
1613.summary: From Jamestown, John Rolfe makes the first shipment to England of tobacco grown in Virginia.

1613.title: Assassination of Diego Marín de Negron
1613.summary: Diego Marín de Negron, the Spanish Governor of Rio de la Plata y Paraguay, is assassinated by poisoning at his palace in Buenos Aires.

1614.title: Trade Expedition to New Spain
1614.summary: Led by Hasekura Tsunenaga, Japan's trade expedition to New Spain arrives on the Mexican coast with 22 samurai and Japanese merchants, marking significant cross-cultural contact.

1614.title: Banning of Christianity in Japan
1614.summary: In Japan, the practice of Christianity is banned, leading to the expulsion of all foreign missionaries and a crackdown on Christian communities.

1614.title: Execution of Crown Prince Mohammad Baqer Mirza
1614.summary: The Safavid dynasty Emperor Abbas the Great executes his oldest son on suspicion of planning his murder, highlighting political intrigue within the dynasty.

1614.title: Proclamation Against Private Challenges
1614.summary: King James I of England issues a proclamation to end duels, showcasing a shift towards legal regulation of personal disputes.

1614.title: Restoration of Roman Catholic Rule in Aachen
1614.summary: Matthias I directs the restoration of Catholic rule to Aachen, allowing a military siege against the town, indicating religious tensions in Europe.

1614.title: Construction of Takada Castle
1614.summary: Major construction begins on Takada Castle in Japan, significant for its military and cultural importance in the region.

1614.title: Raid of Malta
1614.summary: Ottoman forces make a final attempt to conquer Malta, facing a significant defense by the Knights Hospitaller, a key moment in Mediterranean power dynamics.

1614.title: Establishment of the University of Groningen
1614.summary: The University of Groningen is established, marking a significant advancement in higher education in the Dutch Republic.

1614.title: Louis XIII Assumes Full Power
1614.summary: Louis XIII of France assumes full power as king, ending the regency of his mother and marking a pivotal moment in French royal history.

1614.title: Treaty of Xanten
1614.summary: The Treaty of Xanten ends the War of the Jülich Succession, impacting the political landscape of Europe.

1615.title: New Netherland Company Monopoly
1615.summary: The New Netherland Company is granted a three-year monopoly in North American trade, between the 40th and 45th parallels.

1615.title: Hasekura Tsunenaga's Visit to Spain
1615.summary: Japan's diplomatic mission to Europe, led by Hasekura Tsunenaga, meets with King Philip III of Spain at Madrid and presents an offer of a treaty.

1615.title: First English Ambassador to Mughal Empire
1615.summary: Sir Thomas Roe sets out to become the first ambassador from the court of the King of England to the Mughal Emperor Jahangir.

1615.title: John Ogilvie's Martyrdom
1615.summary: John Ogilvie, a Jesuit priest, is hanged and drawn at Glasgow Cross in Scotland for refusing to pledge allegiance to King James VI of Scotland.

1615.title: Inauguration of Wignacourt Aqueduct
1615.summary: The Wignacourt Aqueduct is inaugurated in Malta.

1615.title: Battle of Dōmyōji and Battle of Tennōji
1615.summary: The Eastern Army of Tokugawa Ieyasu and the Osaka Army of Toyotomi Hideyori clash during battles in Japan.

1615.title: Tokugawa Ieyasu Takes Osaka Castle
1615.summary: Forces under shōgun Tokugawa Ieyasu take Osaka Castle in Japan, beginning a period of peace which lasts nearly 250 years.

1615.title: Siege of Pskov
1615.summary: Swedish troops led by King Gustavus Adolphus begin the siege of the Russian city of Pskov, but fail to take the fortress after 12 weeks.

1615.title: Hasekura Tsunenaga's Visit to Italy
1615.summary: Japanese diplomat Hasekura Tsunenaga and his entourage become the first officials from Japan to visit Italy, and are received in Rome by Cardinal Burgecio.

1615.title: End of the Siege of Pskov
1615.summary: The siege of Pskov ends with the withdrawal of Swedish Army troops. The siege is the last battle of the Ingrian War.

1616.title: Opening of British presence in India
1616.summary: English diplomat Sir Thomas Roe presents his credentials to the Mughal Emperor Jahangir, in Ajmer Fort, opening the door to the British presence in India.

1616.title: Foundation of Belém
1616.summary: The city of Belém, Brazil is founded on the Amazon River delta, by Portuguese captain Francisco Caldeira Castelo Branco.

1616.title: Declaration of the Later Jin dynasty
1616.summary: Manchurian leader Qing Tai Zu, referred to in the west as 'Nurhaci', declares himself khan and crowns himself as Emperor of China, founding the Later Jin dynasty.

1616.title: First recorded eruption of Mayon Volcano
1616.summary: The first recorded eruption of Mayon Volcano, the Philippines' most active volcano, takes place.

1616.title: Pocahontas arrives in England
1616.summary: Pocahontas (now Rebecca) arrives in England, with her husband, John Rolfe, as a fund-raising device for the Virginia Company.

1616.title: Publication of Copernicus' work
1616.summary: De revolutionibus orbium coelestium, written by Nicolaus Copernicus in 1543 is placed on the Index of Forbidden Books, by the Congregation of the Index of the Roman Catholic Church 'until corrected'.

1616.title: Release of Sir Walter Ralegh
1616.summary: Sir Walter Ralegh, English explorer of the New World, is released from prison in the Tower of London to conduct a second expedition, in search of El Dorado in South America.

1616.title: Eruption of Manam Volcano
1616.summary: First recorded eruption of Manam Volcano, forming a 10-km-wide island in the Bismarck Sea, 13 km off the coast of Papua New Guinea.

1616.title: King James I invests Prince Charles
1616.summary: Prince Charles is invested as Prince of Wales at Whitehall in London, the last such formal investiture until 1911.

1616.title: Founding of the Collegium Musicum
1616.summary: The Collegium Musicum is founded in Prague, reflecting the growth of musical organization in Europe.

1617.title: Pocahontas meets King James I
1617.summary: Pocahontas and Tomocomo of the Powhatan Algonquian tribe meet King James I of England as his guests at the Banqueting House at Whitehall.

1617.title: Treaty of Stolbovo
1617.summary: The Treaty of Stolbovo ends the Ingrian War between Sweden and Russia. Sweden gains Ingria and Kexholm.

1617.title: Cockpit Theatre Riots
1617.summary: Angry rioters burn down London's Cockpit Theatre due to increased admission prices. Three rioters are killed when actors defend themselves.

1617.title: Francis Bacon appointed Lord Keeper
1617.summary: Francis Bacon is appointed as Lord Keeper of the Great Seal of England and designated by King James I to serve as regent during the King's absence.

1617.title: Death of Pocahontas
1617.summary: Pocahontas dies of smallpox after an illness while preparing to return to America. She is buried at Gravesend.

1617.title: Second Battle of Playa Honda
1617.summary: The Spanish navy defeats a Dutch fleet in the Philippines, marking a significant naval engagement.

1617.title: Assassination of Concino Concini
1617.summary: Louis XIII of France forces his mother into retirement and has her favourite Concino Concini assassinated.

1617.title: Return of King James to Scotland
1617.summary: King James I of England returns to Scotland for the first time since the Union of the Crowns established the dual monarchy.

1617.title: Discovery of the Sharp Resolution
1617.summary: The Sharp Resolution is passed, allowing city governments in Holland to create mercenary armies for public order.

1617.title: Signing of the Peace of Busza
1617.summary: The Peace of Busza is signed between the Ottoman Empire and the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth, affecting regional politics.

1618.title: Audience to the British East India Company
1618.summary: Jahangir, ruler of the Mughal Empire, gives an audience for the first time to a representative of the British East India Company, receiving Sir Thomas Roe at the capital at Ahmedabad.

1618.title: Pleasure Reconciled to Virtue Premiere
1618.summary: Ben Jonson's play Pleasure Reconciled to Virtue is given its premiere performance at the Palace of Whitehall in London.

1618.title: Jeong In-hong appointed Chief State Councillor
1618.summary: Jeong In-hong becomes the new Chief State Councillor of the Joseon Kingdom after being appointed by the Emperor Gwanghaegun.

1618.title: Osman II deposes Mustafa I
1618.summary: Osman II deposes his uncle Mustafa I as Ottoman sultan, marking significant political change in the empire.

1618.title: Kepler discovers third law of planetary motion
1618.summary: Johannes Kepler discovers the third law of planetary motion, which would influence future astronomical studies.

1618.title: Pedro Páez sees the Blue Nile
1618.summary: Spanish-born Jesuit missionary Pedro Páez becomes the first European to see and describe the source of the Blue Nile in Ethiopia.

1618.title: The Second Defenestration of Prague
1618.summary: Protestant noblemen hold a mock trial and throw representatives of Ferdinand II of Germany out of a window, escalating the Bohemian Revolt.

1618.title: First Dutch newspaper printed
1618.summary: Joris Veseler prints the first Dutch newspaper Courante uyt Italien, Duytslandt, &c., marking a milestone in media history.

1618.title: Ferdinand II crowned King of Hungary
1618.summary: Ferdinand II is crowned as King of Hungary, strengthening the Counter-Reformation in the region.

1618.title: Siege of Pilsen begins
1618.summary: The Siege of Pilsen begins as Bohemian Protestants lay siege to the Catholic city, marking a significant battle in the Thirty Years' War.

1619.title: Banqueting House Fire
1619.summary: James I of England's Banqueting House in Whitehall, London is destroyed by fire.

1619.title: Trujillo Earthquake
1619.summary: An earthquake flattens the town of Trujillo, Peru, killing hundreds and causing landslides.

1619.title: Death of Matthias
1619.summary: Matthias, Holy Roman Emperor dies, leaving the Holy Roman Empire without an official leader, impacting the Bohemian Revolt.

1619.title: Battle of Sarhu
1619.summary: Manchu leader Nurhaci is victorious over the Ming forces in the Battle of Sarhu.

1619.title: Execution of Johan van Oldenbarnevelt
1619.summary: Dutch statesman Johan van Oldenbarnevelt is executed in The Hague after being convicted of treason.

1619.title: Conquest of Jayakarta
1619.summary: Jan Pieterszoon Coen conquers Jayakarta and renames it Batavia.

1619.title: Start of the Virginia General Assembly
1619.summary: The first English-speaking representative assembly in the Americas convenes in Jamestown, Virginia.

1619.title: Battle of Věstonice
1619.summary: Bohemian forces defeat the Austrians in the Battle of Věstonice during the Thirty Years' War.

1619.title: Treaty of Angoulême
1619.summary: The Treaty of Angoulême ends the civil war between Louis XIII of France and his mother, Marie de' Medici.

1619.title: Landing of enslaved Africans
1619.summary: A group of enslaved Africans are landed at Point Comfort in colonial Virginia, marking a significant event in American history.

1620.title: Battle of White Mountain
1620.summary: Catholic Habsburg forces are victorious over Bohemian rebels two hours from Prague.

1620.title: Arrival of the Mayflower
1620.summary: The Mayflower arrives inside the tip of Cape Cod, with the Pilgrims and Planters; 41 Plymouth Colony settlers sign the Mayflower Compact on board the ship.

1620.title: First performance of News from the New World Discovered in the Moon
1620.summary: Ben Jonson's play is presented to King James I, featuring fanciful discussions of a lunar civilization.

1620.title: Karan Singh II becomes ruler of Mewar
1620.summary: Karan Singh II ascends to the throne upon the death of his father, Maharana Amar Singh I.

1620.title: Peace treaty between Bethlen Gabor and Ferdinand II
1620.summary: Prince Bethlen Gabor secures a peace treaty with Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor.

1620.title: The first merry-go-round
1620.summary: The first merry-go-round is seen at a fair in Philippapolis, Turkey.

1620.title: First recorded earthquake in South Africa
1620.summary: The earliest recorded earthquake occurs at Robben Island.

1620.title: Battle of Cecora
1620.summary: The Ottoman Empire defeats Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth-Moldavian troops.

1620.title: Creation of a sign alphabet
1620.summary: Juan Pablo Bonet creates a sign alphabet for deaf children in the Spanish court.

1620.title: Development of the modern violin
1620.summary: The modern violin is developed, marking an important advancement in music history.

1621.title: Death of Şehzade Mehmed
1621.summary: Şehzade Mehmed, the half-brother of Ottoman Sultan Osman II, is executed by hanging on Osman's orders.

1621.title: Foundation of Batavia
1621.summary: The Dutch East India Company names its fortress at Jayakarta in Indonesia, later to be called Jakarta.

1621.title: Beginning of the Tianqi Era
1621.summary: The Tianqi era begins in Ming Dynasty China following the ascension of Taichang Emperor.

1621.title: Rioting in Constantinople
1621.summary: Bitter winter weather leads to rioting in Constantinople following the execution of Prince Mehmed.

1621.title: Death of Pope Paul V
1621.summary: Pope Paul V dies after 15 years of papacy.

1621.title: Conclave of Pope Gregory XV
1621.summary: Papal Conclave of 1621 results in the election of Pope Gregory XV, succeeding Pope Paul V.

1621.title: Appointment of Myles Standish
1621.summary: Myles Standish becomes the first commander of Plymouth Colony.

1621.title: Treaty with Massasoit
1621.summary: The Pilgrims of Plymouth Colony sign a peace treaty with Massasoit of the Wampanoags.

1621.title: Foundation of Tornio
1621.summary: King Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden founds the city of Tornio in Lapland.

1621.title: Thirty Years' War Executions
1621.summary: Twenty-seven Czech lords are executed in Prague as a consequence of the Thirty Years' War.

1622.title: Battle of Wimpfen
1622.summary: In a failed diversion maneuver during the Thirty Years' War, the Protestant forces are nearly destroyed by Tilly at Wimpfen.

1622.title: Peace of Nikolsburg
1622.summary: The Holy Roman Empire and Transylvania sign a peace treaty in Nikolsburg, ending hostilities between the two forces.

1622.title: Jamestown Massacre
1622.summary: Algonquian natives execute a major attack, killing 347 English settlers in Jamestown, marking the beginning of the American Indian Wars.

1622.title: Capture of Hormuz
1622.summary: The Anglo-Persian force captures Hormuz from the Portuguese, altering the control of trade routes in the region.

1622.title: Strangulation of Osman II
1622.summary: Ottoman Sultan Osman II is killed by Janissary rebels, a significant event in Ottoman politics leading to instability.

1622.title: Battle of Höchst
1622.summary: In the Thirty Years' War, Tilly inflicts significant casualties on the Protestant forces, influencing the war's trajectory.

1622.title: Battle of Macau
1622.summary: Portuguese forces successfully defend Macau from the Dutch fleet, maintaining their foothold in Asia during the Dutch-Portuguese War.

1622.title: Capture of Mannheim
1622.summary: Spanish and Imperial troops capture Mannheim, strengthening their hold in the region during the Thirty Years' War.

1622.title: Battle of Mbumbi
1622.summary: Portuguese forces, allied with Imbangala, achieve a military victory over the Kingdom of Kongo in a significant conflict in Africa.

1622.title: Foundation of Bucaramanga
1622.summary: The Spanish found the colonial city of Bucaramanga in Nueva Granada, establishing a foothold in southern Colombia.

1623.title: Viscount Falkland's Proclamation
1623.summary: Lord Deputy of Ireland issues a proclamation ordering all Roman Catholic priests to leave Ireland, affecting negotiations over the Spanish match.

1623.title: Battle of Mbanda Kasi
1623.summary: Forces from the Kingdom of Kongo defeat the Portuguese in a significant battle.

1623.title: Treaty of Paris
1623.summary: France, Savoy and Venice sign an agreement to cooperate in removing Spanish forces from Valtelline.

1623.title: First American Temperance Law
1623.summary: The first American temperance law is enacted in Virginia, marking a significant legal milestone.

1623.title: Amboyna Massacre
1623.summary: Ten English merchants and other nationals are executed by agents of the Dutch East India Company in Ambon.

1623.title: Deposition of Crown Prince Yi Ji
1623.summary: Crown Prince Yi Ji is deposed and exiled in Korea, marking a significant political change.

1623.title: First Breach-of-Promise Lawsuit
1623.summary: Rev. Gerville Pooley files the first breach-of-promise lawsuit in Virginia, though he loses the case.

1623.title: PremiÃ¨re of Amor, honor y poder
1623.summary: Pedro Calderón de la Barca's first play premiers at the Court of Habsburg Spain, contributing to the cultural landscape.

1623.title: The Second Thanksgiving
1623.summary: Reportedly celebrated in Plymouth Colony, reflecting the cultural practices of settlers in America.

1623.title: Publication of Shakespeare's First Folio
1623.summary: Publication of the First Folio in London, a significant event in literary history, containing many of Shakespeare's plays.

1624.title: Recapture of Baghdad
1624.summary: After 90 years of Ottoman occupation, Baghdad is recaptured by the Safavid Empire.

1624.title: Korean Uprising
1624.summary: Korean General Yi Gwal leads an uprising of 12,000 soldiers against King Injo in the Joseon Kingdom, occupying Hanseong.

1624.title: Colonization of Saint Kitts and Nevis
1624.summary: England first colonizes Saint Kitts and Nevis.

1624.title: End of Yi Gwal's Rebellion
1624.summary: Yi Gwal's Rebellion ends as the rebels murder Yi Gwal at the town of Mukbang-ri.

1624.title: Decree against Chinese Enslavement
1624.summary: King Filipe III of Portugal issues a decree prohibiting the enslavement of Chinese people in Portugal or in its colonies.

1624.title: Military Resolution by English Parliament
1624.summary: The English House of Commons passes a resolution making it illegal for a Member of Parliament to quit or willfully give up his seat.

1624.title: Enthronement of Garcia I
1624.summary: Garcia Mvemba a Nkanga is enthroned as King Garcia I of Kongo upon the death of his father.

1624.title: Capture of Salvador
1624.summary: A Dutch West India Company fleet captures the Brazilian city of Salvador, Bahia from the Portuguese Empire.

1624.title: Destruction of Oslo
1624.summary: The city of Oslo, Norway, is destroyed by fire for the fourteenth time and is rebuilt on a new site.

1624.title: Treaty of Compiègne
1624.summary: Treaty of Compiègne is signed between the Kingdom of France and the Dutch Republic.

1625.title: Capture of Ré Island
1625.summary: Troops under the Marquis of Toiras successfully recapture the island of Ré, forcing the Duke of Soubise to flee to England, ending the second Huguenot rebellion.

1625.title: Francesca Caccini's Opera Premiere
1625.summary: Francesca Caccini's opera La liberazione di Ruggiero has its premiere in Florence, marking a significant cultural event in the history of opera.

1625.title: Formation of Alliance against Spain
1625.summary: The Treaty of Southampton establishes an alliance between England and the Dutch Republic against Spain.

1625.title: Defeat of Dutch Fleet in Elmina
1625.summary: A Dutch fleet attacks the Portuguese garrison at Elmina castle but suffers a decisive defeat, impacting Dutch colonial efforts.

1625.title: Spanish Conquest of Breda
1625.summary: Spanish troops under Ambrogio Spinola conquer Breda after a nine-month siege during the Eighty Years' War, showcasing military power in the region.

1625.title: Appointment of Albrecht von Wallenstein
1625.summary: Albrecht von Wallenstein is appointed German supreme commander, a key military position in the Thirty Years' War.

1625.title: Archbishop of Armagh Appointment
1625.summary: James Ussher is appointed Archbishop of Armagh and Primate of All Ireland, significantly impacting the Church of Ireland.

1625.title: Marriage of Charles I
1625.summary: King Charles I of England marries Catholic princess Henrietta Maria of France at Canterbury, marking a politically significant union.

1625.title: Treaty of The Hague
1625.summary: The Netherlands and England sign the Treaty of The Hague, providing military aid to Denmark during the Thirty Years' War.

1625.title: Dutch Settling of Manhattan
1625.summary: The Dutch settle Manhattan, founding the town of New Amsterdam, which will evolve into modern New York City.

1626.title: Battle of Wallhof
1626.summary: Gustavus Adolphus, King of Sweden, defeats a Polish army in Latvia during the Polish-Swedish War.

1626.title: Sailing to New Netherland
1626.summary: Peter Minuit sails from Texel Island for America’s New Netherland colony, with two ships of Dutch emigrants.

1626.title: Coronation of King Charles I
1626.summary: King Charles I of England is crowned without his wife, Henrietta Maria, who declines a non-Catholic ceremony.

1626.title: Treaty of Paris
1626.summary: The Huguenot rebels and the French government sign the Treaty of Paris, ending the second Huguenot rebellion.

1626.title: Battle of Ningyuan
1626.summary: Ming dynasty commander Yuan Chonghuan defeats the larger force of Manchu leader Nurhaci in Xingcheng, China.

1626.title: Primacy of the Roman See in Ethiopia
1626.summary: Emperor Susenyos of Ethiopia and Patriarch Afonso Mendes declare the primacy of the Roman See over the Ethiopian Church, making Roman Catholicism the state religion.

1626.title: Treaty of Monzón
1626.summary: The Treaty of Monzón is signed between France and Spain to end the Valtellina War and the First Genoese-Savoyard War.

1626.title: Wanggongchang Explosion
1626.summary: A gunpowder factory explosion in Beijing, China, destroys part of the city and kills 20,000 people.

1626.title: Execution of Jesuit Missionaries
1626.summary: Nine Jesuit Christian missionaries in Japan are executed, followed by eight Japanese converts to Christianity.

1626.title: Death of Nurhaci
1626.summary: Nurhaci, chief of the Jurchens and founder of the Qing dynasty, dies and is succeeded by his son Hong Taiji.

1627.title: The last recorded Aurochs dies
1627.summary: The last recorded aurochs die in the Jaktorów Forest of Poland.

1627.title: First recorded sighting of South Australia
1627.summary: The Dutch ship 't Gulden Zeepaert makes the first recorded sighting of the coast of South Australia.

1627.title: Foundation of Iisalmi parish
1627.summary: The administrative rural parish of Iisalmi is established in Savonia by order of King Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden.

1627.title: First European settlers land on Barbados
1627.summary: England lands the first European settlers on Barbados.

1627.title: Joseon Dynasty becomes Manchu tributary
1627.summary: After the First Manchu invasion of Korea, the Joseon Dynasty becomes a tributary state of the Manchus.

1627.title: Maurice of Hesse-Kassel abdicates
1627.summary: Maurice, Landgrave of Hesse-Kassel, is forced to abdicate after his spending brings the region to bankruptcy.

1627.title: Turkish Abductions by Barbary pirates
1627.summary: The Barbary pirates begin raiding Iceland in attacks.

1627.title: Siege of Grol
1627.summary: Frederick Henry, Prince of Orange, begins the Siege of Grol, capturing it after 30 days.

1627.title: Persecution of Christians in Japan
1627.summary: In a persecution of Christians in Japan, 14 Franciscan missionaries and converts are killed.

1627.title: First Spanish opera premieres
1627.summary: La selva sin amor, written by Lope de Vega and with music by Alessandro Piccinini, premieres as the first Spanish opera.

1628.title: End of Shahryar Mirza's Reign
1628.summary: The reign of Salef-ud-din Muhammad Shahryar as the Mughal Emperor ends following his defeat by his brother Shihab. Shah Jahan is declared as the new ruler after Shahryar and others are sentenced to death.

1628.title: Execution of Shahryar Mirza
1628.summary: Former Mughal Emperor Shahryar Mirza is executed along with several members of his family after being blinded on the orders of his brother.

1628.title: Siege of Nacimiento
1628.summary: The indigenous Mapuche lay siege to the Spanish colonial settlement of Nacimiento in Chile, successfully taking muskets and two cannons during the siege.

1628.title: Start of Chongzhen Era
1628.summary: The Chongzhen Era begins in Ming dynasty China with the ascension of Zhu Youjian as the Chongzhen Emperor.

1628.title: Coronation of Shah Jahan
1628.summary: Shah Jahan is formally crowned as the ruler of the Mughal Empire in a grand ceremony in Agra.

1628.title: Writs for Ship Tax
1628.summary: King Charles I issues writs requiring all counties in England to pay a ship tax, marking a significant tax initiative.

1628.title: Firing of Damat Halil Pasha
1628.summary: Damat Halil Pasha is dismissed as Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire by Sultan Murad IV for his failure to quell a rebellion.

1628.title: Siege of Stralsund
1628.summary: The siege of Stralsund by Wallenstein's forces begins as part of the Thirty Years' War, lasting several months amid fierce resistance.

1628.title: Assassination of the Duke of Buckingham
1628.summary: English courtier George Villiers, the first Duke of Buckingham, is assassinated by John Felton, sparking political repercussions.

1628.title: Publication on Blood Circulation
1628.summary: William Harvey publishes his foundational work on blood circulation, which will have a lasting impact on medicine.

1629.title: Death of Abbas the Great
1629.summary: Abbas the Great, one of the greatest rulers in Iranian history, dies marking the end of an influential reign.

1629.title: Crowning of Shah Safi
1629.summary: Sam Mirza is crowned as the new Shah of Persia and takes the regnal name Safi, continuing the legacy of his grandfather.

1629.title: Massachusetts Bay Colony Charter
1629.summary: The Massachusetts Bay Colony is granted a royal charter, becoming a significant development in the future United States.

1629.title: Edict of Restitution
1629.summary: Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor issues the Edict of Restitution, restoring Catholic properties lost to Protestantism.

1629.title: Capture of Fort Taurege
1629.summary: Portuguese Navy Captain Pedro Teixeira leads an attack to capture Fort Taurege from England, showcasing colonial ambitions in Brazil.

1629.title: Surrender of Quebec
1629.summary: Samuel de Champlain surrenders the city of Quebec to an English force, altering the dynamics of North American colonies.

1629.title: Signing of the Peace of Alès
1629.summary: Louis XIII of France signs the Peace of Alès, ending the Huguenot rebellions and granting religious freedom to Huguenots.

1629.title: Surrender of 's-Hertogenbosch
1629.summary: After a long siege, the city of 's-Hertogenbosch surrenders, which significantly impacts the Spanish position in the Netherlands.

1629.title: Execution of Mao Wenlong
1629.summary: The execution of Mao Wenlong in Joseon marks a significant moment during the Later Jin invasion, affecting the local power dynamics.

1629.title: Abdication of Emperor Go-Mizunoo
1629.summary: Emperor Go-Mizunoo of Japan abdicates the throne in favor of his daughter, marking a notable change in Japanese monarchy.

1630.title: Beginning of the Plague of 1630
1630.summary: A shoemaker in Turin is found to have the first case of bubonic plague there as the plague of 1630 begins spreading through Italy.

1630.title: Portuguese Military Advisers Arrive in China
1630.summary: A team of Portuguese military advisers to China's Ming dynasty government arrive at Zhuozhou, beginning to train troops in using modern cannons.

1630.title: Arrest of General Yuan Chonghuan
1630.summary: In China, General Yuan Chonghuan is invited to an audience with the Chongzhen Emperor and is arrested on charges of collusion with the enemy.

1630.title: Election of Nicolò Contarini as Doge
1630.summary: Nicolò Contarini is elected as the new Doge of the Republic of Venice amid a bubonic plague epidemic.

1630.title: Introduction of Popcorn to Colonists
1630.summary: Native American Quadequine introduces popcorn to English colonists.

1630.title: Capture of Recife by Dutch West India Company
1630.summary: A fleet sent by the Dutch West India Company captures Recife from the Portuguese, establishing Dutch Brazil.

1630.title: The 1630 Crete Earthquake
1630.summary: The 1630 Crete earthquake occurs, causing significant damage.

1630.title: Ottoman Victory in Persia
1630.summary: In an invasion of Persia, Ottoman Empire Grand Vizier Gazi Hüsrev Pasha routs the Persians at Mahidasht near Kermanshah.

1630.title: Plague reported in Milan
1630.summary: The first case of plague is reported in Milan, which will lead to massive deaths.

1630.title: Battle of Villabuona
1630.summary: The Battle of Villabuona is fought in Italy, resulting in significant casualties.

1631.title: Treaty of Bärwalde
1631.summary: Sweden and France sign a military alliance in which France provides funds for the Swedish army invading northern Germany.

1631.title: Founding of Reval Gymnasium
1631.summary: The Reval Gymnasium is founded in Tallinn, Estonia, by Swedish king Gustavus II Adolphus.

1631.title: Death of Ambrosio I Nimi a Nkanga
1631.summary: Ambrosio I Nimi a Nkanga, the ruler of the Kingdom of Kongo, dies after a reign of five years.

1631.title: Sultan of Morocco
1631.summary: Al Walid ben Zidan becomes the new Sultan of Morocco upon the death of Abu Marwan Abd al-Malik II.

1631.title: Siege of Magdeburg
1631.summary: The siege of the Protestant German city of Magdeburg by the Catholic League begins and lasts for more than two months before the city falls and the inhabitants are massacred.

1631.title: Battle of Frankfurt an der Oder
1631.summary: Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden defeats an imperial garrison at the city of Frankfurt an der Oder during the Thirty Years' War.

1631.title: Massacre in Magdeburg
1631.summary: The army of the Holy Roman Empire sacks the Protestant German city of Magdeburg, massacring over 20,000 inhabitants.

1631.title: Construction of the Taj Mahal
1631.summary: The death in childbirth of Mumtaz Mahal causes her husband Shah Jahan to commission the Taj Mahal at Agra, as a mausoleum for her.

1631.title: Treaty of Cherasco
1631.summary: The Treaty of Cherasco is signed, ending the War of the Mantuan Succession.

1631.title: Battle of Breitenfeld
1631.summary: Tilly's Holy Roman Imperial army is decisively defeated by Gustavus II Adolphus of Sweden, marking the first significant victory for the Protestants in the Thirty Years' War.

1632.title: University of Amsterdam established
1632.summary: The University of Amsterdam is established at the site of the Athenaeum Illustre of Amsterdam.

1632.title: Dissection by Dr. Nicolaes Tulp
1632.summary: The dissection of a body for the benefit of medical students is carried out by Dr. Nicolaes Tulp, the anatomist for the city of Amsterdam, and will be immortalized in Rembrandt's painting The Anatomy Lesson.

1632.title: Publication of Galileo's Dialogue
1632.summary: Galileo's Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems is published in Florence.

1632.title: Battle of Bamberg
1632.summary: In the Thirty Years' War, Johann Tserclaes, Count of Tilly, defeats the Swedish army under Gustav Horn and recaptures the town of Bamberg.

1632.title: Triumphant entry into Nuremberg
1632.summary: King Gustavus Adolphus makes a triumphant entry into Nuremberg, pledging to protect the cause of Protestantism.

1632.title: Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye
1632.summary: The Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye is signed, returning Quebec to French control.

1632.title: Battle of Rain
1632.summary: Gustavus Adolphus defeats Tilly's Catholic League armies for the second time within a year during the Battle of Rain; Tilly is severely wounded and dies shortly after.

1632.title: Construction of the Taj Mahal begins
1632.summary: Construction of the Taj Mahal begins after the death of Shah Jahan's beloved wife Mumtaz Mahal.

1632.title: Capture of Munich
1632.summary: The Swedish army captures Munich, the capital of Bavaria, during the Thirty Years' War.

1632.title: Battle of the Alte Veste
1632.summary: In the Thirty Years' War, Swedish king Gustavus Adolphus is defeated while attempting to break the siege by Wallenstein at Nuremberg.

1633.title: Mission San Luis de Apalachee is built
1633.summary: Built in the New World by two Spanish friars, marking a significant event in colonial history.

1633.title: Galileo Galilei leaves for Rome
1633.summary: Galileo is summoned to Rome on orders of Pope Urban VIII, marking a critical moment in the history of science and church conflict.

1633.title: Coronation of Władysław IV Vasa
1633.summary: The formal coronation of Władysław IV Vasa as King of Poland takes place, reinforcing royal power in early 17th century Poland.

1633.title: Galileo arrives in Rome for his trial
1633.summary: Galileo arrives in Rome to face the Inquisition regarding his heliocentric views, a key event in scientific history.

1633.title: Fire engines used for the first time in England
1633.summary: Fire engines are employed for the first time in England to combat a fire at London Bridge, resulting in significant property damage.

1633.title: Samuel de Champlain reclaims command of New France
1633.summary: Samuel de Champlain returns to Quebec as commander of New France, influencing French colonial interests in North America.

1633.title: Galileo convicted of heresy
1633.summary: Galileo is convicted of heresy by the Roman Catholic Church, highlighting the tension between science and religion in the period.

1633.title: Charles I crowned King of Scots
1633.summary: Charles I is crowned King of Scots in a significant royal ceremony that reinforces his authority in Scotland.

1633.title: Battle of Oldendorf
1633.summary: Sweden defeats the Holy Roman Empire in the Battle of Oldendorf, impacting the Thirty Years' War's landscape.

1633.title: Dutch East India Company attacks Zheng Zhilong's base
1633.summary: The surprise attack on Zheng Zhilong's base marks escalating tensions and conflicts in Asian trade routes during this period.

1634.title: Dismissal of Wallenstein
1634.summary: Albrecht von Wallenstein, supreme commander of the Holy Roman Empire's Army, is dismissed by Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor, after high treason accusations.

1634.title: Assassination of Wallenstein
1634.summary: Rebel Scots and Irish soldiers assassinate Bohemian military leader Albrecht von Wallenstein at Cheb.

1634.title: Siege of Smolensk Ends
1634.summary: The Russians vacate their camp, ending the Siege of Smolensk.

1634.title: Battle of Amritsar
1634.summary: The Battle of Amritsar begins in India when Mughal Empire troops attempt to eliminate the Sikh leader, Guru Hargobind, leading to a significant defeat for the Mughals.

1634.title: Union Flag Proclamation
1634.summary: King Charles I first refers to the banner of the British Isles as the Union Flag, setting the course for the flag's designation.

1634.title: Signing of the Treaty of Polyanovka
1634.summary: The Treaty of Polyanovka is signed between the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth and Tsardom of Russia, concluding the Smolensk War.

1634.title: Foundation of Trois-Rivières
1634.summary: The city of Trois-Rivières is founded in New France, which is now part of modern Quebec, Canada.

1634.title: Burning of Urbain Grandier
1634.summary: Urbain Grandier, accused of wizardry, is burned alive in Loudun, France.

1634.title: Battle of Nördlingen
1634.summary: The Battle of Nördlingen ends with a decisive victory for the Army of the Holy Roman Empire over the Army of Sweden and Protestant German troops.

1634.title: Burchardi flood
1634.summary: The Burchardi flood strikes the North Sea coast of Germany and Denmark, causing at least 8,000 deaths.

1635.title: Dutch pacification campaign begins
1635.summary: The Dutch pacification campaign on Formosa begins against Taiwanese aborigines.

1635.title: Capture of Tortuga
1635.summary: The Spanish Navy captures the Caribbean island of Tortuga off Haiti after a three-day battle against the English and French Navy.

1635.title: Capital move to Ava
1635.summary: King Thalun moves the capital of Burma from Pegu to Ava.

1635.title: Academie francaise constituted
1635.summary: The Academie francaise in Paris is formally constituted as the national academy for the preservation of the French language.

1635.title: Peacock Throne inaugurated
1635.summary: The Peacock Throne of India's Mughal Empire is inaugurated in Delhi to support the anniversary of Shah Jahan's accession to the throne.

1635.title: Archbishop taken prisoner
1635.summary: Philipp Christoph von Sötern, the Archbishop-Elector of Trier, is taken prisoner by Spanish Habsburg troops, leading to a declaration of war against Spain by France.

1635.title: Execution of Fakhr-al-Din II
1635.summary: Druze warlord Fakhr-al-Din II is executed in Constantinople.

1635.title: Boston Latin School founded
1635.summary: The oldest school in the United States, Boston Latin School, is founded in Boston, Massachusetts.

1635.title: France declares war on Spain
1635.summary: France declares war on Spain, marking a significant conflict in Europe.

1635.title: Peace of Prague signed
1635.summary: The Peace of Prague is signed, ending the German civil war aspect of the Thirty Years' War.

1636.title: Anthony van Diemen takes office
1636.summary: Anthony van Diemen takes office as Governor-General of the Dutch East Indies, serving until his death in 1645.

1636.title: Assassination of Al Walid ben Zidan
1636.summary: Al Walid ben Zidan, Sultan of Morocco, is assassinated by French renegades.

1636.title: Installation of King Alvaro VI
1636.summary: Nimi a Lukeni a Nzenze a Ntumba is installed as King Alvaro VI of Kongo, ruling until his death in 1641.

1636.title: Oxford University Press established
1636.summary: A great charter to the University of Oxford establishes the Oxford University Press, as the second privileged press in England.

1636.title: Founding of Utrecht University
1636.summary: Utrecht University is founded in the Dutch Republic, marking an important advancement in education.

1636.title: Siege of Schenkenschans ends
1636.summary: The nine-month Siege of Schenkenschans ends, with the Dutch Republic recapturing the fort from the Spanish.

1636.title: Establishment of Agawam Plantation
1636.summary: William Pynchon and his men establish the settlement of Agawam Plantation in territory controlled by the Agawam people.

1636.title: Founding of Providence Plantations
1636.summary: Roger Williams and other Puritan settlers establish the colony of Providence Plantations, leading to the formation of Rhode Island.

1636.title: Establishment of New College (Harvard University)
1636.summary: A vote establishes New College, known today as Harvard University, as the first college founded in the United States.

1636.title: French intervention in Thirty Years' War
1636.summary: French intervention starts in the Thirty Years' War, a significant military and political event in Europe.

1637.title: Le Cid
1637.summary: Pierre Corneille's tragicomedy is first performed.

1637.title: Siege of Nagpur
1637.summary: The siege ends with the surrender of Kok Shah to the Mughal Empire.

1637.title: John Maurice of Nassau
1637.summary: John Maurice arrives to become Governor of Dutch Brazil.

1637.title: Manchu Invasion of Korea
1637.summary: The Manchu armies complete their invasion of northern Korea.

1637.title: Collapse of Tulip Mania
1637.summary: The Tulip mania collapses in the Dutch Republic.

1637.title: Ferdinand III becomes Emperor
1637.summary: Ferdinand III becomes Holy Roman Emperor upon the death of his father.

1637.title: Battle off Lizard Point
1637.summary: A Spanish fleet intercepts an Anglo-Dutch convoy.

1637.title: Opening of Teatro San Cassiano
1637.summary: The world's first opera house opens with the premiere of L'Andromeda.

1637.title: Mystic Massacre
1637.summary: A band of English settlers sets fire to a fortified village, causing many deaths.

1637.title: Shimabara Rebellion
1637.summary: The Shimabara Rebellion erupts when 30,000 peasants revolt in Japan.

1638.title: Naval battle off Goa
1638.summary: A naval battle takes place in the Indian Ocean off the coast of Goa in South India as a Netherlands fleet commanded by Admiral Adam Westerwolt decimates the Portuguese fleet.

1638.title: Spanish invasion of Jolo island
1638.summary: A fleet of 80 Spanish ships led by Governor-General Sebastián Hurtado de Corcuera attacks the Sultanate of Sulu in the Philippines by beginning an invasion of Jolo island, but Sultan Muwallil Wasit I puts up a stiff resistance.

1638.title: Siege of Shimabara Castle
1638.summary: The siege of Shimabara Castle ends after 27 days in Japan's Tokugawa shogunate as the rebel peasants flee reinforcements sent by the shogun Tokugawa Iemitsu.

1638.title: Defense of Hara Castle
1638.summary: The Shimabara and Amakusa rebels, having joined up after fleeing the shogun's troops, begin the defense of Hara Castle in modern-day Minamishimabara in the Nagasaki prefecture. The siege lasts more than 11 weeks before the peasants are massacred.

1638.title: Scottish National Covenant
1638.summary: The Scottish National Covenant is signed in Edinburgh, Scotland, in opposition to changes to the Church of Scotland proposed by King Charles I.

1638.title: Battle of Rheinfelden
1638.summary: A mercenary army under Bernard of Saxe-Weimar, fighting for France, defeats forces of the Holy Roman Empire.

1638.title: Treaty of Hamburg
1638.summary: The Treaty of Hamburg is signed by France and Sweden, providing the latter with funds.

1638.title: Capture of Kandahar
1638.summary: Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan and his sons capture the city of Kandahar from the Safavids.

1638.title: Appointment of Willem Kieft
1638.summary: Dutch merchant Willem Kieft is appointed Director of New Netherland by the Dutch East India Company to succeed Wouter van Twiller.

1638.title: Establishment of New Sweden
1638.summary: Settlers from Sweden arrive on the ships Kalmar Nyckel and Fogel Grip to establish the settlement of New Sweden in Delaware, beginning the Swedish colonization of the Americas.

1639.title: Privileges Granted to Hämeenlinna
1639.summary: Hämeenlinna is granted privileges as its own city in Tavastia after separating from the Vanaja parish.

1639.title: First Printing Press in British North America
1639.summary: The first printing press in British North America is started in Cambridge, Massachusetts, by Stephen Daye.

1639.title: Battle in the English Channel
1639.summary: A sea battle is fought in the English Channel where the Spanish flee after losing three ships and 1,600 men, while the Dutch have 1,700 casualties without loss.

1639.title: Incorporation of Taunton
1639.summary: The early settlement of Taunton, Massachusetts, is incorporated as a town.

1639.title: Battle of Chemnitz
1639.summary: Swedish forces inflict a crushing defeat on the Holy Roman Empire's army, prolonging the Thirty Years' War.

1639.title: Papal Bull Prohibiting Slavery
1639.summary: Pope Urban VIII issues a papal bull prohibiting slavery in the New World colonies of Spain and Portugal.

1639.title: Capture of Trincomalee Fort
1639.summary: After a 40-day siege, the Dutch East India Company captures the Trincomalee Fort from the Portuguese Empire.

1639.title: Beginning of the Bishops' Wars
1639.summary: King Charles I of England arrives with his army at Berwick-upon-Tweed, marking the beginning of the Bishops' Wars.

1639.title: Treaty of Berwick Signed
1639.summary: The Treaty of Berwick is signed between Charles I and the Scots.

1639.title: Naval Battle of the Downs
1639.summary: A Republic of the United Provinces fleet decisively defeats a Spanish fleet in English waters.

1640.title: Siege of Salses
1640.summary: The Siege of Salses ends almost six months after it had started with the French defenders surrendering to the Spanish attackers.

1640.title: Naval Battle over Recife
1640.summary: A naval battle between ships of the Dutch Republic and the Kingdom of Portugal ends with the Dutch driving the Portuguese away from the port of Recife.

1640.title: Succession of Ibrahim I
1640.summary: Ibrahim I succeeds Murad IV as Sultan of the Ottoman Empire.

1640.title: Siege of Galle
1640.summary: Dutch troops take the strategic fortress at Galle, Sri Lanka from the Portuguese.

1640.title: The Short Parliament assembles
1640.summary: The Short Parliament assembles as King Charles I of England attempts to fund the second of the Bishops' Wars.

1640.title: Catalan Revolt
1640.summary: The Catalan Revolt breaks out in Catalonia.

1640.title: Mount Komagatake Eruption
1640.summary: The eruption of the Mount Komagatake volcano occurs, causing heavy ashfall that poisons local crops and leads to a great famine.

1640.title: Inauguration of the Royal Academy of Turku
1640.summary: The first university of Finland, the Royal Academy of Turku, is inaugurated in Turku.

1640.title: Siege of Turin
1640.summary: The Siege of Turin ends after almost four months with a victory by French and Piedmontese forces, recapturing the city from Spain.

1640.title: End of the Iberian Union
1640.summary: The end of the Iberian Union begins as a revolution causes John IV of Portugal to be acclaimed as king, ending 60 years of union with Spain.

1641.title: Eruption of Mount Parker
1641.summary: The stratovolcano Mount Parker in the Philippines has a major eruption.

1641.title: Battle of Malacca
1641.summary: The Battle of Malacca concludes with the Dutch East India Company ending Portuguese control of Malacca.

1641.title: Proclamation of the Catalan Republic
1641.summary: The Junta de Braços of the Principality of Catalonia, led by Pau Claris, proclaims the Catalan Republic under French protection.

1641.title: Triennial Act Assent
1641.summary: King Charles I of England gives his assent to the Triennial Act, reluctantly committing himself to parliamentary sessions of at least fifty days, every three years.

1641.title: Decree Against Catholic Priests
1641.summary: King Charles I of England decrees that all Roman Catholic priests must leave England by April 7 or face being arrested and treated as traitors.

1641.title: Trial of Thomas Wentworth
