1641.summary: The trial for high treason begins for Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl of Strafford, director of England's Council of the North.

1641.title: Battle of Songjin
1641.summary: The Battle of Songjin begins in the modern-day North Korean city of Kimch'aek, with the Ming defeating the Qing rebels.

1641.title: Execution of the Earl of Strafford
1641.summary: Thomas Wentworth, 1st Earl of Strafford, is publicly beheaded in London in front of a crowd of thousands of people.

1641.title: Signature of the Treaty of Alliance
1641.summary: In Paris, representatives of Portugal and France sign a treaty of alliance.

1641.title: Irish Rebellion of 1641
1641.summary: Irish Catholic gentry revolt against the English administration and Scottish settlers in Ireland.

1642.title: Abel Tasman sights New Zealand
1642.summary: Abel Tasman and his crew become the first recorded Europeans to sight New Zealand, arriving at its South Island. In a battle between the Europeans and the Island's Maori inhabitants, four crew members are killed.

1642.title: King Charles I attempts to arrest Parliament members
1642.summary: Accompanied by soldiers, England's King Charles I arrives at a session of the Long Parliament and attempts to arrest his chief opponents, the five leading members of parliament, but they escape and are protected by the Lord Mayor of London.

1642.title: The Bishops Exclusion Act
1642.summary: The Bishops Exclusion Act is passed in England to prevent any member of the clergy from holding political office.

1642.title: Treaty of Axim signed
1642.summary: The Treaty of Axim is signed between the Dutch West India Company and the chiefs of the Nzema people in what is now the African nation of Ghana.

1642.title: Performance of Il palazzo incantato
1642.summary: The Italian opera Il palazzo incantato, by Luigi Rossi with libretto by Giulion Rospigliosi, is given its first performance.

1642.title: Siege of Limerick
1642.summary: In Ireland, the five week Siege of Limerick, under control by English Protestants, is started by the Irish Confederation.

1642.title: First English Civil War - Battle of Edgehill
1642.summary: Royalists and Parliamentarians battle to a draw in the First English Civil War at the Battle of Edgehill.

1642.title: Abel Tasman discovers Van Diemen's Land
1642.summary: Abel Tasman and his crew become the first Europeans to discover Van Diemen's Land, now Tasmania, and the island is claimed for the Netherlands.

1642.title: Battle of Turnham Green
1642.summary: In the First English Civil War, the Royalist forces withdraw in face of the Parliamentarian army, failing to take London at the Battle of Turnham Green.

1642.title: Yellow River flood
1642.summary: In the intentional breaking of the dams and dykes of the Yellow River, some 300,000 people die, done by the Ming dynasty defenders of Kaifeng to break the siege by the Manchu dynasty rebel force of Li Zicheng.

1643.title: Sighting of Tonga
1643.summary: Abel Tasman sights the island of Tonga.

1643.title: Opening of the Taj Mahal
1643.summary: Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan observes the 12th anniversary of the death of his wife and opens the Taj Mahal to thousands of mourners.

1643.title: First Battle of Middlewich
1643.summary: Roundheads rout the Cavaliers at Middlewich in Cheshire during the First English Civil War.

1643.title: Battle of New Ross
1643.summary: English troops defeat those of Confederate Ireland in the Irish Confederate Wars.

1643.title: City Charter of Åmål
1643.summary: Åmål, Sweden, is granted its city charter.

1643.title: Louis XIV becomes King of France
1643.summary: Louis XIV succeeds his father Louis XIII as King of France at age 4.

1643.title: Battle of Rocroi
1643.summary: The French defeat the Spanish at the Battle of Rocroi during the Thirty Years' War.

1643.title: Battle of Adwalton Moor
1643.summary: Royalists gain control of Yorkshire in the First English Civil War.

1643.title: Crowning of the Shunzhi Emperor
1643.summary: The Shunzhi Emperor of China is crowned at five years old,17 days after the death of his father.

1643.title: Abdication of Empress Meishō
1643.summary: Empress Meishō abdicates and Emperor Go-Kōmyō accedes to the throne of Japan.

1644.title: The Royalist Oxford Parliament assembled
1644.summary: First assembly by King Charles I of England during the English Civil War.

1644.title: Battle of Nantwich
1644.summary: Parliamentarians defeat the Royalists, ending the siege of Nantwich.

1644.title: Dutch East Indies Expedition
1644.summary: Abel Tasman departs to map the north coast of Australia for the Dutch East India Company.

1644.title: Battle of Ochmatów
1644.summary: Polish–Lithuanian forces secure a victory over the Crimean Tatars.

1644.title: First livestock branding law in America
1644.summary: Connecticut passes a law on livestock branding, marking a legislative step in colonial America.

1644.title: Upsurge against the English at Jamestown
1644.summary: Opchanacanough leads a failed uprising against English colonists, marking the last rebellion in the region.

1644.title: Beijing sacked by Li Zicheng
1644.summary: A popular rebellion leads to the sacking of Beijing and the last Ming emperor's suicide.

1644.title: Alliance with Manchu invaders
1644.summary: Ming general Wu Sangui opens China's Great Wall for the Manchu invasion.

1644.title: Battle of Montijo
1644.summary: Portugal achieves a significant victory over Habsburg Spain in the Portuguese Restoration War.

1644.title: Beijing captured by Qing army
1644.summary: The Qing army captures Beijing, beginning their rule over China proper.

1645.title: Battle of Naseby
1645.summary: The Parliamentarian Roundheads defeat the Royalist Cavaliers in a decisive battle during the English Civil War.

1645.title: Execution of Archbishop William Laud
1645.summary: Archbishop of Canterbury William Laud is executed for treason on Tower Hill, London.

1645.title: Formation of the New Model Army
1645.summary: The New Model Army is officially founded to fight in the English Civil War.

1645.title: Battle of Jankau
1645.summary: The armies of Sweden decisively defeat the forces of the Holy Roman Empire in one of the bloodiest battles of the Thirty Years' War.

1645.title: Self-denying Ordinance
1645.summary: The House of Lords passes the Self-denying Ordinance, requiring members of the Parliament of England to resign commissions in the armed services.

1645.title: Battle of Herbsthausen
1645.summary: The Bavarian army defeats French forces in a surprise attack during the Thirty Years' War.

1645.title: Siege of Hereford
1645.summary: Scottish Covenanters under Lord Leven begin the siege of Hereford, a Royalist stronghold in England.

1645.title: Battle of Alford
1645.summary: A battle during the English Civil War where the Parliamentarians win against the Royalists in Alford, Aberdeenshire.

1645.title: Founding of the Hôpital-de-Montréal
1645.summary: Jeanne Mance founds the first hospital in North America, the Hôpital-de-Montréal.

1645.title: Seizure of Hereford
1645.summary: The Royalist stronghold of Hereford is taken in a swift attack by Parliamentary forces under John Birch.

1646.title: English House of Commons approves bill for Ireland
1646.summary: The English House of Commons approves a bill to provide for Ireland to be governed by a single Englishman.

1646.title: Battle of Bovey Heath
1646.summary: Oliver Cromwell's New Model Army surprises and routs the Royalist camp of Lord Wentworth.

1646.title: Sir Richard Grenville imprisoned
1646.summary: Sir Richard Grenville, a Royalist, is imprisoned for insubordination after proposing to make Cornwall self-governing.

1646.title: Francesco Molin elected as Doge of Venice
1646.summary: Francesco Molin is elected as the 99th Doge of Venice after 23 ballots, governing for nine years.

1646.title: First English Civil War – Battle of Torrington
1646.summary: A decisive Parliamentary victory is gained over the Royalists in the First English Civil War.

1646.title: Charles II escapes to exile
1646.summary: The future Charles II of England escapes from Cornwall into exile across the English Channel.

1646.title: Joseph Jenkes obtains first colonial machine patent
1646.summary: Joseph Jenkes obtains the first colonial machine patent in Massachusetts, marking a technological advance.

1646.title: Union of Uzhorod
1646.summary: The Union of Uzhorod brings the Ruthenian Greek Orthodox Church into the fold of the Catholic Church.

1646.title: King Charles I surrenders to Scottish army
1646.summary: King Charles I of England surrenders his forces to a Scottish army at Southwell, Nottinghamshire.

1646.title: Third Siege of Oxford concludes
1646.summary: The signing of the surrender of the Royalist garrison at Oxford concludes the Third Siege of Oxford.

1647.title: Death of Zhang Xianzhong
1647.summary: Chinese bandit leader Zhang Xianzhong is killed by a Qing archer after being betrayed by one of his officers.

1647.title: Founding of Posten Norge
1647.summary: Posten Norge is founded as Postvesenet, establishing a new postal service in Norway.

1647.title: Capture of Guangzhou
1647.summary: A Qing force captures Guangzhou and kills the Shaowu Emperor of the Southern Ming dynasty.

1647.title: Proclamation of the Yongli Era
1647.summary: Zhu Youlang is declared the Yongli Emperor of the Southern Ming dynasty, marking a new era.

1647.title: Surrender of Lundy Island
1647.summary: Thomas Bushell surrenders the last remaining Royalist territory of Lundy Island to the Parliamentarians.

1647.title: Truce of Ulm
1647.summary: Bavaria, Cologne, France and Sweden sign a truce to end conflicts in the Thirty Years' War.

1647.title: Battle of Puerto de Cavite
1647.summary: An armada from the Dutch Republic engages in a two-day battle against the Spanish defending fleet.

1647.title: Masaniello's Rebellion
1647.summary: Masaniello launches a rebellion in Naples against Spanish rule, highlighting the growing unrest.

1647.title: The Putney Debates
1647.summary: Officers of the New Model Army discuss the future government form after the military defeat of King Charles.

1647.title: Destruction of Aberystwyth Castle
1647.summary: Aberystwyth Castle is razed by Parliamentarian troops, signifying a shift in control.

1648.title: Capture of Francisco Fernández de Capillas
1648.summary: Manchu invaders of China's Fujian province capture Spanish Dominican priest Francisco Fernández de Capillas, torture him and then behead him. Capillas will be canonized more than 350 years later in 2000 in the Roman Catholic Church as one of the Martyr Saints of China.

1648.title: Marriage of Alexis Tsar of Russia
1648.summary: Alexis, Tsar of Russia, marries Maria Miloslavskaya, who later gives birth to two future tsars (Feodor III and Ivan V) as well as Princess Sophia Alekseyevna, the regent for Peter I.

1648.title: Vote of No Addresses
1648.summary: By a vote of 141 to 91, England's Long Parliament passes the Vote of No Addresses, breaking off negotiations with King Charles I, and thereby setting the scene for the second phase of the English Civil War.

1648.title: Creation of the Académie royale
1648.summary: France's Royal Council votes to create the Académie royale after accepting the proposal of Martin de Charmois.

1648.title: Khmelnytsky Uprising begins
1648.summary: The Khmelnytsky Uprising in Ukraine, at the time part of the Republic of Both Nations (Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth), begins as Bohdan Khmelnytsky becomes Hetman of the Cossacks.

1648.title: Peace of Münster
1648.summary: The Dutch and the Spanish sign the Peace of Münster, ending the Eighty Years' War. The Spanish Empire recognizes the Dutch Republic of United Netherlands as a sovereign state.

1648.title: Stricter laws against stage plays
1648.summary: England's parliament passes stricter laws against performance of stage plays, providing for demolition of seats in theatres, imprisonment for actors and fines for spectators.

1648.title: Death of King Christian IV
1648.summary: King Christian IV of Denmark and Norway dies after a reign of almost 60 years without having named a successor. The Rigsraadet and the Estates of the Realm will debate the matter for more than four months before deciding on July 6 to select Christian's oldest surviving son to become King Frederick III.

1648.title: Battle of Prague
1648.summary: The last major battle of the Thirty Years' War, the Battle of Prague ends in a Swedish victory after three days of fighting over the army of Bohemia. The troops loot the Prague Castle and steal many of Bohemia's most valuable artifacts.

1648.title: Signing of the Treaties of Münster and Osnabrück
1648.summary: Signing of the Treaties of Münster and Osnabrück concludes the Peace of Westphalia, ending the Thirty Years' War. Rulers of the Imperial States can personally convert to Protestant, Catholic or Calvinist.

1649.title: Trial of Charles I
1649.summary: In England, the Rump Parliament passes an ordinance to set up a High Court of Justice, to try Charles I for high treason.

1649.title: Execution of Charles I
1649.summary: King Charles I of England, Scotland and Ireland is found guilty of high treason and is beheaded outside the Banquet Hall in the Palace of Whitehall, London.

1649.title: Declaration of Charles II as King
1649.summary: In Edinburgh, the Scottish Parliament declares Prince Charles, son of the recently executed King Charles I, as King Charles II of Scotland.

1649.title: Start of the Mughal–Safavid War
1649.summary: The Mughal–Safavid War begins as Shah Abbas II of the Safavid Empire captures the Afghan city of Kandahar from the Mughal Empire.

1649.title: Act Abolishing the Kingship
1649.summary: The English Parliament passes the Act Abolishing the Kingship to create a republic under a Lord Protector selected by an elected Parliament.

1649.title: Establishment of the Commonwealth
1649.summary: The Rump Parliament passes an act declaring England to be a Commonwealth after the abolition of the monarchy.

1649.title: Siege of Drogheda
1649.summary: Oliver Cromwell leads England's New Model Army to start the Siege of Drogheda in Ireland, executing the defenders after capturing the city.

1649.title: Sack of Wexford
1649.summary: The Sack of Wexford ends after Cromwell's New Model Army breaks through, killing over 1,500 Irish Catholic defenders and civilians.

1649.title: Battle of Lisnagarvey
1649.summary: Cromwell's forces defeat the Scottish defenders of Ireland in the Battle of Lisnagarvey, ending the Scottish presence in Ireland.

1649.title: Puritan raid on the Red Bull Theatre
1649.summary: The Puritan law enforcers of the Commonwealth of England raid the Red Bull Theatre in London for violations of performance laws.

1650.title: Death of Louis I, Prince of Anhalt-Köthen
1650.summary: Louis I, Prince of Anhalt-Köthen, dies after a reign of more than 63 years.

1650.title: Plot against Cardinal Mazarin
1650.summary: Cardinal Jules Mazarin learns of a plot against him and has several princes arrested, prompting a rebellion.

1650.title: Expulsion of Portuguese from Muscat
1650.summary: The Sultan bin Saif of Oman expels the Portuguese colonial government from Muscat, ending 35 years of occupation.

1650.title: Premiere of Andromède
1650.summary: The French verse play Andromède premieres before the royal family, showcasing elaborate design.

1650.title: Irish bombardment by Cromwell's troops
1650.summary: Oliver Cromwell's troops sweep through Ireland and bombard Kiltinan Castle.

1650.title: Siege of Clonmel
1650.summary: A quarter of the New Model Army is trapped and killed at the Siege of Clonmel in Ireland.

1650.title: Establishment of Harvard Corporation
1650.summary: The Harvard Corporation, the first legal corporation in the Americas, is established.

1650.title: Arrival of Charles II in Scotland
1650.summary: Claimant King Charles II arrives in Scotland, the only kingdom that accepts him as ruler.

1650.title: Lunar map by Gerolamo Sersale
1650.summary: Gerolamo Sersale draws a detailed lunar map using a full moon, which is then reproduced for other astronomers.

1650.title: Battle of Dunbar
1650.summary: Parliamentarian forces under Oliver Cromwell defeat a Scottish army at the Battle of Dunbar.

1651.title: Charles II crowned King of Scots
1651.summary: Charles II is crowned King of Scots at Scone (his first crowning).

1651.title: Parliament of Boroa
1651.summary: Spanish and Mapuche authorities meet at Boroa, renewing the fragile peace established at the parliaments of Quillín, in 1641 and 1647.

1651.title: St. Peter's Flood
1651.summary: A first storm tide in the North Sea strikes the coast of Germany, drowning thousands. The island of Juist is split in half, and the western half of Buise is probably washed away.

1651.title: Another St. Peter's Flood
1651.summary: Another storm tide in the North Sea strikes the Netherlands, flooding Amsterdam.

1651.title: Founding of Kajaani
1651.summary: The town of Kajaani is founded by Count Per Brahe the Younger.

1651.title: Shunzhi Emperor's Purge
1651.summary: Shunzhi, Emperor of China, announces in an imperial edict that he will purge corruption from government.

1651.title: Leviathan Published
1651.summary: Thomas Hobbes publishes his magnum opus, the political tract Leviathan, in England.

1651.title: Battle of Kopychyntsi
1651.summary: General Marcin Kalinowski of Poland wins against Zaporozhian Cossacks forces under the command of Asand Demka during the Khmelnytsky Uprising.

1651.title: Battle of Inverkeithing
1651.summary: The English Parliamentarian New Model Army, under Major-General John Lambert, defeats a Scottish Covenanter army acting on behalf of Charles II.

1651.title: Battle of Worcester
1651.summary: Charles II of England, leading a largely-Scottish army, is defeated in the Battle of Worcester, the last major battle of the English Civil War, and forced to flee.

1652.title: Marriage of Michiel de Ruyter
1652.summary: Michiel de Ruyter marries the widow Anna van Gelder and plans retirement, but months later becomes a vice-commodore in the First Anglo-Dutch War.

1652.title: Tender of Union Proclaimed
1652.summary: At Edinburgh, the parliamentary commissioners of the Commonwealth of England proclaim the Tender of Union to be in force in Scotland, annexing the Scottish nation with the concession that Scotland would have 30 representatives in the parliament of the English Commonwealth.

1652.title: Oliver Cromwell's Announcement
1652.summary: Oliver Cromwell, England's Lord Protector, announces that his Council of Scotland will regulate church affairs as part of the Terms of Incorporation of Scotland into England, and eliminates Presbyterianism as Scotland's state religion.

1652.title: Total Solar Eclipse
1652.summary: Total solar eclipse of April 8, 1652, also known as Black Monday.

1652.title: Founding of Cape Town
1652.summary: Dutch sailor Jan van Riebeeck establishes a resupply camp for the Dutch East India Company at the Cape of Good Hope, thus founding Cape Town.

1652.title: Rhode Island Abolishes Slavery
1652.summary: Rhode Island passes the first law in North America making slavery illegal.

1652.title: Battle of Dover
1652.summary: The opening battle of the First Anglo-Dutch War is fought off Dover between Dutch and English ships; the result is inconclusive.

1652.title: Establishment of the Quakers
1652.summary: George Fox preaches to a large crowd on Firbank Fell in England, leading to the establishment of the Religious Society of Friends (Quakers).

1652.title: Battle of the Faubourg St Antoine
1652.summary: A battle is fought east of Paris between French Parliamentarians and the army of King Louis XIV, with neither side prevailing.

1652.title: The Massacre at the Hôtel de Ville
1652.summary: A mob kills 150 people, including judges, in the massacre at the Hôtel de Ville, Paris.

1653.title: Completion of the Taj Mahal
1653.summary: The gardens surrounding the Taj Mahal mausoleum are completed at Agra.

1653.title: Coonan Cross Oath
1653.summary: The Eastern Church in India cuts itself off from colonial Portuguese tutelage.

1653.title: Swiss Peasant War begins
1653.summary: The Swiss Peasant War begins after magistrates meeting at Lucerne refuse to hear from financially hurt peasants.

1653.title: Municipal Rights Granted to New Amsterdam
1653.summary: New Amsterdam (now New York City) received municipal rights by a charter from New Netherland Governor Peter Stuyvesant.

1653.title: Battle of Leghorn
1653.summary: A Dutch fleet defeats the English in the Battle of Leghorn in the Mediterranean.

1653.title: Cromwell Expels Rump Parliament
1653.summary: Oliver Cromwell expels the Rump Parliament in England.

1653.title: Great Fire of Marlborough
1653.summary: The Great Fire of Marlborough destroys 224 houses and much of the textile businesses in the town.

1653.title: First Anglo-Dutch War
1653.summary: The English navy defeats the Dutch fleet in the Battle of the Gabbard after a two-day fight.

1653.title: Battle of Bordeaux
1653.summary: The Battle of Bordeaux is fought between French and Spanish warships as part of the Franco-Spanish War.

1653.title: Dissolution of Barebone's Parliament
1653.summary: The dissolution of Barebone's Parliament is voted by its members after having passed laws for the Commonwealth of England.

1654.title: Battle of Río Bueno
1654.summary: Indigenous Huilliche warriors rout Spanish troops from Fort Nacimiento, who are attempting to cross the Bueno River.

1654.title: Recapture of Recife
1654.summary: Portugal recaptures the South American city of Recife from the Netherlands after a siege of more than two years during the Dutch-Portuguese War.

1654.title: Capture of Fort Rocher
1654.summary: Spanish troops led by Don Gabriel de Rojas y Figueroa succeed in the capture of Fort Rocher, a pirate-controlled base on the Caribbean island of Tortuga.

1654.title: Battle of Tullich
1654.summary: The Battle of Tullich takes place in Aberdeenshire in Scotland during Glencairn's rising, a revolt by Scottish royalists against the Commonwealth of England.

1654.title: Treaty of Pereyaslav
1654.summary: The Treaty of Pereyaslav is concluded in the city of Pereyaslav during a meeting between the Cossacks of the Zaporozhian Host and Tsar Alexey I of Russia.

1654.title: Treaty of Westminster
1654.summary: The Treaty of Westminster, ending the First Anglo-Dutch War, is signed.

1654.title: Cromwell's Act of Grace
1654.summary: Cromwell's Act of Grace, officially the Act of Pardon and Grace to the People of Scotland, is proclaimed at the Mercat Cross in Edinburgh.

1654.title: Demonstration of the vacuum pump
1654.summary: Otto von Guericke demonstrates the power of atmospheric pressure and the effectiveness of his vacuum pump, using the Magdeburg hemispheres.

1654.title: Crowning of Louis XIV
1654.summary: Louis XIV of France is crowned at Reims.

1654.title: The Delft Explosion
1654.summary: The Delft Explosion devastates the city in the Netherlands, killing more than 100, among whom is Carel Fabritius, the most promising student of Rembrandt.

1655.title: Discovery of Titan
1655.summary: Titan, the largest moon of Saturn, is discovered by Christiaan Huygens.

1655.title: Ascension of Emperor Go-Sai
1655.summary: Emperor Go-Sai ascends to the throne of Japan.

1655.title: Death of Pope Innocent X
1655.summary: Pope Innocent X, leader of the Roman Catholic Church and the Papal States, dies after more than 10 years of rule.

1655.title: Mapuche Uprising begins
1655.summary: The Mapuches launch coordinated attacks against the Spanish in Chile, beginning the Mapuche uprising of 1655.

1655.title: Recognition of John Casor
1655.summary: John Casor becomes the first legally recognized slave in what will become the United States, as a court in Virginia issues its decision.

1655.title: Battle of Porto Farina
1655.summary: English admiral Robert Blake's fleet defeats the Barbary pirates.

1655.title: Piedmontese Easter Massacre
1655.summary: Charles Emmanuel II, Duke of Savoy slaughters 1,500 men, women, and children, which is memorialized in John Milton's sonnet.

1655.title: Invasion of Jamaica
1655.summary: Forces of the English Protectorate led by William Penn and Robert Venables capture the island of Jamaica from Spain during the Anglo-Spanish War.

1655.title: Occupation of Warsaw
1655.summary: Swedish King Karl X Gustav occupies Warsaw, Poland.

1655.title: Massacre of Jews in Lublin
1655.summary: The Jews of Lublin are massacred.

1656.title: The First War of Villmergen
1656.summary: A civil war in the Confederation of Switzerland pitting its Protestant and Roman Catholic cantons against each other.

1656.title: The Treaty of Königsberg
1656.summary: Establishes an alliance between Charles X Gustav of Sweden and Frederick William, Elector of Brandenburg.

1656.title: Arrival of the first Jewish doctor in America
1656.summary: Jacob Lumbrozo arrives in Maryland as the first Jewish doctor in the Thirteen Colonies.

1656.title: Battle of San Fabián de Conuco
1656.summary: Spanish Chilean troops defeat the indigenous Mapuche warriors, turning the tide in the Spanish colonists' favor.

1656.title: Battle of Golab
1656.summary: Swedish Empire troops defeat the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth in the first major engagement of the Swedish Deluge.

1656.title: Christopher Packe's suggestion to Cromwell
1656.summary: The Lord Mayor of London suggests to Oliver Cromwell that he restore the monarchy with himself as king, which Cromwell declines.

1656.title: The Çınar incident
1656.summary: A rebellion of Turkish soldiers occurs after the Ottoman Sultan declines their request regarding payments.

1656.title: Fyodor Baykov's admission to the Forbidden City
1656.summary: The Russian Empire's first envoy to China is admitted to negotiate a trade agreement.

1656.title: End of the First War of Villmergen
1656.summary: The civil war in the Confederation of Switzerland ends with a peace agreement mediated by France and the Duchy of Savoy.

1656.title: Restoration of the monarchy in Poland
1656.summary: John II Casimir Vasa crowns the Black Madonna of Czestochowa as Queen and Protector of Poland.

1657.title: Assassination Attempt on Oliver Cromwell
1657.summary: Miles Sindercombe and his group attempt to assassinate Oliver Cromwell by blowing up the Palace of Whitehall, resulting in their arrest.

1657.title: Abolition of Regional Military Government
1657.summary: The Rule of the Major-Generals in England is abolished, marking a significant political change.

1657.title: Resettlement of the Jews in England
1657.summary: Oliver Cromwell assures Antonio Fernandez Carvajal of the right for Jews to remain in England, a major religious and cultural event.

1657.title: Humble Petition and Advice
1657.summary: The Humble Petition and Advice offers Lord Protector Cromwell the crown, indicating a shift in power dynamics.

1657.title: Great Fire of Meireki
1657.summary: The Great Fire in Edo, Japan, destroys most of the city and damages Edo Castle, causing immense loss of life and property.

1657.title: Anglo-Spanish War Treaty
1657.summary: By the Treaty of Paris, France and England form an alliance against Spain during the ongoing Anglo-Spanish War.

1657.title: King Frederick III Declares War
1657.summary: King Frederick III of Denmark signs a manifesto, de facto declaring war on Sweden, impacting regional power relations.

1657.title: Quaker Settlers in New Amsterdam
1657.summary: The first eleven Quaker settlers arrive in New Amsterdam, allowed to practice their faith, influencing religious diversity.

1657.title: Treaty of Wehlau
1657.summary: Brandenburg and Poland sign the Treaty of Wehlau, affecting territorial and political relationships.

1657.title: Flushing Remonstrance
1657.summary: The Flushing Remonstrance is signed in New Amsterdam, marking a significant moment for religious freedom and governance.

1658.title: Death of Edward Sexby
1658.summary: Edward Sexby, who had plotted against Oliver Cromwell, dies in the Tower of London.

1658.title: March Across the Belts
1658.summary: Sweden's King Karl X Gustav leads troops across the ice belts to capture six of Denmark's islands as Swedish territory.

1658.title: Proclamation of Prince Muhi al-Din Muhammad
1658.summary: Prince Muhi al-Din Muhammad, one of the sons of India's Mughal, proclaims himself Emperor after Jahan names Muhi's older brother as regent.

1658.title: Treaty of Roskilde
1658.summary: The peace between Sweden and Denmark-Norway is concluded, leading to Sweden reaching its territorial height during its time as a great power.

1658.title: Battle of Dharmat
1658.summary: In India, Prince Muhi al-Din Muhammad leads 30,000 men to victory over 22,000 troops, claiming the throne after heavy casualties.

1658.title: Battle of Samugarh
1658.summary: Aurangzeb wins the Battle of Samugarh as regent Dara Shikoh makes a last effort to defend Agra.

1658.title: Battle of the Dunes
1658.summary: A Spanish force attempting to lift a siege of Dunkirk is defeated by the French and English, leading to England being given Dunkirk.

1658.title: Siege of Toruń begins
1658.summary: The Siege of Toruń begins in Poland as Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth troops seek to recapture the city from Swedish garrison.

1658.title: Death of Oliver Cromwell
1658.summary: Oliver Cromwell dies and his son Richard assumes his father's position as Lord Protector of England, Scotland and Ireland.

1658.title: Battle of the Sound
1658.summary: The naval battle between the Dutch Republic and Sweden at the strait, resulting in retreat of Swedish forces from Denmark.

1659.title: Battle of the Lines of Elvas
1659.summary: In the Battle of the Lines of Elvas, the Spanish Army suffers heavy casualties against a smaller Portuguese force during the Portuguese Restoration War.

1659.title: Premiere of Oedipe
1659.summary: Pierre Corneille's play Oedipe premieres in Paris, showcasing important developments in French theatre.

1659.title: Dissolution of the Third Protectorate Parliament
1659.summary: Under pressure from the English Army, Richard Cromwell dissolves the Third Protectorate Parliament, marking a significant political shift in England.

1659.title: Concert of The Hague
1659.summary: The Kingdom of France, the Commonwealth of England, and the Dutch Republic sign the Concert of The Hague, agreeing on a common stance for the Second Northern War.

1659.title: Battles of Booth's Uprising
1659.summary: Booth's Uprising begins in Chester as royalists attempt a revolt against the military government of England, reflecting social unrest during this period.

1659.title: Battle of Winnington Bridge
1659.summary: The Protectorate Army defeats the anti-government rebels at Winnington Bridge, showcasing the military tensions in England during the time.

1659.title: Treaty of the Pyrenees
1659.summary: The Treaty of the Pyrenees is signed, ending the Franco-Spanish War and reshaping the political landscape in Europe.

1659.title: Battle of Konotop
1659.summary: In the Battle of Konotop, Polish Cossack hetman Ivan Vyhovsky defeats Russian forces, marking a significant event during the Russo-Polish War.

1659.title: Dara Shikoh's Betrayal
1659.summary: Dara Shikoh, the heir apparent of the Mughal Empire, is betrayed and captured, leading to significant changes in the Indian subcontinent.

1659.title: Execution of Aqua Tofana Poisoners
1659.summary: Five women convicted of murder for distributing Aqua Tofana poison are executed in Rome, reflecting the severe consequences of the infamous poison's use.

1660.title: Colonel Monck crosses the River Tweed
1660.summary: At daybreak, Colonel George Monck fords the River Tweed at Coldstream to advance toward London, aiming to end military rule and restore the English monarchy.

1660.title: Samuel Pepys begins his diary
1660.summary: Samuel Pepys, a member of the Parliament of England, begins his diary which offers detailed insights into daily life in 17th century England.

1660.title: Colonel Monck marches to London
1660.summary: With 4,000 infantry and 1,800 cavalry, Colonel Monck marches southward toward Nottingham and ultimately London, aiming for the Restoration.

1660.title: Charles XI becomes king of Sweden
1660.summary: Charles XI becomes king of Sweden at the tender age of five following the death of his father, Charles X Gustavus.

1660.title: General Monck enters London
1660.summary: General George Monck enters London on horseback, leading his troops and accompanied by parliament commissioners amidst subdued crowds.

1660.title: King Charles II declared King of England
1660.summary: In exile in the Netherlands, Prince Charles Stuart learns of his declaration as King Charles II of England by the Parliament.

1660.title: King Charles II lands at Dover
1660.summary: King Charles II returns to England, landing at Dover, marking a significant moment in the English Restoration.

1660.title: First English actress on stage
1660.summary: The first English actress appears on stage in a non-singing role as Desdemona in Othello at Vere Street Theatre in London.

1660.title: Batte of Pavan Khind
1660.summary: The Battle of Pavan Khind occurs where a 600-member contingent of the Maratha Empire fights against the Adilshah Sultanate in India.

1660.title: Great Fire of 1660 in Constantinople
1660.summary: The Great Fire of 1660 devastates Constantinople, destroying two-thirds of the city and causing widespread casualties.

1661.title: The Fifth Monarchists' Failed Uprising
1661.summary: The Fifth Monarchists, led by Thomas Venner, unsuccessfully attempt to seize control of London; George Monck's regiment defeats them.

1661.title: Exhumation of Oliver Cromwell
1661.summary: The body of Oliver Cromwell is exhumed and subjected to a posthumous execution in London, along with those of John Bradshaw and Henry Ireton.

1661.title: Death of the Shunzhi Emperor
1661.summary: The Shunzhi Emperor of the Chinese Qing Dynasty dies, and is succeeded by his 7-year-old son the Kangxi Emperor.

1661.title: Koxinga's Invasion of Taiwan
1661.summary: General Zheng Chenggong of China, known as Koxinga, leads an invasion of the island of Taiwan, at the time under the control of the Dutch East India Company.

1661.title: Crowning of King Charles II
1661.summary: King Charles II of England, Scotland, and Ireland is crowned in Westminster Abbey.

1661.title: Opening of the Cavalier Parliament
1661.summary: The "Cavalier Parliament", the longest serving Parliament in British history, is opened following the first parliamentary elections since the restoration of the monarchy.

1661.title: Koxinga Takes Control of Taiwan
1661.summary: General Zheng Chenggong of China takes control of most of the island of Taiwan from the Dutch East India Company and proclaims the Kingdom of Tungning, with himself as the ruler.

1661.title: First Modern Bank Notes
1661.summary: The first modern bank notes are issued in Stockholm, Sweden.

1661.title: Treaty of The Hague Sign
1661.summary: Portugal and the Dutch Republic sign the Treaty of The Hague, whereby the Dutch Republic's South American colony of Nieuw-Holland is sold to Portugal for 63,000 kilograms of gold.

1661.title: Execution of General Wu Sangui
1661.summary: General Wu Sangui of China arrives in Burma with 20,000 troops and demands that the Burmese surrender Yongli, the last of the Ming dynasty rulers.

1662.title: Dziaddin Mukarram Shah becomes Sultan of Kedah
1662.summary: Dziaddin Mukarram Shah becomes the new Sultan of Kedah, an independent kingdom on the Malay Peninsula, upon the death of his father, Sultan Muhyiddin Mansur.

1662.title: Louis Grimaldi becomes Prince of Monaco
1662.summary: At the age of 19, Louis Grimaldi becomes the new Prince of Monaco upon the death of his grandfather, Honoré II.

1662.title: Portuguese garrison invades Morocco
1662.summary: A Portuguese garrison invades Morocco and kidnaps 35 women and girls, then steals 400 head of cattle. The Moroccans counterattack and kill the garrison's commander and others, leading to a brief war between England and Morocco.

1662.title: Execution of Former Emperor Yongli
1662.summary: Former Chinese Emperor Yongli, who had surrendered, is put on a boat along with his sons and grandsons but is instead taken back to China and executed.

1662.title: János Keményi killed in battle
1662.summary: János Keményi, Prince of Transylvania for slightly more than a year, is killed during Transylvania's defeat by the Ottoman Empire.

1662.title: Koxinga captures Fort Zeelandia
1662.summary: Chinese general Koxinga captures the Dutch East India Company's settlement at Fort Zeelandia after a nine-month siege, ending the company's rule on the island and establishing the Kingdom of Tungning.

1662.title: The first public bus system in Paris
1662.summary: A short-lived experiment of the first public bus system begins in Paris as horse-drawn wagons for eight passengers, financed by Blaise Pascal.

1662.title: Hearth tax introduced in England and Wales
1662.summary: The hearth tax is introduced in England and Wales, charging one shilling for each stove or fireplace, collected annually.

1662.title: Catherine of Braganza marries Charles II
1662.summary: Princess Catherine of Braganza marries Charles II of England. As part of the dowry, Portugal cedes Bombay and Tangier to England.

1662.title: The Act of Uniformity receives royal assent
1662.summary: The Act of Uniformity is given royal assent to regulate public prayers, aligning with the latest edition of the Book of Common Prayer.

1663.title: Royal African Company Charter
1663.summary: The Royal African Company is granted a Royal Charter by Charles II of England.

1663.title: Treaty of Ghilajharighat
1663.summary: The Treaty of Ghilajharighat is signed in India between representatives of the Mughal Empire and the independent Ahom Kingdom, ending Mughal occupation of Garhgaon.

1663.title: 7.3 Magnitude Earthquake
1663.summary: An earthquake estimated at least 7.3 magnitude strikes Canada's Quebec Province.

1663.title: Sack of Campeche
1663.summary: English pirates led by Christopher Myngs and Edward Mansvelt sack Campeche in Mexico, looting the town during a two-week occupation.

1663.title: Capture of Chiang Mai
1663.summary: The army of the Kingdom of Siam captures Chiang Mai from the Kingdom of Burma, using it as a base for launching further attacks.

1663.title: Discovery of Prince Edward Islands
1663.summary: The Prince Edward Islands in the sub-antarctic Indian Ocean are discovered and named by Barent Barentszoon Lam.

1663.title: End of Emperor Go-Sai's Reign
1663.summary: Emperor Go-Sai's reign ends, and Emperor Reigen ascends to the throne of Japan.

1663.title: Charter of Carolina
1663.summary: King Charles II of England issues the Charter of Carolina, establishing the Province of Carolina and dividing it between eight Lords Proprietors.

1663.title: Austro-Turkish War Declaration
1663.summary: The Ottoman Empire declares war against Leopold I, Holy Roman Emperor, beginning the Austro-Turkish War.

1663.title: Opening of the King's Theatre
1663.summary: The King's Theatre, now called Drury Lane, opens in London.

1664.title: Battle of Surat
1664.summary: The Maratha leader, Chhatrapati Shivaji, defeats the Mughal Army Captain Inayat Khan, and sacks Surat.

1664.title: Virji Vora's Plunder
1664.summary: Indian entrepreneur Virji Vora suffers the loss of a large portion of his wealth when the Maratha troops of Shivaji plunder his residence at Surat.

1664.title: Journey of Johann Grueber
1664.summary: Jesuit missionary Johann Grueber arrives in Rome after a 214-day journey that had started in Beijing, proving that commerce can be had between Europe and Asia by land rather than ship.

1664.title: Treaty of Pisa
1664.summary: The Treaty of Pisa is signed between France and the Papal States to end the Corsican Guard Affair that began when the French ambassador was shot by soldiers in the employ of Pope Alexander VII.

1664.title: Peace Treaty in Turin
1664.summary: A peace treaty is signed in Turin in Italy to end the War of the Banished between the Duchy of Savoy and the Waldensians.

1664.title: Expansion to the Caribbean
1664.summary: Alexandre de Prouville de Tracy departs from the port of La Rochelle with 1,200 men and seven ships to expand France's property in the Caribbean and South America.

1664.title: Charter for New York territory
1664.summary: King Charles II of England makes royal charter for territory in North America that leases to his brother, Duke of York.

1664.title: Foundation of Kronenbourg Brewery
1664.summary: Kronenbourg Brewery is founded in Strasbourg.

1664.title: Battle of Saint Gotthard
1664.summary: The Ottoman Empire is defeated by a Habsburg army, leading to the Peace of Vasvár.

1664.title: Surrender of New Amsterdam
1664.summary: Peter Stuyvesant surrenders New Amsterdam to an English naval squadron, which renames the city New York.

1665.title: Publication of the Journal des savants
1665.summary: The Journal des savants begins publication of the first scientific journal in France.

1665.title: Premiere of Dom Juan
1665.summary: Molière's comedy Dom Juan ou le Festin de pierre premieres in Paris.

1665.title: Capture of Sadashivgad
1665.summary: Shivaji Bhonsale captures the English East India Company's trading post at Sadashivgad.

1665.title: First blood transfusion
1665.summary: Dr. Richard Lower performs the first blood transfusion between animals in England.

1665.title: Beginning of the Second Anglo-Dutch War
Publication of Philosophical Transactions
1665.summary: The Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London begins publication, the first scientific journal in English.

1665.title: Legal Code Approval in New York
1665.summary: A new legal code is approved for New York, guaranteeing Protestants the right to religious observances.

1665.title: Jewish Settlement in Bucharest
1665.summary: Bucharest allows Jews to settle in the city, in exchange for an annual tax.

1665.title: Death during the Great Plague
1665.summary: The burial of Margaret Porteous is recorded as the first known death during the Great Plague of London.

1665.title: Closure of University of Cambridge
1665.summary: The Great Plague forces the closure of the University of Cambridge, affecting Isaac Newton's studies.

1666.title: The Great Fire of London
1666.summary: The Great Fire of London begins as a blaze in a bakery owned by Thomas Farriner on Pudding Lane, near London Bridge. Over a period of four days, the fire destroys more than 13,000 buildings, including Old St Paul's Cathedral. Although only six people are known to have died, at least 80,000 are left destitute and homeless. The events are recorded by Samuel Pepys in his diary, leading to advances in cartography and surveying.

1666.title: The Battle of Matwy
1666.summary: The Battle of Matwy, the bloodiest engagement of Lubomirski's rebellion, takes place in Poland at the village of Matwy. Jerzy Sebastian Lubomirski defeats a larger number of troops led by John III Sobieski of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, resulting in 4,000 deaths compared to 200 rebel casualties.

1666.title: Molière's The Misanthrope
1666.summary: Molière's comedy of manners The Misanthrope premieres at the Théâtre du Palais-Royal in Paris by the King's Players with himself in the title role, marking a significant event in European theater.

1666.title: The Four Days' Battle
1666.summary: The Four Days' Battle between the Dutch Republic fleet and the English Royal Navy in the North Sea ends with a Dutch victory but heavy losses on both sides. The battle is one of the longest naval engagements in history, and it occurs as part of the Second Anglo-Dutch War.

1666.title: The Agreement of Legonice
1666.summary: The Agreement of Legonice is signed, restoring titles to Jerzy Sebastian Lubomirski and granting amnesty to all rebels, marking an important moment in Polish history.

1666.title: Abbas II dies
1666.summary: Abbas II, the Shah of Iran, dies at the age of 34 after a reign of 24 years, without designating a successor. His 18-year old son Sam Mirza is crowned as the new Safavid dynasty emperor shortly thereafter.

1666.title: Execution of Robert Hubert
1666.summary: Robert Hubert, a Frenchman who falsely confessed to starting the Great Fire of London, is executed based on his statements. This event reflects societal tensions following the disaster.

1666.title: Louis-Isaac Lemaistre de Sacy imprisoned
1666.summary: French theologian Louis-Isaac Lemaistre de Sacy is imprisoned in the Bastille after his conviction for heresy, which leads him to produce the Bible du Port-Royal, a significant French translation of the Bible.

1666.title: Foundation of the French Academy of Sciences
1666.summary: The French Academy of Sciences, founded by Louis XIV, meets for the first time, aiming to promote scientific progress and research in France, impacting future generations of scientists.

1666.title: Great Plague of London subsides
1666.summary: The joint English and Scottish royal court returns to London as the Great Plague of London subsides, marking an important public health milestone for citizens of the time.

1667.title: Removal of Rao Karan Singh
1667.summary: Aurangzeb, monarch of the Mughal Empire, orders the removal of Rao Karan Singh as Maharaja of the Bikaner State due to dereliction of duty in battle.

1667.title: Avalanche in Anzonico
1667.summary: The town of Anzonico in Switzerland is destroyed by an avalanche.

1667.title: Opening of Opernhaus am Taschenberg
1667.summary: The Opernhaus am Taschenberg theater in Dresden opens with its first production, Pietro Ziani's opera Il teseo.

1667.title: Capture of HMS Saint Patrick
1667.summary: In the Second Anglo-Dutch War, the English warship HMS Saint Patrick is captured by the Dutch Navy off the coast of Kent.

1667.title: Treaty of Andrusovo
1667.summary: The Treaty of Andrusovo is signed, ending the Russo-Polish War, with Poland ceding eastern Ukraine to Russia.

1667.title: Opening of the Lejonkulan Theatre
1667.summary: The first permanent theater in Scandinavia, Lejonkulan, opens in Stockholm with a performance of Jean Magnon's Orontes en Satira.

1667.title: John Milton's contract for Paradise Lost
1667.summary: John Milton seals a contract for the publication of Paradise Lost with a London printer.

1667.title: War of Devolution begins
1667.summary: After King Philip IV of Spain reneges on dowry payments, the War of Devolution begins with French invasions.

1667.title: First blood transfusion
1667.summary: Dr. Jean-Baptiste Denys administers the first human blood transfusion, transferring sheep's blood to a 15-year-old boy.

1667.title: Capture of Guwahati
1667.summary: Assam troops led by General Lachit Borphukan capture the Mughal city of Guwahati after a victory in battle.

1668.title: Formation of the Triple Alliance
1668.summary: The Triple Alliance of 1668 is formed between England, Sweden and the United Provinces of the Netherlands.

1668.title: Peace Treaty in Lisbon
1668.summary: A peace treaty is established between Afonso VI of Portugal and Carlos II of Spain, mediated by Charles II of England, recognizing the legitimacy of the Portuguese monarch.

1668.title: Venetian Naval Victory
1668.summary: In the Cretan War, the navy of the Republic of Venice defeats an Ottoman Empire naval force attempting to seize a small Venetian galley near the port of Agia Pelagia.

1668.title: Henry Morgan's Raid
1668.summary: Notable Privateer Henry Morgan lands in Cuba to raid and plunder the inland town of Puerto del Príncipe during the Anglo-Spanish War.

1668.title: Bawdy House Riots in London
1668.summary: The Bawdy House Riots take place in London as a protest against the enforcement of laws against private worshippers and prostitution, resulting in violence over three days.

1668.title: Lease of Bombay
1668.summary: King Charles II of England signs an agreement with the English East India Company to lease the Indian city of Bombay for a rent of 10 pounds sterling per year.

1668.title: Earthquake in Shandong
1668.summary: The magnitude 8.5 Shandong earthquake kills at least 43,000 people in China's Shandong province.

1668.title: Earthquake in North Anatolia
1668.summary: The magnitude 8.0 North Anatolia earthquake causes 8,000 deaths in northern Anatolia, Ottoman Empire, marking a significant disaster.

1668.title: Performance of The Miser
1668.summary: Molière's comedy The Miser is first performed in Paris, showcasing the playwright's influence on European theatre.

1668.title: Establishment of the Sveriges Riksbank
1668.summary: The Sveriges Riksbank, one of the world's earliest central banks, is founded in Stockholm, Sweden, marking a significant development in financial administration.

1669.title: The first performance of the Ballet de Flore
1669.summary: The first performance of the Ballet de Flore, a joint collaboration of Jean-Baptiste Lully and Isaac de Benserade is given, premiering at the Palais du Louvre in Paris. King Louis XIV finances the performance and even appears in a minor role in the production as a dancer.

1669.title: Earthquake in Shamakhi
1669.summary: A 5.7 magnitude earthquake strikes the city of Shamakhi in Iran (now in Azerbaijan) and kills 7,000 people. Fourteen months earlier, an earthquake in Shamakhi killed 80,000 people.

1669.title: Henry Morgan's meeting
1669.summary: Pirate Henry Morgan of Wales holds a meeting of his captains on board his ship, the former Royal Navy frigate Oxford, and an explosion in the ship's gunpowder supply kills 200 of his crew and four of the pirate captains who had attended the summit.

1669.title: Isaac Newton's invention
1669.summary: Isaac Newton writes his first description of his new invention, the reflecting telescope.

1669.title: Mount Etna eruption
1669.summary: Mount Etna erupts, destroying the Sicilian town of Nicolosi.

1669.title: Aurangzeb's decree
1669.summary: Aurangzeb, the Muslim Emperor of the Mughal Empire in India, issues a firman decree for the protection of all Hindu temples and schools in his kingdom.

1669.title: Execution in Sweden's Mora witch trial
1669.summary: The first people executed in Sweden's Mora witch trial are put to death, with seven women and one man beheaded after being convicted of abduction of children to Satan.

1669.title: The founding of the University of Innsbruck
1669.summary: The University of Innsbruck is chartered in Austria by Leopold I, Holy Roman Emperor.

1669.title: Rembrandt's death
1669.summary: Dutch painter Rembrandt van Rijn dies at the age of 63, after completing his final known work Self-Portrait at the Age of 63.

1669.title: The Battle of Cádiz
1669.summary: The Battle of Cádiz begins off of the coast of the Spanish city as the English warship HMS Mary Rose encounters seven pirate ships from Algeria.

1670.title: Burning of Raphael Levy
1670.summary: A Jewish resident of Metz in France is burned at the stake after being accused of abduction and ritual murder of a child. The prosecutor seeks to expel all Jewish families from Metz, but King Louis XIV refuses.

1670.title: Destruction of Hindu Temples
1670.summary: The Muslim emperor Aurangzeb issues an order for the destruction of all Hindu temples and schools in the Mughal Empire, highlighting the religious tensions in India.

1670.title: Battle of Sinhagad
1670.summary: The Maratha army, led by Tanaji Malusare, captures the Kondhana Fortress from the Mughal Empire, marking a significant victory for the Maratha Empire.

1670.title: Christian V becomes King
1670.summary: Christian V ascends to the throne of Denmark-Norway following the death of his father, Frederick III, marking a new era in Danish-Norwegian history.

1670.title: Royal Wedding in Poland
1670.summary: The royal wedding between King Michal Wisniowiecki and Eleonore of Austria takes place at Denhoff Palace, signifying political alliances in Eastern Europe.

1670.title: Oliver Plunkett Returns to Ireland
1670.summary: Catholic Archbishop Oliver Plunkett is allowed to return to Ireland, reflecting shifts in religious tolerance during this period.

1670.title: English Settlement in South Carolina
1670.summary: The first English settlers arrive at Albemarle Point in South Carolina, leading to the establishment of an English colony in the region.

1670.title: Proclamation from Viceroy of Croatia
1670.summary: Petar Zrinski issues a proclamation urging Croatians to rebel against the Habsburg rulers, reflecting rising nationalist sentiments.

1670.title: Wreck of HMS Sapphire
1670.summary: The British warship HMS Sapphire is wrecked while fleeing perceived threat from pirate ships, leading to the court-martial of her captain and lieutenant.

1670.title: Papal Election of Cardinal Emilio Albieri
1670.summary: Cardinal Emilio Albieri is elected Pope Clement X, becoming the oldest person ever elected pope, marking a significant event in the Catholic Church.

1671.title: The Criminal Ordinance of 1670
1671.summary: The first attempt at a uniform code of criminal procedure in France, goes into effect after having been passed on August 26, 1670.

1671.title: The Battle of Salher
1671.summary: The first major confrontation between the Maratha Empire and the Mughal Empire, with the Maratha Army defeating a larger Mughal force.

1671.title: Premiere of Psyché
1671.summary: The ballet with music composed by Jean-Baptiste Lully premieres before the royal court of King Louis XIV at the Théâtre des Tuileries in Paris.

1671.title: Destruction of Panama City
1671.summary: Henry Morgan's Panama expedition destroys the city of Nuestra Señora de la Asunción de Panamá.

1671.title: Marriage of Tsar Alexis
1671.summary: The Tsar Alexis of Russia marries Nataliya Kyrillovna Naryshkina, who later gives birth to Peter the Great.

1671.title: Ortenau meteorite
1671.summary: The Ortenau meteorite lands in Germany.

1671.title: First performance of Pomone
1671.summary: Pomone, considered to be the first French opera, is given its first performance.

1671.title: Tornado in Cadiz
1671.summary: A tornado kills more than 600 people in the city of Cadiz in Spain.

1671.title: Launch of Royal Navy warship
1671.summary: England's Royal Navy launches its first warship with a frame reinforced by iron bars, an innovation by naval architect Anthony Deane.

1671.title: Battle of Pungo Andongo
1671.summary: Portuguese troops win the Battle of Pungo Andongo, capturing the fortress capital of the Kingdom of Ndongo.

1672.title: Stop of the Exchequer
1672.summary: After the government of England is unable to pay the nation's debts, King Charles II decrees the suspension of payments for one year, redirecting the money to the upcoming war with the Dutch Republic.

1672.title: Isaac Newton elected to Royal Society
1672.summary: The Royal Society of London elects Isaac Newton to its membership and demonstrates his reflecting telescope to King Charles II.

1672.title: Burning of Theatre Royal
1672.summary: The Theatre Royal, located on Bridges Street in London, burns down and a replacement structure is built on Drury Lane in 1674.

1672.title: Newton's experiment on light
1672.summary: Isaac Newton sends a paper regarding his experiments on the refraction of light through glass prisms, identifying the primary colors of visible light.

1672.title: Willem, Prince of Orange approved
1672.summary: Willem, Prince of Orange, is approved by the States General of the Dutch Republic to command the Dutch States Army for the impending war with England.

1672.title: Action of 12 March 1672
1672.summary: A naval engagement between an English coastal patrol and a Dutch convoy results in severe damage to the English fleet while most of the Dutch convoy escapes.

1672.title: Third Anglo-Dutch War begins
1672.summary: The Kingdom of England declares war on the Dutch Republic, marking the beginning of the Third Anglo-Dutch War.

1672.title: Battle of Solebay
1672.summary: An indecisive sea battle results between the Dutch Republic and the joined forces of England and France during the Third Anglo-Dutch War.

1672.title: Treaty of Buchach
1672.summary: A treaty is signed between the Ottoman Empire and the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth, impacting the political landscape of Europe.

1672.title: Discovery of Rhea
1672.summary: French astronomer Giovanni Domenico Cassini discovers Rhea, the second-largest moon of Saturn, enhancing the understanding of the solar system.

1673.title: Execution of Mary Carleton
1673.summary: Impostor Mary Carleton is hanged at Newgate Prison for multiple thefts and returning from penal transportation.

1673.title: Premiere of The Imaginary Invalid
1673.summary: Molière's comédie-ballet The Imaginary Invalid premiers in Paris. During the fourth performance, the playwright collapses on stage, dying soon after.

1673.title: Test Act Enforced
1673.summary: The Test Act disallows Roman Catholics and others who refuse to receive the sacrament of the Church of England from voting, holding office, or assembling for meetings in England.

1673.title: First Performance of Cadmus et Hermione
1673.summary: Cadmus et Hermione, the first opera written by Jean-Baptiste Lully, premieres at the Paris Opera in France.

1673.title: Exploration of Mississippi River
1673.summary: Trader Louis Joliet and missionary Jacques Marquette begin exploring the Mississippi River and the Great Lakes.

1673.title: First Battle of Schooneveld
1673.summary: The Dutch Republic fleet defeats the Anglo-French fleet in a significant naval battle off the Netherlands coast.

1673.title: Second Battle of Schooneveld
1673.summary: The Dutch fleet again defeats the joint Anglo-French fleet in a continued naval conflict.

1673.title: Dutch Recapture of New York
1673.summary: Dutch forces recapture New York from the English, renaming it New Orange until regained by the English in 1674.

1673.title: Battle of Khotyn
1673.summary: Polish and Lithuanian military units defeat the Turkish army, utilizing rockets for the first time in battle.

1673.title: Establishment of Chelsea Physic Garden
1673.summary: The Chelsea Physic Garden is founded by the Society of Apothecaries, marking the establishment of a significant botanical study space in England.

1674.title: Dissolution of the French West India Company
1674.summary: The French West India Company is dissolved after less than 10 years.

1674.title: General Wu Sangui takes control of Giuzhou
1674.summary: In the Chinese Empire, General Wu Sangui leads troops into the Giuzhou province, and soon takes control of the entire territory without a loss.

1674.title: Impeachment of the Earl of Arlington
1674.summary: The Earl of Arlington is impeached on charges of popery, but the Commons rejects the motion to remove him from office.

1674.title: First performance of Alceste
1674.summary: The tragic opera Alceste, by Jean-Baptiste Lully, is performed for the first time, presented by the Paris Opera company at the Theatre du Palais-Royal in Paris.

1674.title: Treaty of Westminster
1674.summary: England and the Netherlands sign the Treaty of Westminster, ending the Third Anglo-Dutch War.

1674.title: Battle of Ronas Voe
1674.summary: The English Royal Navy captures the Dutch East India Company ship Wapen van Rotterdam in Shetland, during the Third Anglo-Dutch War.

1674.title: Coronation of Shivaji Maharaj
1674.summary: Shivaji Maharaj is crowned as Chatrapati Shivaji Maharaj of the Maratha Empire at Raigad Fort in India.

1674.title: Dutch invasion of Martinique
1674.summary: In a major battle in the Third Anglo-Dutch War, a large Dutch fleet attempts to invade Martinique but is forced to retreat after heavy losses.

1674.title: Succession of Sukjong of Korea
1674.summary: Sukjong of the Joseon Dynasty becomes the new Emperor of Korea upon the death of his father, the Emperor Hyeonjong.

1674.title: The Battle of Entzheim
1674.summary: The Battle of Entzheim takes place in France during the Franco-Dutch War, with the French winning a strategic victory.

1675.title: Battle of Turckheim
1675.summary: The French defeat Austria and Brandenburg.

1675.title: Death of John Sassamon
1675.summary: An English-educated Native American Christian, dies at Assawampsett Pond, triggering a year-long war between the English American colonists and the Algonquian tribes.

1675.title: Premiere of La divisione del mondo
1675.summary: The Italian opera by Giovanni Legrenzi is performed for the first time in Venice, known for its elaborate sets and special effects.

1675.title: Election of Nicolò Sagredo
1675.summary: Nicolò Sagredo is elected as the new Doge of Venice, replacing Domenico II Contarini.

1675.title: Reinforcement of Messina Revolt
1675.summary: French Army Marshal Louis Victor de Rochechouart reinforces rebels with additional ships, breaking the Spanish blockade.

1675.title: Christiaan Huygens' invention of the balance spring
1675.summary: Netherlands scientist files drawings of his invention, vital for portable clocks and pocket watches.

1675.title: Appointment of John Flamsteed
1675.summary: John Flamsteed is appointed by King Charles II as England's first Astronomer Royal.

1675.title: Sinking of HMY Mary
1675.summary: England's first royal yacht strikes rocks and sinks off Anglesey, resulting in the loss of 35 people.

1675.title: Reconstruction of St Paul's Cathedral
1675.summary: The reconstruction begins under Christopher Wren after the Great Fire of London.

1675.title: Foundation of Royal Greenwich Observatory
1675.summary: King Charles II places the foundation stone of the Royal Greenwich Observatory near London.

1676.title: Feodor III becomes Tsar of Russia
1676.summary: On January 29, Feodor III ascends the Russian throne, marking a significant political shift in the region.

1676.title: Universidad de San Carlos de Guatemala is founded
1676.summary: On January 31, the oldest institution of higher education in Central America is established, facilitating education in the region.

1676.title: Metacomet seeks an alliance with Mohawks
1676.summary: In January, Metacomet attempts to ally with the Mohawks against English colonists, though his efforts fail, reflecting the tensions of King Philip's War.

1676.title: Mary Rowlandson captured
1676.summary: On February 10, colonial woman Mary Rowlandson is taken captive by Nipmuc tribes and later ransomed, highlighting the human cost of conflicts during King Philip's War.

1676.title: Heavy attack on Northampton
1676.summary: On February 14, Metacomet and his forces attack Northampton, raising concerns about colonial safety and defenses.

1676.title: Providence attacked
1676.summary: On March 29, Native Americans destroy Providence, adding to the turmoil of King Philip's War.

1676.title: Chief Canonchet captured
1676.summary: On April 2, Chief Canonchet is executed after refusing English demands, marking a significant event in Native American resistance against colonial expansion.

1676.title: Battle of Augusta
1676.summary: On April 22, a naval battle occurs in the Mediterranean, reflecting the ongoing conflicts in Europe during this period.

1676.title: Peskeomskut Massacre
1676.summary: On May 19, a brutal raid led by Captain William Turner results in significant loss of life among Native Americans, showcasing the violence of colonial conflicts.

1676.title: Scanian War: Battle of Öland
1676.summary: On June 1, the Dutch fleet defeats the Swedish Navy, a decisive moment in the Scanian War.

1677.title: Phèdre is first performed
1677.summary: Jean Racine's tragedy is first performed, in Paris.

1677.title: First medical publication in America
1677.summary: The first medical publication in America, a pamphlet on smallpox, is produced in Boston.

1677.title: Arrest of English Lords
1677.summary: Four members of the English House of Lords embarrass King Charles II at the opening of the Cavalier Parliament and are arrested.

1677.title: Siege of Valenciennes begins
1677.summary: During the Franco-Dutch War, the Siege of Valenciennes by the French Army begins in the Spanish Netherlands.

1677.title: Battle of Cassel
1677.summary: A French force defeats a combined Dutch-Spanish force under William of Orange in French Flanders.

1677.title: Treaty of Middle Plantation
1677.summary: The Treaty establishes peace between the Virginia colonists and the local Indians.

1677.title: Battle of Møn
1677.summary: Danish ships clash with a Swedish fleet, the Danish defeat the Swedish and capture ships.

1677.title: Battle of Landskrona
1677.summary: Sweden successfully repels an invasion force from Denmark, commanded by King Christian V.

1677.title: Henry Purcell appointed
1677.summary: Henry Purcell is appointed a musician to the court of Charles II of England.

1677.title: Discovery of Niagara Falls
1677.summary: Father Louis Hennepin becomes the first known European to discover Niagara Falls.

1678.title: Mutual Defense Treaty
1678.summary: England and the Dutch Republic sign a mutual defense treaty in order to fight against France.

1678.title: First Fire Engine Company
1678.summary: The first fire engine company in North America goes into service in Boston.

1678.title: Publication of The Pilgrim's Progress
1678.summary: The first part of English nonconformist preacher John Bunyan's Christian allegory The Pilgrim's Progress is published in London.

1678.title: First Performance of A True Widow
1678.summary: Thomas Shadwell's comedy A True Widow is given its first performance at The Duke's Theatre in London.

1678.title: Revolt of the Three Feudatories
1678.summary: Rebel general Wu Sangui takes the imperial crown in southern China, leading a significant rebellion against the Kangxi Emperor.

1678.title: Siege of Ypres
1678.summary: The Spanish Netherlands city of Ypres falls after a seven-day siege by the French Army.

1678.title: Discovery of Nova V529 Orionis
1678.summary: The nova V529 Orionis is discovered by Polish astronomer Johannes Hevelius.

1678.title: Treaty of Casco Bay
1678.summary: The Treaty of Casco Bay is signed, bringing an end to fighting between English settlers and the Penobscot tribe in Maine.

1678.title: Raids in Venezuela
1678.summary: French buccaneer Michel de Grammont leads a daring raid in Spanish-held Venezuela with a large pirate force.

1678.title: Impeachment Proceedings
1678.summary: England's House of Commons votes to begin impeachment proceedings against five Roman Catholic members of the House of Lords.

1679.title: Dissolution of the Cavalier Parliament
1679.summary: King Charles II of England dissolves the Cavalier Parliament, after nearly 18 years.

1679.title: Moroccan Ceasefire
1679.summary: Moroccan Sultan Ismail Ibn Sharif negotiates a ceasefire allowing remaining troops safe passage back home after a battle against rebels.

1679.title: Treaty of Celle
1679.summary: The Treaty of Celle is signed between France and Sweden, confirming Sweden's sovereignty over Bremen-Verden.

1679.title: Ajit Singh Rathore becomes Maharaja
1679.summary: Ajit Singh Rathore becomes the new Maharaja of the Jodhpur State, a principality in India.

1679.title: Habeas Corpus Parliament Opened
1679.summary: The Habeas Corpus Parliament is opened in England to address issues of individual liberties.

1679.title: Arrest of La Voisin
1679.summary: Catherine Deshayes Monvoisin, suspected killer of over 1,000 people in France, is arrested outside the Church of Notre-Dame-de-Bonne-Nouvelle.

1679.title: Imposition of Jizya
1679.summary: Aurangzeb decrees the imposition of the jizya, a tax on non-Muslims under Mughal jurisdiction in India.

1679.title: Landslide in Piedmont
1679.summary: A landslide in Piedmont causes the village of Bosia to sink into the ground, killing 200 inhabitants.

1679.title: Eclipse of the Sun
1679.summary: A total eclipse of the Sun takes place over North America, peaking over Lakota Sioux territory.

1679.title: Assassination of James Sharp
1679.summary: James Sharp, the Church of Scotland's Archbishop of St Andrews, is assassinated during an ambush by Scottish Covenanters.

1680.title: King Amangkurat II stabs Trunajaya
1680.summary: King Amangkurat II of Mataram invites Trunajaya for a ceremonial visit and stabs him to death.

1680.title: William Harris captured by pirates
1680.summary: William Harris, one of the Puritans, is captured by Algerian pirates while sailing back to England and sold into slavery.

1680.title: Catherine Deshayes Monvoisin executed
1680.summary: Catherine Deshayes Monvoisin, a fortune teller, is burned at the stake for her involvement in the Affair of the Poisons that killed many.

1680.title: Earl of Shaftesbury informs of rebellion
1680.summary: The Earl of Shaftesbury informs the Privy Council of an impending Catholic rebellion in Ireland, leading to the execution of Archbishop Oliver Plunkett.

1680.title: Troops blockade Tangier
1680.summary: Troops sent by the Sultan of Morocco begin a blockade of the English-occupied port of Tangier.

1680.title: London Penny Post begins
1680.summary: The London Penny Post delivery service begins operations, delivering letters across London for one penny.

1680.title: Prince Rajaram Bhosle becomes Emperor
1680.summary: Prince Rajaram Bhosle is installed as the new Emperor of the Maratha Empire in India shortly after his father's death.

1680.title: King Charles XI's marriage
1680.summary: King Charles XI of Sweden marries Princess Elonora, strengthening ties with Denmark-Norway.

1680.title: Tokugawa Tsunayoshi becomes Shōgun
1680.summary: Tokugawa Tsunayoshi ascends as the new Shōgun of Japan following the death of his brother.

1680.title: Krakatoa erupts
1680.summary: The volcano Krakatoa erupts on a relatively small scale, marking a significant geological event.

1681.title: Civil War Initiation by Prince Muhammad Akbar
1681.summary: Prince Muhammad Akbar initiates a civil war in India against his father, Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb, ultimately resulting in Akbar's defeat.

1681.title: Treaty of Bakhchisarai
1681.summary: The Treaty of Bakhchisarai is signed between the Ottoman vassal Crimean Khanate and the Russian Empire.

1681.title: Dissolution of the Exclusion Bill Parliament
1681.summary: The Exclusion Bill Parliament is dissolved, directing that new elections be held and a new parliament be convened in March.

1681.title: Sacking of Burhanpur
1681.summary: The Mughal Empire city of Burhanpur is sacked by troops of the Maratha Empire, under the orders of Chhatrapati Sambhaji.

1681.title: Land Charter Granted to William Penn
1681.summary: King Charles II grants a land charter to William Penn for territory that will later be called Pennsylvania.

1681.title: Oxford Parliament Summoned
1681.summary: The Oxford Parliament is summoned by King Charles II but is dissolved after just seven days.

1681.title: Opening of the Canal du Midi
1681.summary: The Canal du Midi in France is officially opened as the Canal Royal de Languedoc.

1681.title: Execution of Oliver Plunkett
1681.summary: Oliver Plunkett, the last Catholic martyr to die in England, is executed at Tyburn, London.

1681.title: French Annexation of Strasbourg
1681.summary: France annexes the city of Strasbourg, previously a free imperial city of the Holy Roman Empire.

1681.title: Appointment of the Governor of Bombay
1681.summary: Sir John Child becomes the new Governor of Bombay and assumes control over the East India Company settlements in India.

1682.title: Genoa's Printing Ban
1682.summary: The Republic of Genoa forbids the unauthorized printing of newspapers and all handwritten newssheets; the ban is lifted after three months.

1682.title: Mobilization of Ottoman Army
1682.summary: The Ottoman Empire army is mobilized in preparation for a war against Austria that culminates with the 1683 Battle of Vienna.

1682.title: Public Theater in Brussels
1682.summary: The first public theater in Brussels, the Opéra du Quai au Foin, is opened.

1682.title: Great Fire in Edo
1682.summary: In Japan, a major fire sweeps through Edo (now Tokyo).

1682.title: First Performance of Venice Preserv'd
1682.summary: Thomas Otway's classic play Venice Preserv'd or A Plot Discover'd is given its first performance, premiering at the Duke's Theatre.

1682.title: Construction of Royal Hospital Chelsea
1682.summary: Work begins on construction of the Royal Hospital Chelsea for old soldiers in London, England.

1682.title: Moscow Uprising of 1682
1682.summary: The Moscow Uprising occurs when a mob invades the Kremlin and lynches leading boyars, leading to Ivan V and Peter I being named co-rulers.

1682.title: Crowning of Ivan V and Peter I
1682.summary: Ivan V and Peter I are crowned as joint Tsars of Russia at the Cathedral of the Dormition in Moscow, with real power exercised by their older sister.

1682.title: Foundation of the City of Philadelphia
1682.summary: The city of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania is founded by William Penn.

1682.title: Celia Fiennes Begins Travels
1682.summary: Celia Fiennes begins her journeys across Britain, documenting towns and cities for her life's work.

1683.title: Treaty of Groß Friedrichsburg
1683.summary: The Brandenburger—African Company signs a treaty with representatives of the Ahanta tribe to establish the fort and settlement of Groß Friedrichsburg in Ghana.

1683.title: Premiere of Phaëton
1683.summary: The tragic opera Phaëton, written by Jean-Baptiste Lully and Philippe Quinault, is premiered at the Palace of Versailles.

1683.title: Gove's Rebellion
1683.summary: Gove's Rebellion breaks out in the Province of New Hampshire as a revolt against the Royal Governor, Edward Cranfield.

1683.title: Premiere of Giustino
1683.summary: The opera Giustino by Giovanni Legrenzi, about the life of the Byzantine Emperor Justin, premieres in Venice.

1683.title: Capture of Ageng Tirtayasa
1683.summary: Ageng Tirtayasa, Sultan of Banten on the island of Java, is captured by soldiers hired by the Dutch East India Company.

1683.title: Battle at Kalyan
1683.summary: In a battle at Kalyan, Maratha General Hambirrao Mohite defeats the local Mughal official, Ranamast Khan.

1683.title: Military alliance treaty
1683.summary: Authorized representatives of King John III Sobieski of Poland and Emperor Leopold I of the Holy Roman Empire sign a military alliance treaty in Warsaw.

1683.title: Opening of the Ashmolean Museum
1683.summary: The Ashmolean Museum opens in Oxford as the world's first university museum.

1683.title: Siege of Vienna
1683.summary: The Ottoman siege of Vienna is broken with the arrival of a force of 70,000 Poles, Austrians, and Germans, marking a turning point in the Ottoman Empire's fortunes.

1683.title: Execution of Kara Mustafa Pasha
1683.summary: Kara Mustafa Pasha, Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire, is executed after being blamed for the Ottoman loss in the Battle of Vienna.

1684.title: Duke of St Albans Title Granted
1684.summary: King Charles II of England gives the title Duke of St Albans to Charles Beauclerk, his illegitimate son by Nell Gwyn.

1684.title: Foundation of University of Tokyo
1684.summary: The earliest form of what is now the University of Tokyo, the Temnongata, is established in Japan.

1684.title: Thames Frost Fair
1684.summary: To demonstrate that the River Thames, frozen solid during the Great Frost, is safe to walk upon, a coach and six horses drove over the Thames, leading to whole streets being built on the frozen river.

1684.title: Election of the Doge of Venice
1684.summary: Marcantonio Giustinian is elected Doge of Venice.

1684.title: Morocco Retakes Tangier
1684.summary: Morocco retakes control of the city of Tangier from England, which had controlled the North African port since 1661.

1684.title: Return and Overthrow of Prince Dumitrașcu Cantacuzino
1684.summary: Prince Dumitrașcu Cantacuzino returns to the throne of Moldavia for a third reign but is overthrown 14 months later.

1684.title: End of the Great Frost in Britain
1684.summary: The Great Frost in Britain ends as the Thames begins to thaw, marking significant impact on wildlife and society.

1684.title: Treaty Signed in Ghana
1684.summary: A treaty is signed between European German colonists and African chiefs to allow German colonists to build a fort on the Gold Coast.

1684.title: Formation of the Holy League
1684.summary: Pope Innocent XI forms a Holy League with the Habsburg Empire, Venice, and Poland to end Ottoman rule in Europe.

1684.title: Siege of Luxembourg City
1684.summary: Luxembourg City is taken by the French Army from Spain after a siege that began in April.

1685.title: James II becomes King
1685.summary: Catholic James Stuart, Duke of York, becomes King James II of England and Ireland, and King James VII of Scotland after the death of his brother Charles II.

1685.title: Establishment of Fort St. Louis
1685.summary: René-Robert Cavelier lands at Matagorda Bay with colonists, establishing Fort St. Louis near the Mississippi River.

1685.title: Start of the Morean War
1685.summary: The Ottoman serasker Halil Pasha invades the Mani Peninsula, initiating the Morean War.

1685.title: Siege of Bijapur
1685.summary: An attack on a Mughal envoy leads to a 15-month siege of Bijapur by Mughal forces.

1685.title: Coronation of James II
1685.summary: The coronation of King James II of England and his Queen Consort, Mary of Modena, takes place at Westminster Abbey.

1685.title: Monmouth Rebellion begins
1685.summary: James Scott, 1st Duke of Monmouth, lands in England to challenge James II for the crown.

1685.title: Battle of Sedgemoor
1685.summary: The last pitched battle fought on English soil, King James II's forces defeat Monmouth's rebels.

1685.title: Bloody Assizes
1685.summary: Lord Chief Justice George Jeffreys tries Monmouth's rebels, condemning many to death or transportation.

1685.title: Edict of Fontainebleau
1685.summary: Louis XIV revokes the Edict of Nantes, declaring Protestantism illegal, leading to Huguenots fleeing France.

1685.title: Edict of Potsdam
1685.summary: Frederick William welcomes persecuted Huguenots from France to resettle in Brandenburg.

1686.title: Threat to Boycott in Madras
1686.summary: In Madras, local residents employed by the East India Company threatened to boycott their jobs after corporate administrator William Gyfford imposed a house tax. A compromise is reached the next day on the amount of the taxes.

1686.title: Success of the Edict of Fontainebleau
1686.summary: King Louis XIV of France reports the success of the Edict of Fontainebleau against the Protestant Huguenots, with the majority of the Huguenot population having left the country.

1686.title: Campaign Against Indigenous Maya
1686.summary: Spanish Army Captain Melchor Rodríguez Mazariegos leads a campaign to conquer the indigenous Maya people in Guatemala, departing from Huehuetenango.

1686.title: Edict Against the Valdesi
1686.summary: Duke Victor Amadeus II issues an edict against the Protestant Valdesi, setting a deadline for members to renounce their beliefs or face banishment or death, after the Valdesi decline to obey.

1686.title: Enforcement of Edict Against Valdesi
1686.summary: Duke Victor Amadeus dispatches a force of 9,000 French and Piedmontese soldiers to enforce the edict against the Protestant Valdesi in Savoy.

1686.title: Reforms for Swedish Church Law
1686.summary: Sweden's Council of State endorses reforms proposed by King Charles XI for the Swedish Church Law, confirming rights of the Lutheran Church and literacy regulations for children.

1686.title: Removal of Governor of Danish West Indies
