1686.summary: Gabriel Milan, the controversial Governor of the Danish West Indies, is removed from office and placed under arrest for treason, later to be beheaded.

1686.title: Hudson Bay Expedition
1686.summary: A group of French Canadian soldiers begins the Hudson Bay expedition to take control of properties of British North American settlers of the Hudson's Bay Company.

1686.title: Treaty of Perpetual Peace
1686.summary: The Treaty of Perpetual Peace is signed between the Tsardom of Russia and the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth, recognizing territories and bringing Russia into the Great Turkish War.

1686.title: Battle of Buda
1686.summary: In the Great Turkish War, Imperial forces of the Holy League liberate Buda from Ottoman Turkish rule, ending Ottoman rule in Hungary.

1687.title: Release of Prisoners in Savoy
1687.summary: Victor Amadeus III releases 3,847 surviving prisoners who had been converted to Catholicism and permits them to emigrate to Switzerland.

1687.title: Appointment of Lord Deputy of Ireland
1687.summary: Richard Talbot is appointed as the last Lord Deputy of Ireland, but later loses his position with the removal of King James II.

1687.title: Murder of Denis Hobry
1687.summary: Midwife Mary Hobry murders her husband Denis in a sensational case that ends in her conviction and execution.

1687.title: Arjeplog Blasphemy Trial
1687.summary: Erik Eskilsson and Amund Thorsson are acquitted in a trial resisting conversion to Christianity.

1687.title: East India Company Attacks
1687.summary: Troops under Job Charnock destroy Nawab Shaista Khan's fortresses in Bengal during preparations for war.

1687.title: Declaration of Indulgence in Scotland
1687.summary: King James VII issues the Declaration of Indulgence, establishing freedom of religion in the British Isles.

1687.title: Murder of La Salle
1687.summary: Explorer Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle is murdered by members of his own crew in Texas during a mutiny.

1687.title: Higashiyama becomes Emperor
1687.summary: Emperor Higashiyama succeeds Emperor Reigen on the throne of Japan.

1687.title: Battle of Mohács
1687.summary: The Habsburg army defeats the Ottoman Turks in a significant battle, leading to the conquest of Hungary.

1687.title: Earthquake in Peru
1687.summary: An estimated 8.7 magnitude earthquake strikes off the coast of Peru, causing widespread death and destruction in coastal cities.

1688.title: Arrival of French pirate in Nicaragua
1688.summary: Fleeing from the Spanish Navy, French pirate Raveneau de Lussan and his 70 men arrive on the west coast of Nicaragua, sink their boats, and make a difficult 10 day march to the city of Ocotal.

1688.title: First Englishmen in Australia
1688.summary: Pirates Charles Swan and William Dampier and the crew of the privateer Cygnet become the first Englishmen to set foot on the continent of Australia.

1688.title: Capture of Patta and Avandha Forts
1688.summary: The Patta Fort and the Avandha Fort are captured from the Maratha clan by Mughal Army commander Matabar Khan.

1688.title: Surrender of Palanok Castle
1688.summary: Ilona Zrínyi, who has defended the Palanok Castle in Hungary from Austrian Imperial forces since 1685, is forced to surrender to General Antonio Caraffa.

1688.title: Proclamation by King James II
1688.summary: King James II of England and Scotland issues a proclamation offering amnesty to pirates in the West Indies who surrender to Sir Robert Holmes.

1688.title: Arrival of French Jesuit scientists in China
1688.summary: Six French Jesuit scientists arrive in Beijing and are welcomed by the Emperor of China, Kangxi.

1688.title: Assassination of Abaza Siyavuş Pasha
1688.summary: Abaza Siyavuş Pasha, the Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire, is assassinated by the Janissaries after the new Sultan fails to make payment of an expected bonus.

1688.title: First performance of David et Jonathas
1688.summary: The French opera David et Jonathas, composed by Marc-Antoine Charpentier, is performed for the first time.

1688.title: Great fire in Bungay, England
1688.summary: A great fire devastates Bungay, England.

1688.title: Earthquake in southern Italy
1688.summary: A 7.0 magnitude earthquake strikes southern Italy and kills at least 10,000 people in the Kingdom of Naples.

1689.title: Glorious Revolution in England
1689.summary: The Convention Parliament meets to decide the fate of King James II after his flight to France, ultimately agreeing on a settlement regarding the throne.

1689.title: Captivity of James II in Ireland
1689.summary: James II lands with French support in Ireland seeking to reclaim the throne during the Williamite War, facing significant resistance.

1689.title: Battle of Killiecrankie
1689.summary: Scottish supporters of William III defeat Jacobite forces, marking a pivotal event in the First Jacobite Rising.

1689.title: Siege of Derry begins
1689.summary: James II begins a siege of Derry in an attempt to regain support from the Catholic majority during the Williamite War.

1689.title: Battle of Bantry Bay
1689.summary: A naval battle occurs during the Williamite War, where French forces protect their supplies from the English Royal Navy.

1689.title: Act of Toleration passed
1689.summary: The Convention Parliament passes the Act of Toleration, promoting Protestant rights while excluding Roman Catholics in England.

1689.title: Election of Pope Alexander VIII
1689.summary: The papal conclave elects Alexander VIII as Pope, marking a significant change in the Catholic leadership.

1689.title: Siege of Larache ends
1689.summary: The Spanish troops surrender to Moroccan forces in the Siege of Larache, signaling a turning point in the region.

1689.title: Great Siberian Road decree
1689.summary: Peter the Great orders the construction of the Great Siberian Road to establish better connections with China.

1689.title: Bill of Rights receives royal assent
1689.summary: The Bill of Rights is enacted in England, establishing constitutional monarchy and limiting the powers of the crown.

1690.title: Ottoman victory at Kačanik Gorge
1690.summary: The Ottoman Empire defeats Serbian rebels and Austrian troops in battle at Kačanik Gorge, prompting more than 30,000 Serb refugees to flee northward from Kosovo, Macedonia and Sandžak to the Austrian Empire.

1690.title: Prince Joseph named King of the Romans
1690.summary: At the age of 11 years old, Prince Joseph, son of Leopold I, Holy Roman Emperor, is named as King of the Romans, the next in line to become the Emperor.

1690.title: First recorded full peal rung
1690.summary: The first recorded full peal is rung, at St Sepulchre-without-Newgate in the City of London, marking a new era in change ringing.

1690.title: Schenectady massacre
1690.summary: The Schenectady massacre takes place in the village of Schenectady in the colony of New York, when 200 Frenchmen, Mohawk and Algonquin warriors kill or capture most of the inhabitants in retaliation for the Lachine massacre.

1690.title: Performance of Orphée
1690.summary: The opera Orphée by Louis Lully receives its first performance at the Académie Royale de Musique (the Paris Opera).

1690.title: Battle of Beachy Head
1690.summary: The Anglo-Dutch navy is defeated by the French, giving rise to fears of a Jacobite invasion of England.

1690.title: Founding of Sutanuti
1690.summary: In India, the fort and trading settlement of Sutanuti is founded on the Hooghly River by the English East India Company, following the signing of an Anglo-Mughal treaty.

1690.title: Release of the first performance of Énée et Lavinie
1690.summary: The opera Énée et Lavinie by the French composer Pascal Collasse receives its first performance at the Académie Royale de Musique (the Paris Opera).

1690.title: First authorized paper money in Western World
1690.summary: The General Court of the Province of Massachusetts Bay creates the first authorized paper money issued by any government in the Western World as a substitute for coins.

1690.title: Earthquake in the Eastern Alps
1690.summary: A destructive earthquake in the Eastern Alps causes 24 casualties and results in damage in the Villach, Carinthia area.

1691.title: King William III departs to the Netherlands
1691.summary: King William III of England, who rules Scotland and Ireland as well as being the Stadtholder of the Dutch Republic, departs from Margate to tend to the affairs of the Netherlands.

1691.title: Spanish Navy invasion at Hispaniola
1691.summary: A fleet of ships carrying 827 Spanish Navy sailors and marines arrives at Manzanillo Bay on Hispaniola and joins 700 Spanish cavalry to invade the French side of the island.

1691.title: Louis XIV's prohibition on games of chance
1691.summary: King Louis XIV of France issues an order prohibiting play of games of chance, specifically naming basset and similar games, penalizing offenders.

1691.title: Establishment of Coahuila y Tejas
1691.summary: Spanish colonial administrator Domingo Terán de los Ríos is assigned to administer a new province that governs lands on both sides of the Río Bravo del Norte, becoming the first Governor of Texas.

1691.title: First paper money in North America
1691.summary: The Massachusetts Bay Colony issues the first paper money in North America, following a law authorizing its printing.

1691.title: Annular solar eclipse
1691.summary: An annular solar eclipse is visible across the Philippines, North Borneo, and eastern Sumatra.

1691.title: Siege of Mons
1691.summary: French troops besiege the Spanish-held town of Mons during the Nine Years' War, leading to significant military movements in Europe.

1691.title: Public Security Police Force of Macau founded
1691.summary: The Public Security Police Force of Macau is founded, marking a significant establishment in public safety and governance.

1691.title: First performance of King Arthur
1691.summary: The first performance takes place of the semi-opera King Arthur with a libretto by John Dryden and music by Henry Purcell, a notable cultural event.

1691.title: Treaty of Limerick signed
1691.summary: The Treaty of Limerick, ending the Williamite War in Ireland and guaranteeing civil rights to Roman Catholics, is signed, impacting the political landscape.

1692.title: Candlemas Massacre
1692.summary: At least 75 residents of York, Maine are killed by French soldiers and indigenous allies during King William's War.

1692.title: Firing of John Churchill
1692.summary: English Army General John Churchill is fired from all of his jobs on orders of Mary II of England.

1692.title: Massacre of Glencoe
1692.summary: Forces of Robert Campbell slaughter around 40 members of the Clan MacDonald of Glencoe for delaying an allegiance oath to King William III.

1692.title: Annular Solar Eclipse
1692.summary: An annular solar eclipse is visible across Russia, Mongolia, Xinjiang, Iran, and Afghanistan.

1692.title: Beginning of Salem Witch Trials
1692.summary: The Salem witch trials begin with the charging of 3 women with witchcraft in Salem Village.

1692.title: Edict of Toleration
1692.summary: The Kangxi Emperor issues the Edict of Toleration recognizing all members of the Roman Catholic Church in China.

1692.title: Performance of The Fairy-Queen
1692.summary: The first performance of The Fairy-Queen by Henry Purcell takes place in London.

1692.title: Battle of Barfleur
1692.summary: The Anglo-Dutch fleet breaks the French line off the Cotentin Peninsula, thwarting a French invasion plan.

1692.title: Jamaica Earthquake
1692.summary: An earthquake and tsunami destroy Port Royal, Jamaica, killing approximately 2,000 people.

1692.title: Salem Witch Trials First Execution
1692.summary: Bridget Bishop becomes the first victim executed during the Salem witch trials.

1693.title: Mount Etna Volcano Eruption
1693.summary: The Mount Etna volcano erupts in Italy, causing a devastating earthquake that kills 60,000 people in Sicily and Malta.

1693.title: Total Lunar Eclipse
1693.summary: A total lunar eclipse is visible across North and South America.

1693.title: Royal Charter of College of William & Mary
1693.summary: The College of William & Mary in Williamsburg, Virginia is granted a Royal charter.

1693.title: First Women's Magazine Published
1693.summary: The publication of the first women's magazine, titled The Ladies' Mercury, takes place in London.

1693.title: Bozoklu Mustafa Pasha Becomes Grand Vizier
1693.summary: Bozoklu Mustafa Pasha becomes the new Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire, appointed by Sultan Ahmed II.

1693.title: Execution of Anne Palles
1693.summary: Anne Palles becomes the last accused witch to be executed for witchcraft in Denmark.

1693.title: Creation of the Order of Saint Louis
1693.summary: The Order of Saint Louis, the first medal to be awarded in France to military personnel who are not members of nobility, is created by order of King Louis XIV.

1693.title: Ivorian Pot HMS Windsor Castle Wrecked
1693.summary: The 90-gun English Royal Navy warship HMS Windsor Castle is wrecked beyond repair on the Goodwin Sands.

1693.title: First Performance of Opera Didon
1693.summary: The first performance of the opera Didon by French composer Henri Desmarets takes place at the Théâtre du Palais-Royal in Paris.

1693.title: Battle of Marsaglia
1693.summary: Battle of Marsaglia near Turin in the Duchy of Savoy: A French force defeats the Savoyard forces, with significant casualties.

1694.title: Death of Francesco Morosini
1694.summary: Francesco Morosini, the Doge of Venice since 1688, dies after ruling the Republic for more than five years and a few months after an unsuccessful attempt to capture the island of Negropont from the Ottoman Empire during the Morean War.

1694.title: Escape of Sir James Montgomery
1694.summary: Sir James Montgomery of Scotland, who had been arrested on January 11 for conspiracy to restore King James to the throne, escapes and flees to France.

1694.title: Kiev Academy Recognition
1694.summary: The Kiev Academy, now the national university of Ukraine, receives official recognition by Tsar Ivan V of Russia.

1694.title: Debut of Pirro e Demetrio
1694.summary: Pirro e Demetrio, an opera by Alessandro Scarlatti, is given its first performance, debuting at the Teatro San Bartolomeo in Naples, and later becomes popular in London.

1694.title: Jean-Baptiste Labat in the New World
1694.summary: French missionary Jean-Baptiste Labat arrives in the New World, landing at the Caribbean island of Martinique.

1694.title: Loss of Ridderschap van Holland
1694.summary: The ship Ridderschap van Holland is lost at sea after departing the Cape of Good Hope, with a crew of 300, on its way to Batavia.

1694.title: Destruction of Quilombo dos Palmares
1694.summary: The colony of Quilombo dos Palmares in Brazil is destroyed by the bandeirantes, leading to the flight and eventual capture of its last King, Zumbi.

1694.title: Election of Silvestro Valier
1694.summary: Silvestro Valier is elected as the new Doge of Venice to replace the late Francesco Morosini.

1694.title: HMS Sussex wreck
1694.summary: The HMS Sussex treasure fleet of thirteen ships is wrecked in the Mediterranean off Gibraltar, resulting in approximately 1,200 lives lost.

1694.title: Colonial Conflict over Tunisia
1694.summary: The Army of Algeria captures Tunis, the capital of Tunisia, after a siege of three months, ending the Tunisian–Algerian War.

1695.title: Death of Queen Mary II
1695.summary: The United Kingdom's last joint monarchy ends with the death of Queen Mary at the age of 32.

1695.title: Capture of HMS Nonsuch
1695.summary: The Royal Navy warship HMS Nonsuch is captured by the French privateer Le Francois near England's Isles of Scilly.

1695.title: Milan's Court Theater Fire
1695.summary: Milan's Court Theater is destroyed in a fire.

1695.title: Capture of French Warships
1695.summary: A flotilla of Royal Navy warships captures two French warships after they mistake the English fleet for merchants.

1695.title: Succession of Mustafa II
1695.summary: Mustafa II succeeds his uncle, Ahmed II as Sultan of the Ottoman Empire.

1695.title: Funeral of Queen Mary II
1695.summary: The funeral of Queen Mary II takes place, accompanied by music written for the occasion by Henry Purcell.

1695.title: Battle of Sant Esteve d'en Bas
1695.summary: Most French Army soldiers in a column are killed or captured in the battle against a smaller Spanish force during the War of the Grand Alliance.

1695.title: Expulsion of John Trevor
1695.summary: John Trevor is expelled from the English House of Commons for accepting a bribe.

1695.title: Lifting of the Licensing Order
1695.summary: The decision not to renew the Licensing Order creates a more open society with an explosion of print.

1695.title: Siege of Namur begins
1695.summary: The Siege of Namur begins in the Spanish Netherlands, marking a significant military event of the Nine Years' War.

1696.title: The Recoinage Act
1696.summary: The Recoinage Act, passed by the Parliament of England to pull counterfeit silver coins out of circulation, becomes law.

1696.title: HMS Royal Sovereign Fire
1696.summary: In England, the ship HMS Royal Sovereign catches fire and burns at Chatham, after 57 years of service.

1696.title: Peter the Great Becomes Sole Tsar
1696.summary: Peter the Great becomes the sole Tsar of Russia when his half-brother, Tsar Ivan V, dies at the age of 29.

1696.title: Assassination Plot Foiled
1696.summary: A plot to ambush and assassinate King William III of England is foiled when the King cancels his usual return route.

1696.title: Execution of Robert Charnock
1696.summary: Robert Charnock, arrested for the Jacobite plot, is hanged at the Tower of London.

1696.title: Russo-Turkish War Campaign
1696.summary: Russia begins the second of the Azov campaigns in the ongoing Russo-Turkish War.

1696.title: Fire in Gondar
1696.summary: A fire destroys the Gra Bet of Gondar, capital of Ethiopia, starting in the house of a prostitute and destroying many buildings.

1696.title: Second Pueblo Revolt
1696.summary: A second Pueblo Revolt occurs in Santa Fe de Nuevo México, with Indigenous groups attacking and killing Spanish civilians and priests.

1696.title: Foundation of the Imperial Russian Navy
1696.summary: The Imperial Russian Navy is founded on the recommendation of Tsar Peter the Great and approval by the Russian Duma.

1696.title: House of Commons Conviction
1696.summary: The House of Commons in England approves the bill of attainder to convict Sir John Fenwick of high treason for plotting against King William III.

1697.title: Thomas Aikenhead hanged for blasphemy
1697.summary: Thomas Aikenhead is hanged outside Edinburgh, becoming the last person in Great Britain to be executed for blasphemy.

1697.title: Release of Mother Goose tales
1697.summary: French writer Charles Perrault releases the book Histoires ou contes du temps passé, a collection of popular fairy tales, in Paris.

1697.title: Spanish conquest of Guatemala
1697.summary: Martín de Ursúa y Arizmendi and soldiers arrive at Lake Petén Itzá and begin the Spanish conquest of Guatemala.

1697.title: Grand Embassy of Peter the Great
1697.summary: Tsar Peter the Great of Russia sets out to travel in Europe incognito as Artilleryman Pjotr Mikhailov.

1697.title: Fall of Nojpetén
1697.summary: The Spanish conquest of Petén and of Yucatán is completed with the fall of Nojpetén, the last independent Maya state.

1697.title: Charles XII becomes king of Sweden
1697.summary: Charles XII becomes king of Sweden at age 14 on the death of his father, Charles XI.

1697.title: Siege of Barcelona ends
1697.summary: The Siege of Barcelona ends in Spain after 52 days as Louis Joseph, Duke of Vendôme obtains the surrender of Barcelona.

1697.title: Battle of Zenta
1697.summary: Prince Eugene of Savoy crushes the Ottoman army effectively ending Turkish hopes of recovering lost ground in Hungary.

1697.title: Signing of Treaty of Ryswick
1697.summary: The Treaty of Ryswick is signed by France and the Grand Alliance, ending the Nine Years' War and King William's War.

1697.title: Coronation of King Charles XII of Sweden
1697.summary: The coronation ceremony takes place for King Charles XII of Sweden.

1698.title: Treaty of Abenaki tribe and Massachusetts colonists
1698.summary: The Abenaki tribe and Massachusetts colonists sign a treaty, ending the conflict in New England.

1698.title: Fire at the Palace of Whitehall
1698.summary: The Palace of Whitehall in London, England is destroyed by fire.

1698.title: George Louis becomes Elector of Hanover
1698.summary: George Louis becomes Elector of Hanover upon the death of his father, Ernest Augustus, positioning him to become King of Great Britain.

1698.title: William Kidd becomes an outlaw
1698.summary: William Kidd, who initially seized foreign ships under authority as a privateer, becomes an outlaw after capturing an Indian ship near India.

1698.title: Fall of Gingee Fort
1698.summary: The Maratha Empire fort at Gingee falls after a siege by the Mughal Empire as King Rajaram escapes to safety.

1698.title: Foundation of the Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge
1698.summary: The Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge is founded by clergyman Thomas Bray and others in London.

1698.title: Total solar eclipse in Central America
1698.summary: A total solar eclipse is visible in central America, attracting significant attention.

1698.title: Banishment Act of 1697
1698.summary: The Banishment Act goes into effect for Roman Catholic church officials in Ireland, enforcing strict regulations for clergy.

1698.title: Launch of HMS Hastings
1698.summary: The British Royal Navy ship HMS Hastings, a 32-gun fifth rate, is launched, advancing naval technology.

1698.title: Earthquake in Ecuador
1698.summary: An earthquake of magnitude 7.2–7.9 damages an extended region around Ambato, Ecuador, causing significant casualties.

1699.title: Batavia Earthquake
1699.summary: A violent earthquake damages the city of Batavia on the Indonesian island of Java, killing at least 28 people.

1699.title: Treaty of Karlowitz
1699.summary: The Republic of Venice, Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth and Holy Roman Empire sign the Treaty of Karlowitz with the Ottoman Empire, marking an end to the major phase of the Ottoman–Habsburg wars.

1699.title: Streltsy Uprising Executions
1699.summary: A group of 350 rebels in the Streltsy Uprising are executed in Moscow.

1699.title: First Publication of Edinburgh Gazette
1699.summary: The Edinburgh Gazette is first published in Scotland.

1699.title: Expulsion of Jews from Lübeck
1699.summary: Jews are expelled from Lübeck, Germany.

1699.title: First Performance of Amadis de Grèce
1699.summary: The first performance of Amadis de Grèce, an opera by French composer André Cardinal Destouches, takes place at the Académie Royale de Musique, Paris.

1699.title: Creation of the Khalsa
1699.summary: The 10th Sikh guru, Guru Gobind Singh, creates the Khalsa at Anandpur Sahib.

1699.title: Founding of Fort Maurepas
1699.summary: Pierre Le Moyne d'Iberville founds the first European settlement in the Mississippi River Valley, at Fort Maurepas.

1699.title: Demonstration of First Steam Pump
1699.summary: Thomas Savery demonstrates his first steam pump to the Royal Society of London.

1699.title: Signing of the Treaty of Preobrazhenskoye
1699.summary: The Treaty of Preobrazhenskoye, negotiated by Johann Patkul, is signed by representatives to provide for the partition of Swedish Empire.

1700.title: Protestant nations adopt Gregorian calendar
1700.summary: Protestant nations in Western Europe, except England, start using the Gregorian calendar, aligning with Catholic nations that have used it since 1582.

1700.title: Cascadia earthquake
1700.summary: A megathrust earthquake of magnitude 8.7–9.2 occurs in the Pacific Northwest, causing a tsunami that strikes Japan.

1700.title: Lesser Great Fire
1700.summary: The Lesser Great Fire destroys a substantial part of central Edinburgh, Scotland.

1700.title: Great Northern War begins
1700.summary: The Great Northern War begins with a joint invasion of Swedish territory by Denmark and Poland/Saxony to challenge Sweden's power.

1700.title: Discovery of New Britain
1700.summary: William Dampier discovers the island of New Britain in the western Pacific.

1700.title: Sweden adopts Gregorian calendar
1700.summary: Protestant Germany and Denmark–Norway adopt the Gregorian calendar, transitioning from the Julian calendar.

1700.title: The Way of the World first performed
1700.summary: William Congreve's comedy The Way of the World is first performed in London, marking a significant moment in English literature.

1700.title: Coronation of King Frederick IV
1700.summary: The coronation of King Frederick IV of Denmark takes place at Frederiksborg Castle.

1700.title: Siege of Sajjangad begins
1700.summary: An army led by Fateullahakhan begins the siege of the fortress of Sajjangad in Maharashtra, India.

1700.title: Foundation of the Prussian Academy of Sciences
1700.summary: The Prussian Academy of Sciences is founded with Gottfried Leibniz as its president, marking an important development in science and education.

1701.title: Adoption of the Gregorian calendar
1701.summary: Parts of the Netherlands adopt the Gregorian calendar.

1701.title: Kingdom of Prussia proclaimed
1701.summary: The electorate of Brandenburg-Prussia becomes the Kingdom of Prussia, as Elector Frederick III is proclaimed King Frederick I.

1701.title: Assembly of the 5th Parliament of King William III
1701.summary: The 5th Parliament of King William III is assembled, future Prime Minister Robert Walpole enters the Parliament of England.

1701.title: Formation of Mecklenburg-Strelitz
1701.summary: Mecklenburg-Strelitz is created as a north German duchy.

1701.title: Seppuku of Asano Naganori
1701.summary: In Japan, the young daimyō Asano Naganori is ordered to commit seppuku, leading to plans for his revenge.

1701.title: Hanging of Captain William Kidd
1701.summary: Captain William Kidd is hanged in London after being convicted of murder and piracy.

1701.title: Passage of the Act of Settlement 1701
1701.summary: The Act of Settlement 1701 is passed by the Parliament of England to exclude the Catholic Stuarts from the British monarchy.

1701.title: Battle of Carpi
1701.summary: The Battle of Carpi, the first skirmish in the War of the Spanish Succession, takes place in Italy.

1701.title: Great Peace of Montreal signed
1701.summary: The Great Peace of Montreal is signed, ending 100 years of war between the Iroquois Confederacy and New France.

1702.title: Total Solar Eclipse
1702.summary: A total solar eclipse is visible from the southern Pacific Ocean.

1702.title: Foundation of Fort Louis de la Mobile
1702.summary: Ships from Fort Maurepas arrive at Twenty-Seven Mile Bluff to build Fort Louis de la Mobile, which becomes the capital of French Louisiana.

1702.title: Death of King William III of England
1702.summary: King William III of England is fatally injured in an accident and dies 16 days later. His death leads to a significant change in the monarchy.

1702.title: Earthquake in Calore Valley
1702.summary: An earthquake in the middle of the Calore valley in Italy kills 400 people.

1702.title: Crowning of Princess Anne Stuart
1702.summary: Princess Anne Stuart ascends the thrones of England, Scotland, and Ireland following the death of William III, marking a critical point in British history.

1702.title: Publication of The Daily Courant
1702.summary: The first regular English-language national newspaper, The Daily Courant, begins publication on Fleet Street in London, covering foreign news.

1702.title: Capture of Merestein
1702.summary: The Dutch East India Company ship Merestein strikes rocks and sinks in Saldanha Bay, resulting in significant loss of life.

1702.title: Eruption of Changbaishan
1702.summary: A significant volcanic eruption of Changbaishan volcano takes place, impacting the surrounding environments.

1702.title: Discovery of Comet C/1702 H1
1702.summary: Comet C/1702 H1 is discovered, passing very close to Earth, sparking interest in astronomy.

1702.title: War of the Spanish Succession Declared
1702.summary: War is declared on France by the Grand Alliance, consisting of England, the Dutch Republic, and the Holy Roman Empire.

1703.title: Destruction of Port Royal
1703.summary: The Jamaican town of Port Royal, a center of trade in the Western Hemisphere and, at the time, the largest city in the Caribbean, is destroyed by a fire.

1703.title: Norcia Earthquake
1703.summary: The magnitude 6.7 Norcia earthquake affects Central Italy with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI, resulting in a death toll of 6,240–9,761.

1703.title: Montereale Earthquake
1703.summary: The magnitude 6.2 Montereale earthquake causes damage in several towns in Central Italy, with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII.

1703.title: Assassination of Kira Yoshinaka
1703.summary: In Japan, Forty-seven rōnin assassinate daimyō Kira Yoshinaka in an act of revenge.

1703.title: L'Aquila Earthquake
1703.summary: The magnitude 6.7 L'Aquila earthquake affects Central Italy, with damage reaching as far as Rome and resulting in at least 2,500 deaths.

1703.title: Siege of Kehl
1703.summary: French forces capture the fortress of the Holy Roman Empire at Kehl during the War of the Spanish Succession.

1703.title: Recruiting Act 1703
1703.summary: The Recruiting Act 1703 goes into effect in England, allowing forcible enlistment into the English Army and Royal Navy.

1703.title: Court Case of Rose v Royal College of Physicians
1703.summary: The landmark English court case of Rose v Royal College of Physicians is decided, ending the monopoly of the Royal College over medical practice.

1703.title: Foundation of Saint Petersburg
1703.summary: The city of Saint Petersburg, Russia is founded following Peter the Great's reconquest of Ingria from Sweden during the Great Northern War.

1703.title: Great Storm of 1703
1703.summary: A cyclone strikes the British Isles, destroying buildings and killing thousands at sea; the storm severely damages southern England.

1704.title: Apalachee Massacre
1704.summary: English colonists and their native allies stage brutal raids against the Apalachee population in Spanish Florida.

1704.title: Establishment of First African-American School
1704.summary: Elias Neau establishes the first school open to African-Americans in New York City.

1704.title: Raid on Deerfield
1704.summary: French Canadians and Native Americans sack Deerfield, killing over 50 English colonists during Queen Anne's War.

1704.title: Battle of Biskupice
1704.summary: Hungarians win a costly victory over the Danes in the Battle of Biskupice.

1704.title: First Regular Newspaper in Thirteen Colonies
1704.summary: The Boston News-Letter, the first regular newspaper in the Thirteen Colonies, is published.

1704.title: Vigorous Activity from Mount Vesuvius
1704.summary: Significant volcanic activity is recorded from Mount Vesuvius, affecting surrounding areas.

1704.title: Capture of Gibraltar
1704.summary: Gibraltar is captured from Spain by English and Dutch forces during the War of the Spanish Succession.

1704.title: Battle of Blenheim
1704.summary: Allied troops under John Churchill defeat the Franco-Bavarian army in one of the major battles of the War of the Spanish Succession.

1704.title: Twelfth Siege of Gibraltar
1704.summary: French and Spanish troops begin the siege of Gibraltar, a key event in the ongoing War of the Spanish Succession.

1704.title: Battle of Chamkaur
1704.summary: During the Mughal-Sikh Wars, Sikh Khalsa defeats a Mughal army in the Battle of Chamkaur.

1705.title: Almira
1705.summary: George Frideric Handel's first opera is premiered in Hamburg.

1705.title: The Hester
1705.summary: A British 28-gun sailing ship with a crew of 70 is lost in Persia.

1705.title: Twelfth Siege of Gibraltar
1705.summary: The siege begins as French and Spanish forces attempt to control Gibraltar.

1705.title: Nero
1705.summary: George Frideric Handel's opera premieres in Hamburg.

1705.title: Alien Act 1705
1705.summary: Queen Anne gives royal assent to the Alien Act 1705 affecting Scotland and England.

1705.title: Pact of Genoa
1705.summary: A military alliance is signed between England and Catalonia during the War of Spanish Succession.

1705.title: First Javanese War of Succession
1705.summary: Pakubuwono I becomes the new Sultan of Martaram on the island of Java.

1705.title: Capitol Building
1705.summary: The Capitol Building is completed in Williamsburg, capital of the Colony of Virginia.

1705.title: The Treaty of Warsaw
1705.summary: The treaty is concluded between the Swedish Empire and a faction in Poland during the Great Northern War.

1705.title: Sendlinger Mordweihnacht
1705.summary: Militiamen are killed in Munich during a failed attempt to capture a depot.

1706.title: War of Spanish Succession: Bavarian Uprising
1706.summary: The uprising by Bavarians against the occupation of the Electorate of Bavaria by Austrian troops ends after 75 days, and ends the plans of Maximilian, the Elector of Bavaria, to bring Bavaria under the rule of the House of Wittelsbach.

1706.title: Great Northern War: Battle of Grodno
1706.summary: A coalition of 34,000 Swedish and Polish troops besieges the then-Lithuanian city in the winter time, and clashes with 41,000 Russian and Saxon troops. After almost three months of fighting that lasts to April 10, Sweden takes control of the city.

1706.title: Incorporation of Albuquerque
1706.summary: The city of Albuquerque, New Mexico, is incorporated by governor Don Francisco Cuervo y Valdes as La Villa de Alburquerque in the Spanish colonial province of Santa Fe de Nuevo México in New Spain.

1706.title: Great Northern War: Battle of Fraustadt
1706.summary: Outnumbered more than 4 to 1 in infantry troops, Swedish troops under the command of General Carl Gustaf Rehnskiöld defeat a larger force of 20,000 Russian and Saxon infantry and cavalry.

1706.title: Execution of Mary Channing
1706.summary: Mary Channing, who was pregnant at the time that she was convicted of the murder of her husband, is burned at the stake at Dorset, in front of a crowd of 10,000 onlookers.

1706.title: Appointment of Tekle Haymanot I
1706.summary: Concluding that Emperor Iyasus I of Ethiopia has abdicated by retiring to a monastery, a council of high officials appoint Tekle Haymanot I Emperor of Ethiopia.

1706.title: End of the Courts of Catalonia
1706.summary: The last Courts (parliament) of the Principality of Catalonia are finished; their dissolution is presided over by King Charles III of Spain.

1706.title: Battle of Grodno Ends
1706.summary: The Battle of Grodno ends with a Swedish victory over Russian troops.

1706.title: Siege of Barcelona
1706.summary: After a siege of 14 days, a French and Spanish army retakes control of Barcelona, which had been captured by England's army in 1705.

1706.title: Eclipse of the Sun
1706.summary: A total eclipse of the Sun takes place and is visible in most of Europe, with a path crossing modern-day Spain, France, Germany, Poland, and Russia.

1707.title: Last recorded eruption of Mount Fuji
1707.summary: The last recorded eruption of Mount Fuji begins in Japan.

1707.title: Crowning of John V
1707.summary: John V is crowned King of Portugal and the Algarves in Lisbon.

1707.title: Ratification of the Treaty of Union
1707.summary: The Treaty of Union, of the two Kingdoms of Scotland and England, is ratified by the Parliament of Scotland.

1707.title: Beheading of Otto von Paykull
1707.summary: General Otto von Paykull of Swedish Livonia is beheaded outside of Stockholm for treason in the Great Northern War.

1707.title: Act of Union with Scotland
1707.summary: The Act of Union with Scotland is ratified by the Parliament of England.

1707.title: Battle of Almansa
1707.summary: The Bourbon army defeats the allied forces at the Battle of Almansa during the War of the Spanish Succession.

1707.title: Formation of the Kingdom of Great Britain
1707.summary: The Kingdom of England and the Kingdom of Scotland are united as the Kingdom of Great Britain.

1707.title: Siege of Játiva
1707.summary: The siege of Játiva begins, leading to its capture and mass execution of defenders and deportation of residents.

1707.title: Coronation of Bahadur Shah I
1707.summary: Muhammad Mu'azzam is crowned Bahadur Shah I, the new Emperor of India, in Delhi.

1707.title: British Parliament first meets
1707.summary: The Parliament of the Kingdom of Great Britain first meets in London.

1708.title: Charles XII of Sweden invades Russia
1708.summary: Charles XII of Sweden invades Russia, by crossing the frozen Vistula River with 40,000 men.

1708.title: Shahu I becomes Chhatrapati
1708.summary: Shahu I becomes the fifth Chhatrapati of the Maratha Empire in the Indian subcontinent.

1708.title: Launch of HMS Falmouth
1708.summary: HMS Falmouth, a 50-gun fourth-rate ship of the line built at Woolwich Dockyard for the Royal Navy, is launched.

1708.title: Queen Anne withholds Royal Assent
1708.summary: Queen Anne withholds Royal Assent from the Scottish Militia Bill, the last time a British monarch vetoes legislation.

1708.title: First performance of Handel's La resurrezione
1708.summary: The first performance of George Frideric Handel's oratorio La resurrezione takes place in Rome.

1708.title: The Great Hoei fire
1708.summary: The Great Hoei fire breaks out in Kyoto, Japan, destroying the Imperial Palace and a large portion of the old capital.

1708.title: Wager's Action
1708.summary: Wager's Action, a naval confrontation, takes place between a British squadron and the Spanish treasure fleet off Cartagena, resulting in the explosion and sinking of Spanish galleon San José.

1708.title: Battle of Oudenarde
1708.summary: Allied forces under John Churchill defeat the French at the Battle of Oudenarde during the War of the Spanish Succession.

1708.title: Capture of Menorca
1708.summary: Menorca is captured by British forces during the War of the Spanish Succession.

1708.title: Topping out of St Paul's Cathedral
1708.summary: Topping out of new St Paul's Cathedral in London.

1709.title: Battle of St. John's
1709.summary: The French capture St. John's, the capital of the British colony of Newfoundland.

1709.title: Western Europe's Great Frost of 1709
1709.summary: The coldest period in 500 years begins, lasting three months, with massive crop failures and significant casualties in France.

1709.title: Production of Cast Iron
1709.summary: Abraham Darby I successfully produces cast iron using coke fuel at his Coalbrookdale blast furnace in Shropshire, England.

1709.title: Rescue of Alexander Selkirk
1709.summary: Captain Woodes Rogers rescues marooned privateer Alexander Selkirk, inspiring Daniel Defoe's novel Robinson Crusoe.

1709.title: Tokugawa Ienobu Becomes Shōgun
1709.summary: Tokugawa Ienobu becomes the sixth shōgun of the Tokugawa dynasty of Japan after the death of shōgun Tsunayoshi.

1709.title: Production of Hard-Paste Porcelain
1709.summary: Johann Friedrich Böttger reports the first production of hard-paste porcelain in Europe, at Dresden.

1709.title: Battle of Poltava
1709.summary: Peter the Great leads Russian forces to a decisive victory over Sweden, effectively ending Sweden's role as a major power in Europe.

1709.title: Execution of Christopher Slaughterford
1709.summary: Christopher Slaughterford is executed for the murder of Jane Young, marking a historic trial based solely on circumstantial evidence.

1709.title: Founding of Chihuahua City
1709.summary: Chihuahua City in Mexico is founded, contributing to the establishment of Spanish influence in the region.

1709.title: First Performance of Agrippina
1709.summary: The first performance of the opera Agrippina by George Frideric Handel takes place at the Teatro San Giovanni Grisostomo in Venice.

1710.title: Formation of Berlin
1710.summary: In Prussia, Cölln is merged with Alt-Berlin by Frederick I to form Berlin.

1710.title: Escape of Robert Balfour
1710.summary: Robert Balfour, 5th Lord Balfour of Burleigh, escapes from the Edinburgh Tolbooth by exchanging clothes with his sister.

1710.title: Abandonment of Mauritius
1710.summary: Mauritius, a Dutch colony since 1638, is abandoned by the Dutch.

1710.title: Battle of Helsingborg
1710.summary: Fourteen thousand Danish invaders are decisively defeated by an equally large Swedish army.

1710.title: Sacheverell Riots
1710.summary: The Sacheverell riots start in London with an attack on a Presbyterian meeting-house, leading to further riots.

1710.title: Publication of Statute of Anne
1710.summary: The world's first copyright legislation, Britain's Statute of Anne, becomes effective.

1710.title: Battle of Sirhind
1710.summary: An army of 70,000 Sikh rebels defeats a force of Mughal Empire troops near Sirhind in Punjab.

1710.title: Appointment of Numan Pasha
1710.summary: Köprülüzade Numan Pasha becomes the grand vizier of the Ottoman Empire.

1710.title: Battle of Almenar
1710.summary: The Battle of Almenar takes place in the Iberian theatre of the War of the Spanish Succession.

1710.title: Siege of Port Royal
1710.summary: British forces conduct the successful Siege of Port Royal against a French garrison, marking the start of British control of Nova Scotia.

1711.title: Cary's Rebellion
1711.summary: The Lords Proprietor appoint Edward Hyde to replace Thomas Cary as the governor of the North Carolina portion of the Province of Carolina, leading to armed conflict.

1711.title: Premiere of Tamerlano
1711.summary: The first performance of Francesco Gasparini's most famous opera Tamerlano takes place at the Teatro San Cassiano in Venice, showcasing cultural advancement.

1711.title: Mardi Gras Parade
1711.summary: French settlers celebrate Mardi Gras in Mobile, Alabama, marking the first Mardi Gras parade in America.

1711.title: Lunar Eclipse
1711.summary: A total lunar eclipse occurs, drawing attention from astronomers and the public alike.

1711.title: Rinaldo Premieres
1711.summary: Rinaldo by George Frideric Handel, the first Italian opera written for the London stage, premieres at the Queen's Theatre, signaling a shift in musical theater.

1711.title: The Spectator Founded
1711.summary: The Spectator is founded by Joseph Addison and Richard Steele in London, influencing public discourse.

1711.title: Rediscovery of Clipperton Island
1711.summary: French explorers rediscover Clipperton Island and claim it for France, increasing colonial interests.

1711.title: Treaty of the Lutsk
1711.summary: A secret agreement is signed between the Tsardom of Russia and the Ottoman Protectorate of Moldavia, impacting regional power dynamics.

1711.title: Collapse of Elgin Cathedral
1711.summary: The central tower of Elgin Cathedral collapses, causing a significant loss to Scottish heritage.

1711.title: Death of Joseph I
1711.summary: Joseph I, Holy Roman Emperor dies, complicating the ongoing War of the Spanish Succession.

1712.title: Total eclipse of the sun
1712.summary: Total eclipse of the sun visible from 60°36′S 49°12′E.

1712.title: Premiere of Idoménéee
1712.summary: The premiere of the opera Idoménéee by André Campra takes place at the Théâtre du Palais-Royal in Paris.

1712.title: Military engineering school established
1712.summary: A military engineering school is established in Moscow which is to become the A.F. Mozhaysky Military-Space Academy.

1712.title: Ringing of the Old Pummerin
1712.summary: The Old Pummerin, a 18,161 kg bell newly installed in St. Stephen's Cathedral in Vienna, is rung for the first time.

1712.title: Huilliche uprising
1712.summary: Huilliche people in Chile's Chiloé Archipelago rise up against Spanish encomenderos as vengeance for perceived injustices.

1712.title: Start of Cassard expedition
1712.summary: Start of the Cassard expedition, a sea voyage by French Navy captain Jacques Cassard during which he ransacks various islands, returning to France with loot worth over nine million francs.

1712.title: Scottish Episcopalians Act
1712.summary: Scottish Episcopalians Act 1711 comes into effect, leading to incorporation of the Scottish Episcopal Church.

1712.title: Queen Anne administers Royal touch
1712.summary: Anne, Queen of Great Britain administers the Royal touch for the last time; 300 scrofulous people are touched, the last of whom is Samuel Johnson.

1712.title: New York Slave Revolt
1712.summary: An insurrection in New York City results in nine whites being killed, and 21 slaves and other blacks being convicted and executed.

1712.title: Battle of Fladstrand
1712.summary: The Battle of Fladstrand takes place at sea near Fladstrand, Jylland, between Swedish and Danish forces during the Great Northern War.

1713.title: Tuscarora War Begins
1713.summary: Colonel James Moore leads the Carolina militia out of Albemarle County in a second offensive against the Tuscarora, facing heavy snows.

1713.title: Skirmish at Bender
1713.summary: Charles XII of Sweden is defeated by the Ottoman Empire in a skirmish near Bender, Moldova.

1713.title: King Frederick William I of Prussia
1713.summary: Frederick William I of Prussia begins his reign, marking a significant change in leadership.

1713.title: Fall of Fort Neoheroka
1713.summary: Colonel James Moore's Carolina militia successfully lays siege to Fort Neoheroka, ending the Tuscarora nation's military strength.

1713.title: Treaty of Utrecht
1713.summary: The First Treaty of Utrecht is signed between Great Britain and Spain, recognizing Philip V as king of Spain and ceding Gibraltar and Menorca to Britain.

1713.title: Second Treaty of Utrecht
1713.summary: The Second Treaty of Utrecht ends the War of the Spanish Succession, with France ceding multiple territories to Great Britain.

1713.title: First Performance of Cato
1713.summary: Joseph Addison's influential play Cato, a Tragedy, is performed in London, impacting political thought.

1713.title: Asiento de Negros Agreement
1713.summary: The Spanish Crown agrees to a 30-year monopoly for a British company on the supply of African slaves to colonial Spanish America as part of the Treaty of Utrecht.

1713.title: Death of the Irish Parliament
1713.summary: Queen Anne dissolves the Parliament of Ireland, setting new elections that will greatly change the political landscape.

1713.title: Victor Amadeus crowned King of Sicily
1713.summary: Victor Amadeus, Duke of Savoy, is crowned King of Sicily, following Spain's recognition of Sicilian independence as part of a treaty.

1714.title: Blinding of Prince Azz-ud-din Mirza
1714.summary: After being tricked into deserting a battle against India's Mughal Empire by the rebel Sayyid brothers, Prince Azz-ud-din Mirza is blinded on orders of the Emperor Farrukhsiyar as punishment.

1714.title: Fall of Tönning
1714.summary: The Siege of Tönning ends after almost a year, as Danish forces force the surrender of the remaining 1,600 defenders. The fortress is then leveled by the Danes.

1714.title: Compulsory Education Decree
1714.summary: Russia's Tsar Peter the Great issues a decree requiring compulsory education in mathematics for children of government officials and nobility, applying to children between the ages of 10 and 15 years old.

1714.title: Battle of Storkyro
1714.summary: The Battle of Storkyro is fought between troops of the Swedish Empire and the Russian Empire, resulting in heavy casualties for the outnumbered Swedish forces.

1714.title: Treaty of Rastatt
1714.summary: The Treaty of Rastatt is signed between Austria and France, concluding the War of the Spanish Succession. Austria receives Spanish territories in Italy.

1714.title: Peace Treaties of Utrecht
1714.summary: France signs five separate treaties to end hostilities in the War of the Spanish Succession following the negotiations of the Peace of Utrecht.

1714.title: Performance of Bach's Cantata
1714.summary: Johann Sebastian Bach leads the first performance of his cantata for Pentecost, Erschallet, ihr Lieder, BWV 172, at the chapel of Schloss Weimar.

1714.title: Longitude Prize
1714.summary: The Parliament of Great Britain votes to offer a reward for discovering the Longitude, with various monetary rewards based on precision.

1714.title: Victory at Gangut
1714.summary: The Imperial Russian Navy gains its first important victory against the Swedish Navy in the Battle of Gangut.

1714.title: Coronation of George I
1714.summary: The coronation of George I of Great Britain and Ireland takes place in Westminster Abbey, a little less than three months after he became the new monarch.

1715.title: Fire in London
1715.summary: A fire in London described as the worst since the Great Fire of London starts on Thames Street when fireworks prematurely explode in the house of Mr. Walker, consuming more than 100 houses before it is controlled.

1715.title: Voting for British House of Commons
1715.summary: Voting begins for the British House of Commons, continuing for the next 46 days in different constituencies on different days.

1715.title: Tuscarora War Peace Treaty
1715.summary: The Tuscarora and their allies sign a peace treaty with the Province of North Carolina, agreeing to move to a reservation near Lake Mattamuskeet, effectively ending the Tuscarora War.

1715.title: British House of Commons Election Results
1715.summary: Voting for the British House of Commons concludes with the Whig Party winning 341 of the 558 seats, reducing the Tory Party's share to 217 seats.

1715.title: James Stuart meets Pope Clement XI
1715.summary: James Stuart, the Old Pretender, meets with Pope Clement XI seeking assistance for the Jacobite rising against the British throne.

1715.title: Flight of Henry St John
1715.summary: Henry St John, 1st Viscount Bolingbroke, flees from Great Britain to France due to suspicion by the Whig government after secret negotiations related to the Treaty of Utrecht.

1715.title: Battle of Gurdas Nangal
1715.summary: The Battle of Gurdas Nangal begins during the Mughal-Sikh Wars in India as the Mughal Army lays siege to Sikh General Banda Singh Bahadur and his men.

1715.title: Yamasee War begins
1715.summary: The Yamasee Confederation attacks English settlements in South Carolina, marking the beginning of the two-year long Yamasee War.

1715.title: Battle of Fehmarn
1715.summary: The Battle of Fehmarn takes place in the Baltic Sea as part of the Great Northern War, where Denmark captures Swedish ships.

1715.title: Total solar eclipse
1715.summary: A total solar eclipse is seen across southern England, Sweden, and Finland, marked by English astronomer Edmond Halley's observation of Baily's beads.

1716.title: Application of the Nueva Planta Decrees
1716.summary: The application of the Nueva Planta decrees to Catalonia makes it subject to the laws of the Crown of Castile, abolishing the Principality of Catalonia as a political entity and concluding the unification of Spain under Philip V.

1716.title: Tugaloo Massacre
1716.summary: The Tugaloo massacre changes the course of the Yamasee War, allying the Cherokee nation with the British province of South Carolina against the Creek Indian nation.

1716.title: Burning of Crieff
1716.summary: The town of Crieff, Scotland, is burned to the ground by Jacobites returning from the Battle of Sheriffmuir.

1716.title: 1716 Algiers Earthquake
1716.summary: The 1716 Algiers earthquake sequence began with an Mw 7.0 mainshock that caused severe damage and killed 20,000 in Algeria.

1716.title: Execution of Jacobite Leaders
1716.summary: Jacobite leaders James Radclyffe, 3rd Earl of Derwentwater, and William Gordon, 6th Viscount of Kenmure are executed in London after the failed Jacobite rising.

1716.title: Aurora Borealis
1716.summary: An aurora borealis was seen throughout Europe, from Ireland to Italy.

1716.title: Invasion of Norway
1716.summary: King Charles XII of Sweden leads an invasion of Norway, crossing the border at Basmo, near the modern-day town of Marker.

1716.title: Jesuit Mission to Tibet
1716.summary: Italian Jesuit missionary Ippolito Desideri arrives in Lhasa to become one of the first Europeans to attempt to bring Christianity to Buddhist Tibet.

1716.title: Sikh Khalsa Rebellion Execution
1716.summary: In India, 600 imprisoned members of the failed Sikh Khalsa rebellion against the Mughal Empire are executed on orders of Emperor Farrukhsiyar.

1716.title: Siege of Temeşvar
1716.summary: The fortified city of Temeşvar is surrendered by the Turks to the Austrians after a six-week siege during the war between the Habsburg Empire and the Ottoman Empire.

1717.title: Count Carl Gyllenborg's Arrest
1717.summary: Count Carl Gyllenborg, the Swedish ambassador to the Kingdom of Great Britain, is arrested in London over a plot to assist the Pretender to the British throne, James Francis Edward Stuart.

1717.title: The Triple Alliance
1717.summary: The kingdoms of Great Britain, France and the Dutch Republic sign the Triple Alliance, in an attempt to maintain the Treaty of Utrecht.

1717.title: The Silent Sejm
1717.summary: The Silent Sejm, in the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth, marks the beginning of the Russian Empire's increasing influence and control over the Commonwealth.

1717.title: James Stuart's Refuge
1717.summary: Following the treaty between France and Britain, the Pretender James Stuart leaves France, and seeks refuge with Pope Clement XI.

1717.title: Northeastern U.S. Blizzards
1717.summary: What becomes the northeastern United States is paralyzed by a series of blizzards that bury the region.

1717.title: First Ballet in Britain
1717.summary: Dancer John Weaver performs in the first ballet in Britain, shown at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, The Loves of Mars and Venus.

1717.title: Whydah Gally Wreck
1717.summary: The Whydah Gally, flagship of Black Sam Bellamy, is wrecked in a storm off Wellfleet, Massachusetts, with a reputed treasure on board, and all but two of her crew are lost.

1717.title: Viceroyalty of New Granada
1717.summary: Spain creates the Viceroyalty of New Granada in South America from the northern section of the Viceroyalty of Peru.

1717.title: The Modern Grand Lodge
1717.summary: The Premier Grand Lodge of England, the Modern and first Free-Masonic Grand Lodge, is founded in London.

1717.title: Water Music Premiere
1717.summary: Water Music by George Frederick Handel is first performed, on a Thames barge in London.

1718.title: Beheading of Shah Inayat Shaheed
1718.summary: In India, Sufi rebel leader Shah Inayat Shaheed from Sindh who had led attacks against the Mughal Empire, is beheaded days after being tricked into meeting with the Mughals to discuss peace.

1718.title: Jeremias III becomes Ecumenical Patriarch
1718.summary: Jeremias III reclaims his role as the Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople, chief leader within the Eastern Orthodox Church, 16 days after the Metropolitan Cyril IV of Pruoza had engineered an election to become the Patriarch.

1718.title: Death of Victor Amadeus
1718.summary: The reign of Victor Amadeus over the principality of Anhalt-Bernburg ends after 61 years and 7 months. He is succeeded by his son Karl Frederick.

1718.title: Manuel II becomes King of Kongo
1718.summary: Manuel II becomes the new monarch of the Kingdom of Kongo when King Pedro IV dies after a reign of 22 years. Manuel reigns until 1743.

1718.title: Anton Florian becomes Prince of Liechtenstein
1718.summary: Anton Florian becomes the new Prince of Liechtenstein, succeeding Joseph Wenzel.

1718.title: First smallpox vaccination in Britain
1718.summary: Edward Wortley Montagu, the four-year-old son of the British Ambassador to Turkey, becomes the first British person to be inoculated with the smallpox vaccine, administered by Dr. Charles Maitland at the request of Edward's mother.

1718.title: Treaty of Baden signed
1718.summary: The Treaty of Baden is signed, ending the Toggenburg War.

1718.title: 7.5 earthquake in Tongwei County
1718.summary: A 7.5 earthquake shakes Tongwei County in China, killing 73,000 people.

1718.title: Battle of Cape Passaro
1718.summary: A Spanish fleet is defeated by the British Royal Navy under Admiral George Byng, off Capo Passero, Sicily, a prelude to the War of the Quadruple Alliance.

1718.title: Stede Bonnet's capture
1718.summary: Stede Bonnet and his crew are captured near the mouth of the Cape Fear River and taken to Charleston, South Carolina, where they are tried for piracy.

1719.title: Carolean Death March
1719.summary: A catastrophic retreat by a largely-Finnish Swedish-Carolean army under the command of Carl Gustaf Armfeldt across the Tydal mountains in a blizzard kills around 3,700 men and cripples a further 600 for life.

1719.title: Creation of the Principality of Liechtenstein
1719.summary: The Principality of Liechtenstein is created, within the Holy Roman Empire.

1719.title: Recognition of Ulrika Eleonora
1719.summary: The Riksdag of the Estates recognizes Ulrika Eleonora's claim to the Swedish throne, after she has agreed to sign a new Swedish constitution.

1719.title: Signing of the first Treaty of Stockholm
1719.summary: The first Treaty of Stockholm is signed, marking an important diplomatic agreement.

1719.title: Deposition of Farrukhsiyar
1719.summary: Farrukhsiyar, the Mughal Emperor of India, is deposed by the Sayyid brothers who install Rafi ud-Darajat in his place; Farrukhsiyar is later strangled by assassins.

1719.title: Earthquake in El Salvador
1719.summary: A serious earthquake results in large fractures, liquefaction zones, and a sulphuric gas leak, destroying houses and churches.

1719.title: Coronation of Ulrika Eleonora
1719.summary: The coronation of Ulrika Eleonora as Queen of Sweden takes place in Stockholm.

1719.title: Invasion of the Basque provinces
1719.summary: The French army invades the Basque provinces of Spain, with 20,000 troops crossing into Navarre.

1719.title: Publication of Robinson Crusoe
1719.summary: Daniel Defoe publishes Robinson Crusoe, which becomes a significant literary work.

1719.title: Battle of Ösel Island
1719.summary: A Russian naval force defeats the Swedish fleet in a crucial naval engagement during the Great Northern War.

1720.title: Treaty of Stockholm
1720.summary: Sweden and Prussia sign the Treaty of Stockholm, contributing to the conclusion of the Great Northern War.

1720.title: Appointment of Edmond Halley
1720.summary: Edmond Halley is appointed as Astronomer Royal for England, marking a significant advancement in astronomy.

1720.title: Treaty of The Hague
1720.summary: The Treaty of The Hague is signed, ending the War of the Quadruple Alliance between Spain, Britain, France, Austria, and the Dutch Republic.

1720.title: Battle of Nassau
1720.summary: Spanish forces assault the British settlement of Nassau, Bahamas during the War of the Quadruple Alliance.

1720.title: Abdication of Queen Ulrika Eleonora
1720.summary: Queen Ulrika Eleonora of Sweden resigns to let her husband Frederick I take over as king, marking a significant political change.

1720.title: Coronation of King Frederick I
1720.summary: The coronation of King Frederick I of Sweden takes place in Stockholm, solidifying his rule over Sweden.

1720.title: The South Sea Bubble reaches peak
1720.summary: The phenomenal growth of the South Sea Company reaches its peak, leading to significant economic speculation.

1720.title: Treaty of Frederiksborg
1720.summary: The Treaty of Frederiksborg is signed, ending the Great Northern War between Denmark-Norway and Sweden.

1720.title: Stock Market Crash
1720.summary: The English stock market crashes as the South Sea Bubble bursts, affecting many investors across Europe.

1720.title: Assassination of Sayyid Hussain Ali Khan Barha
1720.summary: Sayyid Hussain Ali Khan Barha, a powerful figure in the Mughal Empire, is assassinated, leading to political instability in India.

1721.title: Collapse of the South Sea Company
1721.summary: The Committee of Inquiry on the collapse of the South Sea Company in Great Britain publishes its findings.

1721.title: Death of James Stanhope
1721.summary: James Stanhope, chief minister of Great Britain, dies a day after collapsing while vigorously defending his government's conduct over the South Sea Bubble in Parliament.

1721.title: Completion of Brandenburg Concertos
1721.summary: Johann Sebastian Bach's Brandenburg concertos are completed, and dedicated to Christian Ludwig of Brandenburg-Schwedt.

1721.title: First British Prime Minister
1721.summary: Robert Walpole becomes the first Prime Minister of Great Britain, although this is more a term of disparagement at this time.

1721.title: Boston smallpox outbreak
1721.summary: The deadliest outbreak of smallpox in the history of Boston begins when the British ship HMS Sea Horse arrives in Boston Harbor.

1721.title: Pirate capture of Nossa Senhora do Cabo
1721.summary: Pirates John Taylor and Olivier Levasseur capture the 700-ton Portuguese galleon Nossa Senhora do Cabo at Réunion.

1721.title: Papal succession
1721.summary: Pope Innocent XIII succeeds Pope Clement XI, as the 244th pope.

1721.title: Inoculation campaign in Boston
1721.summary: Dr. Zabdiel Boylston begins the first public inoculation campaign to slow the smallpox epidemic in Boston.

1721.title: Sack of Shamakhi
1721.summary: The Sack of Shamakhi occurs in the Persian Safavid Empire.

1721.title: Sign of the Treaty of Nystad
1721.summary: The Treaty of Nystad is signed, ending the Great Northern War.

1722.title: Moll Flanders publication
1722.summary: Daniel Defoe's novel Moll Flanders is published anonymously.

1722.title: Battle of Cape Lopez
1722.summary: The Battle of Cape Lopez begins, leading to the end of piracy by Bartholomew Roberts, resulting in numerous pirate captures.

1722.title: Peter the Great's announcement
1722.summary: Peter the Great announces that his heir will be his 4-year old grandson, Prince Pyotr Alekseivich.

1722.title: Nizam-ul-Mulk Appointed
1722.summary: Nasir-ud-Din Muhammad Shah names Nizam-ul-Mulk as his Grand Vizier, a turning point for India's Mughal empire.

1722.title: Battle of Gulnabad
1722.summary: The Pashtun people defeat Persian forces, leading to the fall of the Safavid dynasty in Persia.

1722.title: Silence Dogood Letters
1722.summary: Benjamin Franklin's Silence Dogood letter is printed, marking an important moment in American literature.

1722.title: Rusty-Persian War Begins
1722.summary: The Russo-Persian War starts as Peter the Great leads a campaign in Persia.

1722.title: Atterbury Plot Arrest
1722.summary: Bishop Francis Atterbury is arrested for treason, accused of plotting against the British throne.

1722.title: The Great Hurricane of 1722
1722.summary: New Orleans is struck by a devastating hurricane, causing immense destruction to public buildings.

1722.title: Death of the Kangxi Emperor
1722.summary: Kangxi Emperor dies after a 61-year reign, succeeded by his son Yinzhen as Yongzheng Emperor.

1723.title: Edward Low attacks the Portuguese ship Nostra Signiora de Victoria
1723.summary: English-born pirate Edward Low intercepts the Portuguese ship and orders the captain's brutal torture and execution after the captain throws his treasure into the sea.

1723.title: Beginning of the Yongzheng Era
1723.summary: The Kangxi Era ends and the Yongzheng Era begins with the coronation of Yinzhen, the Yongzheng Emperor in Qing dynasty China.

1723.title: King Louis XV attains his majority
1723.summary: King Louis XV of France attains his majority, ending the regency of his cousin Philippe II, Duke of Orléans, on his 13th birthday.

1723.title: The Mapuche Uprising begins
1723.summary: The Mapuche Uprising begins in Chile as indigenous Mapuche people attack the city of Tucapel, commanded by Toqui Vilumilla.

1723.title: Capture of Rasht by the Russian Empire
1723.summary: The capture of Rasht from the Persian Empire brings Rasht and the Gilan Province under Russian control.

1723.title: Attempt for Vaud's independence
1723.summary: Major Abraham Davel attempts to make the canton of Vaud independent of the Swiss government but is arrested and beheaded after failing.

1723.title: The Black Act 1723 enforced
1723.summary: The Black Act 1723 comes into force in Great Britain, expanding the number of crimes punishable by death to combat illegal hunting.

1723.title: Bach's first new cantata performance
1723.summary: Johann Sebastian Bach assumed the office of Thomaskantor in Leipzig, presenting his first new cantata, Die Elenden sollen essen.

1723.title: Baku surrenders to Russians
1723.summary: Baku surrenders to the Russian forces during the Russo-Persian War.

1723.title: Treaty of Saint Petersburg signed
1723.summary: The Treaty of Saint Petersburg is signed, ending the Russo-Persian War from 1722 to 1723.

1724.title: King Philip V abdicates the throne
1724.summary: King Philip V of Spain abdicates the throne in favour of his 16-year-old son Louis I.

1724.title: Fortuyn departs for Batavia
1724.summary: The Dutch East India Company cargo ship Fortuyn departs from the Cape of Good Hope in South Africa, and is never seen again.

1724.title: Establishment of Saint Petersburg State University
1724.summary: Saint Petersburg State University is established in Russia, marking a significant advancement in education.

1724.title: Catherine I is named tsaritsa
1724.summary: Catherine I of Russia is officially named tsaritsa by her husband, Peter the Great, solidifying her position in the Russian monarchy.

1724.title: Premiere of Giulio Cesare
1724.summary: The premiere of Giulio Cesare, an Italian opera by George Frideric Handel, takes place in London, showcasing significant artistic achievement.

1724.title: Bach leads St John Passion performance
1724.summary: Bach leads the first performance of his St John Passion, crafted with deep musico-theological intent.

1724.title: Creation of the Hyderabad State
1724.summary: The Hyderabad State is created in India, with Mir Qamar-ud-din Khan as the first Nizam, marking a significant political change.

1724.title: The Paris Bourse is created
1724.summary: The Paris Bourse, the stock exchange for France, is created, marking a key development in financial trade.

1724.title: First performance of Handel's Tamerlano
1724.summary: George Frideric Handel's opera Tamerlano is performed for the first time in London, highlighting its lasting cultural significance.

1724.title: Recreation of the Viceroyalty of Zhili
1724.summary: The Viceroyalty of Zhili is recreated in the Chinese Empire by the Emperor Yongzheng, marking an important administrative change.

1725.title: Catherine I becomes Empress of Russia
1725.summary: Catherine I ascends to power following the death of her husband, Peter the Great.

1725.title: First performance of Bach's Wie schön leuchtet der Morgenstern
1725.summary: Bach's chorale cantata is first performed on the Feast of the Annunciation, coinciding with Palm Sunday.

1725.title: Second performance of Bach's St John Passion
1725.summary: The second performance of Bach's St John Passion takes place at St. Thomas Church.

1725.title: The Treaty of Vienna is signed
1725.summary: Charles VI and King Philip V of Spain sign the Treaty of Vienna.

1725.title: The Black Watch is raised
1725.summary: The Black Watch is formed as part of the pacification of the Scottish Highlands.

1725.title: Malt tax riots begin in Scotland
1725.summary: Riots occur in response to increased malt taxes on Scottish brewers and distilleries.

1725.title: Sinking of the Chameau
1725.summary: A ship of the French Navy sinks during a storm, resulting in over 200 deaths.

1725.title: First newspaper in New York
1725.summary: William Bradford introduces the New-York Gazette as the first newspaper in the Province of New York.

1725.title: Astronomical observations begin for stellar parallax
1725.summary: British astronomers set up a telescope to observe the star Gamma Draconis, leading to significant discoveries.

1725.title: The establishment of Freemasonry in France
1725.summary: Freemasonry is established in France as an English import.

1726.title: The Conventicle Act
1726.summary: The Conventicle Act is adopted in Sweden, outlawing all non-Lutheran religious meetings outside of church services.

1726.title: First Treaty of Vienna
1726.summary: The First Treaty of Vienna is signed between Austria, the Holy Roman Empire and Spain, creating the Austro-Spanish Alliance in advance of a war against Great Britain.

1726.title: Maiden Voyage of Aagtekerke
1726.summary: The Dutch East India Company frigate Aagtekerke departs from the Dutch Cape Colony on its journey to the Dutch East Indies and is never seen again.

1726.title: Establishment of Supreme Privy Council
1726.summary: The Supreme Privy Council is established in Russia.

1726.title: End of Mapuche Uprising
1726.summary: The Parliament of Negrete brings an end to the Mapuche uprising of 1723–26.

1726.title: Execution of Catherine Hayes
1726.summary: In London, a night watchman finds a severed head by the River Thames; it is later recognized to be that of the husband of Catherine Hayes, who is later executed.

1726.title: China's Emperor Yongzheng Interrogates Qin Daoran
1726.summary: China's Emperor Yongzheng issues a special edict instructing his Vice Minister of Punishments to interrogate Qin Daoran, who provides evidence of a conspiracy against the Emperor.

1726.title: First Large Shipment of Slaves
1726.summary: The first large shipment of slaves is brought to New Orleans as the slave ship L'Aurore arrives with 290 black Africans captured in Gambia.

1726.title: Establishment of Fort São João Batista
1726.summary: King Haffon of the Kingdom of Whydah allows Portuguese traders to build Fort São João Batista in the capital, leading to increased European competition for trade in slaves.

1726.title: Publication of Gulliver's Travels
1726.summary: Jonathan Swift's satirical novel Gulliver's Travels is first published anonymously in London; it sells out within a week.

1727.title: Thirteenth Siege of Gibraltar
1727.summary: Spain's ambassador to Great Britain demands that the British return Gibraltar after accusing Britain of violating the terms of the 1713 Treaty of Utrecht. Britain refuses and the Thirteenth Siege of Gibraltar begins.

1727.title: Foundation of Charité Hospital
1727.summary: The world-famous Charitè Hospital is established in Berlin, to be used for research and to help the poor. Prussia's King Frederick William I had ordered the conversion of a 16-year old institution.

1727.title: Enthronement of Abd el-Sayed of Egypt
1727.summary: Abd el-Sayed of Egypt is enthroned, as Pope John XVII of Alexandria becomes the leader of the Coptic Christian Church.

1727.title: Premiere of Bach's Ich habe genug
1727.summary: Johann Sebastian Bach's solo cantata, Ich habe genug, BWV 82, premieres in Leipzig.

1727.title: Handel becomes British subject
1727.summary: German composer George Frideric Handel becomes a British subject.

1727.title: Siege of Gibraltar ends
1727.summary: Britain's Royal Navy begins a blockade of Spanish ports and the unsuccessful siege ends with the signing of a truce on June 24.

1727.title: Battle of Halidzor
1727.summary: Battle of Halidzor in Armenia: A small group of defenders overcomes a much larger Ottoman Empire army.

1727.title: Conquest of the Kingdom of Xwéda
1727.summary: The Kingdom of Dahomey, ruled by King Trudo Agaja, conquers and annexes the Kingdom of Xwéda.

1727.title: Death of Sultan Ismail Ibn Sharif
1727.summary: After 55 years as Sultan of Morocco, Ismail Ibn Sharif dies at the age of 81, prompting a 30-year battle between seven of his sons, for succession to the throne.

1727.title: George II becomes King
1727.summary: George, Prince of Wales, becomes King George II of Great Britain, on the death of his father.

1728.title: Foundation of the Real y Pontificia Universidad de San Gerónimo de la Habana
1728.summary: The oldest university in Cuba is founded in Havana.

1728.title: Coronation of Peter II
1728.summary: The coronation of Peter II as the Tsar of the Russian Empire takes place in Moscow.

1728.title: Premiere of The Beggar's Opera
1728.summary: The most popular theatrical production of the 18th century is performed for the first time, satirizing Italian opera.

1728.title: Battle of Palkhed
1728.summary: Maratha Peshwa Bajirao I defeats the first Nizam of Hyderabad, Nizam-ul-Mulk.

1728.title: Dispatch of the Congress of Soissons
1728.summary: Negotiations for a treaty between Great Britain and Spain take place in the French town of Soissons.

1728.title: Signing of the Treaty of Kyakhta
1728.summary: The treaty is signed at the border city of Kyakhta between representatives of Russia and China.

1728.title: Foundation of Nuuk
1728.summary: The City of Nuuk is founded in Greenland as Fort Godt-Haab by royal governor Claus Paarss.

1728.title: Copenhagen Fire of 1728
1728.summary: The largest fire in the history of Copenhagen occurs.

1728.title: Maratha Empire's invasion of Mughal Malwa
1728.summary: The Maratha Empire's army invades the Mughal Empire's Malwa province, leading to the Battle of Amjhira.

1728.title: James Bradley's astronomical observations
1728.summary: James Bradley uses stellar aberration to calculate the speed of light and observes nutation of the Earth's axis.

1729.title: Frederick made Prince of Wales
1729.summary: Frederick, the eldest son of King George II of Great Britain, is made Prince of Wales at the age of 21.

1729.title: Marriage of Joseph, Prince of Brazil
1729.summary: At the age of 14, Joseph, Prince of Brazil, is married to the 10-year-old Princess Mariana Victoria of Spain.

1729.title: Royal cedula by King Philip V
1729.summary: King Philip V of Spain issues a royal cedula, directing an effort to encourage families from the Canary Islands to settle in New Spain.

1729.title: Peace treaty in Resht
1729.summary: Russian and Afghani leaders sign a peace treaty in the city of Resht, Persia.

1729.title: Oglethorpe's investigation of British jails
1729.summary: James Oglethorpe begins service as the Chairman of the Gaols Committee to investigate prison conditions in Britain.

1729.title: Abdallah becomes Sultan of Morocco
1729.summary: Abdallah of Morocco becomes the new Sultan upon the death of his half-brother.

1729.title: Canonization of John of Nepomuk
1729.summary: John of Nepomuk is canonized by Pope Benedict XIII, becoming the patron saint of Roman Catholics in the Czech Republic.

1729.title: Premiere of Bach's First Köthen Funeral music
1729.summary: Johann Sebastian Bach's First Köthen Funeral music premieres at St. Jakob, honoring the funeral of Leopold, Prince of Anhalt-Köthen.

1729.title: Bach's St Matthew Passion performed
1729.summary: Bach's St Matthew Passion is performed again at St. Thomas Church, Leipzig.

1729.title: Battle of Damghan
1729.summary: The Battle of Damghan begins between the Persian Safavid Army and rebel Afghan troops.

1730.title: Death of Emperor Peter II
1730.summary: At dawn, Emperor Peter II of Russia dies of smallpox, aged 14 in Moscow, on the eve of his projected marriage.

1730.title: Anna of Russia becomes Empress
1730.summary: Anna of Russia becomes reigning Empress of Russia following the death of her cousin Emperor Peter II.

1730.title: Vitus Bering returns from First Kamchatka expedition
1730.summary: Vitus Bering returns to the Russian capital of Saint Petersburg after completing the First Kamchatka expedition.

1730.title: Papal conclave begins
1730.summary: The 1730 papal conclave to elect a new Pope for the Roman Catholic church begins with 30 Cardinals, 12 days after the death of Pope Benedict XIII.

1730.title: Start of Ottoman–Persian War
1730.summary: General Nader Khan of Persia opens the first campaign of the Ottoman–Persian War, starting the Western Persia Campaign against the Ottoman Empire.

1730.title: Coronation of Anna of Russia
1730.summary: The coronation of Anna of Russia as Empress of Russia takes place in Saint Petersburg.

1730.title: 1730 Valparaíso earthquake
1730.summary: An earthquake with an estimated magnitude of 9.1 strikes Valparaíso, in modern-day Chile but at this time in the Viceroyalty of Peru.

1730.title: Execution of Maria Madlener
1730.summary: Maria Madlener becomes the last person to be executed after the Galgeninsel witch trials in Bavaria, and is beheaded by sword.

1730.title: General Nader Khan captures Tabriz
1730.summary: General Nader Khan of Persia captures Tabriz from the Ottoman Empire, bringing an end to the Western Persia Campaign.

1730.title: Eruption of Lanzarote volcano
1730.summary: A volcano erupts on Lanzarote, the easternmost of the Canary Islands and threatens the Spanish inhabitants.

1731.title: Avalanche in Storfjorden
1731.summary: An avalanche from the Skafjell mountain causes a massive wave in the Storfjorden fjord in Norway that sinks all boats that are in the water and kills people on both shores.

1731.title: Fire at Coudenberg Palace
1731.summary: A significant fire in Brussels destroys the Coudenberg Palace, home of the ruling Austrian Duchess of Brabant, along with important state records.

1731.title: Grain shipment to Shangzhou
1731.summary: Emperor Yongzheng orders grain to be shipped from Hubei and Guangdong to aid the famine-stricken Shangzhou region of Shaanxi province in China.

1731.title: Louise Hippolyte becomes Princess of Monaco
1731.summary: Louise Hippolyte ascends as the second woman to serve as Princess of Monaco after her father's death, ruling for only nine months before dying of smallpox.

1731.title: Treaty of Vienna signed
1731.summary: The Treaty of Vienna is signed between the Holy Roman Empire, Great Britain, the Dutch Republic, and Spain, marking a significant diplomatic agreement.

1731.title: Battle of Dabhoi
1731.summary: The Battle of Dabhoi is fought between Sarsenapati Trimbakrao Dabhade and Bajirao Peshwa in India, marking a significant conflict in the region.

1731.title: Incident prompting War of Jenkins' Ear
1731.summary: British trader Robert Jenkins has his ear cut off by Spanish coast guards at Havana, becoming the casus belli for the War of Jenkins' Ear in 1739.

1731.title: Establishment of the Russian Pacific Fleet
1731.summary: Empress Anna of Russia establishes the Pacific Fleet of the Russian Navy, directing its development as a major port.

1731.title: Fire destroys Blandford Forum
1731.summary: The English market town of Blandford Forum is largely destroyed by fire, with a significant loss of property and livelihood for its residents.

1731.title: First successful appendectomy
1731.summary: The first successful appendectomy is performed by English surgeon William Cookesley, marking a major advance in medical surgery.

1732.title: Treaty of Riascha
1732.summary: Russia and Persia sign the Treaty of Riascha, ending territorial claims by Russia over Persian territories.

1732.title: Swedish East India Company Expedition
1732.summary: The Swedish East India Company begins its first expedition to China from Gothenburg.

1732.title: The Modern Husband Premiere
1732.summary: Henry Fielding's comedy The Modern Husband premieres at the Royal Theatre in London.

1732.title: Herat Campaign
1732.summary: General Nader Shah of Persia suppresses a rebellion in the city of Herat.

1732.title: Maharaja of Mysore
1732.summary: Chamaraja Wodeyar VII becomes the new Maharaja of the Kingdom of Mysore.

1732.title: Danish Asia Company Charter
1732.summary: King Christian VI of Denmark-Norway signs a charter granting a trade monopoly to the Danish Asia Company.

1732.title: Nader Shah Proclamation
