1732.summary: Nader Khan removes Shah Tahmasp II from the throne and proclaims himself King of Persia.

1732.title: Boundary Survey between Pennsylvania and Maryland
1732.summary: Heirs of William Penn and Lord Baltimore survey the boundary between Pennsylvania and Maryland, leading to future disputes.

1732.title: Governor-General of Dutch East Indies
1732.summary: Dirck van Cloon becomes the new Governor-General of the Dutch East Indies.

1732.title: Montreal Earthquake
1732.summary: A magnitude 5.8 earthquake occurs in Montreal, Quebec, causing significant damage.

1733.title: Borommarachathirat V becomes King of Siam
1733.summary: Borommarachathirat V becomes King of Siam upon the death of King Sanphet IX.

1733.title: Premiere of Orlando
1733.summary: George Frideric Handel's classic opera, Orlando is performed for the first time at the King's Theatre in London.

1733.title: Founding of Savannah
1733.summary: British colonist James Oglethorpe founds Savannah, Georgia.

1733.title: Passing of the Molasses Act
1733.summary: The Molasses Act is passed by British House of Commons, reinforcing negative opinions of the British by American colonists.

1733.title: English replaces Latin in courts
1733.summary: English replaces Latin and Law French as the official language of English and Scottish courts.

1733.title: Withdrawal of the excise tax bill
1733.summary: British Prime Minister Robert Walpole withdraws a proposed excise tax bill due to public rioting.

1733.title: Introduction of the canton system
1733.summary: The canton system is first introduced in Prussia.

1733.title: Introduction of the Flying Shuttle
1733.summary: John Kay's Flying Shuttle is introduced, revolutionizing the textile industry.

1733.title: Marriage of Prince Frederick
1733.summary: Prince Frederick of Prussia marries Duchess Elisabeth Christine of Brunswick-Bevern to secure his claim to the throne.

1733.title: Hurricane off Florida Keys
1733.summary: A hurricane wrecks at least 17 Spanish ships off the coast of the Florida Keys.

1734.title: Salzburgers set sail for Georgia
1734.summary: Salzburgers, Lutherans who were expelled by the Roman Catholic Bishop of Salzburg, set sail for the British Colony of Georgia in America.

1734.title: Ostend Company ceases business
1734.summary: The Ostend Company ceases business following Austria's agreement in the Second Treaty of Vienna.

1734.title: Arrival of Salzburgers in Georgia
1734.summary: Salzburgers arrive at the mouth of the Savannah River in the British Colony of Georgia.

1734.title: Easter occurs on latest date
1734.summary: Easter occurs on the latest possible date.

1734.title: Charles III becomes King of Naples
1734.summary: Prince Charles of Spain becomes the new King of Naples and Sicily after his arrival in Naples.

1734.title: Battle of Bitonto
1734.summary: Spanish forces defeat Austrian forces, completing the conquest of the Kingdom of Naples at the Battle of Bitonto.

1734.title: Suppression of slave insurrection
1734.summary: French and Swiss troops suppress the slave insurrection in the Danish West Indies on the island of Saint John.

1734.title: British general election results
1734.summary: The Whigs lose 85 seats but retain their majority in the British general election.

1734.title: Marie-Joseph Angélique hanged
1734.summary: A black slave known as Marie-Joseph Angélique is tortured and hanged by the French authorities in Montreal.

1734.title: Siege of Philippsburg
1734.summary: The Siege of the Austrian fortress of Philippsburg ends as its defenders surrender to the French Army.

1734.title: Sultan Abdu'llah bin Ismail deposed
1734.summary: Abdu'llah bin Ismail as-Samin is deposed after a 15-year reign as Sultan of Morocco.

1734.title: Martial law in Jamaica
1734.summary: Jamaica's Governor declares martial law to fight the slave rebellion and drafts men into the colonial army.

1734.title: Tomochichi's visit to Britain
1734.summary: Chief Tomochichi ends a successful visit to Great Britain, after ceding land to the Georgia Company.

1734.title: Creation of the Dzików Confederation
1734.summary: The Dzików Confederation is created in Poland.

1734.title: Fire at the Royal Alcázar of Madrid
1734.summary: A fire destroys the Royal Alcázar of Madrid along with valuable artworks and documents.

1734.title: Creation of the Kanem–Bornu Empire
1734.summary: The Kanem–Bornu Empire is created after Kanem is taken over by the Sultan of Bornu.

1734.title: Anton Wilhelm Amo's achievement
1734.summary: Anton Wilhelm Amo becomes the first African to receive a doctorate in Europe and begins teaching at the University of Halle.

1735.title: Publication of Epistle to Dr Arbuthnot
1735.summary: Alexander Pope's poem Epistle to Dr Arbuthnot is published in London.

1735.title: Premiere of Ariodante
1735.summary: George Frideric Handel's opera Ariodante is premiered at the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden, London.

1735.title: Shipwreck of Dutch East India Company ships
1735.summary: All 256 people on board the Dutch East India Company ships Vliegenthart and Anna Catherina die when the two ships sink in a gale off of the Netherlands coast.

1735.title: Signing of the Treaty of Ganja
1735.summary: The Russian Empire and Persia sign the Treaty of Ganja, with Russia ceding territories in the Caucasus mountains to Persia.

1735.title: Accession of Emperor Sakuramachi
1735.summary: Emperor Sakuramachi accedes to the throne of Japan.

1735.title: Engraving Copyright Act
1735.summary: In Great Britain, the Engraving Copyright Act 1734 takes effect, marking the start of copyright protection laws.

1735.title: Peace agreement in War of Polish Succession
1735.summary: An agreement between European powers brings a ceasefire in the War of the Polish Succession, leading to a preliminary peace signed in 1738.

1735.title: Casting of Tsar Kolokol
1735.summary: The largest bell in the world, the Tsar Kolokol, is successfully cast in Moscow within the Kremlin.

1735.title: Second successful appendectomy
1735.summary: The second successful appendectomy is performed by British surgeon Claudius Aymand at St George's Hospital in London.

1735.title: Foundation of Augusta, Georgia
1735.summary: Augusta, Georgia, is founded, which later becomes a significant city in American history.

1736.title: George Hamilton becomes Field Marshal
1736.summary: George Hamilton, 1st Earl of Orkney, becomes the Second Field Marshal of Great Britain.

1736.title: Civil Code of 1734 passed
1736.summary: The Civil Code of 1734 is passed in Sweden.

1736.title: Stanislaus I abdicates
1736.summary: Stanislaus I of Poland abdicates his throne.

1736.title: Marriage of Francis I and Maria Theresa
1736.summary: Francis I, Holy Roman Emperor marries Maria Theresa of Austria at the Augustinian Church in Vienna.

1736.title: Nader Shah crowned
1736.summary: Nader Shah is crowned Shah of Iran on a date selected by court astrologers.

1736.title: Founded Bellevue Hospital
1736.summary: Bellevue Hospital is founded in New York.

1736.title: Porteous Riots in Edinburgh
1736.summary: The Porteous Riots erupt in Edinburgh after the execution of smuggler Andrew Wilson.

1736.title: German adventurer crowned King of Corsica
1736.summary: Theodor Stephan Freiherr von Neuhoff is crowned King Theodore of Corsica.

1736.title: Fire in Stony Stratford
1736.summary: A fire in Stony Stratford, England, consumes 53 houses.

1736.title: Battle of Ackia
1736.summary: Battle of Ackia: British and Chickasaw Native Americans defeat French troops.

1737.title: Cession of Tuscany
1737.summary: Spain and the Holy Roman Empire sign instruments of cession at Pontremoli, granting the Empire control of Tuscany and the Grand Duchy of Parma and Piacenza.

1737.title: Secret Military Alliance
1737.summary: The Empires of Austria and Russia enter into a secret military alliance that leads to Austria's entry into the Russo-Turkish War.

1737.title: Peace Treaty in Sulu
1737.summary: A peace treaty is signed in Manila between Spain and the Sultan of Sulu, recognizing his authority over the Sulu Archipelago.

1737.title: First Weather Tree-Ring Study
1737.summary: French scientists publish the first study correlating past weather conditions with an examination of tree rings.

1737.title: Armistice Signed
1737.summary: Spain and Portugal sign an armistice to end the Spanish–Portuguese War over Uruguay and Rio Grande do Sul.

1737.title: Siege of Kandahar Begins
1737.summary: Persian shah Nader Shah begins the 11-month Siege of Kandahar against the Pashtun Emir of Afghanistan.

1737.title: Venus Transit
1737.summary: The planet Venus passes in front of Mercury, observed by amateur astronomer John Bevis at the Royal Greenwich Observatory.

1737.title: Direct Line of Medici Extinct
1737.summary: The direct male line of the Medici family becomes extinct with the death of Gian Gastone de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany.

1737.title: Battle of Banja Luka
1737.summary: Austria's army is defeated by the Ottoman Army and Bosnian defenders in the Battle of Banja Luka.

1737.title: Tropical Cyclone in Bay of Bengal
1737.summary: A tropical cyclone strikes the Bay of Bengal, killing at least 300,000 people and causing significant flooding.

1738.title: Drowning of Slaves on the Leusden
1738.summary: At least 664 African slaves drown when the Dutch West Indies Company slave ship Leusden capsizes and sinks in the Maroni River during its arrival in Surinam.

1738.title: First Performance of Faramondo
1738.summary: George Frideric Handel's opera Faramondo is given its first performance.

1738.title: Battle of Bhopal
1738.summary: After the Maratha Empire of India wins the Battle of Bhopal over the Jaipur State, Jaipur cedes the Malwa territory to the Maratha in a treaty signed at Doraha.

1738.title: Execution of Joseph Süß Oppenheimer
1738.summary: Court Jew Joseph Süß Oppenheimer is executed in Württemberg.

1738.title: Demonstration of The Flute Player
1738.summary: Jacques de Vaucanson stages the first demonstration of an early automaton, The Flute Player at the Hotel de Longueville in Paris.

1738.title: Start of War of Jenkins' Ear
1738.summary: Mariner Robert Jenkins presents a pickled ear to the Parliament of Great Britain, leading to the War of Jenkins' Ear the following year.

1738.title: Premiere of Serse
1738.summary: Serse, an Italian opera by George Frideric Handel, premieres in London.

1738.title: Establishment of Royal Academy of History
1738.summary: Spain's Royal Academy of History is established by decree of King Philip V of Spain.

1738.title: Inauguration of Vaganova Academy
1738.summary: The Imperial Theatrical School, known as Vaganova Academy of Russian Ballet, is founded, being the first ballet school in Russia.

1738.title: Excavation of Herculaneum Begins
1738.summary: The excavation of Herculaneum begins near the Italian city of Resina on orders from King Charles III of Spain.

1739.title: Discovery of Bouvet Island
1739.summary: Bouvet Island is discovered by French explorer Jean-Baptiste Charles Bouvet de Lozier, in the South Atlantic Ocean.

1739.title: Ningxia Earthquake
1739.summary: A 7.6 earthquake shakes the Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region in China killing 50,000 people.

1739.title: Battle of Karnal
1739.summary: The army of Iranian ruler Nader Shah defeats the forces of the Mughal emperor of India, Muhammad Shah.

1739.title: Occupation of Delhi
1739.summary: Nader Shah occupies Delhi, India and sacks the city, stealing the jewels of the Peacock Throne, including the Koh-i-Noor.

1739.title: Execution of Dick Turpin
1739.summary: English highwayman Dick Turpin is executed by hanging for horse theft.

1739.title: Foundation of the New Room
1739.summary: John Wesley lays the foundation stone of the New Room, Bristol in England, the world's first Methodist meeting house.

1739.title: Foundation of the Royal Swedish Academy
1739.summary: The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences is founded in Stockholm, Sweden.

1739.title: Treaty with the Maratha Empire
1739.summary: The British East India Company signs a treaty with the Maratha Empire to gain the right of free trade within the territory.

1739.title: Retaking of Belgrade
1739.summary: The Ottoman Empire retakes Belgrade from Austria's Habsburg monarchy after winning the Battle of Grocka.

1739.title: Starting of Irish Famine
1739.summary: Months of unseasonably cold weather begin in Ireland, precipitating the Irish Famine of 1740, known as Bliain an Áir.

1740.title: Wreck of the Rooswijk
1740.summary: All 237 crewmen on the Dutch East India Company ship Rooswijk are drowned when the vessel strikes the shoals of Goodwin Sands, off the coast of England.

1740.title: Incorporation of Newton
1740.summary: The North Carolina General Assembly incorporates the town of Newton as Wilmington, North Carolina, named for Spencer Compton, 1st Earl of Wilmington.

1740.title: Treaty of the Miskito
1740.summary: King Edward of the Miskito Indians signs a treaty making his kingdom a protectorate of Great Britain.

1740.title: Construction of Bethesda Orphanage
1740.summary: Construction begins on Bethesda Orphanage for boys near Savannah, Georgia, founded by George Whitefield.

1740.title: Royal Navy captures Princesa
1740.summary: The Royal Navy captures the Spanish ship of the line Princesa off Cape Finisterre during the War of the Austrian Succession.

1740.title: Frederick II becomes King
1740.summary: Frederick II becomes King in Prussia upon the death of his father, Frederick William I.

1740.title: Plantation Act comes into effect
1740.summary: The Plantation Act comes into effect providing for Protestant alien immigrants in the American colonies to receive British nationality.

1740.title: Pour le Mérite first awarded
1740.summary: Pour le Mérite is first awarded in Prussia as a military honour.

1740.title: Siege of Fort Mose
1740.summary: A Spanish column storms Britain's strategically crucial position of Fort Mose, Florida during the War of Jenkins' Ear.

1740.title: First performance of Rule, Britannia!
1740.summary: The song Rule, Britannia! is first performed at Cliveden, the country home of Frederick, Prince of Wales, in England.

1741.title: Lanesborough Township Created
1741.summary: Lanesborough, Massachusetts is created as a township.

1741.title: Balance of Power Speech
1741.summary: Sir Robert Walpole, the Prime Minister of Great Britain, popularizes the term the balance of power in a speech in Parliament.

1741.title: Charles Macklin's Stage Debut
1741.summary: Irish-born actor Charles Macklin makes his London stage debut as Shylock in The Merchant of Venice.

1741.title: Siege of Glogau
1741.summary: Prussian troops bring down the Austrian fortress of Glogau during the War of the Austrian Succession.

1741.title: British Threat to Cartagena
1741.summary: The British Royal Navy takes 180 warships to threaten Cartagena, Colombia, with a large crew against local defenders.

1741.title: New York Slave Insurrection
1741.summary: A plot to set fire to New York City is discovered, known as the New York Slave Insurrection.

1741.title: Battle of Mollwitz
1741.summary: An Austrian army is defeated by Prussian troops of Frederick the Great in the Battle of Mollwitz during the War of the Austrian Succession.

1741.title: Battle of Cartagena de Indias
1741.summary: Spain's defenders defeat the Royal Navy force in the War of Jenkins' Ear, leading to a British retreat.

1741.title: Nader Shah Assassination Attempt
1741.summary: Nader Shah, Emperor of Persia, narrowly escapes an assassination attempt.

1741.title: Crowning of Maria Theresa
1741.summary: Maria Theresa of Austria is crowned Queen Regnant of Hungary in Bratislava.

1742.title: Robert Walpole made Earl of Orford
1742.summary: Robert Walpole is made Earl of Orford, and resigns as First Lord of the Treasury and Chancellor of the Exchequer, effectively ending his period as Prime Minister of Great Britain after serving the longest single term ever.

1742.title: Edmond Halley dies
1742.summary: Edmond Halley dies; James Bradley succeeds him as Astronomer Royal of Great Britain.

1742.title: Charles VII becomes Holy Roman Emperor
1742.summary: Charles VII becomes Holy Roman Emperor.

1742.title: First Silesian War
1742.summary: Troops of the Kingdom of Prussia, Saxony and France capture the Moravian town of Iglau during the First Silesian War, an important conflict of the War of the Austrian Succession.

1742.title: Henry Fielding publishes Joseph Andrews
1742.summary: Henry Fielding publishes his picaresque novel Joseph Andrews anonymously in London when the first edition reaches the bookstalls.

1742.title: Peace of Breslau
1742.summary: Austria cedes Silesia to Prussia as part of the Peace of Breslau agreement, marking a significant territorial change in Europe.

1742.title: Battle of Chotusitz
1742.summary: Frederick the Great's army defeats the Austrians at the Battle of Chotusitz, a pivotal battle in the War of the Austrian Succession.

1742.title: George Frideric Handel's The Messiah performed
1742.summary: George Frideric Handel's oratorio The Messiah is first performed in Dublin, Ireland, contributing to the cultural landscape of the time.

1742.title: Construction of the Foundling Hospital
1742.summary: Construction starts on the Foundling Hospital in London, marking an important development in the care of abandoned children.

1742.title: Foundation of the Royal Danish Academy of Sciences and Letters
1742.summary: The Royal Danish Academy of Sciences and Letters is founded, promoting scholarship and scientific advancement in Denmark.

1743.title: Verendrye brothers see Rocky Mountains
1743.summary: The Verendrye brothers, probably Louis-Joseph and François de La Vérendrye, become the first white people to see the Rocky Mountains from the eastern side.

1743.title: Agreement between Augustus III of Poland and Austria
1743.summary: King Augustus III of Poland signs an agreement with Austria, pledging help in war in return for part of Silesia to be conveyed to Saxony.

1743.title: Peace negotiations between Sweden and Russia
1743.summary: Sweden and Russia begin peace negotiations at Åbo to end the Russo-Swedish War.

1743.title: Premier of Handel's Samson
1743.summary: George Frideric Handel's oratorio, Samson, premieres in London.

1743.title: Battle of La Guaira
1743.summary: A British expeditionary fleet under Sir Charles Knowles is defeated by the Spanish in the Battle of La Guaira.

1743.title: Verendrye brothers bury tablet for King Louis XV
1743.summary: The Verendrye brothers bury a tablet claiming the Great Plains of North America for King Louis XV of France.

1743.title: Prithvi Narayan Shah becomes King
1743.summary: Prithvi Narayan Shah becomes the new King of the Gorkha Kingdom and begins a campaign to unify the principalities in the Himalayas under his rule as part of the unification of Nepal.

1743.title: Battle of Dettingen
1743.summary: British forces defeat a French army in the Battle of Dettingen during the War of the Austrian Succession.

1743.title: Weather observations during lunar eclipse
1743.summary: Benjamin Franklin's view of a lunar eclipse from Philadelphia is spoiled by a rainstorm, highlighting the west-east movement of weather.

1744.title: Battle of Toulon
1744.summary: The British fleet is defeated by a joint Franco-Spanish fleet.

1744.title: Battle of Velletri
1744.summary: Spanish-Neapolitan forces defeat those of the Archduchy of Austria.

1744.title: Siege of Villafranca
1744.summary: A joint French and Spanish force defeats Britain and Sardinia.

1744.title: Second Silesian War
1744.summary: The Prussian Army begins the bombardment of Prague.

1744.title: Declaration of War against the Mi'kmaq and Maliseet
1744.summary: William Shirley announces the declaration of war against the Mi'kmaq and Maliseet Indian tribes.

1744.title: Sink of the HMS Victory
1744.summary: HMS Victory sinks in a storm in the English Channel, killing 1,100 sailors and officers.

1744.title: Foundation of The Female Spectator
1744.summary: The first periodical written for women by a woman is founded by Eliza Haywood in England.

1744.title: French Army at Louisbourg attacks Fort William Augustus
1744.summary: The French Army at Louisbourg attacks the British settlement at Fort William Augustus at Canso, Nova Scotia and forces its surrender.

1744.title: Great Comet of 1744
1744.summary: The Great Comet, one of the brightest ever seen, reaches perihelion.

1744.title: Queen Maria Theresa's Proclamation
1744.summary: Queen Maria Theresa of Austria issues a proclamation to rid Bohemia of its Jewish residents.

1745.title: War of the Austrian Succession: Battle of Amberg
1745.summary: The Austrian Army makes a surprise attack at Amberg and scatters the Bavarian defending troops, then captures the Bavarian capital at Munich.

1745.title: Quadruple Alliance treaty
1745.summary: The Quadruple Alliance treaty is signed at Warsaw by Great Britain, Austria, the Dutch Republic and the Duchy of Saxony.

1745.title: Death of Karl VII Albrecht
1745.summary: The Holy Roman Emperor Karl VII Albrecht dies from gout, leaving Bavaria without an adult ruler.

1745.title: Jamaica Slave Conspiracy Foiled
1745.summary: The ruling white colonial government on the island of Jamaica foils a conspiracy by about 900 black slaves to seize control.

1745.title: Royal Wedding at Versailles
1745.summary: The royal wedding of Crown Prince Louis Ferdinand of France takes place at Versailles with Princess Maria Teresa Rafaela of Spain.

1745.title: Measurement of Earth's Circumference
1745.summary: Pierre Bouguer delivers a report including the first precise measurement of the Earth’s circumference to the French Academy of Sciences.

1745.title: Battle of Pfaffenhofen
1745.summary: The Austrian Army drives the French Army out of Bavaria, leading to Bavaria's withdrawal from the war.

1745.title: Battle of Hohenfriedberg
1745.summary: King Frederick II of Prussia decisively defeats the Austrian and Saxon armies, effectively ending the Second Silesian War.

1745.title: Ewald Georg von Kleist invents Leyden jar
1745.summary: Prussian scientist Ewald Georg von Kleist independently invents the first electrical capacitor to store and discharge electricity.

1745.title: Treaty of Dresden
1745.summary: The Treaty of Dresden gives Prussia full possession of Silesia, concluding significant warfare in the region.

1746.title: Battle of Falkirk Muir
1746.summary: British Government forces are defeated by Jacobite forces.

1746.title: Inauguration of Lake Palace
1746.summary: Jagat Singh II inaugurates his Lake Palace on the island of Jag Niwas in Lake Pichola.

1746.title: Proclamation by Duke of Cumberland
1746.summary: Prince William offers an amnesty to Jacobite participants.

1746.title: Surrender of Brussels
1746.summary: Brussels surrenders to France's Marshal Maurice de Saxe.

1746.title: Massacre of Sikhs
1746.summary: Zakariya Khan Bahadur orders the massacre of the city's Sikh people.

1746.title: Battle of Culloden
1746.summary: The final pitched battle fought on British soil, brings an end to the Jacobite rising of 1745.

1746.title: Capture of Father Joachim Royo
1746.summary: The last of five Spanish missionaries is captured by Chinese authorities.

1746.title: Death of King Philip V of Spain
1746.summary: He dies after a reign of more than 45 years; his son succeeds him.

1746.title: Establishment of College of New Jersey
1746.summary: The College of New Jersey is founded in Princeton, later renamed Princeton University.

1746.title: Earthquake in Lima
1746.summary: An earthquake demolishes Lima and Callao, causing widespread destruction.

1747.title: Opening of the first venereal diseases clinic
1747.summary: The first venereal diseases clinic opens at London Lock Hospital.

1747.title: Battle at Grand-Pré
1747.summary: A combined French and Indian force defeats British troops at Grand-Pré, Nova Scotia.

1747.title: Execution of Simon Fraser
1747.summary: Simon Fraser is beheaded for high treason after being convicted of leading the Jacobite rising against King George II of Great Britain.

1747.title: Ascension of Emperor Momozono
1747.summary: Emperor Momozono ascends to the throne of Japan, succeeding Emperor Sakuramachi.

1747.title: First battle of Cape Finisterre
1747.summary: The British Navy defeats a French fleet in the War of the Austrian Succession.

1747.title: Fall of Bergen op Zoom
1747.summary: The Netherlands city of Bergen op Zoom falls to the Army of France after a 70 day siege during the War of the Austrian Succession.

1747.title: Knowles Riot in Boston
1747.summary: Rioters in Boston protest impressment into the British Royal Navy during the Knowles Riot.

1747.title: Formation of the Pennsylvania Associators
1747.summary: Benjamin Franklin forms the Pennsylvania Associators, the first militia in Pennsylvania.

1747.title: Hurricane sinks British ships
1747.summary: A hurricane in the Caribbean Sea sinks 11 British ships off the coast of Saint Kitts.

1747.title: End of Second Stadtholderless period
1747.summary: Prince William IV of Orange becomes stadtholder of all the United Provinces, marking the end of the Second Stadtholderless period.

1748.title: Ahmad Shah Durrani captures Lahore
1748.summary: Ahmad Shah Durrani captures the city of Lahore, a significant event in the history of the region.

1748.title: Fire at Kinsale Prison
1748.summary: A fire at the prison and barracks in Kinsale, Ireland, kills 54 prisoners and leads to the safe transfer of 500 others.

1748.title: San Gabriel mission project begins
1748.summary: The founding of the first Roman Catholic missions in central Texas under Friar Mariano Marti, marking a notable expansion of religious influence.

1748.title: Mughal forces victorious against Ahmad Shah Durrani
1748.summary: Mughal forces achieve victory near Manupur against Ahmad Shah Durrani's troops, a critical moment in the power dynamics of the region.

1748.title: Great fire in the City of London
1748.summary: A destructive fire in London starts at Change Alley and causes significant damage, leading to increased awareness and development of fire insurance.

1748.title: Siege of Maastricht begins
1748.summary: The French begin a siege on the Dutch fortress of Maastricht as part of the broader War of the Austrian Succession.

1748.title: Fire in Moscow
1748.summary: A catastrophic fire in Moscow results in 482 deaths and the destruction of 5,000 buildings, a major urban disaster.

1748.title: Arrival of Admiral Edward Boscawen in India
1748.summary: Admiral Boscawen arrives with a large fleet to defend Fort St. David from French forces, highlighting naval engagement in colonial conflicts.

1748.title: First Lutheran Church body in America
1748.summary: Establishment of the first Lutheran Church body in America in Philadelphia, marking an important development for the Lutheran community in the New World.

1748.title: Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle signed
1748.summary: The Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle is signed, concluding the War of the Austrian Succession and altering territorial control, especially in India and Canada.

1749.title: New Hampshire Grants
1749.summary: Benning Wentworth issues the first of the New Hampshire Grants, leading to the establishment of Vermont.

1749.title: Berlingske
1749.summary: The first issue of Berlingske, Denmark's oldest continually operating newspaper, is published.

1749.title: Teatro Filarmonico Fire
1749.summary: The Teatro Filarmonico, the main opera theater in Verona, Italy, is destroyed by fire.

1749.title: Fanny Hill Published
1749.summary: The second part of John Cleland's erotic novel Fanny Hill is published in London.

1749.title: The History of Tom Jones Published
1749.summary: Henry Fielding's comic novel The History of Tom Jones is published in London.

1749.title: Corpse Riot
1749.summary: A 'corpse riot' breaks out in Glasgow after a body disappears from a churchyard in the Gorbals district.

1749.title: Handel Conducts Solomon
1749.summary: At London's Covent Garden, composer George Frideric Handel conducts the first performance of his new oratorio, Solomon.

1749.title: HMS Namur Wrecked
1749.summary: British Royal Navy ship HMS Namur is wrecked in a storm near Fort St. David, India, with the loss of 520 lives.

1749.title: Fire in Glasgow
1749.summary: A fire in Glasgow leaves 200 families homeless.

1749.title: Conspiracy of the Slaves Revealed
1749.summary: The Conspiracy of the Slaves, which was to have taken place on June 29, is revealed in Malta.

1750.title: Treaty of Madrid
1750.summary: The Treaty of Madrid between Spain and Portugal authorizes a larger Brazil than had the Treaty of Tordesillas of 1494, which originally established the boundaries of the Portuguese and Spanish territories in South America.

1750.title: Fire in Istanbul
1750.summary: A fire in Istanbul destroys 10,000 homes.

1750.title: Jesuits Evacuated
1750.summary: After Spain and Portugal agree that the Uruguay River will be the boundary line between the two kingdoms' territory in South America, the Spanish Governor orders the Jesuits to vacate seven Indian missions along the river.

1750.title: First Performance Announced
1750.summary: The Murray-Kean Company, a troupe of actors from Philadelphia, gives the first performance of a play announced in advance in a newspaper, presenting Richard III at New York City's Nassau Street Theatre.

1750.title: Maveeran Alagumuthu Kone's Rebellion
1750.summary: Maveeran Alagumuthu Kone, a polygar in Tamil Nadu raise slogans launches a rebellion against Company rule in India due to his opposition to the East India Company's tax collection policies.

1750.title: First Crossing of Cumberland Gap
1750.summary: Dr. Thomas Walker and five other men cross through the Cumberland Gap, a mountain pass through the Appalachian Mountains, to become the first white people to venture into territories that had been inhabited exclusively by various Indian tribes.

1750.title: Slave Ship Rebellion
1750.summary: A group of West African slaves, bound for the Americas, successfully overpowers the crew of the British slave ship Snow Ann, navigates back to Cape Lopez in Gabon.

1750.title: Burning of Beaubassin
1750.summary: The Acadian settlement in Beaubassin, Nova Scotia, is burnt by the French army, and the population is forcibly relocated after an agreement on the new boundary between British Nova Scotia and French Acadia.

1750.title: Riots in Paris
1750.summary: Rioting breaks out in Paris when a rumor spreads that plainclothes policemen are hauling off small children for blood, leading to police reforms after violence ensues.

1750.title: Creation of the Louvre Museum
1750.summary: The Louvre Museum is created in Paris four years after art critic Lafond de Saint-Yenne calls on the King to allow the display of the royal art collection to the general public.

1751.title: Lifting of Slavery Prohibition in Georgia
1751.summary: As the Province of Georgia transitions from a trustee-operated territory to a Crown colony, the Trustees lift the prohibition against slavery.

1751.title: Founding of the University of Pennsylvania
1751.summary: The University of Pennsylvania holds its first classes, aiming to provide non-denominational higher education instead of religious training.

1751.title: First Elected Legislature in Georgia
1751.summary: The American colony of Georgia establishes its first elected legislature, meeting in Savannah with representatives preparing for British colonial status.

1751.title: Beheading of Tibetan Rebels
1751.summary: In Tibet, General Ban Di interrogates and executes seven imprisoned leaders of a rebellion at the guidance of the Qianlong Emperor.

1751.title: Combat between Nizam of Hyderabad and Nawab of Kurnool
1751.summary: In India, a conflict arises between the Nizam of Hyderabad and the Nawab of Kurnool, culminating in a single combat that leads to the Nawab's death.

1751.title: Police Regulations in New Orleans
1751.summary: The Governor of French Louisiana issues the first police regulations for New Orleans to combat crime in the city.

1751.title: Transition to the Gregorian Calendar in Britain
1751.summary: The Calendar Act enacts the transition to the Gregorian calendar in Britain, changing the official New Year's Day to January 1.

1751.title: Death of Frederick, Prince of Wales
1751.summary: Frederick, Prince of Wales, dies at a young age, making his son, Prince George, the heir-apparent to the British throne.

1751.title: Publication of Denis Diderot's Encyclopédie
1751.summary: The first volume of Denis Diderot's Encyclopédie is published, marking a significant achievement in Enlightenment philosophy.

1751.title: Battle of Arnee in the Second Carnatic War
1751.summary: A British-led force defeats a larger Franco-Indian army at the Battle of Arnee, marking a pivotal moment in the Second Carnatic War.

1752.title: Adoption of the Gregorian Calendar
1752.summary: The British Empire adopts January 1 as the first day of the year, completing the transition to the Gregorian calendar established previously by last year's Calendar Act.

1752.title: First Patients at Pennsylvania Hospital
1752.summary: Pennsylvania Hospital, the first hospital in the US, admits its first patients at a temporary location in Philadelphia.

1752.title: Discovery of Messier 83
1752.summary: French astronomer Nicolas-Louis de Lacaille discovers Messier 83, the Southern Pinwheel Galaxy, during a research voyage in the Southern Hemisphere.

1752.title: Law Against Maiming in Virginia
1752.summary: The Virginia Assembly passes a law making maiming a felony, a response to the practice of gouging.

1752.title: Foundation of Konbaung Dynasty
1752.summary: Alaungpaya, a village chief in Upper Burma, founds the Konbaung Dynasty, unifying the country over the next 8 years.

1752.title: Death of Shō Kei
1752.summary: Shō Kei, ruler of Okinawa and the Ryukyu Kingdom, dies and is succeeded by his 12-year-old son.

1752.title: Election of Francesco Loredan as Doge
1752.summary: The electors of the Republic of Venice elect Francesco Loredan as their new executive, the Doge.

1752.title: Publication of Halifax Gazette
1752.summary: The Halifax Gazette, the first Canadian newspaper, is published.

1752.title: Peace Negotiations with Comanche Tribe
1752.summary: Spanish Governor of Santa Fe begins peace negotiations with the Comanche tribe after releasing prisoners.

1752.title: Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice in America
1752.summary: The first presentation of a Shakespearean play in America, The Merchant of Venice, is performed in Williamsburg, Virginia.

1753.title: King Binnya Dala orders burning of Ava
1753.summary: King Binnya Dala of the Hanthawaddy Kingdom orders the burning of Ava, the former capital of the Kingdom of Burma.

1753.title: Elizabeth Canning's abduction claim
1753.summary: Elizabeth Canning returns to her mother's home in London and claims that she was abducted; the following criminal trial causes an uproar.

1753.title: First publication of electrical telegraphy concept
1753.summary: The concept of electrical telegraphy is first published in the form of a letter to Scots' Magazine suggesting an innovative method of conveying intelligence.

1753.title: Sweden adopts the Gregorian calendar
1753.summary: Sweden adopts the Gregorian calendar, by skipping the 11 days difference between it and the Julian calendar.

1753.title: Jewish Naturalisation Act passes House of Lords
1753.summary: The Jewish Naturalisation Act 1753 is passed by Britain's House of Lords, permitting Jewish immigrants to England to become naturalized citizens without receiving the Sacrament of the Lord's Supper.

1753.title: Species Plantarum published
1753.summary: Species Plantarum is published by Linnaeus, marking the formal start date of the scientific classification of plants.

1753.title: British Museum established
1753.summary: The British Museum is established in London by Act of Parliament.

1753.title: First electrocution by Georg Richmann
1753.summary: Russian scientist Georg Richmann becomes the first person to be electrocuted by his own equipment while conducting experiments on thunderstorms and ball lightning.

1753.title: British Cabinet sends warning to colonial governors
1753.summary: After receiving warnings about incursions into land claimed by the Crown Colony of Virginia, the cabinet of British Prime Minister Henry Pelham votes to send a warning to prevent these attempts.

1753.title: George Washington begins his military commission
1753.summary: Virginia Lieutenant Governor Dinwiddie commissions 21-year-old militia Major George Washington to dissuade the French from occupying the Ohio Country.

1754.title: Serendipity Coined
1754.summary: Horace Walpole coins the word serendipity in a letter to Horace Mann.

1754.title: Guarani Attack
1754.summary: The Guarani people stage an attack on a small Brazilian Portuguese settlement at Rio Pardo, starting the Guarani War.

1754.title: Battle Against Pirates
1754.summary: Guatemalan Sergeant Major Melchor de Mencos y Varón defeats British pirates in the Battle of San Felipe and the Cobá Lagoon.

1754.title: Formation of New British Government
1754.summary: Thomas Pelham-Holles, 1st Duke of Newcastle, becomes the new Prime Minister of Great Britain after his brother's death.

1754.title: Clandestine Marriages Act
1754.summary: The Clandestine Marriages Act of 1753 comes into force in England and Wales, establishing statutory marriage.

1754.title: Founding of The Royal and Ancient Golf Club
1754.summary: The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews is founded in Scotland, becoming a key institution in golf.

1754.title: Battle of Jumonville Glen
1754.summary: George Washington leads a militia in an ambush against French Canadians, marking the beginning of the French and Indian War.

1754.title: Surrender at Fort Necessity
1754.summary: George Washington surrenders Fort Necessity to French Captain Louis Coulon de Villiers during the French and Indian War.

1754.title: Founding of Columbia University
1754.summary: Classes begin at Columbia University, originally founded as King's College by royal charter.

1754.title: Earthquake in Constantinople
1754.summary: A powerful earthquake strikes Constantinople, leading to significant destruction and loss of life.

1755.title: Treaty of Giyanti
1755.summary: The kingdom of Mataram on Java is divided in two, creating the sultanate of Yogyakarta and the sunanate of Surakarta.

1755.title: First Use of Steam Engine in American Colonies
1755.summary: A steam engine is used in the American colonies for the first time as New Jersey copper mine owner Arent Schuyler installs a Newcomen atmospheric engine to pump water out of a mineshaft.

1755.title: British Army and Royal Navy Appropriations
1755.summary: Britain's House of Commons votes in favor of £1,000,000 of appropriations to expand British Army and Royal Navy operations in North America.

1755.title: General Braddock Arrives in Virginia
1755.summary: General Edward Braddock and 1,600 British sailors and soldiers arrive at Alexandria, Virginia on transport ships to take command of the British forces against the French.

1755.title: Publication of A Dictionary of the English Language
1755.summary: A Dictionary of the English Language is published by Samuel Johnson after nine years of work.

1755.title: Construction of Fort Duquesne
1755.summary: France completes the construction of Fort Duquesne, which will later be captured by the British during the French and Indian War and renamed Fort Pitt.

1755.title: Defeat in the Braddock Expedition
1755.summary: British troops and colonial militiamen are ambushed and suffer a devastating defeat inflicted by French and Indian forces during the Braddock Expedition.

1755.title: The Expulsion of the Acadians Begins
1755.summary: The Expulsion of the Acadians begins, marking a significant relocation of the Acadian people from Nova Scotia.

1755.title: Lisbon Earthquake
1755.summary: More than 40,000 people are killed by the 8.5 magnitude earthquake in Lisbon, causing a tsunami that strikes the coasts of Portugal, Spain and Morocco.

1756.title: Treaty of Westminster
1756.summary: The Treaty of Westminster is signed between Great Britain and Prussia, guaranteeing the neutrality of the Electorate of Hanover, controlled by King George II of Great Britain.

1756.title: Birth of Mozart
1756.summary: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart was born in Salzburg, Austria.

1756.title: Death of Sepé Tiaraju
1756.summary: The leader of the Guaraní rebels, Sepé Tiaraju, is killed in a skirmish with Spanish and Portuguese troops during the Guaraní War.

1756.title: Massacre of Guaraní rebels
1756.summary: The massacre of the Guaraní rebels at the Jesuit reduction of Caaibaté takes place, resulting in 1,511 dead.

1756.title: Battle of Vijaydurg
1756.summary: The Maratha Navy is destroyed by British attackers in the Battle of Vijaydurg, marking a significant naval defeat for the Maratha Empire.

1756.title: Seven Years' War begins
1756.summary: The Seven Years' War formally begins when Great Britain declares war on France, marking a major conflict in European history.

1756.title: Siege of Fort St Philip
1756.summary: The Siege of Fort St Philip begins when the French besiege the British garrison, setting the stage for more conflict in the Seven Years' War.

1756.title: Battle of Minorca
1756.summary: The British fleet under John Byng is defeated by the French, a pivotal moment in the Seven Years' War.

1756.title: Black Hole of Calcutta incident
1756.summary: A garrison of the British Army in India is imprisoned in the Black Hole of Calcutta, leading to significant political repercussions.

1756.title: Birth of the Marine Society
1756.summary: The Marine Society is founded in London, becoming the world's oldest seafarers' charity.

1757.title: Capture of Calcutta
1757.summary: The British Army, under the command of Robert Clive, captures Calcutta, India.

1757.title: Assassination Attempt on Louis XV
1757.summary: Robert-François Damiens makes an unsuccessful assassination attempt on Louis XV of France, who is slightly wounded by the knife attack.

1757.title: Dismissal of Advisers
1757.summary: King Louis XV of France dismisses his two most influential advisers at the urging of his mistress, Madame de Pompadour.

1757.title: Alliance Against Prussia
1757.summary: Representatives of the Russian Empire and the Austrian Empire enter into an alliance against Prussia, pledging troops.

1757.title: Treaty of Alinagar
1757.summary: The Nawab of Bengal and General Clive sign the Treaty of Alinagar, compensating the British East India Company.

1757.title: Execution of Admiral Byng
1757.summary: British Royal Navy Admiral John Byng is executed by firing squad after his court martial for failing in the Battle of Minorca.

1757.title: Sweden's Alliance with France and Austria
1757.summary: Sweden signs an alliance treaty with France and Austria against King Frederick the Great, agreeing to contribute troops.

1757.title: Battle of Plassey
1757.summary: 3,000 British East India Company troops defeat a 50,000 strong Indian army under Siraj ud-Daulah, marking a significant victory.

1757.title: Hajj Caravan Raid
1757.summary: Bedouin warriors conduct a massive assault against a caravan of Muslim travelers returning to Damascus after the Hajj.

1757.title: Battle of Rossbach
1757.summary: Frederick defeats the French-Imperial army, forcing the French to withdraw from Saxony during the Seven Years' War.

1758.title: Publication of Systema Naturae
1758.summary: Swedish biologist Carl Linnaeus publishes the first volume (Animalia) of the 10th edition of Systema Naturae, introducing binomial nomenclature for animals.

1758.title: Execution of François Mackandal
1758.summary: Former slave turned rebel François Mackandal is executed by the French colonial government in Cap-Haïtien, Haiti.

1758.title: Invasion of East Prussia
1758.summary: Russian troops under William Fermor invade East Prussia and capture Königsberg.

1758.title: British Fleet Departs for North America
1758.summary: A fleet of 158 British warships departs from Plymouth toward North America to conquer French territories in New France.

1758.title: Inoculation Against Smallpox
1758.summary: Jonathan Edwards publicly receives an inoculation against smallpox, but unfortunately develops the disease and dies.

1758.title: Looting of Santa Cruz de San Sabá
1758.summary: Members of the Comanche Nation loot and destroy the Spanish Mission Santa Cruz de San Sabá in Texas.

1758.title: Battle of Cuddalore
1758.summary: A British fleet engages the French fleet near Madras in an indecisive battle.

1758.title: Siege of Louisbourg
1758.summary: James Wolfe's attack at Louisbourg, Nova Scotia begins during the Seven Years' War.

1758.title: Battle of Krefeld
1758.summary: Anglo-Hanoverian forces defeat the French at the Battle of Krefeld during the Seven Years' War.

1758.title: Sinking of the Duke William
1758.summary: The ship Duke William sinks in the North Atlantic while deporting Acadians, resulting in a significant loss of life.

1759.title: George Washington marries Martha Dandridge Custis
1759.summary: George Washington marries Martha Dandridge Custis in a notable union.

1759.title: First American life insurance company incorporated
1759.summary: In Philadelphia, the first American life insurance company is incorporated, marking a significant development in financial services.

1759.title: The British Museum opens
1759.summary: The British Museum opens at Montagu House in London after six years of development, becoming a significant cultural institution.

1759.title: Battle of Río Bueno
1759.summary: Spanish forces led by Juan Antonio Garretón defeat indigenous Huilliches of southern Chile in the Battle of Río Bueno.

1759.title: Siege of Quebec City begins
1759.summary: British troops land on France's North American territory and begin the siege of Quebec City, a pivotal conflict in the Seven Years' War.

1759.title: Battle of Pondicherry
1759.summary: An inconclusive naval battle occurs off the coast of India between the British and French naval forces, showcasing ongoing colonial conflicts.

1759.title: Battle of the Plains of Abraham
1759.summary: Quebec falls to British forces following General Wolfe's victory, a decisive moment in the Seven Years' War that impacts both empires.

1759.title: Smeaton's Tower first illuminated
1759.summary: John Smeaton’s Eddystone Lighthouse is first illuminated, marking a milestone in maritime navigation.

1759.title: Destructive fire in Salonika
1759.summary: A fire destroys the city of Salonika, impacting thousands and showcasing the vulnerability of urban centers to disasters.

1759.title: Alamgir II assassinated
1759.summary: Alamgir II, the Mughal Emperor of India, is assassinated, marking a significant shift in the power dynamics of the Mughal Empire.

1760.title: Battle of Wandiwash
1760.summary: British general Sir Eyre Coote is victorious over the French under the Marquis de Bussy-Castelnau.

1760.title: HMS Royal Katherine Disaster
1760.summary: The British Royal Navy ship runs aground off Bolt Head in England, with the loss of 699 lives.

1760.title: Seven Years' War: Battle of Carrickfergus
1760.summary: A force of French troops captures and holds the town and castle of Carrickfergus before retiring.

1760.title: The Great Fire of Boston
1760.summary: Destroys 349 buildings and marks the biggest conflagration in the American colonies up to this time.

1760.title: 'Tacky's War' Begins
1760.summary: A slave rebellion begins in Jamaica and lasts for 18 months, resulting in the deaths of many.

1760.title: Battle of Sainte-Foy
1760.summary: British defenders and the French Army clash at the Battle of Sainte-Foy to determine the future control of Quebec.

1760.title: King Alaungpaya Dies
1760.summary: King Alaungpaya of Burma dies during a retreat, and his son Naungdawgyi becomes the new King.

1760.title: Siege of Pondicherry Begins
1760.summary: The siege of Pondicherry, a stronghold of France in India, is begun by British Army Lieutenant General Eyre Coote.

1760.title: Abbé Charles-Michel de l'Épée Opens School for Deaf Education
1760.summary: A school for deaf education in Paris becomes the world's first free school for the deaf.

1761.title: Third Battle of Panipat
1761.summary: In India, the armies of the Durrani Empire from Afghanistan, led by Ahmad Shah Durrani and his coalition decisively defeat the Maratha Confederacy, killing over 100,000 Maratha soldiers and civilians and restoring the Mughal Emperor, Shah Alam II, to the throne in Delhi as the nominal ruler.

1761.title: Siege of Pondicherry
1761.summary: The British Empire captures Pondichéry from the French colonial empire after a lengthy siege, marking a significant victory in colonial India.

1761.title: Earthquake in Lisbon
1761.summary: An 8.5 magnitude earthquake strikes Lisbon in the Kingdom of Portugal with effects felt as far north as Scotland; few deaths are reported due to censorship by the Portuguese government.

1761.title: Treaty of Alliance
1761.summary: The Austrian Empire and the Russian Empire sign a new treaty of alliance, strengthening their political and military cooperation.

1761.title: Epidemic of Influenza in London
1761.summary: A severe epidemic of influenza breaks out in London, afflicting practically the entire population, especially pregnant women.

1761.title: First Multiple Death Tornado
1761.summary: The first multiple death tornado in the 13 American colonies strikes Charleston, South Carolina, killing eight people and sinking five ships.

1761.title: Transit of Venus
1761.summary: A transit of Venus occurs, observed from 120 locations around the Earth; Mikhail Lomonosov notes a ring of light around Venus, discovering it has an atmosphere.

1761.title: Bridgewater Canal Opens
1761.summary: The first section of the Bridgewater Canal is opened, enabling the transportation of coal from local mines to Manchester, enhancing industrial transport.

1761.title: Marriages of George III
1761.summary: George III marries Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz, a significant royal union.

1761.title: Slavery Abolished in Portugal
1761.summary: Portugal abolishes slavery, marking a significant change in its colonial policy and societal structure.

1762.title: Britain declares war against Spain and Naples
1762.summary: Britain declares war against Spain and Naples, following their recent alliance with France.

1762.title: Death of Empress Elisabeth of Russia
1762.summary: Empress Elisabeth of Russia dies, and is succeeded by her nephew Peter III, who opens peace negotiations with Prussia.

1762.title: Surrender of French forces on Martinique
1762.summary: Full surrender of French forces on Martinique to the British, the island is subsequently returned to France as part of the Peace of Paris.

1762.title: Execution of Jean Calas
1762.summary: Jean Calas, convicted unjustly, is brutally executed on orders of the Parlement of Toulouse for murdering his son.

1762.title: First Saint Patrick's Day Parade
1762.summary: The first Saint Patrick's Day Parade in New York City takes place, inaugurating an annual tradition that attracts thousands.

1762.title: Treaty of Saint Petersburg
1762.summary: The Treaty of Saint Petersburg ends the war between Russia and Prussia, returning all of Russia's territorial conquests to the Prussians.

1762.title: Catherine II becomes Empress of Russia
1762.summary: Catherine II becomes empress of Russia after planning the overthrow of her husband, the Tsar Peter III.

1762.title: Battle of Havana
1762.summary: The Battle of Havana concludes with the surrender of Havana by Spain to Great Britain after two months of siege.

1762.title: Treaty of Fontainebleau
1762.summary: In the Treaty of Fontainebleau, Louis XV of France secretly cedes Louisiana to Charles III of Spain to compensate for losses to Britain.

1762.title: Catherine the Great's immigration manifesto
1762.summary: Catherine the Great announces that almost all foreigners are welcome to travel to and settle in Russia while waiving previous religious requirements.

1763.title: The seat of colonial administration moved
1763.summary: The seat of colonial administration in the Viceroyalty of Brazil is moved from Salvador to Rio de Janeiro.

1763.title: Treaty of Paris
1763.summary: The Treaty of Paris ends the Seven Years' War, and France cedes Canada to Great Britain.

1763.title: Treaty of Hubertusburg
1763.summary: The Treaty of Hubertusburg ends the Seven Years' War between Prussia and Austria, and their allies France and Russia.

1763.title: Berbice Slave Uprising begins
1763.summary: The Berbice Slave Uprising starts in the former Dutch colony of Berbice.

1763.title: Destruction of the Théâtre du Palais-Royal
1763.summary: The Théâtre du Palais-Royal, home to the Paris Opera for almost 90 years, is destroyed in an accidental fire.

1763.title: Assassination of Teedyuscung
1763.summary: Teedyuscung, known as the King of the Delaware Indians, is assassinated by arsonists who burn down his home.

1763.title: Publication of The North Briton
1763.summary: The controversial Issue 45 of John Wilkes's satirical newspaper is published, leading to his arrest for libel of the King.

1763.title: Pontiac's War begins
1763.summary: Chief Pontiac begins Pontiac's War by attacking the British garrison at Fort Detroit, commencing the Siege of Fort Detroit.

1763.title: Catherine II endorses Foundling Home plans
1763.summary: Catherine II of Russia endorses Ivan Betskoy's plans for a Foundling Home in Moscow.

1763.title: Bayes' theorem announced
1763.summary: Bayes' theorem is first announced, marking a significant moment in statistics.

1764.title: Siculicidium
1764.summary: The Székely minority in Transylvania are massacred by the Austrian Army at Madéfalva.

1764.title: Expulsion of John Wilkes
1764.summary: John Wilkes is expelled from the House of Commons of Great Britain for seditious libel.

1764.title: Establishment of St. Louis
1764.summary: The settlement of St. Louis is established.

1764.title: Presentation of the Zend Avesta
1764.summary: French explorer Anquetil Du Perron presents a complete copy of the Zoroastrian sacred text, the Zend Avesta, to the Bibliothèque Royale in Paris.

1764.title: Mutual Defense Treaty
1764.summary: A mutual defense treaty between the Russian Empire and the Kingdom of Prussia is signed in Saint Petersburg.

1764.title: Sugar Act
1764.summary: The Sugar Act is passed in Great Britain.

1764.title: Mozart's Performance
1764.summary: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart performs a private concert before King George III and Queen Charlotte in Great Britain.

1764.title: Quebec Gazette Established
1764.summary: The English-language Quebec Gazette is established in Quebec City, Canada, becoming the oldest surviving newspaper in North America.

1764.title: Battle of Buxar
1764.summary: The British East India Company defeats the combined armies of Mir Qasim, Nawab of Bengal, Nawab of Awadh, and Mughal Emperor Shah Alam II.

1764.title: Election of King Poniatowski
1764.summary: Stanisław August Poniatowski is elected as the King of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth.

1765.title: Marriage of Prince Joseph of Austria and Princess Maria Josepha
1765.summary: Prince Joseph of Austria marries Princess Maria Josepha of Bavaria in Vienna.

1765.title: Abdication of Mir Jafar
1765.summary: Mir Jafar abdicates in favor of his 18-year-old son, Najmuddin Ali Khan, one week before his death.

1765.title: Decree by Frederick the Great
1765.summary: Frederick the Great abolishes historic punishments against unmarried women in Germany for sex crimes.

1765.title: Introduction of the term 'Sons of Liberty'
1765.summary: Isaac Barré coins the term 'Sons of Liberty' in a rebuttal to Charles Townshend's description of American colonists.

1765.title: Special Junta report in Spain
1765.summary: Spain's special junta reports on ways to address the backwardness of commerce with its colonies and foreign nations.

1765.title: Posthumous exoneration of Jean Calas
1765.summary: Judges in Paris posthumously exonerate Jean Calas of murdering his son after a public campaign by Voltaire.

1765.title: Royal assent for the Stamp Act
1765.summary: Royal assent is given to the Duties in American Colonies Act 1765, imposing the first direct tax on the thirteen American colonies.

1765.title: The Quartering Act
1765.summary: Great Britain passes the Quartering Act, requiring private households in the American colonies to house British soldiers.

1765.title: Peace treaty with Choctaw Indians
1765.summary: Representatives of the British Empire and the Choctaw Indian tribe sign a peace treaty at Fort Tombecbe.

1765.title: James Watt's breakthrough
1765.summary: Scottish engineer James Watt receives inspiration for the steam engine during a stroll in Glasgow Green.

1766.title: Bonnie Prince Charlie becomes King Charles III
1766.summary: Charles Edward Stuart becomes the new Stuart claimant to the throne of Great Britain as King Charles III, becoming a figurehead for Jacobitism.

1766.title: Christian VII becomes King of Denmark-Norway
1766.summary: Christian VII ascends to the throne, marking a significant event in Danish history.

1766.title: Burmese-Siamese War leading to the fall of Ayutthaya
1766.summary: The Thai defenders at Ayutthaya were overwhelmed by Burmese invaders, leading to the fall of the city.

1766.title: Protests against the Stamp Act
1766.summary: Members of the Sons of Liberty burned British tax stamps in a protest against the Stamp Act 1765.

1766.title: Meermin Slave Mutiny
1766.summary: Captive Malagasy people seize a Dutch East India Company slave ship in the Indian Ocean, highlighting resistance to slavery.

1766.title: Repeal of the Stamp Act
1766.summary: The British Parliament repeals the Stamp Act under pressure from the colonies, a pivotal moment in American history.

1766.title: Arrival of Antonio de Ulloa in New Orleans
1766.summary: Antonio de Ulloa arrives as the first Spanish governor of Louisiana, marking a transition in colonial governance.

1766.title: Hurricane in Martinique
1766.summary: A hurricane devastated the island of Martinique, killing over 400 people and destroying plantations.

1766.title: Abolishment of the Patriarch of the Serbs
1766.summary: Sultan Mustafa III abolishes the position of Patriarch of the Serbs, significantly impacting the Serbian Orthodox Church.

1766.title: Law on the Freedom of Printing in Sweden
1766.summary: Sweden becomes the first country to guarantee freedom of the press, leading to significant cultural implications.

1767.title: Sack of Ayutthaya
1767.summary: Troops of the Burmese Konbaung dynasty sack the Siamese city of Ayutthaya, ending the Burmese–Siamese War after 15 months, and bringing the four-century-old Ayutthaya Kingdom to an end.

1767.title: Publication of The Nautical Almanac
1767.summary: The first annual volume of The Nautical Almanac and Astronomical Ephemeris is produced by British Astronomer Royal Nevil Maskelyne, helping navigators find longitude at sea.

1767.title: Building of Tryon Palace
1767.summary: William Tryon, governor of the Royal Colony of North Carolina, signs a contract to build Tryon Palace, a lavish Georgian style mansion.

1767.title: Invasion of Capraia
1767.summary: Corsican soldiers invade Capraia on orders from head of state Pasquale Paoli, and by May 31, the island is conquered.

1767.title: Decree Expelling the Jesuits
1767.summary: King Carlos III of Spain issues a decree expelling the Jesuits from the dominions of the Spanish Empire worldwide.

1767.title: Establishment of forts in Louisiana
1767.summary: Colonial Governor Antonio de Ulloa dispatches Captain Francisco Ríus y Morales to establish forts on the Mississippi River to protect shipping.

1767.title: Control of the Falkland Islands
1767.summary: Spain acquires control of the Falkland Islands from France, renaming them las Islas Malvinas and compensating Admiral Bougainville.

1767.title: Suppression of the Jesuits begins
1767.summary: Enforcement begins of the decree by King Carlos III, resulting in the deportation of approximately 2,200 Jesuit priests and missionaries from the Spanish colonies.

1767.title: First European Visit to Tahiti
1767.summary: Captain Samuel Wallis becomes the first European to visit Tahiti during HMS Dolphin's second circumnavigation.

1767.title: Completion of Mason–Dixon line survey
1767.summary: Surveying of the "Mason–Dixon line" is completed, settling a boundary dispute between Delaware, Pennsylvania, and Maryland.

1768.title: First Modern Circus
1768.summary: Philip Astley stages the first modern circus, with acrobats on galloping horses, in London.

1768.title: Samuel Adams's Circular Letter
1768.summary: Samuel Adams's circular letter is issued by the Massachusetts House of Representatives, leading to potential martial law.

1768.title: Treaty as Protectorate
1768.summary: The government of Poland signs a treaty turning the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth into a protectorate of the Russian Empire.

1768.title: Appointment of Secretary of State for the Colonies
1768.summary: The first Secretary of State for the Colonies is appointed in Britain, the Earl of Hillsborough.

1768.title: Bar Confederation Formed
1768.summary: Polish nobles establish the Bar Confederation to defend the Commonwealth's independence against Russian influence.

1768.title: House Numbering Decree
1768.summary: King Louis XV decrees that all cities and towns in France must post house numbering on residential buildings.

1768.title: Peace Agreement with Iroquois Confederacy
1768.summary: Sir William Johnson concludes a peace agreement with the Iroquois Confederacy leaders in northern America.

1768.title: Cotopaxi Volcano Eruption
1768.summary: The Cotopaxi volcano erupts in Ecuador, covering towns with ash but causing no fatalities.

1768.title: Massacre of St George's Fields
1768.summary: John Wilkes's imprisonment for criticism of King George III provokes protests that result in troops firing on a mob.

1768.title: Ceding of Corsica to France
1768.summary: After the Treaty of Versailles, the island of Corsica is ceded by Genoa to France.

1769.title: Death of Pope Clement XIII
1769.summary: Pope Clement XIII dies, the night before preparing an order to dissolve the Jesuits.

1769.title: John Wilkes and the House of Commons
1769.summary: The British House of Commons votes to not allow MP John Wilkes to take his seat after he wins a by-election.

1769.title: Mozart's Departure from Italy
1769.summary: Mozart departs Italy, after the last of his three tours there.

1769.title: Bougainville's Return
1769.summary: Louis Antoine de Bougainville returns to Saint-Malo, following a three-year circumnavigation of the world, with the loss of only seven out of 330 men.

1769.title: James Cook in Tahiti
1769.summary: James Cook arrives in Tahiti, preparing for the 1769 Transit of Venus observed from Tahiti on June 3.

1769.title: James Watt's Patent
1769.summary: Scottish inventor James Watt is granted a patent for the separate condenser, a key improvement for the Watt steam engine, stimulating the Industrial Revolution.

1769.title: Election of Pope Clement XIV
1769.summary: Cardinal Giovanni Vincenzo Antonio Ganganelli is elected as the 249th pope, succeeding Clement XIII and choosing the name Pope Clement XIV.

1769.title: Transit of Venus and Solar Eclipse
1769.summary: A transit of Venus is followed five hours later by a total solar eclipse, the shortest such interval in historical times, viewed by King George III.

1769.title: Brescia Explosion
1769.summary: The city of Brescia, Italy is devastated when the Church of San Nazaro is struck by lightning, causing a massive explosion that destroys 1/6 of the city and kills 3,000 people.

1769.title: Bengal Famine of 1770
1769.summary: Massive droughts in Bengal lead to the worst natural disaster in human history, causing ten million deaths, a third of the population.

1770.title: Foundation of Fort George
1770.summary: The foundation of Fort George, Bombay is laid by Colonel Keating, principal engineer, on the site of the former Dongri Fort.

1770.title: Destruction of Thomas Jefferson's home
1770.summary: Thomas Jefferson's home at Shadwell, Virginia is destroyed by fire, along with most of his books.

1770.title: Arrival of James Bruce in Abyssinia
1770.summary: Scottish explorer James Bruce arrives at Gondar, capital of Abyssinia (now Ethiopia) and is received by the Emperor Tekle Haymanot II and Ras Mikael Sehul.

1770.title: Boston Massacre
1770.summary: Eleven American men are shot (five fatally) by British troops, in an event that helps start the American Revolutionary War five years later.

1770.title: Shift to Basantapur Palace
1770.summary: King Prithvi Narayan Shah shifts to the newly constructed Basantapur Palace in the capital Kathmandu as the first King of Unified Kingdom of Nepal.

1770.title: First contact with the Australian east coast
1770.summary: English explorer Captain James Cook and his crew become the first recorded Europeans to encounter the eastern coastline of the Australian continent.

1770.title: Battle of Aspindza
1770.summary: Georgian king Erekle II defeats the Ottoman forces, despite being abandoned by an ally, Russian General Totleben.

1770.title: Discovery at Botany Bay
1770.summary: Captain Cook drops anchor on HMS Endeavour in a wide bay, discovering 30,000 specimens of plant life, and names the place Botany Bay.

1770.title: Establishment of Monterey
1770.summary: Gaspar de Portolà and Father Junípero Serra establish Monterey, the presidio of Alta California territory for Spain.

1770.title: Phillis Wheatley's publication
1770.summary: Phillis Wheatley becomes the first African American woman to have her work published, after having written a poetic elegy to the late Reverend George Whitefield.

1771.title: The Great Kalmyk Migration
1771.summary: Led by Ubashi Khan from the east bank of the Lower Volga River back to Dzungaria under Qing rule.

1771.title: Emperor Go-Momozono accedes to the throne
1771.summary: Following his aunt's abdication, he becomes the Emperor of Japan.

1771.title: Death of King Adolf Frederick and succession of Gustav III
1771.summary: Gustav III is unaware of his father's passing while abroad in Paris at the time.

1771.title: Establishment of Wake County
1771.summary: The North Carolina General Assembly forms Wake County from portions of other counties.

1771.title: The Society of Civil Engineers first meets
1771.summary: The world's oldest engineering society holds its inaugural meeting in London.

1771.title: Beginning of quarantines in Moscow and Saint Petersburg
1771.summary: The first quarantines are implemented to combat the bubonic plague epidemic.

1771.title: Battle of Alamance
1771.summary: Governor Tryon's forces crush the Regulator rebellion, affecting many families in North Carolina.

1771.title: First voyage of James Cook around the world ends
1771.summary: After almost three years, HMS Endeavour returns to England marking a significant exploration achievement.

1771.title: Premiere of Ascanio in Alba
1771.summary: Wolfgang Mozart, only 15, composes and premieres his opera in Milan.

1771.title: Beginning of Sommersett's Case
1771.summary: The case against the slave James Somerset marks a pivotal moment towards abolishing slavery in Great Britain.

1772.title: Return of Shah Alam II
1772.summary: Shah Alam II, the Mughal Emperor of India, makes a triumphant return to Delhi after having been forced to flee 15 years prior.

1772.title: Arrest of Johann Friedrich Struensee
1772.summary: Johann Friedrich Struensee and Queen Caroline Matilda are arrested, leading to his execution and her banishment from Denmark.

1772.title: Discovery of Kerguelen Islands
1772.summary: Breton-French explorer Yves-Joseph de Kerguelen-Trémarec discovers the uninhabited Kerguelen Islands in the Southern Indian Ocean.

1772.title: First Partition of Poland
1772.summary: The First Partition of Poland is agreed to by Russia and Prussia, later including Austria.

1772.title: Founding of the Emirate of Diriyah
1772.summary: The Emirate of Diriyah is founded by Muhammad bin Saud Al Muqrin; he is considered the founder of the House of Saud.

1772.title: Discovery of Biela's Comet
1772.summary: Biela's Comet is first discovered by French astronomer Jacques Leibax Montaigne, but not proven to be a periodic comet until 1826.

1772.title: Founding of the Watauga Association Compact
1772.summary: The Watauga Association Compact is signed by a group of white settlers, creating the first non-colonial government body in British North America.

1772.title: Gaspee Affair
1772.summary: In an act of defiance against British Navigation Acts, American patriots attack and burn the HMS Gaspee off of Rhode Island.

1772.title: Beginning of the second voyage of James Cook
1772.summary: The second voyage of James Cook departs from Plymouth in an attempt to prove the existence of an uncharted continent further south.

1772.title: Decision ending slavery in England
1772.summary: Lord Mansfield delivers the decision that leads to the end of slavery in England.

1773.title: Amazing Grace Hymn Premiered
1773.summary: The hymn that becomes known as Amazing Grace is first used to accompany a sermon led by curate John Newton in the town of Olney, Buckinghamshire.

1773.title: First American Museum Established
1773.summary: The first museum in the American colonies is established in Charleston, South Carolina; in 1915, it is formally incorporated as the Charleston Museum.

1773.title: James Cook Crosses Antarctic Circle
1773.summary: Captain Cook in HMS Resolution becomes the first European explorer to cross the Antarctic Circle during his second voyage.

1773.title: First Swedish Language Opera Performance
1773.summary: The first opera performance in the Swedish language, Thetis and Phelée, marks the establishment of the Royal Swedish Opera.

1773.title: Grand Council of Poland Meets
1773.summary: The Grand Council of Poland meets in Warsaw, summoned by a circular letter from King Stanisław August Poniatowski to respond to the Kingdom's threatened partition between three foreign powers.

1773.title: Completion of Christ Church
1773.summary: The construction of Christ Church in Alexandria, Virginia, known for being the house of worship for George Washington and the visiting site for subsequent U.S. presidents, is completed.

1773.title: First Annual Conference of American Methodists
1773.summary: The first annual conference of American Methodists is convened at Philadelphia in St. George's Church.

1773.title: Guatemala Earthquake
1773.summary: The Santa Marta earthquake hits Guatemala, leading to the decision to move the country's capital to La Nueva Guatemala de la Asunción.

1773.title: Boston Tea Party
1773.summary: A group of American colonists, dressed as Mohawk Indians, steal aboard ships of the East India Company and dump their cargo of tea into Boston Harbor, in protest against British tax policies.

1773.title: Establishment of the Moscow State Academy of Choreography
1773.summary: Moscow State Academy of Choreography was founded under the reign of Catherine II. It is the second ballet school in Russia after Vaganova Academy of Russian Ballet.

1774.title: Death of Mustafa III
1774.summary: Mustafa III, Sultan of the Ottoman Empire, dies and is succeeded by his brother Abdul Hamid I.

1774.title: Boston Custom House Riot
1774.summary: An angry crowd in Boston seizes, tars, and feathers British customs collector and Loyalist John Malcolm for striking a boy and a shoemaker.

1774.title: Patent for Boring Cannon
1774.summary: British industrialist John Wilkinson patents a method for boring cannon from the solid, which is subsequently utilized for accurate boring of steam engine cylinders.

1774.title: Abolition of Free Land Grants
1774.summary: The Privy Council of Great Britain votes for the King's abolition of free land grants of North American lands.

1774.title: Founding of Trenton Fire Company
1774.summary: The volunteer fire company of Trenton, New Jersey, is founded, the predecessor to the paid Trenton Fire Department created in 1892.

1774.title: Impeachment of Peter Oliver
1774.summary: The Province of Massachusetts Bay House of Representatives votes to impeach Superior Court Chief Justice Peter Oliver, but the trial is refused by Provincial Governor Thomas Hutchinson.

1774.title: First Reference to Stars and Stripes
1774.summary: The Boston Journal makes the first reference to the Stars and Stripes flag to symbolize the American colonies.

1774.title: Boston Port Act
1774.summary: The British Parliament passes the Boston Port Act, closing the port of Boston as punishment for the Boston Tea Party.

1774.title: Treaty of Kucuk Kaynarca
1774.summary: Russia and the Ottoman Empire sign the Treaty of Kucuk Kaynarca, ending six years of war and allowing Russian intervention in Ottoman politics.

1774.title: Discovery of Oxygen
1774.summary: The element oxygen is discovered for the third time by Joseph Priestley, who publishes the fact.

1775.title: American Revolutionary War begins
1775.summary: The American Revolutionary War began this year, marked by the Battles of Lexington and Concord on April 19, igniting conflict between Britain and its American colonies.

1775.title: George Washington appointed commander
1775.summary: The Second Continental Congress appoints George Washington as commander-in-chief of the Continental Army on June 14, solidifying leadership in the fight for independence.

1775.title: Declaration of the Causes and Necessity of Taking Up Arms
1775.summary: On July 6, Congress issues a declaration outlining the reasons for taking up arms against British rule, emphasizing the colonies' rights and grievances.

1775.title: Battle of Bunker Hill
1775.summary: On June 17, during the siege of Boston, British forces defeat the colonists in the Battle of Bunker Hill, but suffer heavy casualties, marking a pivotal moment in the war.

1775.title: Independence Hurricane
1775.summary: The Independence Hurricane devastates the eastern coast of North America from August 29 to September 13, resulting in over 4,000 deaths, showcasing nature's impact on human life.

1775.title: Establishment of the Continental Navy
1775.summary: On October 13, the Continental Congress orders the establishment of the Continental Navy, paving the way for naval power in the Revolutionary War.

1775.title: Coronation of Louis XVI
1775.summary: The coronation of Louis XVI takes place in Reims on June 11, marking a significant event in the lead-up to the French Revolution.

1775.title: First Postmaster General appointed
1775.summary: Benjamin Franklin is appointed the first Postmaster General on July 26, establishing a crucial communication network in the colonies.

1775.title: Smallpox vaccine developed
1775.summary: Edward Jenner's development of the smallpox vaccine represents a major advancement in medical science during this year.

1775.title: Battle of Quebec
1775.summary: The British forces repel an attack by the American Continental Army on December 31, marking a significant defeat for the colonial forces in Canada.

1776.title: Burning of Norfolk
1776.summary: The town of Norfolk, Virginia is destroyed, by the combined actions of the British Royal Navy and occupying Patriot forces.

1776.title: Publication of Common Sense
1776.summary: Thomas Paine publishes his pamphlet Common Sense, arguing for independence from British rule in the Thirteen Colonies.

1776.title: Battle of Moore's Creek Bridge
1776.summary: Scottish North Carolina Loyalists charge across Moore's Creek Bridge near Wilmington, to attack what they mistakenly believe to be a small force of rebels. The patriot victory virtually ends all British authority in the province.

1776.title: Evacuation of Boston
1776.summary: Threatened by Patriot cannons on Dorchester Heights, the British evacuate Boston, ending the 11-month Siege of Boston.

1776.title: United States Declaration of Independence
1776.summary: The Continental Congress ratifies the declaration by the United States of its independence from the Kingdom of Great Britain.

1776.title: First performance of Mozart's Serenade No. 7
1776.summary: Mozart's Serenade No. 7 (the "Haffner") is first performed in Salzburg, Austria.

1776.title: Nathan Hale executed
1776.summary: Nathan Hale is executed by the British in New York City, for espionage.

1776.title: Battle of Valcour Island
1776.summary: On Lake Champlain near Valcour Island, a British fleet led by Sir Guy Carleton defeats 15 American gunboats, giving Patriot forces enough time to prepare the defenses of New York City.

1776.title: Battle of Trenton
1776.summary: Washington's troops surprise the 1,500 Hessian troops under the command of Col. Johann Rall at 8 a.m. outside Trenton and score a victory, taking 948 prisoners while suffering only five wounded.

1776.title: Foundation of the Phi Beta Kappa Society
1776.summary: The Phi Beta Kappa Society is founded at the College of William & Mary in Virginia.

1777.title: Battle of the Assunpink Creek
1777.summary: American general George Washington's army repulses a British attack by Lieutenant General Charles Cornwallis.

1777.title: Battle of Princeton
1777.summary: American general George Washington's army defeats British troops.

1777.title: Vermont Republic Declaration
1777.summary: Vermont declares its independence from New York, becoming the Vermont Republic.

1777.title: King Joseph I of Portugal dies
1777.summary: King Joseph I of Portugal dies, and is succeeded by his daughter Maria I of Portugal.

1777.title: Fourth Continental Congress begins
1777.summary: The Fourth Continental Congress, with John Hancock as president, begins a session in Philadelphia.

1777.title: Battle of Bound Brook
1777.summary: A British and Hessian force surprises a Continental Army outpost in New Jersey.

1777.title: Battle of Ridgefield
1777.summary: The British Army defeats Patriot militias, galvanizing resistance in Connecticut Colony.

1777.title: The School for Scandal premiere
1777.summary: Richard Brinsley Sheridan's comedy of manners is first performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane in London.

1777.title: The Stars and Stripes adopted
1777.summary: The Stars and Stripes is adopted by the Continental Congress as the flag of the United States.

1777.title: First Battle of Saratoga
1777.summary: Patriot forces withstand a British attack at Saratoga, New York.

1778.title: Third voyage of James Cook
1778.summary: Captain James Cook, with ships HMS Resolution and HMS Discovery, first views Oʻahu then Kauaʻi in the Hawaiian Islands of the Pacific Ocean, which he names the Sandwich Islands.

1778.title: South Carolina ratifies Articles of Confederation
1778.summary: South Carolina becomes the first state to ratify the Articles of Confederation.

1778.title: Treaty of Alliance and Treaty of Amity
1778.summary: In Paris, the Treaty of Alliance and the Treaty of Amity and Commerce are signed by the United States and France, signaling official French recognition of the new republic.

1778.title: Friedrich Wilhelm von Steuben arrives at Valley Forge
1778.summary: Friedrich Wilhelm von Steuben arrives at Valley Forge, Pennsylvania and begins to train the American troops.

1778.title: William Pitt delivers last speech
