1778.summary: Former British Prime Minister William Pitt delivers his last speech to Parliament, and speaks to the House of Lords passionately but incoherently against the granting of independence to the American colonies, but collapses during the debate, and dies five weeks later.

1778.title: Hudson River Chain installation
1778.summary: The 1,800 feet long Hudson River Chain, designed to prevent British ships from moving up the river toward West Point, New York is stretched across the river and anchored by an engineering team under the direction of Captain Thomas Machin.

1778.title: Total solar eclipse
1778.summary: A total solar eclipse takes place across parts of North America, from Texas to Virginia.

1778.title: Treaty of Fort Pitt
1778.summary: The Treaty of Fort Pitt is signed, the first formal treaty between the United States and a Native American tribe (the Lenape or Delaware).

1778.title: Battle of Monmouth
1778.summary: George Washington's Continental Army battles British general Sir Henry Clinton's army to a draw, near Monmouth County, New Jersey.

1778.title: Cherry Valley massacre
1778.summary: British forces and their Iroquois allies attack a fort and the village of Cherry Valley, New York, killing 14 soldiers and 30 civilians.

1779.title: British troops surrender to the Marathas
1779.summary: British troops surrender to the Marathas in Wadgaon, India, and are forced to return all territories acquired since 1773.

1779.title: Claudius Smith hanged
1779.summary: Claudius Smith is hanged at Goshen, Orange County, New York for supposed acts of terrorism upon the people of the surrounding communities.

1779.title: Abolition of Bute County
1779.summary: The North Carolina General Assembly abolishes Bute County by dividing it and names the northern portion Warren County and the southern portion Franklin County.

1779.title: Establishment of New Iberia
1779.summary: Lieutenant Colonel Francisco Bouligny arrives with Malagueño colonists at Bayou Teche, to establish the city of New Iberia, Louisiana.

1779.title: Death of Captain James Cook
1779.summary: Captain James Cook is killed on the Sandwich Islands, on his third voyage.

1779.title: Capture of Vientiane
1779.summary: Capture and sack of Vientiane by Siamese forces.

1779.title: Treaty of Aynalıkavak
1779.summary: The Treaty of Aynalıkavak is signed between Ottoman Turkey and the Russian Empire, regarding the Crimean Khanate.

1779.title: Convention of Aranjuez
1779.summary: Spain and France secretly sign the Convention of Aranjuez, with Spain joining an alliance against Great Britain.

1779.title: Court-martial of Benedict Arnold
1779.summary: Benedict Arnold is court-martialed for malfeasance, in his treatment of government property.

1779.title: Battle of Flamborough Head
1779.summary: The American ship Bonhomme Richard engages the British ship HMS Serapis. The Americans board the Serapis and other vessels, and are victorious.

1780.title: Battle of Cape St. Vincent
1780.summary: British Admiral Sir George Rodney defeats a Spanish fleet.

1780.title: Ceding of Western Territory
1780.summary: The legislature of New York votes to allow its delegates to cede a portion of its western territory to the Continental Congress for the common benefit of the war.

1780.title: Abolition of Slavery Act
1780.summary: The legislature of Pennsylvania votes to approve An Act for the Gradual Abolition of Slavery.

1780.title: Formation of the First League of Armed Neutrality
1780.summary: The First League of Armed Neutrality is formed by Russia with Denmark and Sweden to try to prevent the British Royal Navy from searching neutral vessels for contraband.

1780.title: British San Juan Expedition
1780.summary: The British San Juan Expedition sails from Jamaica to attack the Captaincy General of Guatemala in New Spain.

1780.title: Publication of the British Gazette and Sunday Monitor
1780.summary: The British Gazette and Sunday Monitor, the first Sunday newspaper in Britain, begins publication.

1780.title: Founding of the University of Münster
1780.summary: The University of Münster in Münster, North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany is founded.

1780.title: Capture of Charleston
1780.summary: American Revolutionary War: Charleston, South Carolina is taken by British forces.

1780.title: Battle of Springfield
1780.summary: The Continental Army defeats the British in New Jersey.

1780.title: Benedict Arnold's Betrayal
1780.summary: Benedict Arnold gives detailed plans of West Point to Major John André, who is later captured.

1781.title: The Iron Bridge opens
1781.summary: The Iron Bridge opens across the River Severn in England, marking a significant advancement in engineering during the Industrial Revolution.

1781.title: American Revolutionary War: Richmond burned
1781.summary: British naval forces, led by Benedict Arnold, burn Richmond, Virginia during the American Revolutionary War.

1781.title: Battle of Cowpens
1781.summary: The American Continental Army, under Daniel Morgan, decisively defeats British forces in South Carolina.

1781.title: Articles of Confederation ratified
1781.summary: Maryland ratifies the Articles of Confederation, becoming the 13th and final state to do so, further solidifying the union of states.

1781.title: Discovery of Uranus
1781.summary: Sir William Herschel discovers the planet Uranus and originally names it Georgium Sidus in honor of King George III of Great Britain.

1781.title: Siege of Yorktown
1781.summary: General Charles Cornwallis surrenders to General George Washington at Yorktown, Virginia, effectively ending the armed struggle of the American Revolution.

1781.title: Foundation of Los Angeles
1781.summary: Los Angeles is founded as El Pueblo de Nuestra Señora la Reina de Los Ángeles de Porciuncula by Spanish settlers in California.

1781.title: First bagpipes competition
1781.summary: The first bagpipes competition takes place in the Masonic Arms, Falkirk, Scotland, showcasing a celebration of music and culture.

1781.title: Abolition of serfdom
1781.summary: Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor, abolishes serfdom, marking a pivotal change in the feudal system in Europe.

1781.title: Founding of Philips Exeter Academy
1781.summary: Philips Exeter Academy, an important educational institution, is founded in New Hampshire, contributing to the education of future leaders.

1782.title: Bank of North America opens
1782.summary: The first American commercial bank opens, marking a significant development in the financial system of the United States.

1782.title: Establishment of national mint
1782.summary: Superintendent of Finance Robert Morris recommends the establishment of a national mint and decimal coinage to the United States Congress.

1782.title: Laird of Johnstone's land offer
1782.summary: The Laird of Johnstone invites people to buy marked plots of land for creating a planned town in Johnstone, Scotland, providing employment for his mills.

1782.title: Spanish capture Menorca
1782.summary: The Spanish forces defeat the British and capture Menorca, impacting British colonial interests in the Mediterranean.

1782.title: Gnadenhutten massacre
1782.summary: Colonial militiamen kill 29 Native American men, 27 women, and 34 children in retaliation for previous raids in Ohio.

1782.title: Battle of the Saintes
1782.summary: A British fleet defeats a French fleet in a decisive naval battle in the West Indies during the ongoing conflicts of the era.

1782.title: Recognition of the United States
1782.summary: John Adams secures recognition of the United States as an independent government by the Dutch Republic, vital for international legitimacy.

1782.title: Witchcraft trial of Anna Göldi
1782.summary: In Switzerland, Anna Göldi is sentenced to death for witchcraft, marking one of the final legal repercussions of witchcraft accusations in Europe.

1782.title: Election of Elias Boudinot
1782.summary: Elias Boudinot is elected as the new President of the Congress of the Confederation, a crucial leadership position in the early United States.

1782.title: Treaty of Paris preliminary articles
1782.summary: Representatives from the United States and Great Britain sign preliminary peace articles in Paris, laying the groundwork for the end of the American Revolutionary War.

1783.title: Preliminary peace treaties signed by Great Britain
1783.summary: At Versailles, Great Britain signs preliminary peace treaties with the Kingdom of France and the Kingdom of Spain.

1783.title: Recognition of US Independence
1783.summary: American Revolutionary War: Great Britain acknowledges the independence of the United States of America.

1783.title: End of hostilities with US
1783.summary: American Revolutionary War: Great Britain formally declares that it will cease hostilities with the United States.

1783.title: Calabrian earthquakes
1783.summary: The first of a sequence of five earthquakes strikes Calabria, Italy, leaving 50,000 dead.

1783.title: The Great Siege of Gibraltar abandoned
1783.summary: The Great Siege of Gibraltar is abandoned.

1783.title: American Revolutionary War peace articles ratified
1783.summary: Preliminary articles of peace ending the American Revolutionary War are ratified by the Congress of the Confederation in the United States.

1783.title: Hot air balloon demonstration
1783.summary: The Montgolfier brothers publicly demonstrate their hot air balloon at Annonay, France.

1783.title: Peace of Paris
1783.summary: A treaty between the United States and Great Britain is signed in Paris, formally ending the American Revolutionary War.

1783.title: Mozart's Great Mass performance
1783.summary: Mozart's Great Mass is first performed, in Salzburg, Austria.

1783.title: George Washington resigns
1783.summary: General George Washington resigns his commission as commander-in-chief of the Continental Army to the Congress of the Confederation in Annapolis, Maryland.

1784.title: Treaty of Constantinople
1784.summary: The Ottoman Empire agrees to Russia's annexation of the Crimea.

1784.title: Treaty of Paris
1784.summary: The Congress of the United States ratifies the Treaty of Paris with Great Britain to end the American Revolution, with the signature of President of Congress Thomas Mifflin.

1784.title: Experiments on Air
1784.summary: Henry Cavendish's paper to the Royal Society of London reveals the composition of water.

1784.title: The Marriage of Figaro
1784.summary: The Marriage of Figaro, written by Pierre Beaumarchais as a sequel to The Barber of Seville, premieres at the Comédie-Française in Paris.

1784.title: First Woman in a Hot-Air Balloon
1784.summary: Élisabeth Thible is the first woman to ascend in a hot-air balloon, at Lyon, France.

1784.title: Pitt's India Act
1784.summary: Parliament of Great Britain passes Pitt's India Act, requiring the governor-general to be chosen from outside the Company and making company directors subject to parliamentary supervision.

1784.title: First Long-Distance Flight
1784.summary: The Robert brothers and a Mr. Collin-Hullin become the first people to fly more than 100 km in the air, lifting off from Paris and landing near Bethune after a journey of 186 kilometres.

1784.title: Kettle War
1784.summary: A 1-day action on the Scheldt in which a ship of the Dutch Republic repels forces of the Holy Roman Empire.

1784.title: The Revolt of Horea, Cloșca and Crișan
1784.summary: The revolt causes Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor to suspend the Hungarian Constitution.

1784.title: First President of the Russian Academy
1784.summary: Princess Yekaterina Vorontsova-Dashkova is named first president of the newly created Russian Academy.

1785.title: Burmese Annexation of Mrauk U Kingdom
1785.summary: The Burmese Konbaung Dynasty annexes the Mrauk U Kingdom of Arakan.

1785.title: First Issue of The Times
1785.summary: The first issue of the Daily Universal Register, later known as The Times, is published in London.

1785.title: First Balloon Crossing of the English Channel
1785.summary: Frenchman Jean-Pierre Blanchard and American John Jeffries travel from Dover, England to Calais, France in a hydrogen gas balloon, becoming the first to cross the English Channel by air.

1785.title: Battle of Rạch Gầm-Xoài Mut
1785.summary: Invading Siamese forces, attempting to exploit the political chaos in Vietnam, are ambushed and annihilated at the Mekong River, by the Tây Sơn.

1785.title: Chartering of the University of Georgia
1785.summary: The University of Georgia in the United States is chartered by the Georgia General Assembly meeting in Savannah.

1785.title: Resignation of Warren Hastings
1785.summary: Sir Warren Hastings, who has been governing India, resigns as the Governor-General of the Presidency of Fort William.

1785.title: Establishment of Diplomatic Relations with Morocco
1785.summary: The Confederation Congress votes an $80,000 expense to establish diplomatic relations with Morocco.

1785.title: Hutton's Theory of the Earth Presentation
1785.summary: Scottish geologist James Hutton first presents his landmark work, Theory of the Earth, to the Royal Society of Edinburgh.

1785.title: First Aviation Disaster in Tullamore
1785.summary: A hot air balloon crashes in Tullamore, Ireland, causing a fire that burns down about 100 houses, making it the world's first aviation disaster.

1785.title: Signing of Treaty of Hopewell
1785.summary: The Treaty of Hopewell is signed between the United States of America and the Cherokee Nation.

1786.title: Treaty of Hopewell
1786.summary: The third Treaty of Hopewell is signed, between the United States and the Choctaw.

1786.title: Halsewell Wreck
1786.summary: The outward bound East Indiaman Halsewell is wrecked on the south coast of England in a storm, with only 74 of more than 240 on board surviving.

1786.title: Comparative Linguistics Foundation
1786.summary: In a speech before The Asiatic Society in Calcutta, Sir William Jones notes the formal resemblances between Latin, Greek, and Sanskrit, laying the foundation for comparative linguistics and Indo-European studies.

1786.title: Ohio Company Organization
1786.summary: The Ohio Company of Associates is organized by five businessmen at a meeting at the Bunch-of-Grapes Tavern in Boston, to purchase land from the United States government to form settlements in what is now the U.S. state of Ohio.

1786.title: Four Courts Building Construction
1786.summary: Construction begins in Dublin on the Four Courts Building, with the first stone laid down by the United Kingdom's Viceroy for Ireland, the Duke of Rutland.

1786.title: Creek Nation Declares War
1786.summary: The Creek Nation declares war on the U.S. State of Georgia over the matter of white settlers on land not ceded by the Nation.

1786.title: Columbia College Graduation
1786.summary: Columbia College (modern-day Columbia University) holds its first graduation, with eight students, including DeWitt Clinton.

1786.title: American-Portuguese Treaty
1786.summary: The United States and the Kingdom of Portugal sign their first commercial treaty, but it is never ratified.

1786.title: William Herschel's Discoveries
1786.summary: British astronomer William Herschel publishes his first list of his discoveries, Catalogue of One Thousand New Nebulae and Clusters of Stars.

1786.title: Marriage of Figaro Premiere
1786.summary: Mozart's opera The Marriage of Figaro premieres in Vienna.

1787.title: William Herschel discovers Titania and Oberon
1787.summary: William Herschel discovers Titania and Oberon, two moons of Uranus.

1787.title: Mozart's Symphony No. 38 is premiered
1787.summary: Mozart's Symphony No. 38 is premièred in Prague.

1787.title: Constitutional Convention begins
1787.summary: In Philadelphia, delegates begin arriving for a Constitutional Convention.

1787.title: United States Constitution is signed
1787.summary: The United States Constitution is signed by the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia.

1787.title: Mozart composes Eine kleine Nachtmusik
1787.summary: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart composes his famous Eine kleine Nachtmusik.

1787.title: Mozart's opera Don Giovanni premieres
1787.summary: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's opera Don Giovanni premieres in the Estates Theatre in Prague.

1787.title: Treaty of Versailles signed
1787.summary: Treaty of Versailles signed, forming an alliance between the Kingdom of France and the Lord Nguyễn Phúc Ánh, future Emperor of Vietnam.

1787.title: James Rumsey demonstrates water-jet propelled boat
1787.summary: James Rumsey demonstrates his water-jet propelled boat on the Potomac River.

1787.title: Delaware ratifies the Constitution
1787.summary: Delaware ratifies the Constitution, and becomes the first U.S. state.

1787.title: Pennsylvania becomes the second U.S. state
1787.summary: Pennsylvania becomes the second U.S. state.

1788.title: The Times is published
1788.summary: The first edition of The Times, previously The Daily Universal Register, is published in London.

1788.title: Georgia Ratifies Constitution
1788.summary: Georgia ratifies the United States Constitution, and becomes the fourth U.S. state under the new government.

1788.title: Connecticut Ratifies Constitution
1788.summary: Connecticut ratifies the United States Constitution, and becomes the fifth U.S. state.

1788.title: First Fleet Arrives
1788.summary: The leading ship in Captain Arthur Phillip's First Fleet arrives at Botany Bay, to colonise Australia.

1788.title: Establishment of New South Wales
1788.summary: Eleven ships of the First Fleet from Botany Bay land at Sydney Cove where Captain Arthur Phillip determines to establish the British prison colony of New South Wales, the first permanent European settlement on the continent.

1788.title: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's Symphony
1788.summary: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart completes his antepenultimate symphony, now called the Symphony No. 39 in E-flat.

1788.title: First Recorded Riot
1788.summary: America's first recorded riot, the 'Doctors' Mob', begins in Manhattan due to anger about grave robbers.

1788.title: Day of the Tiles
1788.summary: Day of the Tiles in France, considered the beginning of the French Revolution.

1788.title: The Great New Orleans Fire
1788.summary: The Great New Orleans Fire kills 25% of the population and destroys 856 buildings, including St. Louis Cathedral and The Cabildo.

1788.title: King George III becomes deranged
1788.summary: King George III of the United Kingdom becomes deranged; the Regency Crisis of 1788 starts.

1789.title: French Revolution: Tennis Court Oath
1789.summary: The representatives of the Third Estate at the Estates-General declare themselves the National Assembly, taking the Tennis Court Oath in Versailles, which marks a pivotal event in the onset of the French Revolution.

1789.title: George Washington Elected President
1789.summary: George Washington is unanimously elected as the first president of the United States by the United States Electoral College, marking a significant moment in American history.

1789.title: Estates-General Convenes
1789.summary: The Estates-General convenes for the first time in 175 years in France, a key event marking the start of the French Revolution.

1789.title: Storming of the Bastille
1789.summary: Citizens of Paris storm the fortress of the Bastille, freeing the only seven prisoners held, an iconic event representing the people's uprising during the French Revolution.

1789.title: Foundation of Georgetown University
1789.summary: Georgetown University is founded in Georgetown, Maryland, becoming the first Roman Catholic college in the United States, impacting education and religious practices in the country.

1789.title: Mutiny on the Bounty
1789.summary: Fletcher Christian leads the mutiny on the British Royal Navy ship HMS Bounty against Captain William Bligh, a notable incident in maritime history.

1789.title: Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen
1789.summary: The Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen is proclaimed in France, establishing fundamental rights and principles during the Revolution.

1789.title: First U.S. Congress Meets
1789.summary: The 1st United States Congress meets at Federal Hall in New York City and declares the new United States Constitution to be in effect, shaping the governance of the nation.

1789.title: Foundation of the United States Department of War
1789.summary: The United States Department of War is established, marking the beginning of structured military governance in the United States.

1789.title: Women's March on Versailles
1789.summary: Approximately 7,000 women march from Paris to the Palace of Versailles demanding action over high bread prices, reflecting grassroots dissent during the revolution.

1790.title: First State of the Union Address
1790.summary: United States President George Washington gives the first State of the Union address, in New York City.

1790.title: Treaty of Union
1790.summary: The 11 minor states of the Austrian Netherlands sign a Treaty of Union, creating the United States of Belgium.

1790.title: Hamilton's Debt Plan
1790.summary: U.S. Secretary of the Treasury Alexander Hamilton submits his proposed plan for payment of American debts, which is narrowly approved in Congress.

1790.title: Bounty Mutiny Landings
1790.summary: Fletcher Christian & 8 mutineers aboard the Bounty land on Pitcairn.

1790.title: Premiere of Così fan tutte
1790.summary: Mozart's opera Così fan tutte premieres in Vienna.

1790.title: First United States Census Authorized
1790.summary: The first United States Census is authorized; it is held later in the year.

1790.title: France Divided into Departments
1790.summary: France is divided into 83 départements to dislodge regional loyalties based on noble ownership of land.

1790.title: District of Columbia Established
1790.summary: U.S. President George Washington signs the Residence Act into law, establishing a site along the Potomac River as the District of Columbia.

1790.title: Introduction of the U.S. Patent System
1790.summary: The United States patent system is established, fostering innovation.

1790.title: Peking Opera is Born
1790.summary: The Peking Opera is born as the Four Great Anhui Troupes introduce Anhui opera to Beijing, in honor of the Qianlong Emperor's birthday.

1791.title: Joseph Haydn arrives in England
1791.summary: Austrian composer Joseph Haydn arrives in England, to perform a series of concerts.

1791.title: Big Bottom Massacre
1791.summary: The Northwest Indian War begins in the Ohio Country with this massacre.

1791.title: End of the Liège Revolution
1791.summary: Holy Roman troops reenter Liège, heralding the end of the Liège Revolution, and the restoration of its Prince-Bishops.

1791.title: Constitutional Act 1791
1791.summary: The British Parliament passes the Constitutional Act 1791, splitting the old province of Quebec into Upper and Lower Canada.

1791.title: Bank of the United States incorporated
1791.summary: The Bank of the United States, based in Philadelphia, is incorporated by the federal government with a 20-year charter.

1791.title: Abolition of guilds in France
1791.summary: The abolition of guilds is enacted during the French Revolution.

1791.title: Vermont admitted as a state
1791.summary: Vermont is admitted as the 14th U.S. state.

1791.title: The Polish Constitution of May 3
1791.summary: The Sejm of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth proclaims the Constitution of May 3, the first modern codified constitution in Europe.

1791.title: Flight to Varennes
1791.summary: The French Royal Family is captured when they try to flee in disguise during the French Revolution.

1791.title: First modern secondary school for girls in Denmark
1791.summary: The first serious secondary education school open to girls in Denmark, the Døtreskolen af 1791, is founded in Copenhagen.

1792.title: Treaty of Jassy
1792.summary: The Treaty of Jassy ends the Russian Empire's war with the Ottoman Empire over Crimea.

1792.title: The Road to Ruin
1792.summary: Thomas Holcroft produces the comedy The Road to Ruin in London.

1792.title: Postal Service Act
1792.summary: The Postal Service Act, establishing the United States Post Office Department, is signed by President George Washington.

1792.title: Assassination of Gustav III
1792.summary: King Gustav III of Sweden is shot in the back during a midnight masquerade at the Royal Opera in Stockholm.

1792.title: Haitian Revolution
1792.summary: Black slave insurgents gain a victory in the first major battle of the revolution at the Battle of Croix-des-Bouquets.

1792.title: La Marseillaise
1792.summary: La Marseillaise, the French national anthem, is composed by Claude Joseph Rouget de Lisle.

1792.title: French Revolutionary Wars
1792.summary: France declares war against Austria, beginning the French Revolutionary Wars and the War of the First Coalition.

1792.title: Battle of Valmy
1792.summary: The French revolutionary army defeats the Prussians after a 7-hour artillery duel at the Battle of Valmy.

1792.title: Foundation of Washington, D.C.
1792.summary: The cornerstone of the United States Executive Mansion (known as the White House after 1818) is laid.

1792.title: Mary Wollstonecraft's Publication
1792.summary: Mary Wollstonecraft's A Vindication of the Rights of Woman, one of the earliest works of feminist literature, is published in London.

1793.title: The Ebel riot
1793.summary: A riot occurs in Sweden, marking a significant social upheaval.

1793.title: First gas balloon flight in the U.S.
1793.summary: Jean-Pierre Blanchard becomes the first to fly in a gas balloon in the United States.

1793.title: Lynching of Nicolas Jean Hugon de Bassville
1793.summary: A representative of Revolutionary France is lynched by a mob in Rome.

1793.title: Guillotining of Louis XVI
1793.summary: After being found guilty of treason, Louis XVI of France is guillotined.

1793.title: Second Partition of Poland
1793.summary: The Russian Empire and the Kingdom of Prussia partition the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth.

1793.title: French Republic declares war
1793.summary: The French First Republic declares war on Great Britain and the Dutch Republic.

1793.title: First Cabinet meeting of the U.S.
1793.summary: George Washington holds the first Cabinet meeting as President of the United States.

1793.title: Guillotining of Marie Antoinette
1793.summary: Marie Antoinette is guillotined at the Place de la Révolution in Paris.

1793.title: Battle of Savenay
1793.summary: A Republican force decisively defeats the counterrevolutionary Catholic and Royal Army.

1793.title: Invention of the cotton gin
1793.summary: Eli Whitney invents a cotton gin, causing a resurgence of slavery in the South.

1794.title: The Stibo Group founded
1794.summary: The Stibo Group is founded by Niels Lund as a printing company in Aarhus.

1794.title: U.S. flag law enacted
1794.summary: The U.S. Congress enacts a law providing for a United States flag of 15 stars and 15 stripes, in recognition of the recent admission of Vermont and Kentucky as the 14th and 15th states.

1794.title: British Parliament session opened by King George III
1794.summary: King George III of Great Britain delivers the speech opening Parliament and recommends a continuation of Britain's war with France.

1794.title: French National Convention abolishes slavery
1794.summary: The National Convention of the French First Republic abolishes slavery.

1794.title: Eli Whitney granted patent for cotton gin
1794.summary: Eli Whitney is granted a United States patent for the cotton gin.

1794.title: Battle of Racławice
1794.summary: Polish supporters of the Kościuszko Uprising defeat forces of the Russian Empire.

1794.title: Kościuszko Uprising begins
1794.summary: Tadeusz Kościuszko makes his proclamation starting the Kościuszko Uprising against the Russian Empire and Kingdom of Prussia.

1794.title: First session of the U.S. Senate open to public
1794.summary: The first session of the United States Senate is open to the public.

1794.title: Battle of Fleurus
1794.summary: French forces defeat the Austrians and their allies, marking the first participation of an aircraft in battle.

1794.title: The end of the Kościuszko Uprising
1794.summary: The Kościuszko Uprising ends in the defeat of Tadeusz Kościuszko and his forces.

1795.title: The Batavian Republic Proclaimed
1795.summary: The Batavian Republic is proclaimed in Amsterdam, ending the Dutch Republic, marking a significant change in the political landscape of the Netherlands.

1795.title: University of North Carolina Opens
1795.summary: The University of North Carolina opens to students at Chapel Hill, becoming the first state university in the United States.

1795.title: French Troops Enter Amsterdam
1795.summary: French troops enter Amsterdam, reinforcing their control in the Netherlands during the War of the First Coalition.

1795.title: Ludwig van Beethoven's Debut
1795.summary: Ludwig van Beethoven makes his public debut in Vienna performing his Second Piano Concerto under the baton of his teacher Antonio Salieri, marking an important milestone in classical music.

1795.title: Peace of Basel Signed
1795.summary: The Peace of Basel is signed between France and Prussia, a significant diplomatic event in the context of the War of the First Coalition.

1795.title: Copenhagen Fire
1795.summary: The Copenhagen Fire of 1795, starting in a naval warehouse, destroys 941 houses, causing significant damage in the city.

1795.title: Treaty of Greenville Signed
1795.summary: The signing of the Treaty of Greenville puts an end to the Northwest Indian War, shaping territorial boundaries in North America.

1795.title: Construction of Pontcysyllte Aqueduct Begins
1795.summary: Construction of the Pontcysyllte Aqueduct in Wales begins, an important engineering landmark.

1795.title: Warren Hastings Acquitted
1795.summary: Former Governor-General of India Warren Hastings is acquitted by the British House of Lords of misconduct, marking a notable event in British colonial history.

1795.title: British Capture of Cape Town
1795.summary: British forces capture Cape Town in the Dutch Cape Colony, using its strategic facilities against the French Navy during the Revolutionary Wars.

1796.title: Dutch elections held for the National Assembly
1796.summary: The first Dutch (and general) elections are held for the National Assembly of the Batavian Republic.

1796.title: Capital of Upper Canada moved to York
1796.summary: The capital of Upper Canada is moved from Newark to York.

1796.title: Qianlong Emperor abdicates
1796.summary: The Qianlong Emperor of China abdicates at age 84 to make way for his son, the Jiaqing Emperor.

1796.title: End of the Invasion of Ceylon
1796.summary: The Invasion of Ceylon ends when Johan van Angelbeek, the Batavian governor of Ceylon, surrenders Colombo peacefully to British forces.

1796.title: Ratifications of the Jay Treaty exchanged
1796.summary: Ratifications of the Jay Treaty between Great Britain and the United States are officially exchanged, bringing it into effect.

1796.title: Napoleon marries Joséphine de Beauharnais
1796.summary: Widow Joséphine de Beauharnais marries General Napoléon Bonaparte.

1796.title: Napoleon arrives at Nice
1796.summary: Napoleon Bonaparte arrives at Nice to take command of the Army of Italy, which is scattered in detachments.

1796.title: First smallpox vaccination administered
1796.summary: Edward Jenner administers the first smallpox vaccination, in England.

1796.title: Napoleon's troops take Milan
1796.summary: Napoleon's troops take Milan during the War of the First Coalition.

1796.title: Battle of Arcole
1796.summary: French forces under General Napoleon defeat the Austrians at Arcole, outflanking the army and cutting off its line of retreat.

1797.title: Treaty of Tripoli
1797.summary: A peace treaty between the United States and Ottoman Tripolitania is signed at Algiers.

1797.title: Italian Tricolour Adoption
1797.summary: The parliament of the Cisalpine Republic adopts the Italian green-white-red tricolour as their official flag, considered the birth of the flag of Italy.

1797.title: Action of 13 January 1797
1797.summary: Two British Royal Navy frigates drive the French Droits de l'Homme aground, resulting in over 900 deaths.

1797.title: Battle of Rivoli
1797.summary: French forces under Napoleon Bonaparte defeat an Austrian army near Rivoli, ending Austria's attempt to relieve Mantua.

1797.title: Treaty of the Third Partition of Poland
1797.summary: The treaty is signed in St. Petersburg by the Russian Empire, Austria, and Prussia.

1797.title: Siege of Mantua
1797.summary: Field marshal Dagobert von Wurmser surrenders the fortress city to the French, with only 16,000 men marching out as prisoners of war.

1797.title: Performance of Gott erhalte Franz den Kaiser
1797.summary: The composition by Joseph Haydn is first performed, which becomes the tune to the German national anthem.

1797.title: Battle of Cape St. Vincent
1797.summary: The British Royal Navy defeats a larger Spanish fleet off Cape St. Vincent, Portugal.

1797.title: Invasion of Trinidad
1797.summary: Spanish Governor José María Chacón peacefully surrenders the colony of Trinidad to a British naval force.

1797.title: Battle of Valvasone
1797.summary: The Austrian army, led by Archduke Charles, is defeated by Napoleon Bonaparte at Valvasone.

1798.title: Eli Whitney contracts for muskets
1798.summary: Eli Whitney contracts with the U.S. federal government for 10,000 muskets, which he produces with interchangeable parts.

1798.title: Pope captured
1798.summary: The Pope is taken captive, and the Papacy is removed from power, by French General Louis-Alexandre Berthier.

1798.title: Irish Rebellion of 1798 begins
1798.summary: The Irish Rebellion of 1798 begins, uniting Catholics and Protestants around republican ideals.

1798.title: The Mississippi Territory organized
1798.summary: The Mississippi Territory is organized by the United States from territory ceded by Georgia and South Carolina.

1798.title: Helvetic Republic proclaimed
1798.summary: The Helvetic Republic, a French client republic, is proclaimed following the collapse of the Old Swiss Confederacy after the French invasion.

1798.title: Alien and Sedition Acts signed
1798.summary: The first of the four Alien and Sedition Acts is signed into law by U.S. President Adams, requiring immigrants to wait 14 years to become naturalized citizens.

1798.title: Battle of the Pyramids
1798.summary: Napoleon defeats Ottoman forces near the Pyramids during a campaign in Egypt.

1798.title: Battle of the Nile
1798.summary: Lord Nelson defeats the French navy near Abu Qir, capturing or destroying most of their ships.

1798.title: Lyrical Ballads published
1798.summary: Lyrical Ballads is published anonymously by Samuel Taylor Coleridge and William Wordsworth, inaugurating the English Romantic movement in literature.

1798.title: Edward Jenner publishes smallpox vaccine
1798.summary: Edward Jenner publishes An Inquiry into the Causes and Effects of the Variolæ Vaccinæ, describing the smallpox vaccine, in London.

1799.title: Income Tax Introduced
1799.summary: British Prime Minister William Pitt the Younger introduces an income tax of two shillings to the pound, to raise funds for Great Britain's war effort in the French Revolutionary Wars.

1799.title: Establishment of the Parthenopean Republic
1799.summary: The Parthenopean Republic is established in Naples by French General Jean Étienne Championnet; King Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies flees.

1799.title: Battle of 28 February 1799
1799.summary: British Royal Navy frigate HMS Sybille defeats the French frigate Forte off the mouth of the Hooghly River in the Bay of Bengal, but both captains are killed.

1799.title: Siege of Jaffa
1799.summary: Napoleon captures Jaffa in Palestine from the Ottomans and his troops proceed to kill more than 2,000 Albanian captives.

1799.title: Public Premiere of Haydn’s The Creation
1799.summary: The public premiere of Haydn’s oratorio The Creation takes place at the Burgtheater in Vienna.

1799.title: Battle of the Trebbia
1799.summary: The beginning of the battle that marked the debacle of Étienne Macdonald's French army. Suvorov scores a comprehensive victory.

1799.title: Capture of Rosetta Stone
1799.summary: In the Egyptian port city of Rosetta, French Captain Pierre Bouchard finds the Rosetta Stone.

1799.title: Napoleon Overthrows French Directory
1799.summary: Napoleon overthrows the French Directory in a coup d'état, which ends the French Revolution.

1799.title: Abolishment of the Constitution of the Year III
1799.summary: A remnant of the Council of Ancients in France abolishes the Constitution of the Year III, establishing the French Consulate with Napoleon as First Consul.

1799.title: Death of George Washington
1799.summary: George Washington, first President of the United States, dies at Mount Vernon, Virginia, aged 67.

1800.title: Quasi-War
1800.summary: A naval battle off the coast of Haiti ends indecisively between United States merchant vessels and Haitian pirates.

1800.title: Napoleon as First Consul
1800.summary: A public plebiscite in France confirms Napoleon as First Consul by a substantial majority.

1800.title: Infrared Radiation Discovered
1800.summary: Infrared radiation is discovered by astronomer Sir William Herschel.

1800.title: Papal Conclave
1800.summary: Cardinal Barnaba Chiaramonti succeeds Pius VI as Pius VII during the papal conclave.

1800.title: HMS Queen Charlotte Fire
1800.summary: The British Royal Navy ship catches fire off the coast of Capraia, resulting in the loss of 673 lives.

1800.title: Voltaic Pile Invention
1800.summary: Alessandro Volta describes his invention, the voltaic pile, in a letter to the Royal Society.

1800.title: Beethoven's Symphony No. 1 Premiere
1800.summary: Ludwig van Beethoven's Symphony No. 1 premieres at the Burgtheater in Vienna.

1800.title: U.S. Library of Congress Founded
1800.summary: The U.S. Library of Congress is established in Washington, D.C.

1800.title: Battle of Marengo
1800.summary: Napoleon defeats Austrian troops near Marengo, expanding French control in Italy.

1800.title: Battle of Hohenlinden
1800.summary: The French army defeats Habsburg and Bavarian troops during the War of the Second Coalition.

1801.title: Formation of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland
1801.summary: The legislative union of Great Britain and Ireland is completed under the Act of Union 1800, bringing about the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, and the abolition of the Parliament of Ireland.

1801.title: Discovery of Ceres
1801.summary: Giuseppe Piazzi discovers the asteroid and dwarf planet Ceres.

1801.title: Toussaint Louverture enters Santo Domingo
1801.summary: Toussaint Louverture triumphantly enters Santo Domingo, now a colony of Napoleonic France.

1801.title: John Marshall appointed Chief Justice
1801.summary: John Marshall is appointed Chief Justice of the United States.

1801.title: Resignation of William Pitt the Younger
1801.summary: William Pitt the Younger resigns as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.

1801.title: Treaty of Lunéville
1801.summary: The Treaty of Lunéville ends the War of the Second Coalition between France and Austria, annexing German territories by France.

1801.title: Jefferson elected President
1801.summary: An electoral tie between Thomas Jefferson and Aaron Burr is resolved, and Jefferson is elected President of the United States.

1801.title: Thomas Jefferson sworn in
1801.summary: Thomas Jefferson is sworn in as the third President of the United States.

1801.title: First census in Great Britain
1801.summary: The first census is held in Great Britain, revealing a population of 8.9 million in England and Wales.

1801.title: First Battle of Copenhagen
1801.summary: The British Royal Navy forces the Royal Dano-Norwegian Navy to accept an armistice, leading to notable British naval command decisions.

1802.title: Removal of the Elgin Marbles
1802.summary: Thomas Bruce begins removal of the Elgin Marbles from the Parthenon in Athens, claiming they were at risk of destruction during the Ottoman occupation of Greece.

1802.title: Establishment of Canonsburg Academy
1802.summary: Canonsburg Academy is chartered by the Pennsylvania General Assembly.

1802.title: French expedition to Saint-Domingue
1802.summary: A French expeditionary force lands in Saint-Domingue to restore colonial rule where Toussaint Louverture proclaims himself Governor-General for Life.

1802.title: Beethoven publishes Moonlight Sonata
1802.summary: Ludwig van Beethoven publishes his Piano Sonata No. 14, commonly known as the Moonlight Sonata, in Vienna.

1802.title: Rosetta Stone presented to British Museum
1802.summary: The Rosetta Stone is presented to the Society of Antiquaries of London, which in turn presents it to the British Museum.

1802.title: Treaty of Amiens
1802.summary: The Treaty of Amiens between the French Republic and the United Kingdom ends the War of the Second Coalition and the French Revolutionary Wars.

1802.title: Establishment of the United States Patent Office
1802.summary: The United States Patent and Trademark Office is established within the Department of State.

1802.title: Establishment of the French Legion of Honour
1802.summary: Napoleon establishes the French Legion of Honour as a recognition of military and civil merit.

1802.title: Marie Tussaud's first exhibition
1802.summary: Madame Marie Tussaud first exhibits her wax sculptures in London, having been commissioned to make death masks of the victims of the Reign of Terror in France.

1802.title: Earthquake in Vrancea
1802.summary: A powerful 7.9 earthquake shakes the Romanian district of Vrancea destroying hundreds of buildings and killing 4 people.

1803.title: Publication of Almanach des gourmands
1803.summary: The first edition of a guide to restaurant cooking is published in Paris.

1803.title: Demonstration of the Charlotte Dundas
1803.summary: William Symington demonstrates the first practical steamboat in Scotland.

1803.title: Louisiana Purchase negotiations
1803.summary: Monroe and Livingston sail for Paris to discuss the potential purchase of New Orleans, leading to the Louisiana Purchase.

1803.title: Establishment of the Swiss Confederation
1803.summary: Napoleon Bonaparte issues an Act of Mediation establishing the Swiss Confederation.

1803.title: Admission of Ohio as a state
1803.summary: Ohio is admitted as the 17th U.S. state.

1803.title: Marbury v. Madison ruling
1803.summary: The Supreme Court of the United States establishes the principle of judicial review.

1803.title: Introduction of the franc germinal
1803.summary: The franc germinal is introduced as a new currency in France.

1803.title: Launch of the Louisiana Purchase
1803.summary: The purchase is announced to the American public.

1803.title: Beginning of the Napoleonic Wars
1803.summary: The United Kingdom declares war on France after refusing to withdraw from Dutch territory.

1803.title: Haitian Revolution Battle of Vertières
1803.summary: The Haitian army defeats the French army in this significant battle of the Haitian Revolution.

1804.title: Haiti gains independence
1804.summary: Haiti gains independence from France, and becomes the first black republic, having the only successful slave revolt ever.

1804.title: The Sokoto Caliphate is founded
1804.summary: The Sokoto Caliphate is founded in West Africa.

1804.title: The First Serbian uprising
1804.summary: The First Serbian uprising begins the Serbian Revolution. By 1817, the Principality of Serbia will have proclaimed self-rule from the Ottoman Empire, the first nation-state in Europe to do so.

1804.title: New Jersey abolishes slavery
1804.summary: New Jersey becomes the last of the northern United States to abolish slavery.

1804.title: First Barbary War
1804.summary: First Barbary War: Stephen Decatur leads a raid to burn the pirate-held frigate USS Philadelphia at Tripoli to deny her further use by the captors.

1804.title: Invention of the Penydarren steam locomotive
1804.summary: Cornishman Richard Trevithick's newly built Penydarren steam locomotive operates on the Merthyr Tramroad, the world's first locomotive to work on rails.

1804.title: Louisiana Purchase ceremony
1804.summary: In St. Louis, a formal ceremony is conducted to transfer ownership of Louisiana Territory from France to the United States.

1804.title: First performance of Wilhelm Tell
1804.summary: Friedrich Schiller's play Wilhelm Tell is first performed at Weimar, under the direction of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe.

1804.title: Coronation of Napoleon I
1804.summary: Coronation of Napoleon I: At the cathedral of Notre Dame de Paris, Napoleon crowns himself as the first Emperor of the French in a thousand years.

1804.title: Discovery of morphine
1804.summary: Morphine is first isolated from the opium poppy by the German pharmacist, Friedrich Sertürner.

1805.title: The Michigan Territory is created
1805.summary: The Michigan Territory is officially established, marking an important development in governance in the region.

1805.title: Formation of the Harmony Society
1805.summary: The Harmony Society is officially formed as a Christian communal society in Harmony, Pennsylvania, emphasizing collective living and religious devotion.

1805.title: Beethoven's Symphony No. 3 Premiere
1805.summary: Beethoven's Symphony No. 3, known as Eroica, is premiered at the Theater an der Wien in Vienna, a pivotal moment in the classical music repertoire.

1805.title: Napoleon crowned King of Italy
1805.summary: Napoleon Bonaparte is crowned King of Italy, consolidating his power and influence over the Italian territories during the Napoleonic Wars.

1805.title: Battle of Trafalgar
1805.summary: The British fleet, commanded by Admiral Horatio Nelson, defeats a combined French and Spanish fleet off the coast of Spain in a decisive naval battle.

1805.title: Voyage of the Lewis and Clark Expedition
1805.summary: The Lewis and Clark Expedition reaches the Pacific Ocean, marking a significant exploration milestone in United States history.

1805.title: Battle of Austerlitz
1805.summary: In a decisive battle during the Napoleonic Wars, French troops led by Napoleon defeat a joint Russo-Austrian force, earning a significant victory.

1805.title: The Peace of Pressburg
1805.summary: The Peace of Pressburg is signed, solidifying territorial changes in Europe following Napoleon's victories against the Austrians.

1805.title: Beethoven's only opera Fidelio premieres
1805.summary: Beethoven's only opera, Fidelio, premieres at Theater an der Wien, adding to the cultural significance of the time.

1805.title: The opening of the Pontcysyllte Aqueduct
1805.summary: The Pontcysyllte Aqueduct is opened in Wales, showcasing engineering advancements in the construction of water transport systems.

1806.title: Abolishment of the French Republican Calendar
1806.summary: The French Republican Calendar is abolished.

1806.title: Establishment of the Kingdom of Bavaria
1806.summary: The Kingdom of Bavaria is established by Napoleon.

1806.title: Battle of Blaauwberg
1806.summary: British infantry force troops of the Batavian Republic in the Dutch Cape Colony to withdraw.

1806.title: Capitulation of the Dutch Cape Colony
1806.summary: The Dutch commandant of Cape Town surrenders to British forces, leading to its status as a colony within the British Empire.

1806.title: Battle of San Domingo
1806.summary: The British Royal Navy gains a victory over the French off Santo Domingo.

1806.title: Explorers Lewis and Clark return
1806.summary: Explorers Lewis and Clark and their Corps of Discovery begin their journey home after reaching the Pacific Ocean.

1806.title: Louis Bonaparte appointed King of Holland
1806.summary: Louis Bonaparte is appointed as King of Holland by his brother, Emperor Napoleon.

1806.title: Battle of Jena–Auerstedt
1806.summary: Napoleon defeats the Prussian army at Jena, leading to significant French victories and territorial gains.

1806.title: Napoleon's Continental Blockade
1806.summary: Napoleon declares the Continental Blockade against the British, impacting trade across Europe.

1806.title: Ludwig van Beethoven's violin concerto premiere
1806.summary: Ludwig van Beethoven premieres his violin concerto at the Theater an der Wien, influencing the musical landscape.

1807.title: UK Order in Council
1807.summary: The United Kingdom issues an Order in Council prohibiting British ships from trading with France or its allies.

1807.title: Battle of Montevideo
1807.summary: The British Army captures Montevideo from the Spanish Empire as part of the British invasions of the Río de la Plata.

1807.title: Battle of Eylau
1807.summary: Napoleon fights a hard but inconclusive battle against the Russians under Bennigsen.

1807.title: Slave Trade Act Passed
1807.summary: The Slave Trade Act is passed in the House of Commons of the United Kingdom by an overwhelming majority.

1807.title: Abolition of Slave Trade in UK
1807.summary: The United Kingdom Slave Trade Act becomes law abolishing the slave trade in most of the British Empire.

1807.title: Froberg Mutiny Suppressed
1807.summary: The British suppress a mutiny at Fort Ricasoli, Malta, by men of the irregularly-recruited Frobert Regiment.

1807.title: Siege of Danzig Ends
1807.summary: Siege of Danzig ends after 6 weeks with Prussian and Russian defenders capitulating to French forces.

1807.title: Treaties of Tilsit Signed
1807.summary: The Treaties of Tilsit are signed between France, Prussia and Russia, altering European territories significantly.

1807.title: First Passenger Railway Opens
1807.summary: The Swansea and Mumbles Railway becomes the first passenger-carrying railway in the world.

1807.title: First American Steamboat Service
1807.summary: The North River Steamboat leaves New York City for Albany, inaugurating the first commercial steamboat service in the world.

1808.title: Abolition of the Slave Trade
1808.summary: The slave trade is abolished by the United Kingdom in all of its colonies as the Slave Trade Act 1807 takes effect.

1808.title: Transfer of the Portuguese court to Brazil
1808.summary: John, Prince Regent, and the Bragança royal family of Portugal arrive in their colony of Brazil in exile from the French occupation of their home kingdom.

1808.title: Rum Rebellion
1808.summary: On the 20th anniversary of the foundation of the colony of New South Wales, disgruntled military officers overthrow and imprison Governor William Bligh.

1808.title: First burning of anthracite coal for residential heating
1808.summary: In Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania, Jesse Fell becomes the first person in the world to burn anthracite coal as residential heating fuel.

1808.title: Charles IV of Spain abdicates
1808.summary: Charles IV of Spain abdicates in favor of his son, Ferdinand VII.

1808.title: Battle of Bailén
1808.summary: French General Dupont surrenders to Spanish irregular forces during the Peninsular War.

1808.title: Ferdinand forced to abdicate
1808.summary: Ferdinand is forced to abdicate as King of Spain by Napoleon, effectively ending the Anglo-Spanish War.

1808.title: Peninsular War begins
1808.summary: The people of Madrid rise up against the French troops during the Dos de Mayo Uprising.

1808.title: Beethoven's marathon concert
1808.summary: Ludwig van Beethoven conducts and plays in a benefit concert in Vienna, featuring first public performances of several works.

1808.title: Establishment of Banco do Brasil
1808.summary: Banco do Brasil, a major financial group in South America, is founded in Rio de Janeiro.

1809.title: Battle of Corunna
1809.summary: Sir John Moore is killed at the Battle of Corunna during the Peninsular War as British forces resist an attempt by the French to prevent their embarkation.

1809.title: Patent of the Steamboat
1809.summary: Robert Fulton patents the steamboat in the United States, marking a significant technical advance in transportation.

1809.title: Creation of the Illinois Territory
1809.summary: The Illinois Territory is created from the western part of the Indiana Territory, expanding U.S. governance.

1809.title: Siege of Zaragoza
1809.summary: The Siege of Zaragoza ends after 60 days, with heavy casualties, impacting the Peninsular War and its stakeholders.

1809.title: Battle of Valls
1809.summary: Spanish forces are defeated in Catalonia by Marshal Laurent de Gouvion Saint-Cyr during the Peninsular War.

1809.title: Embargo Act Repealed
1809.summary: The Embargo Act of 1807 is repealed in the United States, marking a shift in trade policy.

1809.title: James Madison Sworn In
1809.summary: James Madison is sworn in as the fourth President of the United States, impacting American politics.

1809.title: Coup in Sweden
1809.summary: A military coup ousts Gustav IV Adolf of Sweden, leading to significant political changes in the region.

1809.title: Battle of Talavera
1809.summary: Sir Arthur Wellesley's British, Portuguese, and Spanish army defeats a French force in a pivotal battle during the Peninsular War.

1809.title: Napoleon's Annexation of Papal States
1809.summary: Napoleon I orders the annexation of the Papal States to the French Empire, ending the Pope's secular power.

1810.title: Lachlan Macquarie becomes Governor of New South Wales
1810.summary: Major-General Lachlan Macquarie officially becomes Governor of New South Wales.

1810.title: Annulment of Napoleon's Marriage
1810.summary: The marriage of Napoleon and Joséphine is annulled.

1810.title: Napoleonic Troops Enter Málaga
1810.summary: After seizing Jaén, Córdoba, Seville and Granada, Napoleonic troops enter Málaga under the command of General Horace Sebastiani.

1810.title: Napoleon Decrees Rome as Second Capital
1810.summary: Napoleon Bonaparte decrees that Rome would become the second capital of the French Empire.

1810.title: Napoleon Marries Marie-Louise
1810.summary: Napoleon marries Marie-Louise of Austria by proxy in Vienna.

1810.title: Venezuela Achieves Home Rule
1810.summary: Venezuela achieves home rule: Vicente Emparán is removed by the people of Caracas, and Supreme Junta is installed.

1810.title: Beethoven Composes Für Elise
1810.summary: Beethoven composes his famous piano piece, Für Elise.

1810.title: May Revolution in Buenos Aires
1810.summary: Armed citizens of Buenos Aires expel the Viceroy and establish a provincial government for Argentina (the Primera Junta).

1810.title: First Commercial Savings Bank Opens
1810.summary: Rev. Henry Duncan opens the world's first commercial savings bank, in Ruthwell, Scotland.

1810.title: Independence Declared in Santa Cruz de Mompox
1810.summary: The city of Santa Cruz de Mompox, in modern-day Colombia, declares independence from the Spanish Empire.

1811.title: An unsuccessful slave revolt led by Charles Deslondes
1811.summary: Charles Deslondes leads a revolt in St. Charles and St. James Parishes, Louisiana.

1811.title: Battle of Calderón Bridge
1811.summary: A Spanish force defeats nearly 100,000 Mexican revolutionaries in Mexico.

1811.title: The Casas Revolt
1811.summary: The Casas Revolt begins in San Antonio, Texas.

1811.title: George, Prince of Wales becomes prince regent
1811.summary: George, Prince of Wales, becomes regent due to the insanity of King George III.

1811.title: Battle of the Gebora
1811.summary: An outnumbered French force routs and nearly destroys the Spanish near Badajoz, Spain.

1811.title: Citadel Massacre
1811.summary: Muhammad Ali kills the last Mamluk leaders in Cairo, marking a significant power shift in Egypt.

1811.title: Battle of Barrosa
1811.summary: A French attack on a larger Anglo-Portuguese-Spanish force fails in Spain.

1811.title: Battle of Lissa
1811.summary: The British fleet defeats the French, asserting naval dominance in the region.

1811.title: Venezuela declares independence
1811.summary: Venezuela declares its independence from the Spanish Empire.

1811.title: The first steam-powered ferry service
1811.summary: John Stevens' boat, the Juliana, begins operation between New York City and Hoboken, marking technological advancement in transportation.

1812.title: The Allgemeines bürgerliches Gesetzbuch
1812.summary: The Austrian civil code enters into force in the Austrian Empire

1812.title: Storming of Ciudad Rodrigo
1812.summary: The French-held fortress of Ciudad Rodrigo is stormed by the Anglo-Portuguese Army, under the Earl of Wellington

1812.title: New Madrid earthquake
1812.summary: The last New Madrid earthquake strikes New Madrid, Missouri, with an estimated moment magnitude of over 8

1812.title: Metric system approval
1812.summary: Napoleon authorizes the usage of Mesures usuelles, the basis of the metric system

1812.title: First Argentine flag raising
1812.summary: Manuel Belgrano raises the Flag of Argentina in the city of Rosario

1812.title: Treaty of Paris between Prussia and France
1812.summary: Prussia and France sign the Treaty of Paris

1812.title: Battle of Badajoz
1812.summary: The Anglo-Portuguese Army besieges Badajoz, Spain and forces the surrender of the French garrison

1812.title: Creation of the modern Spanish constitution
1812.summary: The Cortes of Cádiz creates the first modern Spanish constitution

1812.title: War of 1812 begins
1812.summary: U.S. President James Madison asks the U.S. Congress to declare war on the United Kingdom

1812.title: Assassination of British Prime Minister
1812.summary: John Bellingham assassinates British Prime Minister Spencer Perceval, in the lobby of the British House of Commons

1813.title: Danish state bankruptcy of 1813
1813.summary: Danish state bankruptcy leads to significant economic changes in Denmark.

1813.title: Battle of Frenchtown
1813.summary: The Battle of Frenchtown is fought in modern-day Monroe, Michigan between the United States and a British and Native American alliance.

1813.title: Foundation of the Philharmonic Society
1813.summary: The Philharmonic Society is founded in London, influencing the music scene significantly.

1813.title: Publication of Pride and Prejudice
1813.summary: Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice is published anonymously in London, impacting literature and culture.

1813.title: Inauguration of the Assembly of the Year XIII
1813.summary: The Assembly of the Year XIII is inaugurated in Buenos Aires, marking a significant political event in Argentina.

1813.title: Battle of San Lorenzo
1813.summary: José de San Martín achieves a symbolic victory at the Battle of San Lorenzo against a Spanish royalist army.

1813.title: Construction of Fort Meigs
1813.summary: Construction begins on Fort Meigs in Ohio, a key military installation during the War of 1812.

1813.title: Evacuation of Berlin
1813.summary: The French garrison evacuates Berlin, allowing Russian troops to take the city without a fight.

1813.title: Prussia declares war on France
1813.summary: Prussia declares war on France, escalating the Napoleonic Wars.

1813.title: Beethoven's Symphony No. 7 premiere
1813.summary: Ludwig van Beethoven's Symphony No. 7 premieres in Vienna, showcasing his impact on classical music.

1814.title: Eruption of Mount Mayon
1814.summary: Mount Mayon erupts for the second time, resulting in the destruction of Cagsawa Church and over 1,200 deaths.

1814.title: War of the Sixth Coalition - Siege of Metz
1814.summary: Allied armies lay siege to the French city and fortress of Metz, contributing significantly to the eventual downfall of Napoleon.

1814.title: War of 1812 - Battle of Emuckfaw and Enotachopo Creek
1814.summary: United States forces under General Andrew Jackson defeat the Red Sticks in northern Alabama, a decisive encounter in the War of 1812.

1814.title: Treaty of Fontainebleau
1814.summary: The War of the Sixth Coalition ends with the Treaty of Fontainebleau, forcing Napoleon to abdicate unconditionally as Emperor of the French.

1814.title: Publication of The Corsair
1814.summary: Lord Byron's semi-autobiographical verse tale The Corsair is published, selling 10,000 copies on its release, showcasing the cultural impact of literature during this era.

1814.title: Anglo-Nepalese War begins
1814.summary: The Anglo-Nepalese War begins as Francis Rawdon-Hastings, the Governor-General of India, declares war on the Kingdom of Nepal.

1814.title: The Congress of Vienna opens
1814.summary: The Congress of Vienna formally opens in Austria to settle issues arising from the Napoleonic Wars and redraft national borders in Europe.

1814.title: Battle of Paris
1814.summary: Coalition troops occupy Paris, marking a significant moment in the conflict against Napoleon's regime during the War of the Sixth Coalition.

1814.title: War of the Sixth Coalition - Battle of La Rothière
1814.summary: Blücher's Allied army defeats the French under Napoleon at La Rothière, a crucial battle contributing to Napoleon's decline.

1814.title: The Great Stock Exchange Fraud exposed
1814.summary: A major financial scandal, The Great Stock Exchange Fraud, is exposed in London, highlighting issues of economic stability during this period.

1815.title: Lord Byron marries Anna Isabella Milbanke
1815.summary: Lord Byron marries Anna Isabella Milbanke in Seaham, county of Durham, England.

1815.title: Defensive alliance against Prussia and Russia
1815.summary: Austria, Britain, and Bourbon-restored France form a secret defensive alliance treaty against Prussia and Russia.

1815.title: Battle of New Orleans
1815.summary: American forces led by Andrew Jackson defeat British forces led by Sir Edward Pakenham.

1815.title: Capture of Fort Peter
1815.summary: British troops capture Fort Peter in St. Marys, Georgia, the only battle of the War of 1812 to take place in the state.

1815.title: Capture of USS President
1815.summary: American frigate USS President is captured by a squadron of four British frigates.

1815.title: First commercial cheese factory
1815.summary: The first commercial cheese factory is founded in Switzerland.

1815.title: The Spanish reconquest of Latin America begins
1815.summary: The Spanish reconquest of Latin America begins.

1815.title: The Final Act of the Congress of Vienna is signed
1815.summary: A new European political situation is set with the signing of the Final Act of the Congress of Vienna.

1815.title: Battle of Waterloo
1815.summary: Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington, decisively defeats Napoleon at the Battle of Waterloo.

1816.title: Order to expel Jesuits
1816.summary: Tsar Alexander I of Russia signs an order, expelling the Jesuits from St. Petersburg and Moscow.

1816.title: Davy lamp first tested
1816.summary: Sir Humphry Davy's Davy lamp is first tested underground as a coal mining safety lamp, at Hebburn Colliery in northeast England.

1816.title: Fire in St. John's
1816.summary: Fire nearly destroys the city of St. John's, Newfoundland.

1816.title: Death of Friedrich Karl Ludwig
1816.summary: Friedrich Karl Ludwig, Duke of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Beck, dies and is succeeded by Friedrich Wilhelm, his son and founder of the House of Glücksburg.

1816.title: Premiere of The Barber of Seville
1816.summary: Gioachino Rossini's opera buffa The Barber of Seville premieres at the Teatro Argentina in Rome.

1816.title: End of Gorkha War
1816.summary: The Gorkha War between the United Kingdom and Nepal is ended by the ratification of the Treaty of Sugauli, with Nepal ceding territory to British Indian control.

1816.title: Reorganization of the Institut de France
1816.summary: The Institut de France is reorganized by King Louis XVIII of France into four royal academies.

1816.title: Second Bank of the United States charter
1816.summary: The Second Bank of the United States obtains its charter.

1816.title: Establishment of African Methodist Episcopal Church
1816.summary: In Philadelphia, the African Methodist Episcopal Church is established by Richard Allen and other African-American Methodists, the first such denomination in the U.S.

1816.title: Independence of United Provinces of South America
1816.summary: The United Provinces of South America declares independence from Spain.

1817.title: Discovery of New Year Island
1817.summary: Sailing through the Sandwich Islands, Otto von Kotzebue discovers New Year Island.

1817.title: Crossing of the Andes
1817.summary: An army of 5,423 soldiers, led by General José de San Martín, starts crossing the Andes from Argentina, to liberate Chile and then Peru.

1817.title: Establishment of Hindu College
1817.summary: Ram Mohan Roy and David Hare found Hindu College, Calcutta, offering instructions in Western languages and subjects.

1817.title: Battle of Chacabuco
1817.summary: The Argentine–Chilean patriotic army defeats the Spanish.

1817.title: Veto of Bonus Bill
1817.summary: President James Madison vetoes John C. Calhoun's Bonus Bill.

1817.title: Swearing in of James Monroe
1817.summary: James Monroe is sworn in as the fifth President of the United States.

1817.title: Opening of the American School for the Deaf
1817.summary: The American School for the Deaf opens in Hartford, Connecticut.

1817.title: Signing of the Rush–Bagot Treaty
1817.summary: The Rush–Bagot Treaty is signed, regulating naval armament on the Great Lakes.

1817.title: Creation of Alabama Territory
1817.summary: The Alabama Territory is created by splitting the Mississippi Territory in half, effective in August.

1817.title: Opening of the University of Michigan
1817.summary: The University of Michigan is founded in Detroit, Michigan.

1818.title: Battle of Koregaon
1818.summary: Troops of the British East India Company score a decisive victory over the Maratha Empire.

1818.title: Publication of Frankenstein
1818.summary: English author Mary Shelley published the novel Frankenstein.

1818.title: Treaty of Mandeswar
1818.summary: The Treaty of Mandeswar brings an end to the Third Anglo-Maratha War, ending the dominance of Marathas, and enhancing the power of the British East India Company.

1818.title: Invention of the Dandy horse
1818.summary: The Dandy horse (Laufmaschine bicycle) is invented by Karl Drais in Mannheim.

1818.title: Chilean Declaration of Independence
1818.summary: Chilean Declaration of Independence from Spain is proclaimed in Chile.

1818.title: Battle of Maipú
1818.summary: Chilean War of Independence - Battle of Maipú: Patriot rebels, led by José de San Martín, decisively defeat the Spanish Royalists.

1818.title: Death of King Charles XIII
1818.summary: Upon his death, King Charles XIII of Sweden is succeeded by his adoptive son Charles XIV/III John, starting the Royal House of Bernadotte.

1818.title: The Old Vic Theatre founded
1818.summary: The Old Vic Theatre is founded (as the Royal Coburg Hall) in London.

1818.title: Founding of Anglo-Chinese College
1818.summary: Anglo-Chinese College is founded by Robert Morrison in Malacca, later renamed Ying Wa College.

1818.title: First performance of Silent Night
1818.summary: The Christmas carol Silent Night is first performed at St. Nikolaus Parish Church, in Oberndorf bei Salzburg, Austria.

1819.title: Panic of 1819
1819.summary: The first major peacetime financial crisis in the United States begins.

1819.title: University of Virginia founded
1819.summary: Thomas Jefferson founds the University of Virginia.

1819.title: Foundation of Singapore
1819.summary: Sir Stamford Raffles lands on the island of Singapore.

1819.title: Dartmouth College v. Woodward
1819.summary: The Supreme Court of the United States rules in favor of Dartmouth College, allowing it to keep its charter.

1819.title: Adams–Onís Treaty
1819.summary: Spain cedes Florida to the United States in exchange for renouncing claims on Texas.

1819.title: Launch of USS Columbus
1819.summary: U.S. naval vessel USS Columbus is launched in Washington, D.C.

1819.title: First steamship across the Atlantic
1819.summary: The SS Savannah leaves Savannah, Georgia, to become the first steamship to cross the Atlantic Ocean.

1819.title: Rann of Kutch earthquake
1819.summary: A significant earthquake in Gujarat kills at least 1,543 people, raising land as much as 6 m.

1819.title: Peterloo Massacre
1819.summary: A yeomanry unit charges into a crowd of protesters in Manchester, resulting in deaths and injuries.

1819.title: Republic of Gran Colombia established
1819.summary: The Republic of Gran Colombia is formally established, with Simón Bolívar as its first president.

1820.title: Cato Street Conspiracy
1820.summary: A plot to murder the Cabinet of the United Kingdom is exposed in England.

1820.title: Nominal Beginning of the Trienio Liberal
1820.summary: A constitutionalist military insurrection at Cádiz leads to the summoning of the Spanish Parliament.

1820.title: General Maritime Treaty
1820.summary: Treaty signed between sheikhs of the Arabian Peninsula and the United Kingdom.

1820.title: Discovery of Antarctica
1820.summary: An Imperial Russian Navy expedition sights the Antarctic ice sheet.

1820.title: First Identification of Antarctica
1820.summary: British Royal Navy captain Edward Bransfield identifies Antarctica as a land mass.

1820.title: Capture of Valdivia
1820.summary: Lord Cochrane occupies Valdivia in the name of the Republic of Chile.

1820.title: Coup Attempt in Paraguay
1820.summary: A Coup d'état against Paraguayan dictator fails.

1820.title: Opening of the Union Chain Bridge
1820.summary: The world's longest vehicular suspension bridge opens across the River Tweed.

1820.title: James Monroe Re-elected
1820.summary: James Monroe is re-elected as the President of the United States, virtually unopposed.

1821.title: Discovery of Peter I Island
1821.summary: Peter I Island in the Antarctic is first sighted by Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen.

1821.title: Congress of Laibach convenes
1821.summary: Congress of Laibach convenes in Laibach to deal with outstanding international issues regarding the revolution in southern Italy.

1821.title: Discovery of Alexander Island
1821.summary: Alexander Island, the largest in Antarctica, is first discovered by Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen.

1821.title: Chartering of Columbian College
1821.summary: Columbian College is chartered by President James Monroe.

1821.title: Embrace of Acatempan
1821.summary: In Mexico, the Embrace of Acatempan takes place between Agustín de Iturbide and Vicente Guerrero, sealing peace between troops and insurgents.

1821.title: Beginning of the Greek War of Independence
1821.summary: The raising of the revolutionary flag of Greece marks the beginning of the Greek War of Independence against the Ottoman Empire.

1821.title: Death of Emperor Napoleon
1821.summary: Emperor Napoleon dies in exile on Saint Helena of stomach cancer.

1821.title: Signing of Treaty of Córdoba
1821.summary: The Treaty of Córdoba is signed in Córdoba, Veracruz, Mexico, concluding the Mexican War of Independence.

1821.title: Execution of José Miguel Carrera
1821.summary: Chilean general José Miguel Carrera is executed by an Argentinian military tribunal in Mendoza.

1821.title: Declaration of Independence of Panama
1821.summary: Panama declares independence from Spain, joining Gran Colombia.

1822.title: Greek Constitution of 1822
1822.summary: The Greek Constitution of 1822 is adopted by the First National Assembly at Epidaurus.

1822.title: Aimé Bonpland's Capture
1822.summary: The famous French explorer, Aimé Bonpland, is made prisoner in Paraguay accused of being a spy.

1822.title: Founding of Monrovia
1822.summary: The first group of freed slaves from the United States arrive on the west coast of Africa, founding Monrovia.

1822.title: Brazilian Independence Process
1822.summary: The Portuguese prince Pedro I of Brazil decides to stay in Brazil against the orders of the Portuguese King João VI, beginning the Brazilian independence process.

1822.title: Capture of Acrocorinth
1822.summary: Greek War of Independence: Acrocorinth is captured by Theodoros Kolokotronis and Demetrios Ypsilantis.

1822.title: Sinking of Tek Sing
1822.summary: Chinese junk Tek Sing sinks in the South China Sea, with the loss of around 1,600 people on board.

1822.title: Battle of Pichincha
1822.summary: Battle of Pichincha: Simón Bolívar secures the independence of Quito.

1822.title: Battle of Thermopylae
1822.summary: Greek War of Independence: Greeks defeat Ottoman forces at Thermopylae.

1822.title: Declaration of Brazilian Independence
1822.summary: Brazil declares its independence from Portugal.

1822.title: Volcanic Eruption of Galunggung
1822.summary: The Galunggung volcano erupts on West Java, killing more than 4,000 people and destroying 114 villages.

1823.title: Treaty of Verona
1823.summary: The Quintuple Alliance gives France a mandate to invade Spain to restore Ferdinand VII as absolute monarch.

1823.title: First performance of Semiramide
1823.summary: Gioachino Rossini's opera Semiramide is first performed at La Fenice in Venice.

1823.title: First worldwide carnival parade
1823.summary: The first worldwide carnival parade takes place in Cologne, Prussia.

1823.title: Gold found in Australia
1823.summary: The first officially recognised gold is found in Australia, predating the Australian gold rushes.

1823.title: Explorer Weddell's expedition
1823.summary: Explorer James Weddell reaches latitude 74°15' S, the southernmost position any ship has reached at this time.

1823.title: Franz Liszt's concert
1823.summary: Franz Liszt, 11, gives a concert in Vienna, congratulated by Beethoven.

1823.title: Congress of Central America declares independence
1823.summary: The Congress of Central America declares absolute independence and establishes a republican system of government.

1823.title: Mary Shelley's play opens
1823.summary: The first theatrical adaptation of the Frankenstein story opens at the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden.

1823.title: Death of Pope Pius VII
1823.summary: Pope Pius VII dies after a reign of more than 23 years, remembered for crowning Napoleon.

1823.title: James Monroe's Monroe Doctrine
1823.summary: James Monroe first introduces the Monroe Doctrine, declaring European recolonization attempts as hostile acts.

1824.title: Michael Faraday Elected to Royal Society
1824.summary: After much controversy, Michael Faraday is finally elected as a member of the Royal Society in London, with only one vote against him.

1824.title: Battle of Nsamankow
1824.summary: First Anglo-Ashanti War: Battle of Nsamankow – forces of the Ashanti Empire crush British forces in the Gold Coast, killing the British governor Sir Charles MacCarthy.

1824.title: Publication of The Westminster Review
1824.summary: The first issue of the radical quarterly founded by Jeremy Bentham, The Westminster Review, is published in London.

1824.title: Simón Bolívar Dictatorship Proclaimed
1824.summary: Simón Bolívar is proclaimed dictator of Peru.

1824.title: Name Megalosaurus Announced
1824.summary: William Buckland formally announces the name Megalosaurus, the first scientifically validly named non-avian dinosaur species.

1824.title: Founding of the Royal National Lifeboat Institution
1824.summary: Founding of the Royal National Lifeboat Institution in the British Isles.

1824.title: Death of Lord Byron
1824.summary: Lord Byron, the British poet, dies at the age of 36 in the Greek city of Missolonghi, where he had taken ill while making plans to liberate the Greeks from Ottoman rule.

1824.title: Beethoven's Symphony No. 9 Premieres
1824.summary: Beethoven's Symphony No. 9 (the Choral) premieres at the Theater am Kärntnertor in Vienna.

1824.title: Battle of Ayacucho
1824.summary: Peruvian War of Independence: Battle of Ayacucho – Colombian and Peruvian forces defeat the Spanish.

1825.title: King Ferdinand I dies
1825.summary: King Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies dies in Naples and is succeeded by his son, Francis.

1825.title: Vendsyssel-Thy becomes island
1825.summary: Vendsyssel-Thy becomes an island after a flood drowns its isthmus.

1825.title: John Quincy Adams elected President
1825.summary: The U.S. House of Representatives elects John Quincy Adams President after no candidate receives a majority of Electoral College votes.

1825.title: Simón Bolívar renounces dictatorship
1825.summary: Simón Bolívar gives up his title of dictator of Peru for the title of El Libertador.

1825.title: Second Treaty of Indian Springs
1825.summary: The Creek cede the last of their lands in Georgia to the U.S. government and migrate west.

1825.title: Kent destroyed by fire
1825.summary: The outbound British East Indiaman Kent is destroyed by fire in the Bay of Biscay, losing more than 80 lives.

1825.title: John Quincy Adams sworn in
1825.summary: John Quincy Adams is sworn in as the sixth President of the United States.

1825.title: Capture of the Anne
1825.summary: International naval force defeats pirate Roberto Cofresí, one of the last successful pirates in the Caribbean.

1825.title: Charles X of France recognizes Haiti
1825.summary: Charles X of France recognizes Haiti and demands payment of 150 million gold francs.

1825.title: Founding of Brisbane
1825.summary: The Australian city of Brisbane is founded.

1826.title: Le Figaro Begins Publication
1826.summary: The French newspaper Le Figaro begins publication in Paris, initially as a satirical weekly.

1826.title: The Ballantyne Printing Business Crashes
1826.summary: The Ballantyne printing business in Edinburgh crashes, ruining novelist Sir Walter Scott as a principal investor who undertakes to repay his creditors from his writings.

1826.title: Menai Suspension Bridge Opens
1826.summary: The Menai Suspension Bridge, built by engineer Thomas Telford, is opened between the island of Anglesey and the mainland of Wales.

1826.title: First Printing of The Last of the Mohicans
1826.summary: First printing of James Fenimore Cooper's novel The Last of the Mohicans occurs in Philadelphia.

1826.title: University College London Founded
1826.summary: University College London is founded, under the name University of London.

1826.title: Russian Mathematician Develops Non-Euclidean Geometry
1826.summary: Russian mathematician Nikolai Ivanovich Lobachevsky develops non-Euclidean geometry independently of Janos Bolyai.

1826.title: Treaty of Yandabo
1826.summary: The Treaty of Yandabo ends the First Anglo-Burmese War; Britain gains Assam, Manipur, Rakhine and Tanintharyi.

1826.title: The Last Execution by the Spanish Inquisition
1826.summary: Cayetano Ripoll becomes the last person to be executed by the Spanish Inquisition at its last auto-da-fé, held in Valencia.

1826.title: Construction of the Rideau Canal Begins
1826.summary: Construction of the Rideau Canal begins in Canada.

1826.title: The Paris Stock Exchange Opens
1826.summary: The Paris Stock Exchange opens at the Palais de la Bourse.

1827.title: Battle of Ituzaingó
1827.summary: A Brazilian Imperial Army force is tactically defeated by Argentine–Uruguayan troops.

1827.title: Inauguration of the Christiania Offentlige Theater
1827.summary: The first public theatre in Norway is inaugurated in Christiania (modern-day Oslo).

1827.title: Founding of Freedom's Journal
1827.summary: The first African-American owned and published newspaper in the United States is founded in New York City by John Russwurm.

1827.title: Death of Ludwig van Beethoven
1827.summary: German composer Ludwig van Beethoven dies in Vienna after a prolonged illness.

1827.title: Battle of Monte Santiago
1827.summary: A squadron of the Brazilian Imperial Navy defeats Argentine vessels in a major naval engagement.

1827.title: First Transatlantic Crossing by Steam
