1827.summary: The Royal Netherlands Navy's British-built paddle steamer Curaçao makes the first transatlantic crossing by steam from Hellevoetsluis to Paramaribo.

1827.title: Publication of Die galvanische Kette
1827.summary: Georg Ohm publishes Die galvanische Kette, mathematisch bearbeitet in which Ohm's law appears for the first time.

1827.title: Battle of Navarino
1827.summary: British, French and Russian naval forces destroy the Turko-Egyptian fleet in Greece. This is the last naval action to be fought under sail alone.

1827.title: Completion of elections for France's Chamber of Deputies
1827.summary: Voting is completed in elections for France's 430 member Chamber of Deputies, affecting King Charles X's majority.

1827.title: Mexican expulsion law
1827.summary: Mexico passes its first expulsion law, providing for citizens of Spain to be expelled if Spain does not recognize Mexico's independence.

1828.title: Treaty of Turkmenchay
1828.summary: Russian-Persian peace treaty forces Persia to cede significant territories to Imperial Russia, impacting regional dynamics and Armenian settlement.

1828.title: Founding of the city of Bahía Blanca
1828.summary: The city of Bahía Blanca in modern-day Argentina is founded, contributing to regional development and settlement.

1828.title: First non-Muslim to enter Timbuktu
1828.summary: French explorer René Caillié becomes the first non-Muslim to enter Timbuktu and return alive, marking a significant exploration accomplishment.

1828.title: Gran Colombia–Peru War Declaration
1828.summary: President Simón Bolívar declares war on Peru, escalating conflicts in South America and impacting regional power.

1828.title: Liberal Wars begin in Portugal
1828.summary: King Miguel I of Portugal overthrows his niece Queen Maria II, marking the beginning of the Liberal Wars which would influence Portuguese politics.

1828.title: Siebold typhoon
1828.summary: A devastating typhoon strikes Kyūshū, Japan, resulting in the death of approximately 10,000 people, highlighting the vulnerability to natural disasters.

1828.title: Andrew Jackson elected President
1828.summary: Andrew Jackson is elected President of the United States, defeating incumbent John Quincy Adams in a significant political shift.

1828.title: Medical Academy of Georgia chartered
1828.summary: The U.S. State of Georgia charters the Medical Academy of Georgia, contributing to medical education advancements in the country.

1828.title: Earthquake in Echigo
1828.summary: A 6.8 magnitude earthquake strikes the province of Echigo, Japan, causing the deaths of more than 1,500 people, showcasing the impact of geological events.

1828.title: Publication of Winterreise
1828.summary: The publication of Franz Schubert's song cycle Winterreise is concluded posthumously, indicating the lasting influence of his work on music.

1829.title: Adaptation of Faust
1829.summary: Klingemann's adaptation of Goethe's Faust premieres in Braunschweig.

1829.title: First Inauguration of Andrew Jackson
1829.summary: Andrew Jackson is sworn in as the seventh President of the United States.

1829.title: Performance of St Matthew Passion
1829.summary: Felix Mendelssohn conducts the first performance of Johann Sebastian Bach's St Matthew Passion since Bach's death in 1750, sparking a revival of interest in Bach.

1829.title: Greece gains autonomy
1829.summary: Greece receives autonomy from the Ottoman Empire as outlined in the London Protocol signed by major European powers.

1829.title: Execution of Catholic Relief Act
1829.summary: The Catholic Relief Act is passed by the Parliament of the United Kingdom, granting Catholic emancipation in Britain and Ireland.

1829.title: Patent for Accordion
1829.summary: Cyrill Demian applies for a patent for the accordion, marking a significant development in musical instruments.

1829.title: First boat race by Oxford University
1829.summary: The Oxford University Boat Club wins the first inter-university Boat Race at Henley-on-Thames.

1829.title: First bus service in London
1829.summary: George Shillibeer begins operating the first bus service in London, revolutionizing public transport.

1829.title: First performance of William Tell
1829.summary: Rossini's opera William Tell is first performed in Paris, adding to the cultural landscape of opera in Europe.

1829.title: Founding of King's College London
1829.summary: King's College London is founded by Royal Charter, marking an important development in higher education.

1830.title: LaGrange College begins operation
1830.summary: LaGrange College, which later becomes the University of North Alabama, is the first publicly chartered college in Alabama.

1830.title: Webster–Hayne debate
1830.summary: Robert Y. Hayne debates states' rights vs. federal authority with Daniel Webster in the United States Congress.

1830.title: London Protocol establishes independence of Greece
1830.summary: The London Protocol establishes full independence and sovereignty of Greece from the Ottoman Empire after the Greek War of Independence.

1830.title: Destruction of the Argyll Rooms fire
1830.summary: A fire destroys the Argyll Rooms in London, but firefighters use steam-powered fire engines to contain it.

1830.title: Publication of The Book of Mormon
1830.summary: The Book of Mormon is published in Palmyra, New York by Joseph Smith.

1830.title: Formation of the Church of Christ
1830.summary: Joseph Smith and others organize the Church of Christ, the first formally organized church of the Latter Day Saint movement, in northwestern New York.

1830.title: Ecuador separates from Gran Colombia
1830.summary: Ecuador declares independence from Gran Colombia, marking a significant shift in South American politics.

1830.title: Indian Removal Act passed
1830.summary: The United States Congress passes the Indian Removal Act, beginning the removal of Native Americans from their ancestral lands and leading to mass bison destruction.

1830.title: 7.5 earthquake in Hebei
1830.summary: Hebei province in China is struck by a devastating earthquake killing more than 7,400 people.

1830.title: The July Revolution in France
1830.summary: The July Revolution begins in Paris as people rebel against the July Ordinances, leading to significant political changes in France.

1831.title: The Liberator begins publication
1831.summary: William Lloyd Garrison begins publishing The Liberator, an anti-slavery newspaper, in Boston, Massachusetts.

1831.title: Foundation of Takashimaya
1831.summary: Japanese department store, Takashimaya in Kyoto established.

1831.title: Austrian troops crush revolts
1831.summary: Revolts in Modena, Parma and the Papal States are put down by Austrian troops.

1831.title: Pope Gregory XVI succeeds
1831.summary: Pope Gregory XVI succeeds Pope Pius VIII, as the 254th pope.

1831.title: Battle of Olszynka Grochowska
1831.summary: Polish rebel forces divide a Russian army.

1831.title: French Foreign Legion founded
1831.summary: The French Foreign Legion is founded.

1831.title: Publication of Notre-Dame de Paris
1831.summary: Victor Hugo's historical romantic Gothic novel Notre-Dame de Paris is published in Paris.

1831.title: National presidential nominating convention
1831.summary: The first national presidential nominating convention is held by the Anti-Masonic Party in Baltimore, Maryland.

1831.title: Assassination of Ioannis Kapodistrias
1831.summary: Ioannis Kapodistrias, Greek head of state and founder of Greek independence, is assassinated in Nafplion.

1831.title: First Canut Revolt
1831.summary: After a bloody battle with the military causing 600 casualties, rebellious silk workers seize Lyon, France.

1832.title: Abolition of Slavery Society Founded
1832.summary: Abolitionist William Lloyd Garrison founds the New-England Anti-Slavery Society.

1832.title: End of the Christmas Rebellion
1832.summary: The Christmas Rebellion of slaves is brought to an end in Jamaica, with more than 300 slave rebels hanged.

1832.title: Cholera Epidemic in London
1832.summary: A cholera epidemic in London claims at least 3,000 lives, spreading to France and North America.

1832.title: Black Hawk War Begins
1832.summary: The Black Hawk War begins in the United States, marking significant conflict with Native Americans.

1832.title: Kingdom of Greece Established
1832.summary: The Treaty of London creates an independent Kingdom of Greece, beginning modern Greek history.

1832.title: Reform Act Passed in the UK
1832.summary: The Reform Act becomes law in the United Kingdom, expanding the franchise to more citizens.

1832.title: Founding of Jardine Matheson
1832.summary: Global conglomerate Jardine Matheson is founded in Canton (Guangzhou), China, by Scottish merchants.

1832.title: Siege of Antwerp
1832.summary: The Siege of Antwerp ends with the Dutch garrison losing the citadel during the Belgian Revolution.

1832.title: Jackson Reelected President
1832.summary: Andrew Jackson is re-elected president during the 1832 U.S. presidential election.

1832.title: Battle of Konya
1832.summary: The Egyptians defeat the main Ottoman army in central Anatolia, affirming their military strength.

1833.title: British sovereignty over the Falkland Islands
1833.summary: Reassertion of British sovereignty over the Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic.

1833.title: Barron v. Mayor and City Council of Baltimore
1833.summary: The United States Supreme Court hands down its landmark decision of Barron v. Mayor and City Council of Baltimore.

1833.title: Election of General Antonio López de Santa Anna
1833.summary: General Antonio López de Santa Anna is elected President of Mexico by the legislatures of 16 of the 18 Mexican states.

1833.title: Abolition of slavery call
1833.summary: Over 300 delegates call for the immediate abolition of slavery throughout the British Empire.

1833.title: Building of the electromagnetic telegraph
1833.summary: Carl Friedrich Gauss and Wilhelm Weber obtain permission to build an electromagnetic telegraph in Göttingen.

1833.title: Establishment of Chicago
1833.summary: The settlement of Chicago is established by 350 settlers at the estuary of the Chicago River in the Illinois Territory.

1833.title: British Slavery Abolition Act
1833.summary: The British Slavery Abolition Act 1833, beginning the process of giving slaves in much of the British Empire their freedom, receives royal assent.

1833.title: Founding of Oberlin College
1833.summary: Oberlin College is founded in Oberlin, Ohio.

1833.title: Performance of God Save the Tsar!
1833.summary: The national anthem of the Russian Empire, God Save the Tsar!, is first performed.

1834.title: Slavery Abolished in the British Empire
1834.summary: Slavery is abolished in the British Empire, by the Slavery Abolition Act 1833.

1834.title: Cyrus McCormick Patent
1834.summary: American inventor and businessman Cyrus McCormick is granted a patent for his mechanical reaper.

1834.title: Wilmington and Raleigh Railroad Chartered
1834.summary: The Wilmington and Raleigh Railroad is chartered in Wilmington, North Carolina.

1834.title: Spanish Inquisition Suppressed
1834.summary: The Spanish Inquisition, which began in the 15th century, is suppressed by royal decree.

1834.title: Zollverein Customs Charges Abolished
1834.summary: Customs charges are abolished at borders within Zollverein member states.

1834.title: John Scott Russell's Scottish Steam Carriage Company
1834.summary: John Scott Russell's company begins operating a regular passenger service between Glasgow and Paisley.

1834.title: Advanced Rail Transport
1834.summary: The Wilmington and Raleigh Railroad is chartered, enhancing rail transport in North Carolina.

1834.title: Fires in New Orleans
1834.summary: The LaLaurie mansion in New Orleans burns, and Madame Marie Delphine LaLaurie flees to France.

1834.title: Palace of Westminster Destroyed by Fire
1834.summary: The Palace of Westminster is destroyed by fire, along with the House of Commons and House of Lords.

1834.title: William Lamb's Dismissal
1834.summary: William Lamb, 2nd Viscount Melbourne becomes the last Prime Minister of the United Kingdom dismissed by the monarch.

1835.title: HMS Beagle anchors off Chonos Archipelago
1835.summary: HMS Beagle anchors off the Chonos Archipelago on her second voyage, with Charles Darwin on board as naturalist.

1835.title: United States Public Debt Contracts to Zero
1835.summary: The United States public debt contracts to zero, for the only time in history.

1835.title: Malê Revolt
1835.summary: African slaves of Yoruba Muslim origin revolt in Salvador, Bahia.

1835.title: Marriage of Queen Maria II
1835.summary: Queen Maria II of Portugal marries Auguste de Beauharnais, 2nd Duke of Leuchtenberg, in Lisbon; he dies only two months later.

1835.title: Assassination Attempt on Andrew Jackson
1835.summary: An assassination is attempted against United States President Andrew Jackson in the United States Capitol.

1835.title: 1835 Concepción Earthquake
1835.summary: Concepción, Chile, is destroyed by an earthquake; the resulting tsunami destroys the neighboring city of Talcahuano.

1835.title: Lord Melbourne Succeeds as Prime Minister
1835.summary: Lord Melbourne succeeds Sir Robert Peel as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.

1835.title: British Barque Neva Wrecked
1835.summary: British barque Neva, transporting female convicts from Cork, Ireland, to Australia, is wrecked in the Bass Strait with the loss of 224 people and only 15 survivors.

1836.title: Hill Street Academy Established
1836.summary: Hill Street Academy is named Colombo Academy and acquired by the Government, establishing the first public school in Sri Lanka.

1836.title: Battle of the Alamo Begins
1836.summary: The Battle of the Alamo begins, with an American settler army surrounded by the Mexican Army, under Santa Anna.

1836.title: Samuel Colt Receives Patent for Revolver
1836.summary: Samuel Colt receives a United States patent for the Colt revolver, the first revolving barrel multishot firearm.

1836.title: Texas Declaration of Independence Signed
1836.summary: The Texas Declaration of Independence is signed by 60 delegates, and the Republic of Texas is declared.

1836.title: Treaties of Velasco Signed
1836.summary: The Treaties of Velasco are signed between Mexican General Antonio López de Santa Anna and the Republic of Texas, but never ratified by the Mexican government.

1836.title: Darwin's HMS Beagle Returns to England
1836.summary: Charles Darwin returns to England aboard HMS Beagle, with biological data he will later use to develop his theory of evolution.

1836.title: University of London Established
1836.summary: The University of London is established by Royal Charter, with University College London and King's College London named as the first affiliated colleges.

1836.title: First U.S. Patent for Friction Match
1836.summary: The earliest United States patent for a phosphorus friction match is granted to Alonzo Dwight Phillips.

1836.title: First Civil Marriage Act in UK
1836.summary: The Marriage Act in the United Kingdom establishes civil marriage and registration systems that permit marriages in nonconformist chapels.

1836.title: Sam Houston Inaugurated as President of Texas
1836.summary: Sam Houston is inaugurated as first elected President of the Republic of Texas.

1837.title: Galilee Earthquake
1837.summary: The destructive Galilee earthquake causes 6000–7000 casualties in Ottoman Syria.

1837.title: Admission of Michigan
1837.summary: Michigan becomes the 26th state admitted to the United States.

1837.title: Publication of Oliver Twist
1837.summary: Charles Dickens's Oliver Twist begins publication in serial form in London.

1837.title: Foundation of Institute for Colored Youth
1837.summary: In Philadelphia, the Institute for Colored Youth (ICY) is founded as the first institution for the higher education of black people in the United States.

1837.title: Formation of the Congregation of Holy Cross
1837.summary: The Congregation of Holy Cross is formed in Le Mans, France, by the signing of the Fundamental Act of Union.

1837.title: Founding of Procter & Gamble
1837.summary: The origins of Procter & Gamble begin when William Procter and James Gamble start selling manufactured goods in Cincinnati, Ohio.

1837.title: The Panic of 1837
1837.summary: The Panic of 1837 begins in New York City.

1837.title: Accession of Queen Victoria
1837.summary: Queen Victoria accedes to the throne of the United Kingdom on the death of her uncle William IV.

1837.title: Development of the Telegraph
1837.summary: W. F. Cooke and Charles Wheatstone patent a system of electrical telegraph.

1837.title: Establishment of the First Electric Locomotive
1837.summary: The first electric locomotive built is a miniature battery locomotive constructed by chemist Robert Davidson of Aberdeen.

1838.title: Demonstration of the Telegraph
1838.summary: At Morristown, New Jersey, Samuel Morse, Alfred Vail and Leonard Gale give the first public demonstration of Morse's new invention, the telegraph.

1838.title: Vrancea Earthquake
1838.summary: A 7.5 earthquake strikes the Romanian district of Vrancea causing damage in Moldavia and Wallachia, killing 73 people.

1838.title: Weenen Massacre
1838.summary: Zulu impis massacre about 532 Voortrekkers, Khoikhoi and Basuto around the site of Weenen in South Africa.

1838.title: Danube River Flood
1838.summary: A combination of rain and melting snow causes the Danube River to overflow its banks, washing away villages in western Hungary and inundating the twin cities that become Budapest. More than 150 people are drowned and Europe's nations come to Hungary's aid to prevent the spread of famine and disease.

1838.title: First Steamship Service to New York
1838.summary: Isambard Kingdom Brunel's paddle steamer SS Great Western makes the transatlantic crossing to New York from Avonmouth, England, in 15 days, inaugurating a regular steamship service.

1838.title: Nicaragua Independence Declaration
1838.summary: Nicaragua declares independence from the Federal Republic of Central America.

1838.title: Coronation of Queen Victoria
1838.summary: The coronation of Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom takes place at Westminster Abbey in London.

1838.title: Killough Massacre
1838.summary: Killough massacre, believed to be the largest and last Native American attack on white settlers in East Texas with 18 casualties either killed or carried away.

1838.title: Pastry War
1838.summary: Mexico is invaded by French forces during the Pastry War.

1839.title: First photograph of the Moon
1839.summary: The first photograph of the Moon is taken by French photographer Louis Daguerre.

1839.title: Night of the Big Wind
1839.summary: Ireland is struck by the most damaging cyclone in 300 years.

1839.title: French Academy of Sciences and Daguerreotype
1839.summary: The French Academy of Sciences announces the daguerreotype photography process.

1839.title: Battle of Yungay
1839.summary: Chile defeats the Peru–Bolivian Confederation, leading to the restoration of an independent Peru.

1839.title: Establishment of the University of Missouri
1839.summary: The University of Missouri is established, becoming the first public university west of the Mississippi River.

1839.title: Patent for steam shovel
1839.summary: William Otis receives a patent for the steam shovel.

1839.title: Establishment of Longwood University
1839.summary: Longwood University is founded in Farmville, Virginia.

1839.title: Establishment of Baltimore City College
1839.summary: Baltimore City College, the third public high school in the United States, is established in Baltimore, Maryland.

1839.title: Treaty of London
1839.summary: The Treaty of London establishes Belgium as a kingdom, with its independence and neutrality guaranteed by the great powers of Europe.

1839.title: First Opium War begins
1839.summary: Destruction of opium at Humen begins, casus belli for Britain to open the 3-year First Opium War against Qing Dynasty China.

1840.title: The Port Phillip Herald founded
1840.summary: One of the predecessor papers of the Herald Sun is founded in Melbourne, Australia.

1840.title: Uniform Penny Post introduced
1840.summary: The introduction of the Uniform Penny Post marks a significant change in postal services in the United Kingdom.

1840.title: Lexington disaster
1840.summary: The steamship Lexington burns and sinks in icy waters off Long Island, leading to a high number of casualties.

1840.title: Discovery of Wilkes Land
1840.summary: Captain Charles Wilkes sights what becomes known as Wilkes Land in Antarctica, claiming it for the United States.

1840.title: Discovery of Adélie Land
1840.summary: Jules Dumont d'Urville discovers Adélie Land in Antarctica, claiming it for France.

1840.title: Founding of Wellington
1840.summary: British colonists officially found the settlement of Wellington in New Zealand.

1840.title: Signing of the Treaty of Waitangi
1840.summary: The Treaty of Waitangi, granting British sovereignty in New Zealand, is signed.

1840.title: Queen Victoria marries Prince Albert
1840.summary: Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom marries her cousin Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha.

1840.title: Premiere of La fille du régiment
1840.summary: Gaetano Donizetti's opera La fille du régiment premieres in Paris, influencing music and culture.

1840.title: Completion of the longest railroad
1840.summary: The Wilmington and Raleigh Railroad is completed, becoming the world's longest railroad.

1841.title: Convention of Chuenpi
1841.summary: Charles Elliot of the United Kingdom, and Qishan of the Qing dynasty, agree to the Convention of Chuenpi.

1841.title: Occupation of Hong Kong
1841.summary: Britain occupies Hong Kong, with a later census recording a population of about 7,500.

1841.title: Discovery of Mount Erebus
1841.summary: The active volcano Mount Erebus in Antarctica is discovered by James Clark Ross.

1841.title: Discovery of Victoria Barrier
1841.summary: Ross discovers the 'Victoria Barrier', later known as the Ross Ice Shelf.

1841.title: Fire in Mayagüez
1841.summary: A fire ruins and destroys two-thirds of the villa of Mayagüez, Puerto Rico.

1841.title: The Act of Union
1841.summary: The Act of Union (British North America Act, 1840) is proclaimed in Canada.

1841.title: Independence of El Salvador
1841.summary: El Salvador proclaims itself an independent republic, ending the Federal Republic of Central America.

1841.title: Swearing in of President Harrison
1841.summary: William Henry Harrison is sworn in as the ninth president of the United States.

1841.title: First ongoing filibuster in U.S. Senate
1841.summary: The first ongoing filibuster in the United States Senate begins, and lasts until March 11.

1841.title: Founding of St. John's College
1841.summary: St. John's College, later Fordham University, is founded in The Bronx by the Society of Jesus.

1842.title: First Anglo-Afghan War – Massacre of Elphinstone's army
1842.summary: British East India Company troops are destroyed by Afghan forces on the road from Kabul to Jalalabad, Afghanistan, by Akbar Khan, son of Dost Mohammad Khan.

1842.title: Delft University of Technology established
1842.summary: Delft University of Technology is established by William II of the Netherlands, as a 'Royal Academy for the education of civilian engineers'.

1842.title: First Anglo-Afghan War – Battle of Jellalabad
Commonwealth v. Hunt
1842.summary: The Massachusetts Supreme Court makes strikes and unions legal in the United States.

1842.title: Giuseppe Verdi's opera Nabucco premieres
1842.summary: Its success establishes Verdi as one of Italy's foremost operatic composers.

1842.title: The Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra performs its first concert
1842.summary: Founded by Otto Nicolai, it marks the beginning of a prestigious institution in classical music.

1842.title: Queen Victoria travels by train
1842.summary: Becomes the first reigning British monarch to travel by train, on the Great Western Railway.

1842.title: Great fire of Hamburg
1842.summary: Destroys around one-third of the city centre and kills 51.

1842.title: The Mines Act 1842 becomes law
1842.summary: Prohibiting underground work for all women and boys under 10 years old in the United Kingdom.

1842.title: The University of Notre Dame established
1842.summary: Establishment of the University of Notre Dame in Notre Dame, Indiana by Father Edward Sorin.

1843.title: Martin Chuzzlewit Serial Publication
1843.summary: Charles Dickens's novel Martin Chuzzlewit begins serial publication in London; in the July chapters, he lands his hero in the United States.

1843.title: The Tell-Tale Heart Publication
1843.summary: Edgar Allan Poe's short story The Tell-Tale Heart is published in a Boston magazine.

1843.title: The Friend Magazine
1843.summary: The Quaker magazine The Friend is first published in London.

1843.title: Publication of Illustrated Treatise
1843.summary: The Illustrated Treatise on the Maritime Kingdoms, the first significant Chinese work on the West, is published in China.

1843.title: James Clark Ross Discovers Snow Hill Island
1843.summary: Antarctic explorer James Clark Ross discovers Snow Hill Island.

1843.title: Brazil's First Prime Minister
1843.summary: Honório Hermeto Carneiro Leão, Marquis of Paraná, becomes de facto first prime minister of the Empire of Brazil.

1843.title: First Minstrel Show
1843.summary: The Virginia Minstrels perform the first minstrel show, at the Bowery Amphitheatre in New York City.

1843.title: 1843 Guadeloupe Earthquake
1843.summary: The 1843 Guadeloupe Earthquake hits the Caribbean island of Guadeloupe, killing 1,500-5000 people.

1843.title: I Lombardi alla prima crociata Premieres
1843.summary: Giuseppe Verdi's opera I Lombardi alla prima crociata premieres at La Scala in Milan.

1843.title: Thames Tunnel Opens
1843.summary: Marc Isambard Brunel's Thames Tunnel, the first tunnel under the River Thames, opens in London for pedestrians.

1844.title: First Telegraph Message Sent
1844.summary: The first telegraph message is sent, marking a significant advancement in communication technology.

1844.title: Publication of Saima Newspaper
1844.summary: The first issue of the Swedish-languaged Saima newspaper is published, contributing to the spread of information in Finland.

1844.title: University of Notre Dame Charter
1844.summary: The University of Notre Dame receives its charter, establishing a significant educational institution in the U.S.

1844.title: Dominican Republic Independence
1844.summary: The Dominican Republic gains independence from Haiti, marking a crucial moment in its history.

1844.title: USS Princeton Disaster
1844.summary: A gun on the USS Princeton explodes during a cruise, resulting in the deaths of several key officials.

1844.title: King Oscar I Ascends the Throne
1844.summary: King Oscar I ascends to the throne of Sweden–Norway upon the death of Charles XIV/III John.

1844.title: Giuseppe Verdi's Opera Ernani Debuts
1844.summary: Giuseppe Verdi's opera Ernani debuts at Teatro La Fenice, contributing to the music scene of the period.

1844.title: First Railroad Charter in Ohio
1844.summary: The Columbus and Xenia Railroad is chartered, representing a key development in transportation.

1844.title: Establishment of YMCA
1844.summary: The first youth organization, YMCA, is established in London, promoting health and community.

1844.title: Publication of The Concept of Anxiety
1844.summary: Søren Kierkegaard's influential work, The Concept of Anxiety, is published, impacting philosophy and psychology.

1845.title: Philippines Date Line Reform
1845.summary: The Philippines began using the International Date Line to reckon Asian dates, skipping December 31, 1844, to align its calendar with the rest of Asia and boost trade interests with Imperial China and neighboring countries.

1845.title: Uniform Federal Election Date
1845.summary: The United States Congress establishes a uniform date for federal elections to be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November.

1845.title: Publication of The Raven
1845.summary: Edgar Allan Poe's poem The Raven is published for the first time in the New York Evening Mirror.

1845.title: Establishment of Baylor University
1845.summary: Anson Jones, the President of the Republic of Texas, signs the charter creating Baylor University, the oldest university in Texas operating under its original name.

1845.title: Annexation of Texas
1845.summary: The United States Congress approves the annexation of Texas, marking a significant territorial expansion for the United States.

1845.title: Presidential Bill to Annex Texas
1845.summary: President John Tyler signs a bill authorizing the annexation of the Republic of Texas, pushing forward the process begun in Congress.

1845.title: Florida Admitted as a U.S. State
1845.summary: Florida is admitted as the 27th state of the United States, expanding the geographic footprint of the nation.

1845.title: New Zealand Wars Begin
1845.summary: The New Zealand Wars open when Maori chiefs lead a significant attack on the British colonial settlement of Kororareka, marking the beginning of violent conflict in New Zealand.

1845.title: Felix Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto Premiere
1845.summary: Felix Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto, a landmark in classical music, premieres in Leipzig with Ferdinand David as the soloist.

1845.title: Death of Andrew Jackson
1845.summary: Former U.S. President Andrew Jackson dies at The Hermitage in Nashville, Tennessee, marking the end of an era in American politics.

1846.title: Oregon Country Decision
1846.summary: The United States House of Representatives votes to stop sharing the Oregon Country with the United Kingdom.

1846.title: Opening of the Milan–Venice Railway Bridge
1846.summary: The Milan–Venice railway's 3.2 km bridge, over the Venetian Lagoon between Mestre and Venice, opens, becoming the world's longest since 1151.

1846.title: Mormon Migration
1846.summary: Many Mormons begin their migration west from Nauvoo to the Great Salt Lake, led by Brigham Young.

1846.title: Battle of Sobraon
1846.summary: In the First Anglo-Sikh War, British forces defeat the Sikhs at the Battle of Sobraon.

1846.title: Texas Annexation Ceremony
1846.summary: The annexation of the Republic of Texas is finalized in a formal ceremony, leading to the installation of the newly formed Texas state government.

1846.title: Galician Slaughter
1846.summary: A peasant revolt known as the Galician slaughter begins, involving significant social unrest in the region.

1846.title: Treaty of Lahore
1846.summary: The First Anglo-Sikh War ends with the signing of the Treaty of Lahore, with Kashmir ceded to the British East India Company.

1846.title: The Oregon Treaty
1846.summary: The Oregon Treaty establishes the 49th parallel as the border between the United States and Canada.

1846.title: The Saxophone Patent
1846.summary: The saxophone is patented by Adolphe Sax, marking a significant development in musical instruments.

1846.title: First Successful Public Demonstration of Ether Anesthesia
1846.summary: Dr. William T. G. Morton gives the first successful public demonstration of ether anesthesia at Massachusetts General Hospital.

1847.title: Samuel Colt sells his first revolver pistol
1847.summary: Samuel Colt sells his first revolver pistol to the U.S. government.

1847.title: Treaty of Cahuenga
1847.summary: The Treaty of Cahuenga ends fighting in the Mexican–American War in California.

1847.title: Battle of Buena Vista
1847.summary: 5,000 American troops use their superiority in artillery to drive off 15,000 Mexican troops, defeating the Mexicans the next day.

1847.title: Verdi's opera Macbeth premieres
1847.summary: Verdi's opera Macbeth premieres at the Teatro della Pergola, in Florence, Italy.

1847.title: Birkenhead Park opens
1847.summary: The world's first municipally-funded civic public park opens in Birkenhead, England.

1847.title: American Medical Association founded
1847.summary: The American Medical Association is founded in Philadelphia.

1847.title: The Nagano earthquake
1847.summary: The Nagano earthquake leaves more than 8,600 people dead in Japan.

1847.title: Mormon pioneers reach Salt Lake Valley
1847.summary: Brigham Young leads 148 Mormon pioneers into Salt Lake Valley, resulting in the establishment of Salt Lake City.

1847.title: U.S. troops take Veracruz
1847.summary: United States forces under General Winfield Scott take Veracruz after a siege.

1847.title: Charlotte Brontë publishes Jane Eyre
1847.summary: Charlotte Brontë publishes Jane Eyre under the pen name of Currer Bell in England.

1848.title: Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo
1848.summary: The Treaty ends the Mexican–American War, ceding all Texas territorial claims to the United States for $15 million.

1848.title: The Communist Manifesto
1848.summary: Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels publish the foundational text of modern socialism in London.

1848.title: Monster Rally of Chartists
1848.summary: A huge rally demanding political reforms is held at Kennington Common, with the first photograph of a crowd taken during the event.

1848.title: California Gold Rush
1848.summary: James W. Marshall finds gold at Sutter's Mill, sparking the Gold Rush that leads to mass migration to California.

1848.title: Hungarian Revolution of 1848
1848.summary: Hungarian revolutionaries, led by Sándor Petőfi, demand self-determination and freedom from the Habsburg Empire.

1848.title: March Unrest in Sweden
1848.summary: A wave of protests and riots breaks out in Sweden, part of the revolutionary tides sweeping through Europe.

1848.title: First Schleswig War begins
1848.summary: Military conflict arises in southern Denmark and northern Germany over the control of the Duchies of Schleswig and Holstein.

1848.title: Foundation of the Republic of San Marco
1848.summary: The Republic of San Marco is declared in Venice amidst the revolutionary wave across Europe.

1848.title: Ratification of Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo
1848.summary: The Mexican government ratifies the treaty, formally ending the Mexican-American War and cementing U.S. territorial gains.

1848.title: Opening of the Frankfurt Parliament
1848.summary: The first German National Assembly opens in Frankfurt, marking a significant step towards German unification and democracy.

1849.title: First Postage Stamps of France
1849.summary: France begins issue of the Ceres series, the nation's first postage stamps.

1849.title: Hungarian Revolution of 1848 Begins
1849.summary: The Austrian army, led by Alfred I, Prince of Windisch-Grätz, enters the Hungarian capitals, Buda and Pest, and the Hungarian government flees to Debrecen.

1849.title: Elizabeth Blackwell Becomes First Woman Doctor in the US
1849.summary: Elizabeth Blackwell is awarded her M.D. by the Medical Institute of Geneva, New York, thus becoming the United States' first woman doctor.

1849.title: Battle of Gujrat
1849.summary: Forces of the British East India Company defeat those of the Sikh Empire in Punjab.

1849.title: Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo Signed
1849.summary: The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo is signed, ending the Mexican–American War.

1849.title: Proclamation of the New Roman Republic
1849.summary: The new Roman Republic is proclaimed amid the revolutionary fervor spreading across Europe.

1849.title: Zachary Taylor Becomes President
1849.summary: Zachary Taylor becomes the 12th president of the United States after refusing to be sworn in on a Sunday.

1849.title: Battle of Vác
1849.summary: Hungarian forces, led by Arthur Görgei, defeat the main imperial forces, forcing them to retreat westward.

1849.title: Hungarian Parliament Declares Independence
1849.summary: The Hungarian revolutionary parliament in Debrecen declares independence from the Habsburg Empire.

1849.title: First Segment of Pennsylvania Railroad Opens
1849.summary: The first segment of the Pennsylvania Railroad, from Lewistown to Harrisburg, opens for service.

1850.title: Compromise of 1850
1850.summary: Henry Clay introduces the Compromise of 1850 to the United States Congress.

1850.title: University of Rochester Founded
1850.summary: The University of Rochester is founded in Rochester, New York.

1850.title: University of Utah Opens
1850.summary: The University of Utah opens in Salt Lake City.

1850.title: Britannia Bridge Opens
1850.summary: The Britannia Bridge opens over the Menai Strait in Wales.

1850.title: Publication of The Scarlet Letter
1850.summary: Nathaniel Hawthorne's historical novel The Scarlet Letter is published in Boston, Massachusetts.

1850.title: American Express Founded
1850.summary: American Express is founded by Henry Wells and William Fargo.

1850.title: Los Angeles Incorporation
1850.summary: Los Angeles is incorporated as a city in California.

1850.title: Richard Wagner's Lohengrin Premieres
1850.summary: Richard Wagner's romantic opera Lohengrin premieres under the direction of Franz Liszt, in Weimar.

1850.title: California Admitted to the U.S.
1850.summary: California is admitted as the 31st U.S. state.

1850.title: Foundation of the University of Sydney
1850.summary: The University of Sydney, the oldest in Australia, is founded.

1851.title: Taiping Rebellion
1851.summary: Hong Xiuquan officially begins the Taiping Rebellion in China.

1851.title: Founding of Northwestern University
1851.summary: Northwestern University is founded in Illinois.

1851.title: Gold Discovery in Australia
1851.summary: Edward Hargraves claims to have found gold in Australia.

1851.title: The Great Exhibition
1851.summary: The Great Exhibition of the Works of Industry of All Nations opens in the Crystal Palace, Hyde Park, London.

1851.title: First Women's Secret Society
1851.summary: Alpha Delta Pi sorority, the first secret society for women, is founded at Wesleyan College in Macon, Georgia.

1851.title: The Immortal Game
1851.summary: The Immortal Game, a famous chess match, is played in London.

1851.title: Discovery of Asteroid 15 Eunomia
1851.summary: Annibale de Gasparis discovers asteroid 15 Eunomia in Naples, Italy.

1851.title: New York Times Founded
1851.summary: The New York Times is founded in New York City.

1851.title: YMCA Established in North America
1851.summary: The first YMCA in North America is established in Montreal.

1851.title: French Coup of 1851
1851.summary: President Louis-Napoleon Bonaparte dissolves the French National Assembly in a coup.

1852.title: Proclamation of a New Constitution
1852.summary: President Louis-Napoléon Bonaparte proclaims a new constitution for the French Second Republic.

1852.title: Formation of Mount Sinai Hospital
1852.summary: Nine men representing various Jewish charitable organizations come together to form what will become Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City.

1852.title: Recognition of Transvaal Independence
1852.summary: The United Kingdom recognizes the independence of the Transvaal.

1852.title: Battle of Caseros
1852.summary: The provinces of Entre Rios and Corrientes, allied with Brazil, defeat Buenos Aires troops under Juan Manuel de Rosas.

1852.title: Opening of the Great Ormond Street Hospital
1852.summary: The Great Ormond Street Hospital for Sick Children admits its first patient in London.

1852.title: Inauguration of Helsinki Cathedral
1852.summary: The Helsinki Cathedral is officially inaugurated in Helsinki, Finland.

1852.title: First Airship Trip
1852.summary: Henri Giffard makes the first airship trip from Paris to Trappes.

1852.title: Napoleon III Becomes Emperor
1852.summary: Napoleon III becomes Emperor of the French, marking a significant shift in French leadership.

1852.title: 1852 United States Presidential Election
1852.summary: Democrat Franklin Pierce defeats Whig Winfield Scott in the presidential election.

1852.title: The First Roadside Pillar Boxes
1852.summary: The first roadside pillar boxes are brought into public use in the British Isles.

1853.title: East Florida Seminary Established
1853.summary: Florida Governor Thomas Brown signs legislation that provides public support for the new East Florida Seminary, leading to the establishment of the University of Florida.

1853.title: Taiping Rebellion - Zeng Guofan's Order
1853.summary: Zeng Guofan is ordered to assist the governor of Hunan in organising a militia force to search for local bandits during the Taiping Rebellion.

1853.title: Il Trovatore Premiere
1853.summary: Giuseppe Verdi's opera Il Trovatore premieres in performance at Teatro Apollo in Rome.

1853.title: Puerta Montt Founded
1853.summary: The city of Puerto Montt is founded in the Reloncavíd Sound.

1853.title: Washington University Established
1853.summary: Washington University in St. Louis is founded as Eliot Seminary.

1853.title: Levi Strauss & Co. Founded
1853.summary: The clothing company Levi Strauss & Co. is founded in the United States.

1853.title: First Passenger Railway in India
1853.summary: The first passenger railway in India opens from Bombay to Thana, Maharashtra, 22 miles long.

1853.title: Opening of the London Zoo Aquarium
1853.summary: The world's first public aquarium opens, at the London Zoo.

1853.title: First Meteorological Organization
1853.summary: The first true International Meteorological Organization is established in Brussels, Belgium.

1853.title: First True Naval Museum Founded
1853.summary: The Royal Norwegian Navy Museum is founded at Karljohansvern in Horten, perhaps the world's first naval museum.

1854.title: Discovery of McDonald Islands
1854.summary: The McDonald Islands are discovered by Captain William McDonald aboard the Samarang.

1854.title: Foundation of Teutonia Männerchor
1854.summary: The Teutonia Männerchor in Pittsburgh, U.S.A. is founded to promote German culture.

1854.title: RMS Tayleur Shipwreck
1854.summary: The iron clipper RMS Tayleur runs aground off the east coast of Ireland, on her maiden voyage out of Liverpool, bound for Australia, with the loss of at least 300 out of 650 on board.

1854.title: First Use of Coal Gas Street Lighting
1854.summary: Major streets are lit by coal gas for the first time by the San Francisco Gas Company.

1854.title: British Recognition of Orange Free State
1854.summary: The British recognize the independence of the Orange Free State in Southern Africa; its official independence is declared six days later in the Orange River Convention.

1854.title: Opening of United States Navy
1854.summary: The first class of the United States Naval Academy graduates at Annapolis, Maryland.

1854.title: Foundation of Catholic University of Ireland
1854.summary: The Catholic University of Ireland (forerunner of University College Dublin) is founded.

1854.title: Battle of Balaclava
1854.summary: Battle of Balaclava – The allies gain an overall victory, except for the disastrous cavalry Charge of the Light Brigade, from which only 200 of 700 men survive.

1854.title: Establishment of Suez Canal Company
1854.summary: In Egypt, the Suez Canal Company is formed.

1854.title: Eureka Stockade Miners' Rebellion
1854.summary: The Eureka Stockade Miners' Rebellion breaks out in Ballarat, Victoria (Australia).

1855.title: Incorporation of Ottawa
1855.summary: Ottawa, Ontario, is incorporated as a city.

1855.title: Wairarapa Earthquake
1855.summary: The 8.2–8.3 Mw Wairarapa earthquake claims between five and nine lives near the Cook Strait area of New Zealand.

1855.title: Panama Railway
1855.summary: The Panama Railway becomes the first railroad to connect the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.

1855.title: Alexander II Ascends the Throne
1855.summary: Alexander II ascends the Russian throne, upon the death of his father Nicholas I.

1855.title: Exposition Universelle
1855.summary: The Exposition Universelle officially opens in Paris, introducing the Bordeaux Wine Official Classification of 1855.

1855.title: Mount Sinai Hospital Dedication
1855.summary: Mount Sinai Hospital, New York, is dedicated as the Jews' Hospital in New York City.

1855.title: Siege of Sevastopol
1855.summary: Sevastopol falls to French and British troops during the Crimean War.

1855.title: Publication of Leaves of Grass
1855.summary: Walt Whitman's poetry collection Leaves of Grass is published in Brooklyn.

1855.title: David Livingstone Sees Victoria Falls
1855.summary: Scottish missionary explorer David Livingstone becomes the first European to see Victoria Falls, in modern-day Zambia–Zimbabwe.

1855.title: Establishment of the Colt Armory
1855.summary: Samuel Colt incorporates his business as the Colt's Patent Firearms Manufacturing Company and opens a new factory in Hartford, Connecticut.

1856.title: Discovery of Borax Deposits
1856.summary: Borax deposits are discovered in large quantities by John Veatch in California.

1856.title: SS Pacific Disaster
1856.summary: American paddle steamer SS Pacific leaves Liverpool for a transatlantic voyage on which she will be lost with all 186 on board.

1856.title: Bleeding Kansas Declaration
1856.summary: U.S. President Franklin Pierce declares the new Free-State Topeka government in 'Bleeding Kansas' to be in rebellion.

1856.title: First Battle of Seattle
1856.summary: Marines from the USS Decatur suppress an indigenous uprising, in response to Governor Stevens' declaration of a 'war of extermination' on Native communities.

1856.title: Completion of North Carolina Railroad
1856.summary: The 223-mile North Carolina Railroad is completed from Goldsboro through Raleigh and Salisbury to Charlotte.

1856.title: Victoria Cross Instituted
1856.summary: Queen Victoria institutes the Victoria Cross as a British military decoration.

1856.title: Mauveine Discovered
1856.summary: Mauveine, the first synthetic organic dye, is discovered by William Henry Perkin, while attempting to synthesize quinine.

1856.title: Fire at Covent Garden Theatre
1856.summary: Fire destroys the Covent Garden Theatre in London.

1856.title: Treaty of Paris Signed
1856.summary: The Treaty of Paris is signed, ending the Crimean War.

1856.title: The Second Opium War Begins
1856.summary: The Second Opium War between several Western powers and China begins with the Arrow Incident on the Pearl River.

1857.title: Postimees Established
1857.summary: The biggest Estonian newspaper, Postimees, is established by Johann Voldemar Jannsen.

1857.title: Fort Tejon Earthquake
1857.summary: The 7.9 Mw Fort Tejon earthquake shakes Central and Southern California, with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX.

1857.title: University of Calcutta Established
1857.summary: The University of Calcutta is established in Calcutta, becoming the first multidisciplinary modern university in South Asia.

1857.title: Dred Scott v. Sandford Ruling
1857.summary: The Supreme Court of the United States rules that blacks are not citizens and slaves cannot sue for freedom, driving the U.S. closer to the Civil War.

1857.title: Spirit Lake Massacre
1857.summary: The Spirit Lake Massacre occurs near Okoboji and Spirit lakes in Iowa, leading to significant loss of life.

1857.title: First Elevator Installed
1857.summary: Elisha Otis' first elevator is installed at 488 Broadway, New York City, marking a major advance in building technology.

1857.title: Phonautograph Patented
1857.summary: The phonautograph, the earliest known device for recording sound, is patented by Édouard-Léon Scott de Martinville.

1857.title: Siege of Lucknow Begins
1857.summary: The Siege of Lucknow begins as part of the Indian Rebellion of 1857, leading to a prolonged conflict.

1857.title: Panic of 1857
1857.summary: Speculation in U.S. railroad shares triggers a financial crisis that extends to Europe, impacting economies broadly.

1857.title: Queen Victoria Chooses Ottawa
1857.summary: Queen Victoria chooses Ottawa as the capital of Canada, marking a significant political decision for the country.

1858.title: Benito Juárez becomes Liberal President of Mexico
1858.summary: Benito Juárez becomes the first indigenous president of Mexico amidst a civil conflict with conservatives backing another president.

1858.title: Revolt of Rajab Ali
1858.summary: British forces finally defeat Rajab Ali Khan of Chittagong, ending a significant conflict in the region.

1858.title: Orsini affair
1858.summary: Felice Orsini's attempted assassination of Napoleon III in Paris results in multiple casualties, inciting anti-British sentiment in France.

1858.title: The Wedding March
1858.summary: Felix Mendelssohn's Wedding March gains popularity after being played at the marriage of Queen Victoria's daughter.

1858.title: Lourdes apparitions
1858.summary: Bernadette Soubirous has the first vision at the grotto of Massabielle, marking the beginning of the Lourdes apparitions.

1858.title: Discovery of Lake Tanganyika
1858.summary: Richard Francis Burton and John Hanning Speke become the first Europeans to discover Lake Tanganyika, contributing to geographical knowledge.

1858.title: Felice Orsini executed
1858.summary: Felice Orsini is executed for his assassination attempt on Napoleon III, highlighting political tensions in France.

1858.title: U.S. admits Minnesota
1858.summary: Minnesota is admitted as the 32nd state in the United States, expanding American territory.

1858.title: First transatlantic telegraph cable completed
1858.summary: Cyrus West Field and others complete the first transatlantic telegraph cable, enabling communication between the U.S. and Europe.

1858.title: Jacques Offenbach's operetta
1858.summary: Jacques Offenbach's operetta Orpheus in the Underworld is first performed in Paris, influencing music and culture.

1859.title: José Mariano Salas becomes President of Mexico
1859.summary: José Mariano Salas becomes Conservative interim President of Mexico.

1859.title: Unification of Wallachia and Moldavia
1859.summary: Under the rule of Alexandru Ioan Cuza, the provinces of Wallachia and Moldavia are united under the jurisdiction of the Ottoman Empire, a principal step in forming modern Romania.

1859.title: Incorporation of Olympia
1859.summary: The city of Olympia is incorporated in the Washington Territory of the United States.

1859.title: Rediscovery of Codex Sinaiticus
1859.summary: German scholar Constantin von Tischendorf rediscovers the Codex Sinaiticus, a 4th-century manuscript of the Greek Bible, at Saint Catherine's Monastery.

1859.title: Oregon admitted as U.S. state
1859.summary: Oregon is admitted as the 33rd U.S. state.

1859.title: Siege of Saigon begins
1859.summary: French naval forces capture the city and Citadel of Saigon in Vietnam, beginning the Siege of Saigon.

1859.title: Construction of first railway in northern India
1859.summary: Construction begins on the first railway in northern India with tracks laid between Allahabad and Kanpur.

1859.title: Battle of Montebello
1859.summary: During the Austro-Sardinian War, the Austrian army faces the French-Sardinian combined forces at the Battle of Montebello.

1859.title: Founding of The Cooper Union
1859.summary: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art is founded by Peter Cooper in New York City.

1859.title: A Tale of Two Cities published
1859.summary: Charles Dickens publishes A Tale of Two Cities in England.

1860.title: Discovery of Hypothetical Planet Vulcan
1860.summary: The discovery of a hypothetical planet Vulcan is announced at a meeting of the French Academy of Sciences.

1860.title: Pemberton Mill Collapse
1860.summary: The Pemberton Mill in Lawrence collapses, killing 146 workers.

1860.title: Battle of Tétouan
1860.summary: Spanish troops defeat the Moroccan army in the Battle of Tétouan.

1860.title: Camillo Benso Resignation
1860.summary: Camillo Benso, Count of Cavour is recalled as Prime Minister of Piedmont-Sardinia.

1860.title: SS Hungarian Wreck
1860.summary: The Canadian Royal Mail steamer SS Hungarian is wrecked on Cape Sable Island, all 205 onboard lost.

1860.title: Wiyot Indians Massacre
1860.summary: White settlers massacre a band of Wiyot Indians, killing at least 60 women, children and elders.

1860.title: First Taranaki War Begins
1860.summary: The First Taranaki War begins when Māori refuse to sell land to British settlers.

1860.title: Annexation of the Grand Duchy of Tuscany
1860.summary: The Grand Duchy of Tuscany is annexed to the newly formed Kingdom of Italy.

1860.title: Italian Parliament Meets
1860.summary: The first Italian Parliament meets at Turin.

1860.title: Founding of TSV 1860 München
1860.summary: The German football club TSV 1860 München is founded.

1861.title: Benito Juárez captures Mexico City
1861.summary: Benito Juárez successfully captures Mexico City, asserting control over the capital during a tumultuous period in Mexican history.

1861.title: American Civil War begins
1861.summary: The American Civil War commences with the bombardment of Fort Sumter in South Carolina, marking the start of a conflict that would change the nation.

1861.title: Abraham Lincoln's Proclamation
1861.summary: President Abraham Lincoln issues a Proclamation calling for 75,000 men to suppress the rebellion in the South, signaling a full-scale military response to the Civil War.

1861.title: Texas secedes from the Union
1861.summary: Texas officially secedes from the Union, aligning itself with the Confederate states amidst the rising tensions of the Civil War.

1861.title: Formation of the Confederate States of America
1861.summary: The Confederate States of America is formed, consolidating the seceded states of the South into a new government and military coalition.

1861.title: Acquisition of thallium
1861.summary: Sir William Crookes announces the discovery of thallium, a significant advancement in the field of chemistry and the discovery of new chemical elements.

1861.title: Battle of Bull Run
1861.summary: The First Battle of Bull Run occurs in Virginia, marking the first major battle of the American Civil War and ending in a Confederate victory.

1861.title: Completion of HMS Warrior
1861.summary: HMS Warrior, the world's first ocean-going iron-hulled armored battleship, is completed and commissioned into the British Royal Navy, representing a significant advancement in naval technology.

1861.title: Trent Affair
1861.summary: The USS San Jacinto stops the British mail ship Trent and arrests two Confederate envoys, causing a diplomatic crisis between the United Kingdom and the United States.

1861.title: First public weather forecast
1861.summary: Admiral Robert FitzRoy successfully produces the first public weather forecast, marking a milestone in meteorological science and public information.

1862.title: USS Monitor Launched
1862.summary: The first U.S. ironclad warship, USS Monitor, is launched in Brooklyn.

1862.title: Annexation of Lagos Island
1862.summary: The United Kingdom annexes Lagos Island, in modern-day Nigeria.

1862.title: Battle of Fort Henry
1862.summary: General Ulysses S. Grant gives the Union Army its first victory of the war by capturing Fort Henry in Tennessee.

1862.title: Inauguration of Jefferson Davis
1862.summary: Jefferson Davis is officially inaugurated in Richmond, Virginia, to a six-year term as president of the Confederate States.

1862.title: Publication of Battle Hymn of the Republic
1862.summary: Julia Ward Howe's "Battle Hymn of the Republic" is published for the first time in the Atlantic Monthly.

1862.title: Observation of Sirius B
1862.summary: Alvan Graham Clark makes the first observation of Sirius B, a white dwarf star, through an eighteen-inch telescope at Northwestern University.

1862.title: Battle of Antietam
1862.summary: Union forces strategically defeat Confederate troops at Sharpsburg, Maryland, in the bloodiest day in U.S. history, with over 22,000 casualties.

1862.title: Publication of Les Misérables
1862.summary: Victor Hugo's epic French historical novel Les Misérables begins publication in Brussels.

1862.title: Signing of the Homestead Act
1862.summary: U.S. President Abraham Lincoln signs the Homestead Act into law, promoting Westward expansion and land distribution.

1862.title: Emancipation Proclamation Announcement
1862.summary: The preliminary announcement of the Emancipation Proclamation is made by U.S. President Abraham Lincoln, stating that slaves in the Confederate States will be considered free.

1863.title: Emancipation Proclamation
1863.summary: Abraham Lincoln signs the Emancipation Proclamation, making the abolition of slavery in the Confederate states an official war goal, proclaiming the freedom of 3.1 million slaves.

1863.title: Eruption of the Second Battle of Springfield
1863.summary: The Second Battle of Springfield takes place, marking a significant event in the American Civil War with Union forces achieving victory over the Confederates.

1863.title: Opening of the London Underground
1863.summary: The first section of the London Underground Railway officially opens, enhancing public transport in London.

1863.title: Foundation of the International Red Cross
1863.summary: The Committee of the Five holds their first meeting in Geneva, which is regarded as the foundation of the International Committee of the Red Cross, following humanitarian endeavors.

1863.title: Siege of Vicksburg
1863.summary: The Siege of Vicksburg ends with the capture of the Confederate city by Ulysses S. Grant and the Union army, After the town surrenders following a 47-day siege.

1863.title: Gettysburg Address
1863.summary: Abraham Lincoln delivers the Gettysburg Address at the military cemetery dedication ceremony, emphasizing unity and the principles of liberty.

1863.title: Formation of the General German Workers' Association
1863.summary: Ferdinand Lassalle founds the Allgemeiner Deutscher Arbeiterverein, the first socialist workers party in Germany, marking a significant moment in labor movement history.

1863.title: Publication of Five Weeks in a Balloon
1863.summary: Jules Verne's first adventure novel, Five Weeks in a Balloon, is published, significantly contributing to the genre of science fiction.

1863.title: Opening of the First Steam-Operated Passenger Railway in New Zealand
1863.summary: The first steam-operated passenger railway opens in Christchurch, New Zealand, marking a development in public transportation in the region.

1863.title: Opening of the First Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe
1863.summary: The first Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe horse race is held, establishing one of the premier horse racing events globally.

1864.title: Stephen Foster dies
1864.summary: American songwriter Stephen Foster dies aged 37 in New York City, leaving a scrap of paper reading Dear friends and gentle hearts. His parlor song Beautiful Dreamer is published in March.

1864.title: Battle of Olustee
1864.summary: The Union suffers one of its costliest defeats at the Battle of Olustee near Lake City, Florida.

1864.title: H. L. Hunley sinks USS Housatonic
1864.summary: The tiny Confederate hand-propelled submarine H. L. Hunley sinks the USS Housatonic, becoming the first submarine to sink an enemy ship.

1864.title: Siege of Petersburg
1864.summary: Union forces, led by General William T. Sherman, launch an assault on Atlanta.

1864.title: Battle of Fort Pillow
1864.summary: Confederate forces kill most of the African American soldiers that surrender at Fort Pillow, Tennessee.

1864.title: Gallaudet University founded
1864.summary: Gallaudet University is founded in Washington, D.C., as the first university for the deaf and hard of hearing.

1864.title: Battle of the Wilderness
1864.summary: The Battle of the Wilderness begins in Spotsylvania County, Virginia, marking a significant engagement in the American Civil War.

1864.title: Establishment of Arlington National Cemetery
1864.summary: Arlington National Cemetery is established in the United States, when 200 acres of the grounds of Robert E. Lee's home are set aside as a military cemetery.

1864.title: Sherman's March to the Sea begins
1864.summary: Union General Sherman burns Atlanta and starts to move south, living off the land, and causing extensive devastation to crops and mills.

1864.title: Election of Abraham Lincoln
1864.summary: Abraham Lincoln is reelected in an overwhelming victory over George B. McClellan during the 1864 United States presidential election.

1865.title: Thirteenth Amendment Passed
1865.summary: The Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution passes narrowly in the House of Representatives, conditional upon the prohibition of slavery and involuntary servitude.

1865.title: Union Captures Fort Fisher
1865.summary: Union forces capture Fort Fisher, a significant stronghold of the Confederates, during the American Civil War.

1865.title: Abraham Lincoln Assassinated
1865.summary: President Abraham Lincoln is shot while attending a play at Ford's Theatre in Washington, D.C., by Confederate sympathizer John Wilkes Booth.

1865.title: End of the American Civil War
1865.summary: General Robert E. Lee surrenders to General Ulysses S. Grant at Appomattox Court House, effectively ending the American Civil War.

1865.title: Steamboat Sultana Disaster
1865.summary: The steamboat Sultana explodes and sinks in the Mississippi River, killing approximately 1,800 passengers, mostly Union survivors of Andersonville Prison.

1865.title: Introduction of the First Speed Limit
1865.summary: The first speed limit is introduced in Britain, establishing 2 mph in towns and 4 mph in the countryside.

1865.title: Tristan und Isolde Premiere
1865.summary: Richard Wagner's opera Tristan und Isolde debuts at the Munich Court Theatre, becoming a significant work in the repertoire of opera.

1865.title: Formation of the International Telegraph Union
1865.summary: The International Telegraph Union is founded, enhancing global communication and telegraphy standards.

1865.title: Matterhorn First Ascent
1865.summary: The summit of the Matterhorn in the Alps is reached for the first time by a party of climbers led by Edward Whymper, marking a significant achievement in mountaineering.

1865.title: Publication of Alice's Adventures in Wonderland
1865.summary: Lewis Carroll publishes his novel Alice's Adventures in Wonderland, which becomes a seminal work in children's literature.

1866.title: Fisk University Established
1866.summary: Fisk University, a historically black university, is established in Nashville, Tennessee.

1866.title: Last Issue of The Liberator
1866.summary: The last issue of the abolitionist magazine The Liberator is published.

1866.title: Formation of The Royal Aeronautical Society
1866.summary: The Royal Aeronautical Society is formed as The Aeronautical Society of Great Britain in London, the world's oldest such society.

1866.title: Battle of Abtao
1866.summary: A Spanish naval squadron fights a combined Peruvian-Chilean fleet at the island of Abtao, in the Chiloé Archipelago of southern Chile.

1866.title: First Daylight Bank Robbery
1866.summary: The first daylight bank robbery in United States history during peacetime takes place in Liberty, Missouri, considered to be the first robbery committed by Jesse James and his gang.

1866.title: U.S. Civil Rights Act of 1866
1866.summary: The United States Congress overwhelmingly passes the Civil Rights Act of 1866 to protect the rights of African-Americans; U.S. President Andrew Johnson vetoes the bill.

1866.title: Formation of ASPCA
1866.summary: The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (ASPCA) is founded in New York City by Henry Bergh.

1866.title: Battle of Tuyutí
1866.summary: 32,000 soldiers of the Triple Alliance defeat 24,000 Paraguayan soldiers in the Paraguayan War, with 16,000 casualties.

1866.title: SS Great Eastern Completes Transatlantic Cable
1866.summary: The SS Great Eastern successfully completes laying the transatlantic telegraph cable between Ireland and Newfoundland, restoring a communications link.

1866.title: Oaks Explosion
1866.summary: The worst mining disaster in England kills 383 miners and rescuers.

1867.title: Purchase of Alaska
1867.summary: Alaska is purchased for $7.2 million from Alexander II of Russia, about 2 cents/acre, by United States Secretary of State William H. Seward. Newspapers call this Seward's Folly.

1867.title: Emperor Kōmei dies
1867.summary: Emperor Kōmei of Japan dies suddenly, age 36, leaving his 14-year-old son to succeed as Emperor Meiji.

1867.title: Abdication of Tokugawa Yoshinobu
1867.summary: Shōgun Tokugawa Yoshinobu abdicates, and the late Emperor Kōmei's son, Prince Mutsuhito, becomes Emperor Meiji in a brief ceremony in Kyoto, ending the Late Tokugawa shogunate.

1867.title: Establishment of West Virginia University
1867.summary: West Virginia University is established in Morgantown, West Virginia.

1867.title: Foundation of the Augusta Institute
1867.summary: Augusta Institute is founded in Augusta, Georgia, later known as Morehouse College.

1867.title: Performing of The Blue Danube
1867.summary: Johann Strauss II's waltz The Blue Danube is first performed at a concert of the Vienna Men's Choral Association.

1867.title: Founding of the first women's fraternity
1867.summary: I.C. Sorosis, the first women's fraternity founded upon the men's fraternity model is established at Monmouth College in Illinois.

1867.title: Formation of American temperance movement
1867.summary: The Prohibition National Committee is formed in the United States, marking a significant movement in American history.

1867.title: End of the Luxembourg Crisis
1867.summary: The great powers of Europe reaffirm the neutrality of Luxembourg through the Treaty of London, concluding the Luxembourg Crisis.

1867.title: Publication of Das Kapital
1867.summary: The first volume of Das Kapital, later translated as Capital, is published by Karl Marx.

1868.title: Meiji Restoration
1868.summary: The 15-year-old Mutsuhito, Emperor Meiji of Japan, declares the Meiji Restoration, his own restoration to full power, under the influence of supporters from the Chōshū and Satsuma Domains, triggering the Boshin War.

1868.title: Battle of Toba–Fushimi
1868.summary: Forces of the Tokugawa shogunate and the allied pro-Imperial forces clash near Fushimi, Kyoto, ending in a decisive victory for the Imperial forces.

1868.title: Impeachment of Andrew Johnson
1868.summary: The United States House of Representatives votes in favor of a resolution to impeach Andrew Johnson, President of the United States, the first of three Presidents to be impeached by the full House.

1868.title: Battle of Magdala
1868.summary: A British-Indian task force under Robert Napier inflicts a crushing defeat on the army of Emperor Tewodros II, ending the British Expedition to Abyssinia.

1868.title: University of California founded
1868.summary: The University of California is founded in Oakland, California, when the Organic Act is signed into California law.

1868.title: California's First Elevated Railway
1868.summary: The cable-operated West Side and Yonkers Patent Railway in Manhattan becomes the first elevated railway in the United States.

1868.title: Chulalongkorn starts to rule in Siam
1868.summary: Chulalongkorn begins his reign in Siam, introducing significant reforms in Thailand.

1868.title: Cuban national anthem created
1868.summary: Pedro Figueredo creates the Cuban national anthem, El Himno de Bayamo, which becomes an important symbol for Cuban independence.

1868.title: The first traffic signal lights
1868.summary: The world's first traffic signal lights are installed at the junction of Great George Street and Bridge Street in London.

1868.title: Establishment of the Greek Presidential Guard
1868.summary: The Greek Presidential Guard is established as the royal escort by King George I.

1869.title: Defeat of Abdur Rahman Khan
1869.summary: Abdur Rahman Khan is defeated at Tinah Khan, and exiled from Afghanistan.

1869.title: Founding of Kilmarnock F.C.
1869.summary: Scotland's second oldest professional football team, Kilmarnock F.C., is founded.

1869.title: Elizabeth Cady Stanton's Testimony
1869.summary: Elizabeth Cady Stanton is the first woman to testify before the United States Congress.

1869.title: Proclamation of the Republic of Ezo
1869.summary: The Republic of Ezo is proclaimed on the northern Japanese island of Ezo by remaining adherents to the Tokugawa shogunate.

1869.title: Discovery of the Welcome Stranger Nugget
1869.summary: Prospectors in Moliagul, Victoria, Australia, discover the largest alluvial gold nugget ever found, known as the Welcome Stranger.

1869.title: Formation of the Iron and Steel Institute
1869.summary: The Iron and Steel Institute is formed in London.

1869.title: Mendeleev's Periodic Table Presentation
1869.summary: Dmitri Mendeleev makes a formal presentation of his periodic table to the Russian Chemical Society.

1869.title: Inauguration of the Suez Canal
1869.summary: In Egypt, the Suez Canal, linking the Mediterranean Sea with the Red Sea, is inaugurated in an elaborate ceremony.

1869.title: Launch of the Cutty Sark
1869.summary: In Dumbarton, Scotland, the clipper ship Cutty Sark is launched, one of the last clippers built.

1869.title: Publication of War and Peace
1869.summary: Leo Tolstoy's novel War and Peace is published in complete book form, in Russia.

1870.title: The first edition of The Northern Echo newspaper
1870.summary: The first edition of The Northern Echo newspaper is published in Priestgate, Darlington.

1870.title: Construction of Brooklyn Bridge begins
1870.summary: Construction of the Brooklyn Bridge begins in New York City.

1870.title: Inauguration of The Musikverein
1870.summary: The Musikverein, Vienna, is inaugurated in Austria-Hungary.

1870.title: John D. Rockefeller incorporates Standard Oil
1870.summary: John D. Rockefeller incorporates Standard Oil.

1870.title: Political cartoon symbolizes Democratic Party
1870.summary: A political cartoon for the first time symbolizes the United States Democratic Party with a donkey.

1870.title: Marias Massacre
1870.summary: U.S. soldiers attack a peaceful camp of Piegan Blackfeet Indians, led by chief Heavy Runner.

1870.title: Virginia rejoins the Union
1870.summary: Virginia rejoins the Union during the Reconstruction Era and adopts a new Constitution expanding suffrage.

1870.title: British SS City of Boston lost at sea
1870.summary: British SS City of Boston departs Halifax, Nova Scotia, on a transatlantic passage on which it will be lost with all 191 aboard.

1870.title: 15th Amendment passed
1870.summary: The 15th Amendment to the United States Constitution, guaranteeing African American men the right to vote, is passed.

1870.title: Opening of the first pneumatic subway
1870.summary: In New York City, the first pneumatic subway, Beach Pneumatic Transit, is opened.

1871.title: Proclamation of the German Empire
1871.summary: The member states of the North German Confederation and the south German states unite into a single nation state, known as the German Empire. The King of Prussia is declared the first German Emperor as Wilhelm I of Germany.

1871.title: Battle of Bapaume
1871.summary: Prussians win a strategic victory in the Franco-Prussian War.

1871.title: Civil Rights Act of 1871
1871.summary: U.S. President Ulysses S. Grant signs the Civil Rights Act of 1871, aimed at addressing civil rights issues.

1871.title: Paris Commune established
1871.summary: The Paris Commune is formally established in France, leading to significant political upheaval.

1871.title: Treaty of Frankfurt
1871.summary: The Treaty of Frankfurt is signed, confirming the frontiers between Germany and France, transferring Alsace and Lorraine to Germany.

1871.title: First Major League Baseball game
1871.summary: The first supposedly Major League Baseball game is played in America, marking a significant development in sports culture.

1871.title: Great Chicago Fire
1871.summary: Four major fires break out on the shores of Lake Michigan, with the Great Chicago Fire leaving nearly 100,000 people homeless.

1871.title: Establishment of the first scientific organization dedicated to astrophysics
1871.summary: The Società degli Spettroscopisti Italiani is established in Rome, marking a milestone in scientific collaboration.

1871.title: Gold rush in South Africa
1871.summary: Gold is discovered at Pilgrim's Creek in South Africa, resulting in a diamond rush, prompting the arrival of Colonial Commissioners.

1871.title: Aida opens in Cairo
1871.summary: The opera Aida opens in Cairo, Egypt, marking a significant cultural milestone in operatic history.

1872.title: Yohannes IV crowned Emperor of Ethiopia
1872.summary: Yohannes IV is crowned Emperor of Ethiopia in Axum, the first ruler crowned in that city in over 500 years.

1872.title: Cavite mutiny
1872.summary: The Cavite mutiny was an uprising of Filipino military personnel of Fort San Felipe, the Spanish arsenal in Cavite, Philippine Islands.

1872.title: Great solar flare
1872.summary: A great solar flare, and associated geomagnetic storm, makes northern lights visible as far south as Cuba.

1872.title: Metropolitan Museum of Art opens
1872.summary: The Metropolitan Museum of Art opens in New York City.

1872.title: Yellowstone National Park established
1872.summary: In the United States, Yellowstone National Park is established as the world's first national park.

1872.title: George Westinghouse patent
1872.summary: George Westinghouse receives a United States patent for the failsafe automatic railway air brake.

1872.title: FA Cup Final
1872.summary: In the first ever final of the FA Cup, Wanderers F.C. defeat Royal Engineers A.F.C. 1–0 at The Oval in Kennington, London.

1872.title: Great Boston Fire
1872.summary: In Boston, Massachusetts, a large fire begins to burn on Lincoln Street, destroying about 65 acres and causing US$60 million in damage.

1872.title: Impression, Sunrise painting begins
1872.summary: Claude Monet begins painting Impression, Sunrise, the painting that will give a name to Impressionism, as viewed from his hotel room at Le Havre in France.

1872.title: HMS Challenger sets sail
1872.summary: HMS Challenger sails from Portsmouth, England, on the 4-year scientific expedition that lays the foundation for the science of oceanography.

1873.title: Japan adopts the Gregorian calendar
1873.summary: Japan officially adopts the Gregorian calendar, marking a significant shift in their timekeeping system.

1873.title: First Spanish Republic proclaimed
1873.summary: The Spanish Cortes deposes King Amadeus I and proclaims the First Spanish Republic, a major political change in Spain.

1873.title: United States ends bimetallism
1873.summary: The Coinage Act of 1873 is signed into law, placing the US on the gold standard, impacting the economy.

1873.title: University of California medical school opens
1873.summary: The University of California opens its first medical school in San Francisco, advancing medical education.

1873.title: RMS Atlantic sinks
1873.summary: The British ocean liner RMS Atlantic sinks off Nova Scotia, resulting in the loss of 547 lives, a major maritime disaster.

1873.title: Heinrich Schliemann discovers Priam's Treasure
1873.summary: Classical archaeologist Heinrich Schliemann discovers Priam's Treasure, significant for archaeology and history.

1873.title: The Long Depression begins
1873.summary: The Long Depression starts in the United States, leading to widespread economic challenges.

1873.title: SS Ville du Havre disaster
1873.summary: The SS Ville du Havre collides with another vessel in mid-Atlantic, sinking and causing the loss of 226 lives.

1873.title: Founding of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union
1873.summary: The Woman's Christian Temperance Union is founded in Hillsboro, Ohio, advocating for temperance and women's rights.

1873.title: Tchaikovsky's The Tempest premiered
1873.summary: Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky's fantasia The Tempest is premiered in Moscow, contributing to the classical music repertoire.

1874.title: New York City annexes The Bronx
1874.summary: New York City expands its territory by annexing The Bronx, increasing its influence and population.

1874.title: Ignacio María González becomes head of state of the Dominican Republic
1874.summary: Ignacio María González assumes leadership for the first time, marking a significant political change in the Dominican Republic.

1874.title: Battle of Caspe
1874.summary: Republican forces defeat Carlist troops at Caspe during the Third Carlist War, impacting the ongoing conflict in Spain.

1874.title: Pangkor Treaty signed
1874.summary: The British sign the Pangkor Treaty, consolidating their control over the Sultanate of Perak and other Malay States.

1874.title: Prince Alfred marries Grand Duchess Maria Alexandrovna of Russia
1874.summary: A significant royal marriage takes place in Saint Petersburg, strengthening ties between Britain and Russia.

1874.title: Patent of lawn tennis
1874.summary: Walter Clopton Wingfield patents 'sphairistike', later known as lawn tennis, marking an important development in the world of sports.

1874.title: First performance of Verdi's Requiem
1874.summary: Giuseppe Verdi's Requiem is first performed in Milan, showcasing a significant contribution to classical music.

1874.title: Founding of the Universal Postal Union
1874.summary: The establishment of the Universal Postal Union marks a significant advancement in international postal services and cooperation.

1874.title: First public zoo opens in Philadelphia
1874.summary: The Philadelphia Zoo opens, becoming the first public zoo in the United States and enhancing public education about animals.

1874.title: Chicago Fire of 1874
1874.summary: The Chicago Fire destroys large parts of the city, leading to significant reforms in fire safety and urban planning.

1875.title: Abolition of Second Class
1875.summary: The Midland Railway of England abolishes the Second Class passenger category, leaving First Class and Third Class.

1875.title: Inauguration of Palais Garnier
1875.summary: The Palais Garnier, one of the most famous opera houses in the world, is inaugurated as the home of the Paris Opera.

1875.title: Guangxu Emperor ascends the throne
1875.summary: Guangxu becomes the 11th Qing dynasty Emperor of China at the age of 3, succeeding his cousin, the Tongzhi Emperor.

1875.title: Restoration of the Monarchy in Spain
1875.summary: The newly proclaimed King Alfonso XII of Spain arrives to restore the monarchy during the Third Carlist War.

1875.title: Première of Danse macabre
1875.summary: Camille Saint-Saëns' orchestral Danse macabre receives its première.

1875.title: Battle of Lácars
1875.summary: Carlist commander Torcuato Mendíri secures a victory in the Third Carlist War against a Government force.

1875.title: Start of Mason County War
1875.summary: The Mason County War begins, involving a German-American mob lynching cattle rustlers.

1875.title: Sinking of the SS Gothenburg
1875.summary: The SS Gothenburg sinks off Australia's east coast with the loss of approximately 102 lives.

1875.title: Civil Rights Act passes in the US
1875.summary: The United States Congress passes the Civil Rights Act, prohibiting racial discrimination in public accommodations and jury duty.

1875.title: First performance of Bizet's Carmen
1875.summary: Bizet's Carmen is first performed at the Opéra-Comique, Paris, France.

1876.title: Reichsbank opens
1876.summary: The Reichsbank opens in Berlin, becoming the central bank of Germany, a critical institution in economic management.

1876.title: Bass Brewery Red Triangle
1876.summary: The Bass Brewery Red Triangle becomes the world's first registered trademark symbol, marking a significant advancement in brand identity.
