1876.title: National League of Professional Base Ball Clubs formed
1876.summary: The National League of Professional Base Ball Clubs is formed in Chicago at a meeting, influencing the structure of organized baseball.

1876.title: Patent for the telephone
1876.summary: Alexander Graham Bell applies for a patent for the telephone, representing a major technological advance in communication.

1876.title: Founding of Johns Hopkins University
1876.summary: Johns Hopkins University is founded in Baltimore, Maryland, establishing a key institution for higher education and research in the United States.

1876.title: Japan-Korea Treaty of 1876
1876.summary: The Japanese force the Korean government to sign the Japan–Korea Treaty of 1876, opening Korea to Japanese trade and shifting regional dynamics.

1876.title: First successful telephone call
1876.summary: Alexander Graham Bell makes the first successful telephone call, showcasing the practicality of his invention and changing communication.

1876.title: First Symphony of Johannes Brahms
1876.summary: The long-awaited First Symphony of Johannes Brahms has its premiere at Karlsruhe, marking a significant event in the world of classical music.

1876.title: Centennial Exposition begins
1876.summary: The Centennial Exposition in Philadelphia begins, celebrating the 100th anniversary of American independence and showcasing advances.

1876.title: Battles of the Little Bighorn
1876.summary: The Battle of the Little Bighorn occurs, marking a significant conflict in the American Indian Wars and altering U.S. military policies.

1877.title: Queen Victoria proclaimed Empress of India
1877.summary: Queen Victoria is proclaimed Empress of India by the Royal Titles Act 1876, introduced by Benjamin Disraeli, the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.

1877.title: Battle of Wolf Mountain
1877.summary: Crazy Horse and his warriors fight their last battle with the United States Cavalry in Montana during the Great Sioux War of 1876.

1877.title: Conference of Constantinople ends
1877.summary: The Conference of Constantinople ends, with Ottoman Turkey rejecting proposals of internal reform and Balkan provisions.

1877.title: The Satsuma Rebellion
1877.summary: The Satsuma Rebellion, a revolt of disaffected samurai in Japan, breaks out against the new imperial government; it lasts until September.

1877.title: Emile Berliner patents the microphone
1877.summary: Emile Berliner patents the microphone in the United States, marking a significant advancement in sound technology.

1877.title: Swan Lake debuts
1877.summary: Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky's ballet Swan Lake debuts in Moscow, becoming a significant work in classical music.

1877.title: First Test cricket match
1877.summary: The first Test cricket match is held between England and Australia, an event in cricket history.

1877.title: First human cannonball act
1877.summary: The first human cannonball act is performed by 17-year-old Rossa Matilda Richter at the London Royal Aquarium.

1877.title: Alexander Graham Bell installs first commercial telephone service
1877.summary: Alexander Graham Bell installs the world's first commercial telephone service in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada, transforming communication.

1877.title: Thomas Edison announces the phonograph
1877.summary: Thomas Edison announces his invention of the phonograph, a machine that can record sound, considered his first great invention.

1878.title: Cleopatra's Needle erected
1878.summary: Cleopatra's Needle, an ancient Egyptian obelisk, is erected in London, marking a significant architectural event.

1878.title: Battle of Shipka Pass IV
1878.summary: Russian and Bulgarian forces defeat the Ottoman Empire in a significant battle during the Russo-Turkish War.

1878.title: Umberto I becomes King of Italy
1878.summary: Umberto I ascends the throne as King of Italy, a major moment in Italian history.

1878.title: Telephone Exchange begins operation
1878.summary: The world's first Telephone Exchange begins commercial operation in New Haven, Connecticut, revolutionizing communication.

1878.title: Phonograph patented by Thomas Edison
1878.summary: Thomas Edison patents the phonograph, a groundbreaking invention in the field of sound recording.

1878.title: Treaty of Berlin
1878.summary: The Treaty of Berlin is signed, confirming the independence of Serbia, Montenegro, and Romania and altering the map of the Balkans.

1878.title: H.M.S. Pinafore premieres
1878.summary: Gilbert and Sullivan's comic opera H.M.S. Pinafore debuts in London, influencing music and theatre.

1878.title: First recorded floodlit football match
1878.summary: The world's first recorded floodlit football fixture takes place in Sheffield, England, signalling a new era in sports.

1878.title: Byzantin tragedy
1878.summary: The French passenger steamer Byzantin founders in the Dardanelles, resulting in a significant loss of life.

1878.title: James McNeill Whistler libel case
1878.summary: The High Court rules on Whistler's libel case against Ruskin, profoundly affecting the artist's career.

1879.title: Specie Resumption Act takes effect
1879.summary: The United States Note is valued the same as gold, for the first time since the American Civil War.

1879.title: Anglo-Zulu War begins
1879.summary: The war marks the beginning of significant conflicts in Africa between the British Empire and the Zulu Kingdom.

1879.title: Battle of Isandlwana
1879.summary: A force of 1,200 British soldiers is wiped out by over 20,000 Zulu warriors.

1879.title: Battle of Rorke's Drift
1879.summary: A smaller British force of 140 successfully repels an attack by 4,000 Zulus following the previous day's defeat.

1879.title: First public highway lit by electric light
1879.summary: Mosley Street in Newcastle upon Tyne becomes the world's first public highway to be lit by the electric incandescent light bulb invented by Joseph Swan.

1879.title: Standard time proposal
1879.summary: Sandford Fleming first proposes the global adoption of standard time at a meeting of the Royal Canadian Institute.

1879.title: US Geological Survey founded
1879.summary: The US Geological Survey is established to provide scientific information about the landscape and natural resources.

1879.title: Battle of Ulundi
1879.summary: A British victory effectively ends the Anglo-Zulu War.

1879.title: Invention of the incandescent light bulb
1879.summary: Thomas Edison tests his first practical electric light bulb using a filament of carbonized thread.

1879.title: Tay Bridge disaster
1879.summary: The central part of the Tay Rail Bridge at Dundee collapses in a storm as a train passes over it, killing 75.

1880.title: Thomas Edison is granted a patent for the incandescent light bulb
1880.summary: Edison filed for a US patent for an electric lamp using a carbon filament or strip coiled and connected to platina contact wires. Edison and his team later discovered that a carbonized bamboo filament could last more than 1200 hours.

1880.title: First electric streetlight installed
1880.summary: The first electric streetlight is installed in Wabash, Indiana, marking a significant advancement in urban lighting.

1880.title: The Black Donnelly Massacre
1880.summary: The Black Donnelly Massacre takes the lives of five members of one family in Biddulph Township, Middlesex County, Ontario, Canada.

1880.title: Launch of the SS Columbia
1880.summary: The SS Columbia, which will be the first outside usage of Thomas Edison's incandescent light bulb, is launched at the Delaware River Iron Ship Building and Engine Works.

1880.title: Formation of the Royal University of Ireland
1880.summary: The Royal University of Ireland is founded by charter, allowing the Catholic University of Ireland to re-form as University College Dublin, enhancing higher education in Ireland.

1880.title: Maiden voyage of the SS Columbia
1880.summary: The SS Columbia sets off on her maiden voyage around Cape Horn to Portland, Oregon, carrying 13 locomotives and 200 railcars, showcasing advancements in transport.

1880.title: Completion of Cologne Cathedral
1880.summary: Cologne Cathedral is completed, after construction began in 1248, marking a significant architectural achievement in Germany.

1880.title: Second Anglo-Afghan War - Battle of Kandahar
1880.summary: General Frederick Roberts commands British forces to victory against Afghan troops, bringing an end to the Second Anglo-Afghan War, which impacts British imperial policy.

1880.title: First cash register patented
1880.summary: The first cash register is patented by James and John Ritty, revolutionizing the retail industry and accounting practices.

1880.title: A major earthquake strikes Zagreb
1880.summary: A major earthquake strikes Zagreb, destroying many buildings, including Zagreb Cathedral, impacting the city and its community.

1881.title: Siege of Geok Tepe
1881.summary: Russian troops under General Mikhail Skobelev defeat the Turkomans.

1881.title: Battle of San Juan and Chorrillos
1881.summary: The Chilean army defeats Peruvian forces.

1881.title: Battle of Miraflores
1881.summary: The Chileans take Lima, capital of Peru, after defeating its second line of defense in Miraflores.

1881.title: Formation of the Oriental Telephone Company
1881.summary: Thomas Edison and Alexander Graham Bell form the Oriental Telephone Company.

1881.title: Transmission of Yellow Fever by Mosquitoes
1881.summary: Carlos Finlay introduces his discovery of the transmission of Yellow Fever by mosquitoes Aedes aegypti, in the Fifth International Sanitary Conference held in Washington, D.C.

1881.title: First Steel Transatlantic Liner Launched
1881.summary: The Cunard Line's SS Servia, the first steel transatlantic liner, is launched at Clydebank in Scotland.

1881.title: Assassination of Alexander II of Russia
1881.summary: Emperor Alexander II of Russia is killed near his palace in Saint Petersburg when bombs are thrown at him.

1881.title: First Regular Electric Tram Service
1881.summary: The world's first regular electric tram service is started in Berlin, by Siemens & Halske.

1881.title: Savoy Theatre Opens
1881.summary: Richard D'Oyly Carte's Savoy Theatre opens in London, the world's first public building to be fully lit by electricity.

1881.title: Brahms' Piano Concerto No. 2 Premieres
1881.summary: Brahms' Piano Concerto No. 2 premieres in Budapest.

1882.title: Standard Oil Trust Creation
1882.summary: The Standard Oil Trust is secretly created in the United States to control multiple corporations set up by John D. Rockefeller and his associates.

1882.title: Oscar Wilde Arrives in New York
1882.summary: Irish-born author Oscar Wilde arrives in New York at the beginning of a lecture tour of the United States and Canada.

1882.title: First Coal-Fired Power Station
1882.summary: Holborn Viaduct power station in the City of London, the world's first coal-fired public electricity generating station, begins operation.

1882.title: Discovery of Mycobacterium tuberculosis
1882.summary: Robert Koch announces the discovery of the bacterium responsible for tuberculosis (Mycobacterium tuberculosis).

1882.title: Electromote Begins Operation
1882.summary: The Elektromote, the world's first trolleybus, begins operation in Berlin.

1882.title: Berlin Philharmonic Founded
1882.summary: The Berlin Philharmonic orchestra is founded in Germany, as Frühere Bilsesche Kapelle.

1882.title: Tchaikovsky's 1812 Overture Debuts
1882.summary: Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky's 1812 Overture debuts in Moscow.

1882.title: First Commercial Electrical Power Plant
1882.summary: Thomas Edison flips the switch to the first commercial electrical power plant in the United States, lighting one square mile of lower Manhattan.

1882.title: University of the Punjab Founded
1882.summary: The University of the Punjab at Lahore (Undivided India) is founded in modern-day Pakistan.

1882.title: Great Fire of Oulu
1882.summary: The Great Fire of Oulu destroys 27 buildings in the downtown of Oulu, Finland.

1883.title: Life Magazine Founded
1883.summary: Life magazine is founded in Los Angeles, California, marking a significant moment in American media history.

1883.title: Newhall Hotel Fire
1883.summary: A fire at the Newhall Hotel in Milwaukee causes the tragic death of 73 people, highlighting the need for improved safety standards.

1883.title: First Electric Lighting System
1883.summary: The first electric lighting system employing overhead wires begins service in Roselle, New Jersey, signifying a major advancement in public utilities.

1883.title: Tokyo Electrical Lightning Grid Founded
1883.summary: The Tokyo Electrical Lightning Grid is founded in Japan, becoming one of the largest electrical grids in Asia and the world.

1883.title: Brooklyn Bridge Opened to Traffic
1883.summary: After 13 years of construction, the Brooklyn Bridge is officially opened to traffic in New York City, becoming a symbol of engineering achievement.

1883.title: Victoria Hall Disaster
1883.summary: A rush for treats at Victoria Hall results in the asphyxiation of 183 children in a concert hall in Sunderland, England, a significant tragedy.

1883.title: Krakatoa Eruption
1883.summary: The volcanic island of Krakatoa erupts, leading to the destruction of 163 villages and the death of over 36,000 people from the resulting tsunami.

1883.title: Treaty of Ancón
1883.summary: Peru and Chile sign the Treaty of Ancón, ceding the Tarapacá province to Chile and ending Peru's involvement in the War of the Pacific.

1883.title: First Electric Tram in Vienna
1883.summary: The Mödling and Hinterbrühl Tram in Vienna becomes the first electric tram powered by overhead wire, indicating progress in public transportation.

1883.title: Battleford Industrial School Opens
1883.summary: Battleford Industrial School opens as the first government-operated Indian residential school in Canada, shaping indigenous education.

1884.title: The Fabian Society is founded
1884.summary: A socialist organization established to promote social democracy through gradual reform.

1884.title: Princess Ida premieres
1884.summary: Gilbert and Sullivan's comic opera makes its debut at the Savoy Theatre, enhancing the cultural scene.

1884.title: William Price attempts cremation
1884.summary: William Price conducts the first modern cremation in the UK, setting a crucial legal precedent.

1884.title: First fascicle of The Oxford English Dictionary published
1884.summary: The initial volume of an influential dictionary is released, shaping the English language.

1884.title: Derby County Football Club is founded
1884.summary: A significant event in sports history with the establishment of a key football club.

1884.title: The siege of Khartoum begins
1884.summary: A pivotal conflict marks the beginning of a significant military engagement.

1884.title: Pope Leo XIII publishes Humanum genus
1884.summary: An important religious encyclical addressing the issues of Freemasonry and liberalism.

1884.title: Angelo Moriondo patents espresso machine
1884.summary: Innovation in coffee making technology is introduced with the patent of the espresso machine.

1884.title: The Norwegian Association for Women's Rights is founded
1884.summary: A milestone in the feminist movement as a significant organization is established in Norway.

1884.title: Establishment of the United States Naval War College
1884.summary: A crucial development in military education takes place with the founding of this institution.

1885.title: Washington Monument Dedication
1885.summary: United States President Chester A. Arthur dedicates the Washington Monument.

1885.title: Battle of Nùi Bop
1885.summary: French troops under General Oscar de Négrier defeat a numerically superior Qing Chinese force, in northern Vietnam.

1885.title: Battle of Abu Klea
1885.summary: British troops defeat Mahdist forces in the Mahdist War in Sudan.

1885.title: Patent of Roller Coaster
1885.summary: American inventor LaMarcus Adna Thompson patents a roller coaster.

1885.title: Establishment of Congo Free State
1885.summary: King Leopold II of Belgium establishes the Congo Free State, as a personal possession.

1885.title: First Edition of the Dow Jones Industrial Average
1885.summary: Charles Dow publishes the first edition of the Dow Jones Industrial Average, representing the dollar average of 14 stocks.

1885.title: The Mikado Opera Opening
1885.summary: Gilbert and Sullivan's comic opera The Mikado opens, at the Savoy Theatre in London.

1885.title: Statue of Liberty Arrival
1885.summary: The Statue of Liberty arrives in New York Harbor.

1885.title: Louis Pasteur's Rabies Vaccine Test
1885.summary: Louis Pasteur and Émile Roux successfully test their rabies vaccine on Joseph Meister.

1885.title: Execution of Louis Riel
1885.summary: Louis Riel, Canadian rebel leader of the Métis, is executed for high treason.

1886.title: Annexation of Upper Burma
1886.summary: Upper Burma is formally annexed to British Burma, following its conquest in the Third Anglo-Burmese War of November 1885.

1886.title: Publication of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde
1886.summary: Robert Louis Stevenson's novella Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde is published in New York and London.

1886.title: Resolution Against Prussian Deportations
1886.summary: A resolution is passed in the German Parliament to condemn the Prussian deportations, the politically motivated mass expulsion of ethnic Poles and Jews from Prussia, initiated by Otto von Bismarck.

1886.title: Birth of Modern Field Hockey
1886.summary: Modern field hockey is born with the formation of The Hockey Association in England.

1886.title: Patent of the Benz Patent-Motorwagen
1886.summary: Karl Benz patents the first successful gasoline-driven automobile, the Benz Patent-Motorwagen.

1886.title: Seattle Riot of 1886
1886.summary: Anti-Chinese sentiments result in riots in Seattle, Washington.

1886.title: Treaty of Bucharest
1886.summary: The Treaty of Bucharest ends the Serbo-Bulgarian War in the Balkans.

1886.title: Invention of Coca-Cola
1886.summary: American pharmacist Dr. John Pemberton invents a carbonated beverage that will be named 'Coca-Cola'.

1886.title: First Trainload of Oranges
1886.summary: The first trainload of oranges leaves Los Angeles via the United States transcontinental railroad.

1886.title: Circumnavigation by Bicycle
1886.summary: English adventurer Thomas Stevens concludes the first circumnavigation by bicycle in Yokohama, having set out on his penny-farthing from San Francisco in 1884.

1887.title: Anti-rabies treatment defense
1887.summary: Louis Pasteur's anti-rabies treatment is defended in the Académie Nationale de Médecine by Dr. Joseph Grancher.

1887.title: Pearl Harbor lease
1887.summary: The United States Senate allows the United States Navy to lease Pearl Harbor as a naval base.

1887.title: British ship disaster
1887.summary: British emigrant ship Kapunda sinks after a collision off the coast of Brazil, killing 303 with only 16 survivors.

1887.title: Amateur Athletic Union formed
1887.summary: The Amateur Athletic Union (AAU) is formed in the United States.

1887.title: Battle of Dogali
1887.summary: Abyssinian troops defeat the Italians in the Battle of Dogali.

1887.title: Eiffel Tower construction begins
1887.summary: Construction work begins on the foundations of the Eiffel Tower in Paris, France.

1887.title: Groundhog Day observed
1887.summary: The first Groundhog Day is observed in Punxsutawney, Pennsylvania.

1887.title: French Riviera earthquake
1887.summary: The French Riviera is hit by a large earthquake, killing around 2,000 along the coast of the Mediterranean.

1887.title: Hells Canyon massacre
1887.summary: The Hells Canyon massacre begins: 34 Chinese gold miners are ambushed and murdered in Hells Canyon, Oregon, United States.

1887.title: Yamaha Corporation founded
1887.summary: Yamaha Corporation, the global musical instrument and audiovisual brand, is founded as Yamaha Organ Manufacturing in Hamamatsu, Japan.

1888.title: Great Blizzard of 1888
1888.summary: The Great Blizzard begins along the eastern seaboard of the United States, shutting down commerce and killing more than 400.

1888.title: The National Geographic Society is founded
1888.summary: The National Geographic Society is founded in Washington, D.C.

1888.title: Thomas Edison meets Eadweard Muybridge
1888.summary: In West Orange, New Jersey, Thomas Edison meets with Eadweard Muybridge, who proposes a scheme for sound film.

1888.title: Wilhelm I dies, Frederick III becomes German Emperor
1888.summary: Wilhelm I dies, Frederick III becomes German Emperor and King of Prussia.

1888.title: First Romani language operetta premieres
1888.summary: The first Romani language operetta premieres in Moscow, Russia.

1888.title: The Lawn Tennis Association is founded
1888.summary: The Lawn Tennis Association is founded in England.

1888.title: International Exhibition of Science, Art and Industry opens
1888.summary: The International Exhibition of Science, Art and Industry in Kelvingrove Park, Glasgow opens.

1888.title: Establishment of The Football League
1888.summary: A meeting to discuss establishment of The Football League is held in London.

1888.title: Washington Monument officially opens
1888.summary: The Washington Monument officially opens to the general public in Washington, D.C.

1888.title: Vincent van Gogh cuts off his ear
1888.summary: Dutch painter Vincent van Gogh infamously cuts off the lower part of his left ear in Arles.

1889.title: Total Solar Eclipse
1889.summary: The total solar eclipse of January 1, 1889 is seen over parts of California and Nevada.

1889.title: Ghost Dance Movement
1889.summary: Paiute spiritual leader Wovoka experiences a vision, leading to the start of the Ghost Dance movement in the Dakotas.

1889.title: Cleveland's Act
1889.summary: An Act to Regulate Appointments in the Marine Hospital Service of the United States is signed by President Grover Cleveland, establishing a Commissioned Corps of officers.

1889.title: Inaugural Football League Winner
1889.summary: Preston North End F.C. is declared the winner of the inaugural Football League in England.

1889.title: Patent for Tabulating Machine
1889.summary: Herman Hollerith receives a patent for his electric tabulating machine in the United States.

1889.title: Incorporation of Coca-Cola Company
1889.summary: The Coca-Cola Company is originally incorporated as the Pemberton Medicine Company in Atlanta, Georgia.

1889.title: Rudolf & Maria at Mayerling
1889.summary: Rudolf, Crown Prince of Austria and his mistress Baroness Mary Vetsera commit a double suicide in the Mayerling hunting lodge.

1889.title: Meiji Constitution of Japan
1889.summary: The Meiji Constitution of Japan is adopted; the 1st Diet of Japan convenes in 1890.

1889.title: Eiffel Tower Inauguration
1889.summary: The Eiffel Tower is inaugurated in Paris, becoming the tallest structure in the world.

1889.title: Johnstown Flood
1889.summary: The South Fork Dam collapses in western Pennsylvania, killing more than 2,200 people in and around Johnstown, Pennsylvania.

1890.title: The foundation of the United Mine Workers of America
1890.summary: The United Mine Workers of America is founded, advocating for the rights and working conditions of miners in the United States.

1890.title: Premiere of The Sleeping Beauty
1890.summary: Ballet The Sleeping Beauty, with music by Tchaikovsky, is premiered at the Imperial Mariinsky Theatre in St. Petersburg, Russia, influencing the world of dance and music compositions.

1890.title: Allianz foundation
1890.summary: The worldwide insurance and financial service brand Allianz is founded in Berlin, Germany, marking a significant development in the financial sector.

1890.title: Chicago Columbian Exposition selection
1890.summary: Chicago is selected to host the Columbian Exposition, which will celebrate the 400th anniversary of Christopher Columbus's arrival in the Americas.

1890.title: Wreck of the British steamship Duburg
1890.summary: The British steamship Duburg is wrecked in the South China Sea; 400 lives are lost, highlighting maritime safety issues of the time.

1890.title: The first official English County Championship cricket match
1890.summary: The first ever official English County Championship cricket match begins in Bristol, £Yorkshire beats Gloucestershire, marking a key moment in sporting history.

1890.title: Establishment of the Weather Bureau
1890.summary: The Weather Bureau is established within the United States Department of Agriculture, leading to advancements in meteorology and public weather services.

1890.title: The Forth Bridge opens
1890.summary: The Forth Bridge, a vital railway structure and engineering accomplishment, is opened to rail traffic, enhancing transportation in Scotland.

1890.title: Wounded Knee Massacre
1890.summary: At Wounded Knee, South Dakota, U.S. troops attempt to disperse a Native American camp resulting in the deaths of many, marking a tragic chapter in Native American history.

1890.title: Hunkpapa Lakota leader Sitting Bull is killed
1890.summary: Hunkpapa Lakota leader Sitting Bull is killed by police on Standing Rock Indian Reservation, impacting Native American leadership and resistance.

1891.title: Chilean Civil War
1891.summary: The Chilean Civil War of 1891 breaks out, resulting in significant political changes in Chile.

1891.title: Music Hall Opening
1891.summary: The Music Hall in New York, known later as Carnegie Hall, has its grand opening with Tchaikovsky conducting.

1891.title: First Official Game in Argentina
1891.summary: The first official game in the Association football league of Argentina is held in Buenos Aires.

1891.title: First Penalty Kick
1891.summary: The first penalty kick is awarded in a football match, creating a significant change in football regulations.

1891.title: Opening of Stanford University
1891.summary: Stanford University in California opens its doors, contributing to higher education in the United States.

1891.title: International Copyright Act
1891.summary: The International Copyright Act of 1891 is passed in the United States, impacting copyright laws significantly.

1891.title: Japanese Earthquake
1891.summary: The 8.0 Ms Mino–Owari earthquake strikes Japan, causing thousands of deaths and injuries.

1891.title: First Long-Distance AC Transmission
1891.summary: The first long-distance transmission of alternating current is achieved in Colorado, marking a milestone in electrical engineering.

1891.title: Liliuokalani Proclaimed Queen
1891.summary: Liliuokalani is proclaimed Queen of Hawaii, an important event in Hawaiian history.

1891.title: Foundation of AIK Sports Club
1891.summary: Allmänna Idrottsklubben (AIK) sports club is founded in Stockholm, Sweden, contributing to sports culture in the region.

1892.title: Ellis Island begins processing immigrants
1892.summary: Ellis Island, a gateway for millions of immigrants to the United States, officially begins operation, marking a significant event in American immigration history.

1892.title: Patent for Diesel engine
1892.summary: Rudolf Diesel applies for a patent on his innovative compression ignition engine known as the Diesel engine, paving the way for advancements in automotive technology.

1892.title: Founding of Liverpool Football Club
1892.summary: Liverpool Football Club is founded in England by John Houlding, highlighting the importance of local football culture and the rise of club sports in the country.

1892.title: First basketball game
1892.summary: The first public basketball game is played at the Springfield YMCA, which introduces the sport to a wider audience and sets the stage for its future popularity.

1892.title: Incorporation of St. Petersburg, Florida
1892.summary: St. Petersburg is incorporated as a town, experiencing growth and development which impacts local citizens and community identity.

1892.title: Establishment of General Electric Company
1892.summary: The merger of the Thomson-Houston Electric Company and the Edison General Electric Company leads to the establishment of General Electric, a major player in technology and innovation.

1892.title: Establishment of Limelight Department
1892.summary: The Limelight Department is officially established in Melbourne, Australia, marking a milestone in the history of film and media production.

1892.title: Plessy v. Ferguson landmark case
1892.summary: Homer Plessy is arrested for sitting in a whites-only railroad car, leading to a landmark Supreme Court case that legalizes racial segregation in the United States.

1892.title: First collection of Sherlock Holmes published
1892.summary: Arthur Conan Doyle's first collection of Sherlock Holmes stories is published, influencing literature and popular culture significantly in the years to come.

1892.title: Premiere of The Nutcracker ballet
1892.summary: The Nutcracker ballet, composed by Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky, premieres in Saint Petersburg, marking a significant cultural event in the world of classical music and dance.

1893.title: Introduction of Railroad Chronometers
1893.summary: Webb C. Ball introduces railroad chronometers, which become the general railroad timepiece standards in North America.

1893.title: Overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii
1893.summary: Lorrin A. Thurston and the Citizen's Committee of Public Safety in Hawaii, with the intervention of the United States Marine Corps, overthrow the government of Queen Liliuokalani.

1893.title: First Motion Picture Studio
1893.summary: Thomas Edison finishes construction of the first motion picture studio in West Orange, New Jersey.

1893.title: Patent for Diesel Engine
1893.summary: Rudolf Diesel receives a patent for the diesel engine.

1893.title: World's Columbian Exposition Opens
1893.summary: The 1893 World's Fair, also known as the World's Columbian Exposition, opens to the public in Chicago, Illinois.

1893.title: Gandhi Arrives in South Africa
1893.summary: Gandhi arrives in South Africa, where he will live until 1914 and lead non-violent protests on behalf of Indian immigrants.

1893.title: Introduction of Driving Licenses
1893.summary: The world's first driving licenses are introduced in France under the Paris Police Ordinance.

1893.title: Edison Demonstrates Kinetoscope
1893.summary: Edison's 1½ inch system of Kinetoscope is first demonstrated in public, at the Brooklyn Institute.

1893.title: First Performance of Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 6
1893.summary: Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky conducts the first performance of his Symphony No. 6 in B minor, Pathétique, nine days before his death.

1893.title: Debut of Dvořák's Symphony No. 9
1893.summary: Antonín Dvořák's Symphony No. 9 (From the New World) receives its premiere at Carnegie Hall, New York City, conducted by the composer, to immediate acclaim.

1894.title: Military alliance between France and Russia
1894.summary: A military alliance is established between the French Third Republic and the Russian Empire.

1894.title: Patent for motion picture film
1894.summary: William Kennedy Dickson receives a patent for motion picture film in the United States.

1894.title: First battery-operated telephone switchboard
1894.summary: New England Telephone and Telegraph installs the first battery-operated telephone switchboard, in Lexington, Massachusetts.

1894.title: French anarchist bombing
1894.summary: French anarchist Émile Henry sets off a bomb in a Paris café, killing one person and wounding twenty.

1894.title: Donghak Peasant Revolution
1894.summary: In Korea, peasant unrest erupts in the Donghak Peasant Revolution, a massive revolt of followers of the Donghak movement.

1894.title: Coxey's Army protest
1894.summary: Coxey's Army, the first significant protest march in the United States, departs from Massillon, Ohio, for Washington, D.C.

1894.title: Coca-Cola sold in bottles
1894.summary: Coca-Cola is sold in bottles for the first time.

1894.title: Foundation of the International Olympic Committee
1894.summary: The International Olympic Committee is founded at the Sorbonne, Paris, at the initiative of Baron Pierre de Coubertin.

1894.title: Assassination of Sadi Carnot
1894.summary: Sadi Carnot, president of France, is assassinated in Lyon.

1894.title: Women's right to vote in South Australia
1894.summary: Women in South Australia become the first in Australia to gain the right to vote and the first in the world with the right to be elected to Parliament.

1895.title: Dreyfus Affair
1895.summary: French officer Alfred Dreyfus is stripped of his army rank and sentenced to life imprisonment on Devil's Island on what is later admitted to be a false charge of treason.

1895.title: First Italo-Ethiopian War: Battle of Coatit
1895.summary: Italian forces defeat the Ethiopians in the first battle of the war.

1895.title: Gold Reserve Loan to U.S. Treasury
1895.summary: J. P. Morgan and the Rothschilds loan $65 million worth of gold to the U.S. government, saving its gold reserve.

1895.title: Cuban War of Independence Rebellions
1895.summary: The first rebellions of the Cuban War of Independence break out, initiating a significant conflict.

1895.title: World's First Gasoline Bus Route
1895.summary: The world's first gasoline bus route is started in Germany, marking a significant advancement in public transportation.

1895.title: Treaty of Shimonoseki
1895.summary: The Treaty signed between China and Japan marks the end of the First Sino-Japanese War, with significant territorial implications.

1895.title: Oscar Wilde's Arrest
1895.summary: Oscar Wilde is arrested in London for gross indecency after losing a criminal libel case.

1895.title: Colombia Sidelines Presidential Elections
1895.summary: The Liberal Revolution begins, escalating civil unrest in Ecuador leading to a revolution.

1895.title: First Indoor Promenade Concert
1895.summary: The first indoor promenade concert, known as The Proms, is held in London, establishing a musical tradition.

1895.title: Major Earthquake in Charleston
1895.summary: A significant earthquake occurs in Charleston, South Carolina, increasing awareness of seismic activity in the region.

1896.title: Röntgen's Discovery
1896.summary: Wilhelm Röntgen's discovery of X-rays is reported by an Austrian newspaper, significantly advancing medical imaging technology that would impact countless lives.

1896.title: Jameson Raid Surrenders
1896.summary: The Jameson Raid comes to an end as Jameson surrenders to the Boers, impacting British colonial ambitions in South Africa.

1896.title: Puccini's La Bohème Premiere
1896.summary: Puccini's opera La bohème premieres in Turin, Italy, influencing the future of opera and music composition.

1896.title: Oscar Wilde's Salomé Premiere
1896.summary: Oscar Wilde's play Salomé has its stage premiere in Paris, reflecting the societal issues of the time, while Wilde is incarcerated.

1896.title: Braamfontein Explosion
1896.summary: A train carrying dynamite explodes at Braamfontein, Johannesburg, killing more than 78 people, marking a tragic industrial incident.

1896.title: Battle of Adwa
1896.summary: Ethiopia defends its independence from Italy, significantly impacting the nation's sovereignty and colonial dynamics in Africa.

1896.title: Coronation of Nicholas II
1896.summary: Coronation of Nicholas II and Alexandra Feodorovna in Moscow, marking the last coronation of a Russian monarch.

1896.title: Introduction of 'Separate but Equal'
1896.summary: The U.S. Supreme Court introduces the separate but equal doctrine in Plessy v. Ferguson, impacting civil rights and racial segregation.

1896.title: Henry Ford's Quadricycle Completion
1896.summary: The completion of Henry Ford's Quadricycle marks a significant step in automotive history, leading to the mass production of cars.

1896.title: Opening of the Glasgow Subway
1896.summary: The Glasgow Subway opens, becoming the third-oldest underground metro system and influencing urban transportation.

1897.title: International Alpha Omicron Pi sorority founded
1897.summary: The International Alpha Omicron Pi sorority is founded in New York City.

1897.title: First use of 'computer' in engineering
1897.summary: The word computer is first used to refer to a mechanical calculation device in an engineering journal.

1897.title: Discovery of the electron
1897.summary: J. J. Thomson announces his discovery of the electron as a subatomic particle at a lecture in London.

1897.title: Isolation of epinephrine
1897.summary: John Jacob Abel announces the successful isolation of epinephrine in a paper read before the Association of American Physicians.

1897.title: The Stars and Stripes Forever performed
1897.summary: The patriotic march by John Philip Sousa is performed for the first time.

1897.title: Publication of Dracula
1897.summary: Bram Stoker's Gothic horror novel Dracula is first published in London, influencing the vampire literature genre.

1897.title: Foundation of Juventus FC
1897.summary: Juventus FC is founded as an association football club in Turin.

1897.title: Proclamation of the Korean Empire
1897.summary: The Korean Empire is proclaimed, marking the end of the Joseon dynasty after over 500 years.

1897.title: Adoption of Ethiopian flag
1897.summary: Ethiopia adopts a new tricolor flag symbolizing the land, gold, and the blood shed in defense of the country.

1897.title: First issue of La Fronde published
1897.summary: The first issue of the feminist newspaper La Fronde is published by Marguerite Durand in Paris.

1898.title: New York City annexes land
1898.summary: New York City creates the City of Greater New York as the world's second largest city, divided into five boroughs.

1898.title: Émile Zola's J'Accuse published
1898.summary: Novelist Émile Zola publishes an open letter in L'Aurore, accusing the French government of antisemitism in the Dreyfus affair.

1898.title: First automobile fatality
1898.summary: Henry Lindfield's automobile rolls out of control in London, resulting in the world's first automobile accident fatality on a public highway.

1898.title: USS Maine explosion
1898.summary: The USS Maine explodes in Havana Harbor, leading to the Spanish-American War declaration.

1898.title: Formation of the Commonwealth of Australia
1898.summary: Representatives of five Australian colonies adopt a constitution in Melbourne, laying the foundation for the Commonwealth of Australia.

1898.title: First American-built automobile sale
1898.summary: Robert Allison becomes the first person to buy an American-built automobile, a Winton, in Pennsylvania.

1898.title: Philippine Declaration of Independence
1898.summary: General Emilio Aguinaldo declares the Philippines' independence from Spain after 333 years of dominance.

1898.title: Spanish-American War Battles
1898.summary: The United States achieves significant victories in the Spanish-American War, capturing Guam and winning the Battle of San Juan Hill.

1898.title: Gornergrat railway opens
1898.summary: The Gornergrat railway connecting Zermatt to the Gornergrat in Switzerland is inaugurated.

1898.title: Founding of the Sinfonia Club
1898.summary: The Sinfonia Club is founded at the New England Conservatory of Music, later becoming the Phi Mu Alpha Sinfonia fraternity.

1899.title: Spanish rule ends in Cuba
1899.summary: Cuba becomes free, concluding 400 years of the Spanish Empire in the Americas.

1899.title: Battle of Caloocan
1899.summary: U.S. Army troops defeat Filipino forces in the Battle of Caloocan, gaining control of strategic routes.

1899.title: Launch of RMS Oceanic
1899.summary: The White Star Line's RMS Oceanic is launched, becoming the largest ship afloat at the time.

1899.title: First public performance of Shéhérazade
1899.summary: Maurice Ravel conducts the first public performance of his orchestral suite Shéhérazade in Paris, marking a significant cultural milestone.

1899.title: Establishment of the Canadian Northern Railway
1899.summary: The Canadian Northern Railway is established, enhancing transportation and trade across Canada.

1899.title: First automobile race in Europe
1899.summary: The Empire of Austria holds its first automobile race, increasing interest in automotive transportation in Europe.

1899.title: Discovery of V606 Aquilae
1899.summary: The nova V606 Aquilae is first observed from Earth, marking a significant astronomical event.

1899.title: The founding of the National League
1899.summary: The American Baseball Association is announced as a rival to the National League, changing the landscape of U.S. baseball.

1899.title: First performance of Cendrillon
1899.summary: Jules Massenet’s opera Cendrillon, based on the Cinderella fairy tale, premieres in Paris, showcasing opulent musical storytelling.

1899.title: Establishment of the Philippines Republic
1899.summary: Emilio Aguinaldo is sworn in as President of the First Philippine Republic, marking a key political change.

1900.title: Open Door Policy
1900.summary: U.S. Secretary of State John Hay announces the Open Door Policy to promote American trade with China.

1900.title: Battle of Platrand
1900.summary: Boers attempt to end the Siege of Ladysmith, leading to the Battle of Platrand during the Second Boer War.

1900.title: Premiere of Tosca
1900.summary: Puccini's opera Tosca premieres in Rome, Italy.

1900.title: Treaty for Central American Canal
1900.summary: The United Kingdom and the United States sign a treaty for the building of a shipping canal across Nicaragua.

1900.title: Battle of Paardeberg
1900.summary: British troops defeat the Boers at the Battle of Paardeberg during the Second Boer War.

1900.title: Establishment of the British Labour Party
1900.summary: The British Labour Party is officially established in London.

1900.title: Scofield Mine Disaster
1900.summary: An explosion in a coal mine in Scofield, Utah, kills 200 people.

1900.title: Hoboken Docks Fire
1900.summary: A wharf fire at the docks in Hoboken, New Jersey, kills 326 people as it spreads to ships.

1900.title: Galveston Hurricane
1900.summary: The 1900 Galveston hurricane kills around 8,000 people, becoming the deadliest hurricane in U.S. history.

1900.title: Max Planck's Law
1900.summary: Max Planck first states Planck's law of black-body radiation, marking the birth of modern quantum mechanics.

1901.title: Formation of the Commonwealth of Australia
1901.summary: The British colonies of New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania, Victoria and Western Australia federate as the Commonwealth of Australia; Edmund Barton becomes the first Prime Minister of Australia.

1901.title: Death of Queen Victoria
1901.summary: Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom dies at Osborne House on the Isle of Wight, having ruled for nearly 64 years, making her the second longest-reigning monarch in British history.

1901.title: King Edward VII Ascends the Throne
1901.summary: Edward VII ascends to the British throne following the death of Queen Victoria, becoming King of the United Kingdom and Emperor of India.

1901.title: The Hay-Pauncefote Treaty
1901.summary: The Hay-Pauncefote Treaty is signed by the United Kingdom and United States, ceding control of the Panama Canal to the United States.

1901.title: U.S. Steel Incorporated
1901.summary: U.S. Steel is incorporated by industrialist J. P. Morgan, marking the creation of the first billion-dollar corporation.

1901.title: Assassination of William McKinley
1901.summary: William McKinley is shot and fatally wounded by an anarchist at the Pan-American Exposition in Buffalo, New York.

1901.title: First Submarine of the British Royal Navy Launched
1901.summary: The British Royal Navy's first submarine, Holland 1, is launched at Barrow-in-Furness, marking a significant advance in naval technology.

1901.title: Nobel Prize Ceremony
1901.summary: The first Nobel Prize ceremony is held in Stockholm, commemorating the contributions of Alfred Nobel.

1901.title: First Trans-Atlantic Radio Signal
1901.summary: Guglielmo Marconi receives the first trans-Atlantic radio signal, sent from England to Newfoundland; it is the letter 'S' in Morse code.

1901.title: Black Sea Earthquake
1901.summary: A 7.2 Mw earthquake strikes off the northeast coast of Bulgaria, resulting in a destructive tsunami affecting the province of Dobrich.

1902.title: Nurses Registration Act
1902.summary: The Nurses Registration Act 1901 comes into effect in New Zealand, making it the first country in the world to require state registration of nurses.

1902.title: First Registered Nurse
1902.summary: Ellen Dougherty becomes the world's first registered nurse.

1902.title: Train Collision
1902.summary: A train collision in the New York Central Railroad's Park Avenue Tunnel kills 17 people, injures 38, and leads to increased demand for electric trains and the banning of steam locomotives in New York City.

1902.title: Hakkōda Mountains Incident
1902.summary: A snowstorm in the Hakkōda Mountains of northern Honshu, Japan, kills 199 during a military training exercise.

1902.title: Police Demonstrations in Brussels
1902.summary: Police and universal suffrage demonstrators are involved in a physical altercation in Brussels, Belgium.

1902.title: Women Suffrage Conference
1902.summary: The 1st Conference of the International Woman Suffrage Alliance takes place in Washington, D.C.

1902.title: Opening of Berlin U-Bahn
1902.summary: The Berlin U-Bahn underground is opened.

1902.title: Battle of Tweebosch
1902.summary: South African Boers win their last battle over the British Army, with the capture of a British general and 200 of his men.

1902.title: Electric Theatre Opens
1902.summary: The Electric Theatre, the first movie theater in the United States, opens in Los Angeles.

1902.title: Mount Pelée Erupts
1902.summary: Mount Pelée erupts, destroying the town of Saint-Pierre and killing over 30,000.

1903.title: Edward VII proclaimed Emperor of India
1903.summary: Edward VII becomes the Emperor of India, marking a significant expansion of the British Empire.

1903.title: Electrocuting an Elephant
1903.summary: The Edison Manufacturing Company releases a film showing the electrocution of Topsy, an Asian elephant, sparking discussions on animal rights and ethics.

1903.title: First west-east transatlantic radio broadcast
1903.summary: A historic transmission made from the United States to England, enhancing global communication capabilities.

1903.title: Washington Protocols
1903.summary: Settlement reached among the United Kingdom, Germany, and Italy regarding the Venezuelan crisis, ending the naval blockade.

1903.title: First hotel exclusively for women opens
1903.summary: The Martha Washington Hotel opens in New York City, catering exclusively to female patrons, reflecting changing social norms.

1903.title: Ford Motor Company founded
1903.summary: Henry Ford establishes the Ford Motor Company, which will revolutionize the automobile industry and manufacturing.

1903.title: The first Tour de France
1903.summary: The inaugural Tour de France bicycle race takes place, marking the beginning of one of the world's most famous cycling events.

1903.title: Serbian royal assassination
1903.summary: King Alexander I and Queen Draga of Serbia are assassinated, leading to significant political changes in the region.

1903.title: Discovery of powered flight
1903.summary: Orville Wright successfully performs the first powered flight with the Wright Flyer at Kitty Hawk, changing the future of aviation.

1903.title: Independence of Panama
1903.summary: Panama proclaims its independence from Colombia, with U.S. support, leading to the construction of the Panama Canal.

1904.title: The establishment of CQD
1904.summary: The distress signal CQD is established, only to be replaced 2 years later by SOS.

1904.title: The dedication of Blackstone Library
1904.summary: The Blackstone Library is dedicated, marking the beginning of the Chicago Public Library system.

1904.title: Herero Wars begin
1904.summary: The Herero Wars in German South West Africa begin.

1904.title: The opening of Chekhov's play
1904.summary: Anton Chekhov's last play, The Cherry Orchard, opens at the Moscow Art Theatre directed by Constantin Stanislavski.

1904.title: Ålesund fire
1904.summary: The Ålesund fire destroys most buildings in the town of Ålesund, Norway, leaving about 10,000 people without shelter.

1904.title: Kaiser Wilhelm II's recording
1904.summary: Kaiser Wilhelm II of Germany becomes the first person to make a recording of a political document, using Thomas Edison's cylinder.

1904.title: The Great Baltimore Fire
1904.summary: The Great Baltimore Fire in Baltimore, Maryland, destroys over 1,500 buildings in 31 hours.

1904.title: Battle of Port Arthur
1904.summary: A surprise Japanese naval attack on Port Arthur starts the Russo-Japanese War.

1904.title: Madama Butterfly debuts
1904.summary: Puccini's opera Madama Butterfly, with a background theme of Japan–United States relations, debuts at La Scala in Milan, to no great acclaim.

1904.title: Establishment of FIFA
1904.summary: The International Federation of Association Football, FIFA, is established.

1905.title: The Bloody Sunday Massacre
1905.summary: The Bloody Sunday massacre of Russian demonstrators takes place at the Winter Palace in Saint Petersburg, leading to an unsuccessful uprising.

1905.title: Russo-Japanese War Defeat
1905.summary: In a major defeat in the Russo-Japanese War, Russian General Anatoly Stessel surrenders Port Arthur to the Japanese.

1905.title: Discovery of a Sixth Moon of Jupiter
1905.summary: The Lick Observatory announces the discovery of a sixth moon of Jupiter, named Himalia years later.

1905.title: Prime Minister of Romania
1905.summary: Gheorghe Grigore Cantacuzino becomes Prime Minister of Romania for the second time.

1905.title: The Scarlet Pimpernel Opens
1905.summary: Baroness Emma Orczy's play The Scarlet Pimpernel opens at the New Theatre in London, beginning a notable run.

1905.title: Tsunamis in Norway
1905.summary: A series of three tsunamis kill 61 people in Norway after a rockslide hits Lake Lovatnet.

1905.title: Formation of a New Belgian Government
1905.summary: Maurice Rouvier forms a government as the new Prime Minister of France.

1905.title: Assassination of Grand Duke Sergei Alexandrovich
1905.summary: Grand Duke Sergei Alexandrovich, the Governor-General of Moscow, is assassinated.

1905.title: First International Soccer Match
1905.summary: The Switzerland national football team plays its first international game, losing to France.

1905.title: Treaty of Portsmouth Signed
1905.summary: The Treaty of Portsmouth, mediated by U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt, is signed to end the Russo-Japanese War, marking a significant geopolitical shift.

1906.title: Persian Constitutional Revolution
1906.summary: A nationalistic coalition of merchants, religious leaders and intellectuals in Persia forces the shah Mozaffar ad-Din Shah Qajar to grant a constitution, and establish a national assembly, the Majlis.

1906.title: The Algeciras Conference
1906.summary: Convened to resolve the First Moroccan Crisis between France and Germany.

1906.title: SS Valencia disaster
1906.summary: The SS Valencia strikes a reef off Vancouver Island, Canada, killing over 100 (officially 136) in the ensuing disaster.

1906.title: Ecuador-Colombia earthquake
1906.summary: An 8.8 magnitude earthquake and associated tsunami cause at least 500 deaths.

1906.title: Launch of HMS Dreadnought
1906.summary: The launch of HMS Dreadnought sparks a naval race between Britain and Germany.

1906.title: Courrières mine disaster
1906.summary: An explosion in a coal mine in France kills 1,060.

1906.title: San Francisco Earthquake
1906.summary: The San Francisco Earthquake destroys much of San Francisco, California, killing at least 3,000 and leaving 225,000–300,000 homeless.

1906.title: Cunard liner RMS Lusitania launched
1906.summary: RMS Lusitania is launched in Glasgow as the world's largest ship.

1906.title: Valparaíso earthquake
1906.summary: A magnitude 8.2 earthquake in Valparaíso, Chile leaves approximately 20,000 injured.

1906.title: First powered flight in Europe
1906.summary: An aeroplane of Alberto Santos-Dumont takes off at Bagatelle in France, and flies 60 meters, the first officially recorded powered flight in Europe.

1907.title: Kingston earthquake
1907.summary: A 6.5 Mw earthquake in Kingston, Jamaica, kills between 800 and 1,000.

1907.title: The Mud March
1907.summary: The first large procession organised by The National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies takes place in London.

1907.title: Larchmont collision
1907.summary: The steamship Larchmont collides with the Harry Hamilton in Long Island Sound; 183 lives are lost.

1907.title: SKF founded
1907.summary: SKF, a worldwide mechanical parts manufacturing brand, is founded in Gothenburg, Sweden.

1907.title: Wreck of the Berlin
1907.summary: The English mail steamship Berlin is wrecked off the Hook of Holland; 142 lives are lost.

1907.title: Romanian Peasants' Revolt
1907.summary: The 1907 Romanian Peasants' Revolt results in possibly as many as 11,000 deaths.

1907.title: Taxicabs with taximeters
1907.summary: The first taxicabs with taximeters begin operating in London.

1907.title: Hershey Park opens
1907.summary: Hershey Park opens in Hershey, Pennsylvania.

1907.title: Marconi initiates transatlantic radio
1907.summary: Guglielmo Marconi initiates commercial transatlantic radio communications between his stations in Clifden, Ireland, and Glace Bay, Nova Scotia.

1907.title: J. P. Morgan financial crisis aversion
1907.summary: A major United States financial crisis is averted when financiers create a $25 million pool to invest in shares on the plunging New York Stock Exchange.

1908.title: The British Nimrod Expedition
1908.summary: The British Nimrod Expedition led by Ernest Shackleton sets sail from New Zealand for Antarctica.

1908.title: Fire at Rhoads Opera House
1908.summary: A fire breaks out at the Rhoads Opera House in Boyertown, Pennsylvania, killing 171 people.

1908.title: Lisbon Regicide
1908.summary: King Carlos I of Portugal and Prince Luis Filipe are shot dead in Lisbon.

1908.title: 1908 New York to Paris Race
1908.summary: The first around-the-world car race begins from New York to Paris.

1908.title: Young Turk Revolution
1908.summary: Major Ahmed Niyazi begins an open revolution in the Ottoman Empire.

1908.title: First Flight with a Passenger
1908.summary: French aviator Henri Farman makes the world's first flight with a passenger, Léon Delagrange.

1908.title: H. H. Asquith becomes Prime Minister
1908.summary: H. H. Asquith of the Liberal Party takes office as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.

1908.title: Franco-British Exhibition
1908.summary: The Franco-British Exhibition is held in London.

1908.title: The Great Storm of 1908
1908.summary: The Great Storm of 1908 starts to pound the Bristol Channel.

1908.title: Ford Model T Launch
1908.summary: The official launch of Henry Ford's Ford Model T automobile takes place.

1909.title: Explorer Aeneas Mackintosh escapes death
1909.summary: Explorer Aeneas Mackintosh of the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition escapes death by fleeing across ice floes.

1909.title: Colombia recognizes Panama's independence
1909.summary: Colombia recognizes the independence of Panama.

1909.title: Nimrod Expedition reaches farthest south
1909.summary: The British Nimrod Expedition to the South Pole, led by Ernest Shackleton, arrives at the farthest south reached by any prior expedition, at 88°23' S, prior to turning back due to diminishing supplies.

1909.title: RMS Republic sinks
1909.summary: The White Star Liner RMS Republic sinks the day after a collision with SS Florida off Nantucket.

1909.title: Paris Film Congress opens
1909.summary: The Paris Film Congress opens. It is an attempt to create a cartel of leading European producers similar to the MPPC in the United States.

1909.title: Inauguration of William Howard Taft
1909.summary: Inauguration of William Howard Taft as the 27th President of the United States.

1909.title: Construction begins on the RMS Titanic
1909.summary: Construction begins on the RMS Titanic, at the Harland and Wolff Shipyard in Belfast.

1909.title: Louis Blériot crosses the English Channel
1909.summary: Louis Blériot becomes the first man to fly across the English Channel in a heavier-than-air craft.

1909.title: Armenian Massacre
1909.summary: Ottoman Turks kill 15,000–30,000 Armenian Christians, in the Adana Vilayet.

1909.title: Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 3 premieres
1909.summary: Sergei Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 3 is premiered in New York City with the composer as soloist.

1910.title: Abé Rebellion
1910.summary: Abé people in the French West Africa colony of Côte d'Ivoire rise against the colonial administration; the rebellion is brutally suppressed by the military.

1910.title: Treaty of Punakha
1910.summary: By the Treaty of Punakha, the Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan becomes a protectorate of the British Empire.

1910.title: Charcot Island Discovery
1910.summary: Charcot Island is discovered by the Antarctic expedition led by French explorer Jean-Baptiste Charcot on the ship Pourquoi Pas?

1910.title: Great January Comet of 1910
1910.summary: Great January Comet of 1910 first observed, with its perihelion on January 17.

1910.title: Great Flood of Paris
1910.summary: The Great Flood of Paris begins when the Seine overflows its banks.

1910.title: Metropolitan Life Insurance Company Tower Completion
1910.summary: Completion of construction of New York City's Metropolitan Life Insurance Company Tower, at 700 feet the world's tallest building at this time, is celebrated.

1910.title: First Air Flight for Freight
1910.summary: The first air flight for the purpose of delivering commercial freight takes place in the United States.

1910.title: Launch of RMS Olympic
1910.summary: The hull of White Star ocean liner RMS Olympic is launched, at the Harland and Wolff shipyards in Belfast.

1910.title: Giacomo Puccini's Opera Premiere
1910.summary: Giacomo Puccini's opera La fanciulla del West has its world première at the Metropolitan Opera in New York City.

1910.title: Magnitude of the Manchurian Plague
1910.summary: Approximate date of origin of Manchurian plague, a form of pneumonic plague which spreads through northeastern China, killing more than 40,000.

1911.title: Foundation of Zamalek SC
1911.summary: Egypt's Zamalek SC is founded as a general sports and Association football club by Belgian lawyer George Merzbach as Qasr El Nile Club.

1911.title: South Pole Expedition
1911.summary: Roald Amundsen's South Pole expedition makes landfall, on the eastern edge of the Ross Ice Shelf.

1911.title: First Aircraft Landing on a Ship
1911.summary: Eugene B. Ely lands on the deck of the USS Pennsylvania stationed in San Francisco harbor, the first time an aircraft has landed on a ship.

1911.title: Première of Symphony No. 4
1911.summary: Jean Sibelius conducts the première of his Symphony No. 4, in Helsinki.

1911.title: Triangle Shirtwaist Factory Fire
1911.summary: The Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire in New York City kills 146 people.

1911.title: Discovery of Superconductivity
1911.summary: Heike Kamerlingh Onnes discovers superconductivity; he presents his findings on April 28.

1911.title: Agadir Crisis Starts
1911.summary: The presence of the German warship Panther in the Moroccan port of Agadir triggers the Agadir Crisis.

1911.title: Mona Lisa Stolen
1911.summary: Leonardo da Vinci's Mona Lisa is stolen from the Louvre museum in Paris by Vincenzo Peruggia; the painting is returned in 1913.

1911.title: Wuchang Uprising
1911.summary: The Wuchang Uprising starts the Xinhai Revolution, which leads to the founding of the Republic of China.

1911.title: Foundation of Omega Psi Phi
1911.summary: Omega Psi Phi fraternity is founded on the campus of Howard University, in Washington, D.C.

1912.title: Establishment of the Republic of China
1912.summary: The Republic of China is established marking a significant shift in Chinese governance and ending thousands of years of imperial rule.

1912.title: Foundation of the African National Congress
1912.summary: The African National Congress is founded to promote improved rights for black South Africans, with John Langalibalele Dube as its first president.

1912.title: Establishment of the RMS Titanic
1912.summary: The White Star liner RMS Titanic departs from Southampton for her maiden voyage, which would later become infamous after her sinking.

1912.title: Sinking of the RMS Titanic
1912.summary: The RMS Titanic strikes an iceberg and sinks in the North Atlantic Ocean with a loss of over 1,500 lives, igniting international awareness on ship safety regulations.

1912.title: Formation of the French Protectorate in Morocco
1912.summary: France establishes a protectorate in Morocco by treaty with Sultan Abd al-Hafid, shifting control of Moroccan territory to France.

1912.title: First Parachute Jump from a Flying Airplane
1912.summary: Albert Berry is reported to have made the first parachute jump from a flying airplane, marking a significant advancement in aviation.

1912.title: End of the Manchu Qing Dynasty
1912.summary: The abdication of the Xuantong Emperor Puyi marks the end of the Manchu Qing dynasty in China, directly leading to the establishment of the Republic of China.

1912.title: Launch of the SS Imperator
1912.summary: The Hamburg America Line's SS Imperator is launched in Hamburg, becoming the world's largest ship at the time, showcasing advancements in maritime engineering.

1912.title: First Use of Airships in War
1912.summary: Italian forces become the first to use airships in combat, marking a notable advancement in military technology during the Italo-Turkish War.

1912.title: Balkan Wars Begin
1912.summary: The First Balkan War begins when Montenegro declares war against the Ottoman Empire, setting the stage for significant geopolitical changes in Europe.

1913.title: First Balkan War: Greece captures Chios
1913.summary: Greece completes its capture of the eastern Aegean island of Chios, as the last Ottoman forces on the island surrender.

1913.title: Founding of the Ulster Volunteer Force
1913.summary: Edward Carson founds the (first) Ulster Volunteer Force, by unifying several existing loyalist militias to resist home rule for Ireland.

1913.title: Battle of Lemnos
1913.summary: Greek admiral Pavlos Kountouriotis forces the Turkish fleet to retreat to its base within the Dardanelles, from which it will not venture for the rest of the war.

1913.title: 1913 Ottoman coup d'état
1913.summary: Enver Pasha comes to power following a coup in the Ottoman Empire.

1913.title: Reopening of Grand Central Terminal
1913.summary: New York City's Grand Central Terminal, having been rebuilt, reopens as the world's largest railroad station.

1913.title: Ratification of the Sixteenth Amendment
1913.summary: The Sixteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified, authorizing the Federal government to impose and collect income taxes on all sources of income.

1913.title: Mexican Revolution: La Decena Trágica begins
1913.summary: The rebellion of some military chiefs against President Francisco I. Madero begins, marking a significant point in the Mexican Revolution.

1913.title: Dalai Lama declares independence of Tibet
1913.summary: Thubten Gyatso declares the independence of Tibet from Qing dynasty China.

1913.title: Assassination of Francisco I. Madero
1913.summary: President Francisco I. Madero and Vice President José María Pino Suárez are forced to resign and later assassinated after a coup led by General Huerta.

1913.title: The Rite of Spring premiere
1913.summary: The ballet The Rite of Spring, music by Igor Stravinsky, is premiered in Paris, provoking one of the most famous classical music riots in history.

1914.title: St. Petersburg–Tampa Airboat Line starts services
1914.summary: The St. Petersburg–Tampa Airboat Line in the United States starts services between St. Petersburg and Tampa, Florida, becoming the first airline to provide scheduled regular commercial passenger services with heavier-than-air aircraft.

1914.title: Sakurajima volcano erupts
1914.summary: The Sakurajima volcano in Japan begins to erupt, becoming effusive after a very large earthquake on January 13.

1914.title: The sinking of Karluk
1914.summary: The Karluk, flagship of the Canadian Arctic Expedition, sinks after being crushed by ice.

1914.title: Establishment of ASCAP
1914.summary: In New York City, the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers is established, to protect the copyrighted musical compositions of its members.

1914.title: Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand
1914.summary: Serbian nationalist Gavrilo Princip assassinates Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria and his wife, Duchess Sophie, in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, triggering the July Crisis and eventually World War I.

1914.title: Germany declares war on Belgium
1914.summary: The July Crisis ends when German troops invade Belgium, leading to Britain's declaration of war on Germany.

1914.title: The Panama Canal inaugurated
1914.summary: The Panama Canal is inaugurated with the passage of the SS Ancon.

1914.title: Battle of Cer
1914.summary: Serbian troops defeat the Austro-Hungarian army, marking the first Entente victory of the War.

1914.title: Battle of the Falkland Islands
1914.summary: A superior British Royal Navy squadron defeats ships of the Imperial German Navy in the Battle of the Falkland Islands.

1914.title: Battle of Ypres begins
1914.summary: The First Battle of Ypres begins, marking a significant battle in World War I.

1915.title: Sinking of HMS Formidable
1915.summary: British Royal Navy battleship HMS Formidable is sunk off Lyme Regis, Dorset, England, by a German U-boat, with the loss of 547 crew.

1915.title: Battle of Broken Hill
1915.summary: A train ambush near Broken Hill, Australia, is carried out by two men (claiming to be in support of the Ottoman Empire) who are killed, together with four civilians.

1915.title: Joseph E. Carberry's altitude record
1915.summary: Joseph E. Carberry sets an altitude record of 11,690 feet in a fixed-wing aircraft.

1915.title: Women’s suffrage vote proposal rejected
1915.summary: The United States House of Representatives rejects a proposal to give women the right to vote.

1915.title: Caucasus Campaign – Battle of Sarikamish
1915.summary: Russia defeats Ottoman Turkey in the Caucasus Campaign.

1915.title: German Zeppelin bombing
1915.summary: German Zeppelins bomb the coastal towns of Great Yarmouth and King's Lynn in England for the first time, killing more than 20.

1915.title: Kiwanis founded
1915.summary: Kiwanis is founded in Detroit, Michigan, as The Supreme Lodge Benevolent Order Brothers.

1915.title: First coast-to-coast telephone call
1915.summary: The first United States coast-to-coast long-distance telephone call is facilitated by a newly invented vacuum tube amplifier, inaugurated by Alexander Graham Bell.

1915.title: Lusitania sunk
1915.summary: RMS Lusitania is sunk by a German U-boat, killing 1,199 civilians, mostly traveling from New York City to Liverpool.

1915.title: Establishment of the Rocky Mountain National Park
1915.summary: The Rocky Mountain National Park is established by an act of the United States Congress.

1916.title: Successful Blood Transfusion
1916.summary: The British Royal Army Medical Corps carries out the first successful blood transfusion, using blood that has been stored and cooled.

1916.title: Gallipoli Campaign Evacuation
1916.summary: The last British troops are evacuated from Gallipoli, as the Ottoman Empire prevails over a joint British and French operation to capture Constantinople.

1916.title: Battle of Verdun
1916.summary: The Battle of Verdun begins in France, which will become one of the longest battles in WWI.

1916.title: Dadaism Movement Founded
1916.summary: Tristan Tzara founds the art movement Dadaism, reflecting cultural shifts during wartime.

1916.title: American Birth Control Clinic Opened
1916.summary: Margaret Sanger opens the first U.S. birth control clinic, a forerunner of Planned Parenthood.

1916.title: Gas Attack at Hulluch
1916.summary: The gas attack at Hulluch in France decimates the 47th Brigade, 16th (Irish) Division in one of the most heavily concentrated German gas attacks of the war.

1916.title: Battle of the Somme
1916.summary: The Battle of the Somme begins, leading to over a million soldiers dying by its conclusion.

1916.title: Mary Pickford Signs Million-Dollar Contract
1916.summary: Mary Pickford becomes the first movie star to sign a million-dollar contract, making her one of the highest-paid people in the world.

1916.title: Sykes–Picot Agreement
1916.summary: Britain and France conclude the secret Sykes–Picot Agreement, dividing Arab areas of the Ottoman Empire after WWI.

1916.title: First Use of Tanks in Warfare
1916.summary: The WWI Battle of Flers-Courcelette is significant for the first use of tanks in warfare.

1917.title: Battle of Rafa
1917.summary: The last substantial Ottoman Army garrison on the Sinai Peninsula is captured by the Egyptian Expeditionary Force's Desert Column.

1917.title: Kingsland Explosion
1917.summary: Unknown saboteurs set off the Kingsland Explosion at Kingsland, one of the events leading to United States involvement in WWI.

1917.title: Sale of Danish West Indies
1917.summary: The Danish West Indies is sold to the United States for $25 million.

1917.title: Wireless Telecommunication Breakthrough
1917.summary: Germany announces its U-boats will resume unrestricted submarine warfare, rescinding the 'Sussex Pledge'.

1917.title: Zimmermann Telegram Revealed
1917.summary: The text of the Zimmermann Telegram is released to the public, offering Mexican territory to Mexico in exchange for an alliance against the United States.

1917.title: First Jazz Recording
1917.summary: "Livery Stable Blues" by the Original Dixieland Jazz Band is recorded, becoming the first jazz recording commercially released.

1917.title: The February Revolution
1917.summary: The February Revolution begins in Russia with women calling for bread in Petrograd, leading to widespread riots.

1917.title: U.S. Declaration of War on Germany
1917.summary: President Woodrow Wilson asks Congress for a declaration of war against Germany, which is granted on April 6, 1917.

1917.title: October Revolution
1917.summary: The October Revolution in Russia happens when Bolsheviks storm the Winter Palace, ending the Provisional Government.

1917.title: Halifax Explosion
1917.summary: Two freighters collide in Halifax Harbour, causing an explosion that kills at least 1,963 people, becoming the biggest man-made explosion in history at the time.

1918.title: Act of Independence of Lithuania
1918.summary: The Council of Lithuania adopts the Act of Independence of Lithuania, declaring Lithuania's independence from Germany, Russia or any other state.

1918.title: Spanish flu pandemic begins
1918.summary: The "Spanish flu" (influenza) is first observed in Haskell County, Kansas, leading to a global pandemic that results in over 30 million deaths.

1918.title: Finnish Declaration of Independence recognized
1918.summary: The Finnish Declaration of Independence is recognized by Soviet Russia, Sweden, Germany and France, marking an important step in Finland's sovereignty.

1918.title: Russian Constituent Assembly proclamation
1918.summary: The Russian Constituent Assembly proclaims the Russian Democratic Federative Republic but is dissolved by the Bolshevik government on the same day.

1918.title: First purpose-designed aircraft carrier laid down
1918.summary: The keel of HMS Hermes is laid in Britain, marking the beginning of a new era in naval aviation.

1918.title: Historic concert for widows and orphans
1918.summary: The Historic Concert for the Benefit of Widows and Orphans of Austrian and Hungarian Soldiers is held at the Konzerthaus, Vienna, gathering support for those affected by the war.

1918.title: The Treaty of Brest-Litovsk
1918.summary: The Central Powers and Bolshevist Russia sign the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk, ending Russia's involvement in WWI, significantly altering the eastern front.

1918.title: Formation of the Royal Air Force
1918.summary: The Royal Flying Corps and the Royal Naval Air Service in Britain are merged to form the Royal Air Force, the first autonomous Air Force in the world.

1918.title: Independence of Czechoslovakia proclaimed
1918.summary: The Washington Declaration proclaims the independent Czechoslovak Republic, marking the country's emergence as a new nation.

1918.title: End of WWI Armistice
1918.summary: End of WWI: Armistice of 11 November 1918 – Germany signs an armistice agreement with the Allies, officially bringing an end to the war.

1919.title: Iolaire sinks
1919.summary: HMY Iolaire sinks off the coast of the Hebrides; 201 people, mostly servicemen returning home to Lewis and Harris, are killed.

1919.title: Faisal–Weizmann Agreement
1919.summary: The Faisal–Weizmann Agreement is signed for Arab–Jewish cooperation in the development of a Jewish homeland in Palestine.

1919.title: Estonian War of Independence
1919.summary: Estonian forces start a general and successful counter-offensive against the Soviet Russian forces outside Tallinn.

1919.title: Spartacist uprising in Berlin
1919.summary: The Marxist Spartacus League, with the newly formed Communist Party of Germany, begin mass demonstrations which will be suppressed by armed force.

1919.title: Estonian forces liberate Tapa
1919.summary: Estonian forces liberate Tapa, Estonia, from the Red Army during the Estonian War of Independence.

1919.title: Great Molasses Flood
1919.summary: A wave of molasses released from an exploding storage tank sweeps through Boston, Massachusetts, killing 21 people and injuring 150.

1919.title: The Paris Peace Conference
1919.summary: The Paris Peace Conference opens in France, with delegates from 27 nations attending for meetings at the Palace of Versailles.

1919.title: The Eighteenth Amendment ratified
1919.summary: The Eighteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, authorizing Prohibition, is ratified.

1919.title: The League of Nations is founded
1919.summary: The League of Nations is founded in Paris, France, aiming to promote peace and cooperation among countries.

1919.title: Amritsar Massacre
1919.summary: Under the command of Reginald Dyer, detachments of the Indian army massacre 379 Sikh civilians at Jallianwala Bagh in Amritsar.

1920.title: Beginning of Prohibition in the United States
1920.summary: Prohibition begins with the Eighteenth Amendment, banning the sale of alcohol across all States.

1920.title: 1920 Xalapa earthquake
1920.summary: The earthquake in Mexico kills over 600 people, marking it as the second deadliest in the country.

1920.title: Treaty of Versailles takes effect
1920.summary: The treaty officially ends World War I, bringing significant geopolitical changes in Europe.

1920.title: Founding of Zeta Phi Beta Sorority
1920.summary: The sorority is founded on the campus of Howard University, promoting service and scholarship among African American women.

1920.title: Establishment of the League of Nations
1920.summary: The League is officially established to promote peace and cooperation among countries post World War I.

1920.title: The formation of the South African Air Force
1920.summary: The South African Air Force is established as the second autonomous air force in the world.

1920.title: Estonian War of Independence concludes
1920.summary: The Tartu Peace Treaty is signed, recognizing Estonia's independence.

1920.title: Battle of Warsaw
1920.summary: The Red Army is defeated, marking a significant turning point in the Polish–Soviet War.

1920.title: The first commercial radio station in the US
1920.summary: 8MK (WWJ) begins operations in Detroit, being the first U.S. radio station owned by a newspaper.

1920.title: Foundation of the Edmonton Symphony Orchestra
1920.summary: The orchestra holds its first concert, contributing to the cultural landscape of Canada.

1921.title: Founding of Cruzeiro Esporte Clube
1921.summary: The Association football club Cruzeiro Esporte Clube, from Belo Horizonte, is founded as the multi-sports club Palestra Italia by Italian expatriates in Brazil.

1921.title: Sinking of Santa Isabel
1921.summary: The Spanish liner Santa Isabel breaks in two and sinks off Villa Garcia, Mexico, with the loss of 244 of the 300 people on board.

1921.title: Public performance of sawing a woman in half
1921.summary: The first recorded public performance of the illusion of 'sawing a woman in half' is given by English stage magician P. T. Selbit at the Finsbury Park Empire variety theatre in London.

1921.title: HMS K5 sinks
1921.summary: British K-class submarine HMS K5 sinks in the English Channel; all 57 on board are lost.

1921.title: Release of The Kid
1921.summary: The full-length silent comedy drama film The Kid, written, produced, directed by and starring Charlie Chaplin, is released in the United States.

1921.title: Red Army invasion of Georgia
1921.summary: The Democratic Republic of Georgia is invaded by forces of Bolshevist Russia.

1921.title: Founding of the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia
1921.summary: The Communist Party of Czechoslovakia is founded.

1921.title: Tulsa Race Massacre
1921.summary: Mobs of white residents attack black residents and businesses in Greenwood District, Tulsa, Oklahoma, leading to a significant loss of life and property.

1921.title: Anglo-Irish Treaty
1921.summary: The Anglo-Irish Treaty establishing the Irish Free State, an independent nation incorporating 26 of Ireland's 32 counties, is signed in London.

1921.title: First radio baseball game broadcast
1921.summary: The first radio baseball game is broadcast from Pittsburgh, marking a significant milestone in sports and media history.

1922.title: Use of insulin for diabetes
1922.summary: The first successful insulin treatment of diabetes is made, by Frederick Banting in Toronto.

1922.title: Irish Civil War: General Michael Collins is assassinated
1922.summary: General Michael Collins is assassinated in West Cork.

1922.title: The silent horror film Nosferatu is premièred
1922.summary: The silent horror film Nosferatu is premiered at the Berlin Zoological Garden in Germany.

1922.title: The first issue of the magazine Krestyanka is published
1922.summary: The first issue of the magazine Krestyanka is published in Russia.

1922.title: Discovery of the tomb of Tutankhamun
1922.summary: In Egypt, English archaeologist Howard Carter and his men find the entrance to the pharaonic tomb of Tutankhamun in the Valley of the Kings.

1922.title: The British Broadcasting Company is formed
1922.summary: The British Broadcasting Company is formed, marking a milestone in media history.

1922.title: Transition of the Ottoman Empire
1922.summary: The Ottoman Empire is abolished after 600 years, marking the end of a significant historical era.

1922.title: The inaugural session of the Permanent Court of International Justice
1922.summary: The inaugural session of the Permanent Court of International Justice (PCIJ) is held in The Hague.

1922.title: The Lincoln Memorial is dedicated
1922.summary: In Washington, D.C., the Lincoln Memorial is dedicated, honoring a pivotal figure in American history.

1922.title: The March on Rome
1922.summary: In Italy, the March on Rome brings the National Fascist Party and Benito Mussolini to power.
